\typeout{Section 2.2 The Sine and Cosine Functions}
\typeout{************************************************}
\section[{The Sine and Cosine Functions}]{The Sine and Cosine Functions}\label{sec-2-2-sin-cos}
\begin{objectives}{Motivating Questions}\label{objectives-10}
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1497}{}%
What do the graphs of \(y = \sin(x)\) and \(y = \cos(x)\) suggest as formulas for their respective derivatives?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1498}{}%
Once we know the derivatives of \(\sin(x)\) and \(\cos(x)\), how do previous derivative rules work when these functions are involved?%
\end{itemize}
\end{objectives}
\hypertarget{p-1499}{}%
Throughout \hyperref[C-2]{Chapter~\ref{C-2}}, we will develop shortcut derivative rules to help us bypass the limit definition and quickly compute \(f'(x)\) from a formula for \(f(x)\). In \hyperref[sec-2-1-elem-rules]{Section~\ref{sec-2-1-elem-rules}}, we stated the rule for power functions:%
\begin{equation*}
\text{if}~ f(x) = x^n,~ \text{then}~ f'(x) = nx^{n-1}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and the rule for exponential functions:%
\begin{equation*}
\text{if}~ a ~ \text{is a positive real number and}~ f(x) = a^x,~
\text{then}~ f'(x) = a^x \ln(a)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
In this section, we will use a graphical argument to conjecture derivative formulas for the sine and cosine functions.%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.2.1 The Sine and Cosine Functions}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{The Sine and Cosine Functions}]{The Sine and Cosine Functions}\label{subsection-53}
\hypertarget{p-1500}{}%
The sine and cosine functions are among the most important functions in all of mathematics.  These periodic functions play a key role in modeling repeating phenomena such as tidal elevations, the behavior of an oscillating mass attached to a spring, or the location of a point on a bicycle tire. Like polynomial and exponential functions, the sine and cosine functions are considered basic functions, ones that are often used in building more complicated functions. As such, we would like to know formulas for \(\frac{d}{dx} [\sin(x)]\) and \(\frac{d}{dx} [\cos(x)]\), and the next two examples lead us to that end.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-2-1}
\hypertarget{p-1501}{}%
Consider the function \(f(x) = \sin(x)\), with the graph of \(y=f(x)\) shown below in \hyperref[F-2-2-A1]{Figure~\ref{F-2-2-A1}}. Note that the grid in the diagram does not have boxes that are \(1 \times 1\), but rather approximately \(1.57 \times 1\), as the horizontal scale of the grid is \(\frac{\pi}{2}\) units per box.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_2_sine1.jpg}
\caption{The graph of \(y = f(x)\), for \(f(x) = \sin(x)\).\label{F-2-2-A1}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-1502}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-973}{}\hypertarget{p-1503}{}%
At each of \(x = -2\pi, -\frac{3\pi}{2}, -\pi, -\frac{\pi}{2}, 0, \frac{\pi}{2}, \pi, \frac{3\pi}{2}, 2\pi\), use a straightedge to sketch an accurate tangent line to \(y = f(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-974}{}\hypertarget{p-1504}{}%
Use the provided grid to estimate the slope of the tangent line you drew at each point. Pay careful attention to the scale of the grid.%
\item\hypertarget{li-975}{}\hypertarget{p-1505}{}%
Use the limit definition of the derivative to estimate \(f'(0)\) by using small values of \(h\), and compare the result to your visual estimate for the slope of the tangent line to \(y = f(x)\) at \(x = 0\) in (b). Using periodicity, what does this result suggest about \(f'(2\pi)\)? About \(f'(-2\pi)\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-976}{}\hypertarget{p-1506}{}%
Based on your work in (a), (b), and (c), sketch an accurate graph of \(y = f'(x)\) on the  interval \(-2\pi\le x\le 2\pi\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-977}{}\hypertarget{p-1507}{}%
What familiar function do you think is the derivative of \(f(x) = \sin(x)\)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-39}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1508}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-978}{}\hypertarget{p-1509}{}%
It's very important to use a straightedge for accuracy.%
\item\hypertarget{li-979}{}\hypertarget{p-1510}{}%
First determine the slopes that appear to be zero. Then estimate \(f'(0)\) carefully using the grid. Use symmetry and periodicity to help you estimate other nonzero slopes on the graph.%
\item\hypertarget{li-980}{}\hypertarget{p-1511}{}%
\(f'(0) \approx \frac{\sin(h)}{h}\) for small values of \(h\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-981}{}\hypertarget{p-1512}{}%
Recall that \(y\)-coordinates on the graph of \(y=f'(x)\) come from slopes on the graph of \(y=f(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-982}{}\hypertarget{p-1513}{}%
It might be reasonable to expect that the derivative of a trigonometric function is another trigonometric function.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-64}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1514}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-983}{}\hypertarget{p-1515}{}%
\hyperref[F-2-2-A1-soln-a]{Figure~\ref{F-2-2-A1-soln-a}}.%
\item\hypertarget{li-984}{}\hypertarget{p-1516}{}%
\(1,0,-1,0,1,0,-1,0,1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-985}{}\hypertarget{p-1517}{}%
\(f'(0) = f'(-2\pi) = f'(2\pi) = 1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-986}{}\hypertarget{p-1518}{}%
\hyperref[F-2-2-A1-soln-a]{Figure~\ref{F-2-2-A1-soln-a}}.%
\item\hypertarget{li-987}{}\hypertarget{p-1519}{}%
\(\frac{d}{dx}[\sin(x)] = \cos(x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_2_sineSoln.pdf}
\caption{At left, the graph of \(y = f(x)\), where \(f(x) = \sin(x)\).  At right, the graph of \(y=f'(x)\).\label{F-2-2-A1-soln-a}}
\end{figure}
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-90}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1520}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-988}{}\hypertarget{p-1521}{}%
See \hyperref[F-2-2-A1-soln]{Figure~\ref{F-2-2-A1-soln}} below.%
\item\hypertarget{li-989}{}\hypertarget{p-1522}{}%
Reading left to right from \(-2\pi\) to \(2\pi\) with stepsize \(\pi/2\), the respective slopes of tangent lines appear to be \(1,0,-1,0,1,0,-1,0,1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-990}{}\hypertarget{p-1523}{}%
From the limit definition,%
\begin{align*}
f'(0) =\mathstrut \amp  \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(0 + h) - f(0)}{h}\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(0 + h) - \sin(0)}{h}\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(h)}{h}\text{.}
\end{align*}
Because we cannot simplify the fraction \(\frac{\sin(h)}{h}\) any further algebraically, we estimate the value of the limit using small values of \(h\). Doing so, it appears that \(\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(h)}{h}  = 1\), and thus \(f'(0) = 1\). This matches the estimate generated visually by sketching the tangent line at \((0,f(0))\). Finally, by the periodicity of the sine function, we expect the value of the derivative at 0 to match the derivative value at \(-2\pi\) and \(2\pi\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-991}{}\hypertarget{p-1524}{}%
See the figure below.%
\item\hypertarget{li-992}{}\hypertarget{p-1525}{}%
It appears that \(\frac{d}{dx}[\sin(x)] = \cos(x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_2_sineSoln.pdf}
\caption{At left, the graph of \(y = f(x)\), where \(f(x) = \sin(x)\).  At right, the graph of \(y=f'(x)\).\label{F-2-2-A1-soln}}
\end{figure}
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-2-2}
\hypertarget{p-1526}{}%
Consider the function \(g(x) = \cos(x)\), with the graph of \(y=g(x)\) shown below in \hyperref[F-2-2-A2]{Figure~\ref{F-2-2-A2}}. Note that the grid in the diagram does not have boxes that are \(1 \times 1\), but rather approximately \(1.57 \times 1\), as the horizontal scale of the grid is \(\frac{\pi}{2}\) units per box.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_2_cosine1.jpg}
\caption{The graph of \(y = g(x)\), where \(g(x) = \cos(x)\).\label{F-2-2-A2}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-1527}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-993}{}\hypertarget{p-1528}{}%
At each of \(x = -2\pi, -\frac{3\pi}{2}, -\pi, -\frac{\pi}{2}, 0, \frac{\pi}{2}, \pi, \frac{3\pi}{2}, 2\pi\), use a straightedge to sketch an accurate tangent line to \(y = g(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-994}{}\hypertarget{p-1529}{}%
Use the provided grid to estimate the slope of the tangent line you drew at each point. Again, note the scale of the axes and grid.%
\item\hypertarget{li-995}{}\hypertarget{p-1530}{}%
Use the limit definition of the derivative to estimate \(g'\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)\) by using small values of \(h\), and compare the result to your visual estimate for the slope of the tangent line to \(y = g(x)\) at \(x = \frac{\pi}{2}\) in (b). Using periodicity, what does this result suggest about \(g'\big(-\frac{3\pi}{2}\big)\)? Can symmetry on the graph help you estimate other slopes easily?%
\item\hypertarget{li-996}{}\hypertarget{p-1531}{}%
Based on your work in (a), (b), and (c), sketch an accurate graph of \(y = g'(x)\) on  the interval \(-2\pi\le x\le2\pi\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-997}{}\hypertarget{p-1532}{}%
What familiar function do you think is the derivative of \(g(x) = \cos(x)\)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-40}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1533}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-998}{}\hypertarget{p-1534}{}%
It's very important to use a straightedge for accuracy.%
\item\hypertarget{li-999}{}\hypertarget{p-1535}{}%
First determine the slopes that appear to be zero. Then estimate \(g'\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)\) carefully using the grid. Use symmetry and periodicity to help you estimate other nonzero slopes on the graph.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1000}{}\hypertarget{p-1536}{}%
\(g'\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big) \approx \frac{\cos\big(\frac{\pi}{2}+h\big)}{h}\) for small values of \(h\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1001}{}\hypertarget{p-1537}{}%
Recall that \(y\)-coordinates on the graph of \(y=g'(x)\) come from slopes on the graph of \(y=g(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1002}{}\hypertarget{p-1538}{}%
It might be reasonable to expect that the derivative of a trigonometric function is another trigonometric function.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-65}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1539}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1003}{}\hypertarget{p-1540}{}%
\hyperref[F-2-2-A2-soln-a]{Figure~\ref{F-2-2-A2-soln-a}}.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1004}{}\hypertarget{p-1541}{}%
\(0,-1,0,1,0,-1,0,1,0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1005}{}\hypertarget{p-1542}{}%
\(g'\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)=g'\big(-\frac{3\pi}{2}\big)=-1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1006}{}\hypertarget{p-1543}{}%
\hyperref[F-2-2-A2-soln-a]{Figure~\ref{F-2-2-A2-soln-a}}.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1007}{}\hypertarget{p-1544}{}%
\(\frac{d}{dx}[\cos(x)] = -\sin(x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_2_cosineSoln.pdf}
\caption{At left, the graph of \(y = g(x)\), where \(g(x) = \cos(x)\).  At right, the graph of \(y = g'(x)\)\label{F-2-2-A2-soln-a}}
\end{figure}
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-91}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1545}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1008}{}\hypertarget{p-1546}{}%
See \hyperref[F-2-2-A2-soln]{Figure~\ref{F-2-2-A2-soln}} below.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1009}{}\hypertarget{p-1547}{}%
Reading left to right from \(-2\pi\) to \(2\pi\) with stepsize \(\pi/2\), the respective slopes of tangent lines appear to be \(0,-1,0,1,0,-1,0,1,0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1010}{}\hypertarget{p-1548}{}%
From the limit definition,%
\begin{align*}
g'\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) =\mathstrut \amp  \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{g\big(\frac{\pi}{2} + h\big) - g\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)}{h}\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\cos\big(\frac{\pi}{2} + h\big) - \cos\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)}{h}\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\cos\big(\frac{\pi}{2}+h\big)}{h}
\end{align*}
Because we cannot simplify the fraction \(\frac{\cos\big(\frac{\pi}{2}+h\big)}{h}\) any further algebraically, we estimate the value of the limit using small values of \(h\). Doing so, it appears that \(\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\cos\big(\frac{\pi}{2}+h\big)}{h}  = -1\), and thus \(g'\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big) = -1\). This matches the estimate generated visually by sketching the tangent line at \(\big(\frac{\pi}{2},g\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)\big)\). Finally, by the periodicity of the cosine function, we expect the value of the derivative at \(\frac{\pi}{2}\) to match the derivative value at \(-\frac{3\pi}{2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1011}{}\hypertarget{p-1549}{}%
See \hyperref[F-2-2-A2-soln-a]{Figure~\ref{F-2-2-A2-soln-a}}.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1012}{}\hypertarget{p-1550}{}%
It appears that \(\frac{d}{dx}[\cos(x)] = -\sin(x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_2_cosineSoln.pdf}
\caption{At left, the graph of \(y = g(x) = \cos(x)\).  At right, the graph of \(y = g'(x)\)\label{F-2-2-A2-soln}}
\end{figure}
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-1551}{}%
The results of the two preceding examples suggest that the sine and cosine functions not only have beautiful connections such as the identities \(\sin^2(x) + \cos^2(x) = 1\) and \(\cos\big(x - \frac{\pi}{2}\big) = \sin(x)\), but that they are even further linked through calculus, as the derivative of each involves the other. The following rules summarize the results of the examples.\footnote{These two rules may be formally proved by using the limit definition of the derivative and the expansion identities for \(\sin(x+h)\) and \(\cos(x+h)\).\label{fn-13}}%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1552}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Derivative of Sine and Cosine Functions]\label{sine-cosine-fxns}
\hypertarget{p-1553}{}%
\index{derivative!cosine} \index{derivative!sine} For all real numbers \(x\),%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} [\sin(x)] = \cos(x) \ \ \text{and}  \ \ \frac{d}{dx} [\cos(x)] = -\sin(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1554}{}%
We have now added the sine and cosine functions to our library of basic functions whose derivatives we know. The constant multiple and sum rules still hold, of course, as well as all of the inherent meaning of the derivative.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-2-3}
\hypertarget{p-1555}{}%
Answer each of the following questions. Where a derivative is requested, be sure to label the derivative function with its name using proper notation. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1013}{}\hypertarget{p-1556}{}%
Determine the derivative of \(h(t) = 3\cos(t) - 4\sin(t)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1014}{}\hypertarget{p-1557}{}%
If \(f(x)=2x+\frac{\sin(x)}{2}\), find the exact slope of the tangent line to the graph of \(y = f(x)\) at the point where \(x = \frac{\pi}{6}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1015}{}\hypertarget{p-1558}{}%
If \(g(x)=x^2+2\cos(x)\), find the equation of the tangent line to the graph of \(y = g(x)\) at the point where \(x = \frac{\pi}{2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1016}{}\hypertarget{p-1559}{}%
Determine the derivative of \(p(z) = z^4 + 4^z + 4\cos(z) - \sin\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1017}{}\hypertarget{p-1560}{}%
The function \(P(t) = 24 + 8\sin(t)\) represents a population of a particular kind of animal that lives on a small island, where \(P\) is measured in hundreds and \(t\) is measured in decades since January 1, 2010. What is the instantaneous rate of change of \(P\) on January 1, 2030? What are the units of this quantity? Write a sentence in everyday language that explains how the population is behaving at this point in time.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-41}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1561}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1018}{}\hypertarget{p-1562}{}%
Recall the constant multiple and sum rules.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1019}{}\hypertarget{p-1563}{}%
\(f'\big(\frac{\pi}{6}\big)\) tells us the slope of the tangent line at \(\big(\frac{\pi}{6},f\big(\frac{\pi}{6}\big)\big)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1020}{}\hypertarget{p-1564}{}%
Find both \(\big(\frac{\pi}{2}, g\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)\big)\) and \(g'\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1021}{}\hypertarget{p-1565}{}%
Note that \(\sin\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)\) is a constant.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1022}{}\hypertarget{p-1566}{}%
\(P'(a)\) tells us the instantaneous rate of change of \(P\) with respect to time at the instant \(t = a\), and its units are ``units of \(P\) per unit of time.''%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-66}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1567}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1023}{}\hypertarget{p-1568}{}%
\(\frac{dh}{dt} = -3\sin(t) - 4\cos(t)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1024}{}\hypertarget{p-1569}{}%
\(2+\frac{\sqrt3}4\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1025}{}\hypertarget{p-1570}{}%
\(y - \frac{\pi^2}{4} = (\pi-2)\big(x-\frac{\pi}{2}\big)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1026}{}\hypertarget{p-1571}{}%
\(p'(z) = 4z^3 + 4^z \ln(4) - 4\sin(z)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1027}{}\hypertarget{p-1572}{}%
\(P'(2) = 8\cos(2) \approx -3.329\) hundred animals per decade.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-92}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1573}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1028}{}\hypertarget{p-1574}{}%
By the sum and constant multiple rules,%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dh}{dt} = 3(-\sin(t)) - 4(\cos(t)) = -3\sin(t) - 4\cos(t)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1029}{}\hypertarget{p-1575}{}%
The exact slope of the tangent line to the graph of \(y = f(x)\) at \(x = \frac{\pi}{6}\) is given by \(f'\big(\frac{\pi}{6}\big)\). So, we first compute \(f'(x)\). Since \(f(x)=2x+\frac{\sin(x)}{2}\), we may use the sum and constant multiple rules to find \(f'(x) = 2 + \frac{1}{2}\cos(x)\). Thus%
\begin{equation*}
f'\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 2 + \frac{1}{2} \cos\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 2 + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1030}{}\hypertarget{p-1576}{}%
The tangent line to \(y=g(x)\) at \(x=\frac{\pi}2\) passes through the point \(\big(\frac{\pi}{2}, g\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)\big)\) with slope \(g'\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)\). We observe first that \(g\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big) = \big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)^2 + 2\cos\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big) = \frac{\pi^2}{4}\). Next, we compute the derivative function, \(g'(x)\), and find that%
\begin{align*}
g'(x)=\mathstrut \amp \frac{d}{dx}[x^2]+2\frac{d}{dx}[\cos(x)]\\
=\mathstrut \amp [2x]+2[-\sin(x)]\\
=\mathstrut \amp 2x - 2\sin(x)\text{.}
\end{align*}
Thus \(g'\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big) = 2 \cdot \frac{\pi}{2} - 2 \sin\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big) = \pi - 2\). Hence, the equation of the tangent line (in point-slope form) is given by%
\begin{equation*}
y - \frac{\pi^2}{4} = (\pi-2)\left(x-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1031}{}\hypertarget{p-1577}{}%
We first use the power rule to find \(\frac{d}{dz}[z^4]=4z^3\). We then use the rule for exponential functions to find \(\frac{d}{dz}[4^z]=4^z\ln(4)\), and the rule for cosine and constant multiples to compute \(\frac{d}{dz}[4\cos(z)]=4[-\sin(z)]=-4\sin(z)\). Finally, using the sum rule and noting that \(\sin\big(\frac{\pi}{2}\big)\) is a constant, we have%
\begin{equation*}
p'(z) = 4z^3 + 4^z \ln(4) - 4\sin(z)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1032}{}\hypertarget{p-1578}{}%
The value of \(P'(2)\) will tell us the instantaneous rate of change of \(P\) at the instant two decades have elapsed. Observe that \(P'(t) = 8\cos(t)\), and thus \(P'(2) = 8\cos(2) \approx -3.329\) hundred animals per decade. This tells us that the instantaneous rate of change of \(P\) on January 1, 2030 is about \(-333\) animals per decade, which tells us that the animal population is shrinking moderately at this point in time. We might say that for whatever the population is on January 1, 2030, we expect that population to drop by about 333 animals over the next ten years if the current population trend continues.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.2.2 Summary}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Summary}]{Summary}\label{subsection-54}
\hypertarget{p-1579}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1580}{}%
By carefully analyzing the graphs of \(y = \sin(x)\) and \(y = \cos(x)\), and by using the limit definition of the derivative at select points, we found that \(\frac{d}{dx} [\sin(x)] = \cos(x)\) and \(\frac{d}{dx} [\cos(x)] = -\sin(x)\).%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1581}{}%
We note that all previously encountered derivative rules still hold and may now also be applied to functions involving the sine and cosine. All of the established meaning of the derivative applies to these trigonometric functions as well.%
\end{itemize}
%

\subsection[{Exercises}]{Exercises}\label{exercises-13}
\begin{exerciselist}
\item[1.]\hypertarget{ez-2-2-WW1}{}(Compute the Derivative)\space\space{}\item[2.]\hypertarget{ez-2-2-WW2}{}(Compute the Derivative)\space\space{}\item[3.]\hypertarget{ez-2-2-WW3}{}(Derivative Computation and Evaluation)\space\space{}\item[4.]\hypertarget{ez-2-2-WW4}{}(Find the Tangent Line)\space\space{}\item[5.]\hypertarget{ez-2-2-WW5}{}(Find the Tangent Line)\space\space{}\item[6.]\hypertarget{ez-2-2-WW6}{}(Finding Tangent and Normal Lines)\space\space{}\item[7.]\hypertarget{ez-2-2-WW7}{}(Horizontal Tangent Lines)\space\space{}\item[8.]\hypertarget{ez-2-2-WW8}{}(Making Two Graphs Tangent For Specific Values)\space\space{}\item[9.]\hypertarget{ez-2-2-WW9}{}(An Elastic Band)\space\space{}\item[10.]\hypertarget{exercise-106}{}(Analyzing the Value of an Investment)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-1582}{}%
Suppose that \(V(t) = 24 \cdot 1.07^t + 6 \sin(t)\) represents the value of a person's investment portfolio in thousands of dollars in year \(t\), where \(t = 0\) corresponds to January 1, 2010. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1035}{}\hypertarget{p-1583}{}%
At what instantaneous rate is the portfolio's value changing on January 1, 2012? Include units on your answer.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1036}{}\hypertarget{p-1584}{}%
Determine the value of \(V''(2)\). What are the units on this quantity and what does it tell you about how the portfolio's value is changing?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1037}{}\hypertarget{p-1585}{}%
On the interval \(0 \le t \le 20\), graph the function \(V(t) = 24 \cdot 1.07^t + 6 \sin(t)\) and describe its behavior in the context of the problem. Then, compare the graphs of the functions \(A(t) = 24 \cdot 1.07^t\) and \(V(t) = 24 \cdot 1.07^t + 6 \sin(t)\), as well as the graphs of their derivatives \(A'(t)\) and \(V'(t)\). What is the impact of the term \(6 \sin(t)\) on the behavior of the function \(V(t)\)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-67}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1586}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1038}{}\hypertarget{p-1587}{}%
\(V'(2) = 24 \cdot 1.07^2 \cdot \ln(1.07) + 6 \cos(2) \approx -0.63778\) thousands of dollars per year.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1039}{}\hypertarget{p-1588}{}%
\(V''(2) = 24 \cdot 1.07^2 \cdot \ln(1.07)^2 - 6 \sin(2) \approx -5.33\) thousands of dollars per year per year. At this moment, \(V'\) is decreasing and we expect the derivative's value to decrease by about \(5.33\) thousand dollars per year over the course of the next year.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1040}{}\hypertarget{p-1589}{}%
See the figure below. Adding the term \(6\sin(t)\) to \(A\) to create the function \(V\) adds volatility to the value of the portfolio.%

\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-93}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1590}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1041}{}\hypertarget{p-1591}{}%
January 1, 2012 corresponds to the instant \(t = 2\), so we compute \(V'(2)\). First, we observe by the sum and constant multiple rules that \(V'(t) = 24 \cdot 1.07^t \cdot \ln(1.07) + 6 \cos(t)\). Thus, \(V'(2) = 24 \cdot 1.07^2 \cdot \ln(1.07) + 6 \cos(2) \approx -0.63778\). Since \(V\) is measured in thousands of dollars and \(t\) in years, we know that the portfolio's value is decreasing at a rate of \(637.78\) dollars per year on January 1, 2012.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1042}{}\hypertarget{p-1592}{}%
Since \(V'(t) = 24 \cdot 1.07^t \cdot \ln(1.07) + 6 \cos(t)\), it follows that \(V''(t) = 24 \cdot 1.07^t \cdot (\ln(1.07))^2 - 6 \sin(t)\), and thus \(V''(2) = 24 \cdot 1.07^2 \cdot \ln(1.07)^2 - 6 \sin(2) \approx -5.33\), with units ``thousands of dollars per year per year.'' This means that at the moment \(t = 2\), the portfolio's value is decreasing at a decreasing rate. More specifically, we know that \(V'\) is decreasing at the moment \(t = 2\) and expect the derivative's value to decrease by about \(5.33\) thousand dollars per year over the course of the next year. In other words, the portfolio's value is not only decreasing, but we expect it to decrease more rapidly as the year goes on.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1043}{}\hypertarget{p-1593}{}%
In the figure below, we see plots of both \(V\) and \(A\) along with their corresponding derivatives. We see that the function \(A\) is a purely exponential function that always increases at an increasing rate. By adding the term \(6\sin(t)\) to \(A\) to create the function \(V\), we add volatility to the value of the portfolio: the oscillating nature of the sine function not only creates variance in the stock's value, but also in its rate of change. We also observe that as time progresses and the value of \(24 \cdot (1.07)^t\) increases, the effect of \(6 \sin(t)\) lessens.%

\item[11.]\hypertarget{exercise-107}{}(Differentiating Sine and Cosine)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-1594}{}%
Let \(f(x) = 3\cos(x) - 2\sin(x) + 6\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1044}{}\hypertarget{p-1595}{}%
Determine the exact slope of the tangent line to \(y = f(x)\) at the point where \(a = \frac{\pi}{4}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1045}{}\hypertarget{p-1596}{}%
Determine the equation of the tangent line to \(y = f(x)\) at the point where \(a = \pi\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1046}{}\hypertarget{p-1597}{}%
At the point where \(a = \frac{\pi}{2}\), is \(f\) increasing, decreasing, or neither?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1047}{}\hypertarget{p-1598}{}%
At the point where \(a = \frac{3\pi}{2}\), does the tangent line to \(y = f(x)\) lie above the curve, below the curve, or neither? How can you answer this question without even graphing the function or the tangent line?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-68}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1599}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1048}{}\hypertarget{p-1600}{}%
\(f'\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) = -5\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1049}{}\hypertarget{p-1601}{}%
\(L(x) = 3+2(x-\pi)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1050}{}\hypertarget{p-1602}{}%
Decreasing.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1051}{}\hypertarget{p-1603}{}%
The tangent line to \(f\) lies above the curve at this point.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-94}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1604}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1052}{}\hypertarget{p-1605}{}%
The slope of the line tangent to the graph of \(f\) at \(a = \frac{\pi}{4}\) is given by \(f'\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\). To find \(f'\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\) we first find \(f'(x)\), which is \(f'(x) = -3\sin(x) - 2\cos(x)\). Thus,%
\begin{align*}
f'\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) &= -3\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) - 2\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\\
& -3\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) - 3\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) = -5\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1053}{}\hypertarget{p-1606}{}%
The linearization \(L(x)\) to \(f\) at \(a = \pi\) is \(L(x) = f(\pi) + f'(\pi)(x-\pi)\). We calculated \(f'(x)\) in part (a) and so \(f'(\pi) = -3\sin(\pi) - 2\cos(\pi) = 2\). We also have \(f(\pi) = 3\cos(\pi) - 2\sin(\pi) + 6 = 3\). Hence \(L(x) = 3+2(x-\pi)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1054}{}\hypertarget{p-1607}{}%
A differentiable function \(f\) is increasing at \(x=a\) if and only if \(f'(a) \gt 0\) and decreasing if and only if \(f'(a) \lt 0\). Now \(f'\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = -3\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) - 2\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = -3\), so \(f\) is decreasing at \(a = \frac{\pi}{2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1055}{}\hypertarget{p-1608}{}%
If a curve defined by a function \(f\) is concave up at \(x=a\), then the tangent line to \(f\) at \(x=a\) lies below the curve and if the graph of \(f\) is concave down at \(x=a\), then the tangent line to \(f\) at \(x=a\) lies above the curve. The concavity of a curve is determined by the second derivative and \(f''(x) = -3\cos(x)+2\sin(x)\). Since%
\begin{equation*}
f''\left(\frac{3\pi}{2}\right) = -3\cos\left(\frac{3\pi}{2}\right) + 2\sin\left(\frac{3\pi}{2}\right) = -2\text{,}
\end{equation*}
the graph of \(f\) is concave down at \(a = \frac{3\pi}{2}\) and the tangent line to \(f\) lies above the curve at this point.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[12.]\hypertarget{exercise-108}{}(Understanding the Derivatives of Sine and Cosine)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-1609}{}%
In this exercise, we explore how the limit definition of the derivative more formally shows that \(\frac{d}{dx}[\sin(x)] = \cos(x)\). Letting \(f(x) = \sin(x)\), note that the limit definition of the derivative tells us that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(x+h) - \sin(x)}{h}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1056}{}\hypertarget{p-1610}{}%
Recall the trigonometric identity for the sine of a sum of angles \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\): \(\sin(\alpha + \beta) = \sin(\alpha)\cos(\beta) + \cos(\alpha)\sin(\beta)\). Use this identity and some algebra to show that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(x)(\cos(h)-1) + \cos(x)\sin(h)}{h}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1057}{}\hypertarget{p-1611}{}%
Next, note that as \(h\) changes, \(x\) remains constant. Explain why it therefore makes sense to say that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \sin(x) \cdot \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\cos(h) -1 }{h} + \cos(x) \cdot \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(h)}{h}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1058}{}\hypertarget{p-1612}{}%
Finally, use small values of \(h\) to estimate the values of the two limits in (c):%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\cos(h) - 1}{h} \ \ \text{and}  \ \ \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(h)}{h}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1059}{}\hypertarget{p-1613}{}%
What do your results in (b) and (c) thus tell you about \(f'(x)\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1060}{}\hypertarget{p-1614}{}%
By emulating the steps taken above, use the limit definition of the derivative to argue convincingly that \(\frac{d}{dx}[\cos(x)] = -\sin(x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-69}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1615}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1061}{}\hypertarget{p-1616}{}%
Hint: in the numerator of the difference quotient, combine the first and last terms and remove a factor of \(\sin(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1062}{}\hypertarget{p-1617}{}%
Hint: divide each part of the numerator by \(h\) and consider the sum of two separate limits.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1063}{}\hypertarget{p-1618}{}%
\(\lim_{h \to 0} \left( \frac{\cos(h)-1}{h} \right) = 0\) and \(\lim_{h \to 0} \left( \frac{\sin(h)}{h} \right) = 1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1064}{}\hypertarget{p-1619}{}%
\(f'(x) = \sin(x) \cdot 0 + \cos(x) \cdot 1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1065}{}\hypertarget{p-1620}{}%
Hint: \(\cos(\alpha + \beta)\) is \(\cos(\alpha + \beta) = \cos(\alpha) \cos(\beta) - \sin(\alpha) \sin(\beta)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-95}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1621}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1066}{}\hypertarget{p-1622}{}%
By definition, we know that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(x+h) - \sin(x)}{h}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
By the sum of two angles identity for the sine function, \(\sin(x+h) = \sin(x)\cos(h) + \cos(x)\sin(h)\), and thus%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(x)\cos(h) + \cos(x)\sin(h) - \sin(x)}{h}\text{..}
\end{equation*}
Combining the first and last terms and removing a factor of \(\sin(x)\),%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{ \sin(x)(\cos(h)-1) + \cos(x)\sin(h) - \sin(x) }{h}\text{..}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1067}{}\hypertarget{p-1623}{}%
Continuing our work in (a), we divide each part of the numerator by \(h\) and see it follows%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \left( \frac{\sin(x) (\cos(h)-1) }{h}  + \frac{\cos(x)\sin(h)}{h} \right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Next, we note that \(\sin(x)\) does not depend on \(h\), and likewise \(\cos(x)\) is independent of \(h\). It thus makes sense to view those constants as being outside the limit being taken, and also that the limit of a sum is the sum of the limits. Hence we write%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \sin(x) \cdot \lim_{h \to 0} \left( \frac{\cos(h)-1}{h} \right)  + \cos(x) \cdot \lim_{h \to 0} \left( \frac{\sin(h)}{h} \right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1068}{}\hypertarget{p-1624}{}%
Using small positive and negative values of \(h\) to estimate the desired limits, we find that it appears%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{h \to 0} \left( \frac{\cos(h)-1}{h} \right) = 0
\end{equation*}
and%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{h \to 0} \left( \frac{\sin(h)}{h} \right) = 1
\end{equation*}
It suffices in each case to consider \(h\)-values of \(h = \pm 0.01, \pm 0.001, \pm 0.0001\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1069}{}\hypertarget{p-1625}{}%
Combining our results in (b) and (c), we have found that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \sin(x) \cdot \lim_{h \to 0} \left( \frac{\cos(h)-1}{h} \right)  + \cos(x) \cdot \lim_{h \to 0} \left( \frac{\sin(h)}{h} \right) = \sin(x) \cdot 0 + \cos(x) \cdot 1 = \cos(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1070}{}\hypertarget{p-1626}{}%
The argument for showing \(\frac{d}{dx}[\cos(x)] = -\sin(x)\) is almost identical. Do note that the sum of two angles identity for \(\cos(\alpha + \beta)\) is \(\cos(\alpha + \beta) = \cos(\alpha) \cos(\beta) - \sin(\alpha) \sin(\beta)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{exerciselist}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Section 2.3 The Product and Quotient Rules}
\typeout{************************************************}
\section[{The Product and Quotient Rules}]{The Product and Quotient Rules}\label{sec-2-3-prod-quot}
\begin{objectives}{Motivating Questions}\label{objectives-11}
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1627}{}%
How does the algebraic structure of a function guide us in computing its derivative using shortcut rules?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1628}{}%
How do we compute the derivative of a product of two basic functions in terms of the derivatives of the basic functions?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1629}{}%
How do we compute the derivative of a quotient of two basic functions in terms of the derivatives of the basic functions?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1630}{}%
How do the product and quotient rules combine with the sum and constant multiple rules to expand the library of functions we can differentiate quickly?%
\end{itemize}
\end{objectives}
\hypertarget{p-1631}{}%
So far, we can differentiate power functions \(x^n\), exponential functions \(a^x\), and the two fundamental trigonometric functions \(\sin(x)\) and \(\cos(x)\). With the sum rule and constant multiple rules, we can also compute the derivative of combined functions.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-85}
\hypertarget{p-1632}{}%
Differentiate%
\begin{equation*}
f(x) = 7x^{11} - 4 \cdot 9^x + \pi \sin(x) - \sqrt{3}\cos(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-42}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1633}{}%
Use a combination of all the differentiation rules we've learned in this chapter.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-70}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1634}{}%
\(f'(x) = 77x^{10} - 4 \cdot 9^x \ln(9) + \pi \cos(x) + \sqrt{3} \sin(x)\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-96}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1635}{}%
Because \(f\) is a sum of basic functions, we can now quickly say that \(f'(x)=77x^{10}-4\cdot9^x\ln(9)+\pi\cos(x)+\sqrt{3}\sin(x)\).%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-1636}{}%
What about a product or quotient of two basic functions, such as \(p(z) = z^3 \cos(z)\), or \(q(t) = \frac{\sin(t)}{2^t}\)?%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1637}{}%
While the derivative of a sum is the sum of the derivatives, it turns out that the rules for computing derivatives of products and quotients are more complicated.%
\begin{example}[]\label{PA-2-3}
\hypertarget{p-1638}{}%
Let \(f\) and \(g\) be the functions defined by \(f(t) = 2t^2\) and \(g(t) = t^3 + 4t\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1075}{}\hypertarget{p-1639}{}%
Determine \(f'(t)\) and \(g'(t)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1076}{}\hypertarget{p-1640}{}%
Let \(p(t) = 2t^2 (t^3 + 4t)\) and observe that \(p(t) = f(t) \cdot g(t)\). Rewrite the formula for \(p\) by distributing the \(2t^2\) term. Then compute \(p'(t)\) using the sum and constant multiple rules.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1077}{}\hypertarget{p-1641}{}%
True or false: \(p'(t) = f'(t) \cdot g'(t)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1078}{}\hypertarget{p-1642}{}%
Let \(q(t) = \frac{t^3 + 4t}{2t^2}\) and observe that \(q(t) = \frac{g(t)}{f(t)}\). Rewrite the formula for \(q\) by dividing each term in the numerator by the denominator and simplify to write \(q\) as a sum of constant multiples of powers of \(t\). Then compute \(q'(t)\) using the sum and constant multiple rules.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1079}{}\hypertarget{p-1643}{}%
True or false: \(q'(t) = \frac{g'(t)}{f'(t)}\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-43}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1644}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1080}{}\hypertarget{p-1645}{}%
Use a combination of the power rule, the constant multiple rule, and the sum rule.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1081}{}\hypertarget{p-1646}{}%
\(p(t)\) is a polynomial.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1082}{}\hypertarget{p-1647}{}%
Multiply your answers from (a) together; does the result match what you found in (b)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1083}{}\hypertarget{p-1648}{}%
Start by splitting the fraction into two pieces, then simplify.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1084}{}\hypertarget{p-1649}{}%
Divide your answers from (a) in the correct order; does this match what you found in (d)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-71}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1650}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1085}{}\hypertarget{p-1651}{}%
\(f'(t)=4t\) and \(g'(t)=3t^2+4\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1086}{}\hypertarget{p-1652}{}%
Since \(p(t)=2t^5+8t^3\), then \(p'(t)=10t^4+24t^2\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1087}{}\hypertarget{p-1653}{}%
False, \(p'(t)\neq f'(t)\cdot g'(t)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1088}{}\hypertarget{p-1654}{}%
Since \(q(t)=\frac12t+2t^{-1}\), then \(q'(t)=\frac12-2t^{-2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1089}{}\hypertarget{p-1655}{}%
False, \(q'(t)\neq\frac{g'(t)}{f'(t)}\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-97}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1656}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1090}{}\hypertarget{p-1657}{}%
Using the power rule and the constant multiple rule, we see that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(t)=\frac{d}{dt}[2t^2]=2\frac{d}{dt}[t^2]=2(2t)=4t\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Using the same rules together with the sum rule, we see that%
\begin{equation*}
g'(t)=\frac{d}{dt}[t^3+4t]=\frac{d}{dt}[t^3]+4\frac{d}{dt}[t]=(3t^2)+4(1)=3t^2+4\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1091}{}\hypertarget{p-1658}{}%
Observe that \(p(t)=2t^2(t^3+4t)=2t^5+8t^3\). Since \(\frac{d}{dt}[t^5]=5t^4\) and \(\frac{d}{dt}[t^3]=3t^2\), we can use the sum and constant multiple rules to say that the derivative of \(p\) with respect to \(t\) is%
\begin{equation*}
p'(t)=\frac{d}{dt}[2t^5+8t^3]=2(5t^4)+8(3t^2)=10t^4+24t^2\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1092}{}\hypertarget{p-1659}{}%
From our answers in (a), we know%
\begin{equation*}
f'(t)\cdot g'(t)=(4t)\cdot(3t^2+4)=12t^3+16t\text{.}
\end{equation*}
This does not match what we found in (b) as the formula for \(p'(t)=10t^4+24t^2\). We conclude that even though \(p(t)=f(t)\cdot g(t)\), it is \emph{not} the case that \(p'(t)=f'(t)\cdot g'(t)\). In other words, the derivative of a product of two functions need not be the product of the derivatives.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1093}{}\hypertarget{p-1660}{}%
To put \(q(t)\) into a form we can differentiate, notice that%
\begin{equation*}
q(t)=\frac{t^3+4t}{2t^2}=\frac{t^3}{2t^2}+\frac{4t}{2t^2}=\frac12t+2t^{-1}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Now since \(\frac{d}{dt}[t]=1\) and \(\frac{d}{dt}[t^{-1}]=-t^{-2}\), we use the sum and constant multiple rules to find%
\begin{equation*}
q'(t)=\frac12(1)+2(-t^{-2})=\frac12-2t^{-2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1094}{}\hypertarget{p-1661}{}%
From our answers in (a), we know%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{g'(t)}{f'(t)}=\frac{3t^2+4}{4t}=\frac34t+t^{-1}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
This does not match what we found in (d) as the formula for \(q'(t)=\frac12-2t^{-2}\). We conclude that even though \(q(t)=\frac{g(t)}{f(t)}\), it is \emph{not} the case that \(q'(t)=\frac{g'(t)}{f'(t)}\). In other words, the derivative of a quotient of two functions need not be the quotient of the derivatives.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.3.1 The Product Rule}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{The Product Rule}]{The Product Rule}\label{subsection-55}
\hypertarget{p-1662}{}%
As part (b) of \hyperref[PA-2-3]{Example~\ref{PA-2-3}} shows, it is not true in general that the derivative of a product of two functions is the product of the derivatives of those functions. To see why this is the case, we consider a situation involving functions with physical context.%
\begin{example}[]\label{stock-share}
\hypertarget{p-1663}{}%
Say that an investor is regularly purchasing stock in a particular company. Let \(N(t)\) represent the number of shares owned on day \(t\), where \(t = 0\) represents the first day on which shares were purchased. Let \(S(t)\) give the value of one share of the stock on day \(t\); note that the units on \(S(t)\) are dollars per share. To compute the total value of the stock on day \(t\), we take the product%
\begin{equation*}
V(t) = N(t) \, \text{shares}  \cdot S(t) \, \text{dollars per share}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
Observe that over time, both the number of shares and the value of a given share will vary. The derivative \(N'(t)\) measures the rate at which the number of shares is changing, while \(S'(t)\) measures the rate at which the value per share is changing. How do these respective rates of change affect the rate of change of the total value function?%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1664}{}%
To help us understand the relationship among changes in \(N\), \(S\), and \(V\), let's consider some specific data. \leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}Suppose that on day 100, the investor owns 520 shares of stock and the stock's current value is \textdollar{}27.50 per share. This tells us that \(N(100) = 520\) and \(S(100) = 27.50\).%
\item{}On day 100, the investor purchases an additional 12 shares (so the number of shares held is rising at a rate of 12 shares per day).%
\item{}On that same day the price of the stock is rising at a rate of 0.75 dollars per share per day.%
\end{itemize}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1665}{}%
In calculus notation, the latter two facts tell us that \(N'(100) = 12\) (shares per day) and \(S'(100) = 0.75\) (dollars per share per day). At what rate is the value of the investor's total holdings changing on day 100?%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1666}{}%
Observe that the increase in total value comes from two sources: the growing number of shares and the rising value of each share.%
\leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1667}{}%
If only the number of shares is increasing (and the value of each share is constant), the rate at which the total value would rise is the product of the rate at which the number of shares is changing and the current value of the shares. That is, the rate at which the total value would change when the share value is constant is given by%
\begin{equation*}
N'(100) \cdot S(100) =  12 \, \frac{\text{shares}}{\text{day}} \cdot 27.50 \, \frac{\text{dollars}}{\text{share}} = 330 \, \frac{\text{dollars} }{\text{day} }\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1668}{}%
Note particularly how the units make sense and show the rate at which the total value \(V\) is changing, measured in dollars per day.%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1669}{}%
If instead the number of shares is constant, but the value of each share is rising, the rate at which the total value would rise is  the product of the number of shares and the rate of change of share value. In this case, the total value is rising at a rate of%
\begin{equation*}
N(100) \cdot S'(100) = 520 \, \text{shares}  \cdot 0.75 \, \frac{\text{dollars per share} }{\text{day} } = 390 \, \frac{\text{dollars} }{\text{day} }\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1670}{}%
Of course, when both the number of shares and the value of each share are changing, we have to include both of these sources. In that case the rate at which the total value is rising is%
\begin{equation*}
V'(100) =  N'(100) \cdot S(100) + N(100) \cdot S'(100) = 330 + 390 = 720 \, \frac{\text{dollars} }{\text{day} }\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{itemize}
\hypertarget{p-1671}{}%
We expect the total value of the investor's holdings to rise by about \textdollar{}720 on the 100th day.\footnote{While this example highlights why the product rule is true, there are some subtle issues to recognize. For one, if the stock's value really does rise exactly \textdollar{}0.75 on day 100, and the number of shares really rises by 12 on day 100, then we would expect that \(V(101) = N(101) \cdot S(101) = 532 \cdot 28.25 = 15,029\). If, as noted above, we expect the total value to rise by \textdollar{}720, then with \(V(100) = N(100) \cdot S(100) = 520 \cdot 27.50 = 14,300\), then it seems we should find that \(V(101) = V(100) + 720 = 15,020\). Why do the two results differ by 9? One way to understand why this difference occurs is to recognize that \(N'(100) = 12\) represents an \emph{instantaneous} rate of change, while our (informal) discussion has also thought of this number as the total change in the number of shares over the course of a single day. The formal proof of the product rule reconciles this issue by taking the limit as the change in the input tends to zero.\label{fn-14}}%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-1672}{}%
Next, we expand our perspective from the specific example above to the more general and abstract setting of a product \(P\) of two differentiable functions, \(f\) and \(g\). If \(P(x) = f(x) \cdot g(x)\), our work above suggests that \(P'(x) = f'(x) g(x) + f(x) g'(x)\). Indeed, a formal proof using the limit definition of the derivative can be given to show that the following rule, called the \terminology{product rule}, holds in general.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1673}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Product Rule]\label{prod-rule}
\hypertarget{p-1674}{}%
\index{product rule} \index{derivative!product rule} If \(f\) and \(g\) are differentiable functions, then their product \(P(x) = f(x) \cdot g(x)\) is also a differentiable function, and%
\begin{equation*}
P'(x) = f'(x) g(x) + f(x) g'(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1675}{}%
In light of \hyperref[stock-share]{Example~\ref{stock-share}} involving shares of stock, the product rule also makes sense intuitively: the rate of change of \(P\) should take into account both how fast \(f\) and \(g\) are changing, as well as how large \(f\) and \(g\) are at the point of interest. In words, the product rule says: if \(P\) is the product of two functions \(f\) (the first function) and \(g\) (the second), then ``the derivative of \(P\) is the derivative of the first times the second, plus the first times the derivative of the second.'' It is often a helpful mental exercise to say this phrasing aloud when executing the product rule.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-88}
\hypertarget{p-1676}{}%
If \(P(z) = z^3 \cdot \cos(z)\), we can use the product rule to differentiate \(P\). The first function is \(z^3\) and the second function is \(\cos(z)\). By the product rule, \(P'\) will be given by the derivative of the first, \(3z^2\), times the second, \(\cos(z)\), plus the first, \(z^3\), times the derivative of the second, \(-\sin(z)\). That is,%
\begin{equation*}
P'(z) = 3z^2\cos(z)+z^3(-\sin(z)) = 3z^2 \cos(z)-z^3\sin(z)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-3-1}
\hypertarget{p-1677}{}%
Use the product rule to answer each of the questions below. Throughout, be sure to carefully label any derivative you find by name. It is not necessary to algebraically simplify any of the derivatives you compute. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1101}{}\hypertarget{p-1678}{}%
Let \(m(w)=3w^{17} 4^w\). Find \(m'(w)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1102}{}\hypertarget{p-1679}{}%
Let \(h(t) = (\sin(t) + \cos(t))t^4\). Find \(h'(t)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1103}{}\hypertarget{p-1680}{}%
Determine the slope of the tangent line to the curve \(y = f(x)\) at the point where \(a = 1\) if \(f\) is given by the rule \(f(x) = e^x \sin(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1104}{}\hypertarget{p-1681}{}%
Find an equation for the tangent line \(L\) to the graph of \(y = g(x)\) at the point where \(a = -1\) if \(g\) is given by the rule \(g(x) = (x^2 + x) 2^x\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-44}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1682}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1105}{}\hypertarget{p-1683}{}%
Let the first function be \(3w^{17}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1106}{}\hypertarget{p-1684}{}%
Let the first function be \((\sin(t) + \cos(t))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1107}{}\hypertarget{p-1685}{}%
Remember that the slope of the tangent line to \(y = f(x)\) at \((a,f(a))\) is given by \(f'(a)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1108}{}\hypertarget{p-1686}{}%
Recall that the tangent line to \(y=g(x)\) at \((a,g(a))\) is given by the equation \(y-g(a)=g'(a)(x-a)\). To denote this line by a function \(L\), we can write \(L(x)=g'(a)(x-a)+g(a)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-72}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1687}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1109}{}\hypertarget{p-1688}{}%
\(m'(w) = 51w^{16} \cdot 4^w  + 3w^{17}\cdot 4^w \ln(4)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1110}{}\hypertarget{p-1689}{}%
\(h'(t) = (\cos(t) - \sin(t)) \cdot t^4 + (\sin(t) + \cos(t))\cdot 4t^3\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1111}{}\hypertarget{p-1690}{}%
\(f'(1) = e(\sin(1) + \cos(1)) \approx 3.756\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1112}{}\hypertarget{p-1691}{}%
\(L(x) = -\frac{1}{2}(x+1)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-98}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1692}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1113}{}\hypertarget{p-1693}{}%
By the product rule,%
\begin{equation*}
m'(w) = 51w^{16}\cdot 4^2+3w^{17}\cdot 4^2\ln(4)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1114}{}\hypertarget{p-1694}{}%
By the product rule,%
\begin{equation*}
h'(t) = (\cos(t) - \sin(t)) \cdot t^4 + (\sin(t) + \cos(t))\cdot 4t^3\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1115}{}\hypertarget{p-1695}{}%
To determine the slope of the tangent line at \(a = 1\), we want to find \(f'(1)\). Since \(f(x) = e^x \sin(x)\), the product rule tells us that \(f'(x) = e^x \cdot \sin(x) + e^x \cdot \cos(x)\). Thus, \(f'(1) = e^1 \cdot \sin(1) + e^1\cdot \cos(1) = e(\sin(1) + \cos(1)) \approx 3.756\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1116}{}\hypertarget{p-1696}{}%
First, observe that \(g(-1) = ((-1)^2 - 1) \cdot 2^{-1} = 0\), so we are looking for the tangent line to \(g\) at the point \((-1,0)\). Furthermore, by the product rule, \(g'(x) = (2x + 1) \cdot 2^x + (x^2+x)\cdot 2^x\ln(2)\), and hence%
\begin{align*}
g'(-1) \amp= (2(-1)+ 1) \cdot 2^{-1} + ((-1)^2 - 1)\cdot 2^{-1}\ln(2) \\
\amp= (-1)\frac{1}{2} +0 = -\frac{1}{2}\text{.}
\end{align*}
Therefore, \(L(x)-0=-\frac{1}{2}(x-(-1))\), or%
\begin{equation*}
L(x) = -\frac{1}{2}(x+1)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.3.2 The Quotient Rule}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{The Quotient Rule}]{The Quotient Rule}\label{subsection-56}
\hypertarget{p-1697}{}%
Because quotients and products are closely linked, we can use the product rule to understand how to take the derivative of a quotient. Let \(Q(x)\) be defined by \(Q(x) = \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\), where \(f\) and \(g\) are both differentiable functions. It turns out that \(Q\) is differentiable everywhere that \(g(x) \ne 0\). We would like a formula for \(Q'\) in terms of \(f\), \(g\), \(f'\), and \(g'\). Multiplying both sides of the equation \(Q = \frac{f}{g}\) by \(g\), we observe that%
\begin{equation*}
f(x) = Q(x) \cdot g(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1698}{}%
Now we can use the product rule to differentiate \(f\):%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = Q'(x) g(x) + Q(x)g'(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1699}{}%
We want to know a formula for \(Q'\), so we solve this equation for \(Q'(x)\). Then%
\begin{equation*}
Q'(x) g(x) = f'(x) - Q(x) g'(x)\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and dividing both sides by \(g(x)\), we have%
\begin{equation*}
Q'(x) = \frac{f'(x) - Q(x) g'(x)}{g(x)}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1700}{}%
Finally, we recall that \(Q(x) = \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\). Substituting this expression in the preceding equation, we have%
\begin{align*}
Q'(x) =\mathstrut \amp  \frac{f'(x) - \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} g'(x)}{g(x)}\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \frac{f'(x) - \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} g'(x)}{g(x)} \cdot \frac{g(x)}{g(x)}\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \frac{f'(x)g(x) -  f(x) g'(x)}{[g(x)]^2}\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1701}{}%
This calculation gives us the \terminology{quotient rule}.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1702}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Quotient Rule]\label{quot-rule}
\hypertarget{p-1703}{}%
\index{quotient rule} \index{derivative!quotient rule} If \(f\) and \(g\) are differentiable functions, then their quotient \(Q(x) = \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\) is also a differentiable function for all \(x\) where \(g(x) \ne 0\), and%
\begin{equation*}
Q'(x) = \frac{f'(x)g(x) -  f(x) g'(x)}{[g(x)]^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1704}{}%
As with the product rule, it can be helpful to think of the quotient rule verbally. If a function \(Q\) is the quotient of a top function \(f\) and a bottom function \(g\), then \(Q'\) is given by ``the derivative of the top times the bottom, minus the top times the derivative of the bottom, all over the bottom squared.''\footnote{If you have studied differentiation before, you may have seen this rule as \(\frac{d}{dx}\left[\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\right]=\frac{g(x)f'(x)-f(x)g'(x)}{[g(x)]^2}\), with the mnemonic "``low-d-high minus high-d-low all over low squared.''" If this version is more comfortable for you, you are welcome to use it instead.\label{fn-15}}%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-90}
\hypertarget{p-1705}{}%
If \(Q(t) = \frac{\sin(t)}{2^t}\), we call  \(\sin(t)\) the top function and \(2^t\) the bottom function. By the quotient rule, \(Q'\) is given by the derivative of the top, \(\cos(t)\), times the bottom, \(2^t\), minus the top, \(\sin(t)\), times the derivative of the bottom, \(2^t \ln(2)\), all over the bottom squared, \((2^t)^2\). That is,%
\begin{equation*}
Q'(t) = \frac{\cos(t)2^t - \sin(t) 2^t \ln(2)}{(2^t)^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1706}{}%
In this particular example, it is possible to simplify \(Q'(t)\) by removing a factor of \(2^t\) from both the numerator and denominator, so that%
\begin{equation*}
Q'(t) = \frac{\cos(t) - \sin(t) \ln(2)}{2^t}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-1707}{}%
In general, we must be careful in doing any such simplification, as we don't want to follow a correct execution of the quotient rule with an algebraic error.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-3-2}
\hypertarget{p-1708}{}%
Use the quotient rule to answer each of the questions below. Throughout, be sure to carefully label any derivative you find by name. That is, if you're given a formula for \(f(x)\), clearly label the formula you find for \(f'(x)\). It is not necessary to algebraically simplify any of the derivatives you compute. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1117}{}\hypertarget{p-1709}{}%
Let \(r(z)=\frac{3^z}{z^4 + 1}\). Find \(r'(z)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1118}{}\hypertarget{p-1710}{}%
Let \(v(t) = \frac{\sin(t)}{\cos(t) + t^2}\). Find \(v'(t)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1119}{}\hypertarget{p-1711}{}%
Determine the slope of the tangent line to the curve \(y=R(x)\) at the point where \(x=0\), if \(\displaystyle R(x) = \frac{x^2 - 2x - 8}{x^2 - 9}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1120}{}\hypertarget{p-1712}{}%
When a camera flashes, the intensity \(I\) of light seen by the eye \(t\) milliseconds after the initial flash point is given by the function%
\begin{equation*}
I(t) = \frac{100t}{e^t}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
where \(I\) is measured in candles. Compute \(I'(0.5)\), \(I'(2)\), and \(I'(5)\); include appropriate units on each value; and discuss the meaning of each.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-45}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1713}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1121}{}\hypertarget{p-1714}{}%
When applying the quotient rule, use parentheses around the bottom function, \(z^4 + 1\), to ensure that when you compute ``the derivative of the top times the bottom'' that the rule is applied correctly.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1122}{}\hypertarget{p-1715}{}%
When applying the quotient rule, use parentheses around the bottom function, \(\cos(t) + t^2\), and its derivative to ensure that the rule is applied correctly.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1123}{}\hypertarget{p-1716}{}%
Remember one of the key interpretations of the derivative.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1124}{}\hypertarget{p-1717}{}%
Let the top function be \(100t\) and simply use the constant multiple rule to find its derivative.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-73}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1718}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1125}{}\hypertarget{p-1719}{}%
\(r'(z)=\frac{3^z \ln(3)(z^4+1) - 3^z(4z^3)}{(z^4 + 1)^2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1126}{}\hypertarget{p-1720}{}%
\(v'(t) = \frac{\cos(t)(\cos(t) + t^2) - \sin(t)(\sin(t) + 2t)}{(\cos(t) + t^2)^2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1127}{}\hypertarget{p-1721}{}%
\(R'(0) = \frac{2}{9}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1128}{}\hypertarget{p-1722}{}%
\(I'(0.5) = \frac{50}{e^{0.5}} \approx 30.327\), \(I'(2) = \frac{-100}{e^{2}} \approx -13.534\), and \(I'(5) = \frac{-400}{e^4} \approx -2.695\), each in candles per millisecond.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-99}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1723}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1129}{}\hypertarget{p-1724}{}%
By the quotient rule,%
\begin{equation*}
r'(z)=\frac{3^z \ln(3) (z^4+1) - 3^z(4z^3)}{(z^4 + 1)^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1130}{}\hypertarget{p-1725}{}%
By the quotient rule,%
\begin{equation*}
v'(t) = \frac{\cos(t)(\cos(t) + t^2) - \sin(t)(\sin(t) + 2t)}{(\cos(t) + t^2)^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1131}{}\hypertarget{p-1726}{}%
We first compute \(R'(x)\). By the quotient rule,%
\begin{equation*}
R'(x) = \frac{(2x - 2)(x^2 - 9) - (x^2 - 2x - 8)(2x)}{(x^2 - 9)^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
From this, it follows that \(R'(0) = \frac{(-2)(-9)-(-8)(0)}{(-9)^2} = \frac{2}{9}\), which is the slope of the tangent line to the curve at the point where \(x = 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1132}{}\hypertarget{p-1727}{}%
By the quotient rule and algebraic simplification,%
\begin{equation*}
I'(t) = \frac{100e^t - 100te^t}{(e^t)^2} = \frac{100-100t}{e^t}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Thus, \(I'(0.5) = \frac{50}{e^{0.5}} \approx 30.327\), \(I'(2) = \frac{-100}{e^{2}} \approx -13.534\), and \(I'(5) = \frac{-400}{e^4} \approx -2.695\), each measured in candles per millisecond. These results show that at \(t = 0.5\), the intensity of the flash is increasing rapidly, while at \(t = 2\) and \(t = 5\), the intensity is decreasing, with the intensity decreasing more rapidly when \(t = 2\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.3.3 The Product and Quotient Rule Using Tables and Graphs}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{The Product and Quotient Rule Using Tables and Graphs}]{The Product and Quotient Rule Using Tables and Graphs}\label{subsection-57}
\hypertarget{p-1728}{}%
In addition to being used to finding the derivatives of functions given by equations, the product and quotient rule can be useful for finding the derivatives of functions given by tables and graphs.  The following examples illustrate this process.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-92}
\hypertarget{p-1729}{}%
Suppose the functions \(f\) and \(g\) are described by \hyperref[T-prod-ex]{Table~\ref{T-prod-ex}} below, and the function \(h\) is given by the formula \(h(x)=f(x)g(x)\). Then we can calculate \(h'(2)=f'(2)g(2)+f(2)g'(2)=4 \times 5 + 2 \times 6=32\).%
\begin{table}
\centering
\begin{tabular}{llllll}
\multicolumn{1}{lB}{\(x\)}&-2&-1&0&1&2\tabularnewline\hrulemedium
\multicolumn{1}{lB}{\(f(x)\)}&3&2&4&3&2\tabularnewline[0pt]
\multicolumn{1}{lB}{\(f'(x)\)}&1&2&5&2&4\tabularnewline[0pt]
\multicolumn{1}{lB}{\(g(x)\)}&2&3&7&1&5\tabularnewline[0pt]
\multicolumn{1}{lB}{\(g'(x)\)}&0&2&3&4&6
\end{tabular}
\caption{Table of values describing \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\).\label{T-prod-ex}}
\end{table}
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{example-93}
\hypertarget{p-1730}{}%
Suppose the function \(f\) is described by \hyperref[T-quot-ex]{Table~\ref{T-quot-ex}} below, the function \(g\) is described by the graph in \hyperref[F-2-3-quottable]{Figure~\ref{F-2-3-quottable}}, and the function \(h\) is given by the formula \(h(x)=\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\). Then for certain values of \(x\), we can calculate%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x)=\frac{f'(x)g(x)-f(x)g'(x)}{(g(x))^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1731}{}%
Suppose we want to find \(h'(0)\). \hyperref[T-quot-ex]{Table~\ref{T-quot-ex}} tells us that \(f(0)=4\) and \(f'(0)=5\). From visual inspection of \hyperref[F-2-3-quottable]{Figure~\ref{F-2-3-quottable}}, we also notice that \(g(0)=2\) and \(g'(0)=1\).  Therefore%
\begin{equation*}
h'(0)=\frac{f'(0)g(0)-f(0)g'(0)}{(g(0))^2}=\frac{5\times 2-4 \times 1}{(2)^2}=\frac{6}{4}=\frac{3}{2}.
\end{equation*}
%
