\typeout{Section 2.4 Derivatives of Other Trigonometric Functions}
\typeout{************************************************}
\section[{Derivatives of Other Trigonometric Functions}]{Derivatives of Other Trigonometric Functions}\label{sec-2-4-other-trig}
\begin{objectives}{Motivating Questions}\label{objectives-12}
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1846}{}%
What are the derivatives of the tangent, cotangent, secant, and cosecant functions?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1847}{}%
How do the derivatives of \(\tan(x)\), \(\cot(x)\), \(\sec(x)\), and \(\csc(x)\) combine with other derivative rules we have developed to expand the library of functions we can quickly differentiate?%
\end{itemize}
\end{objectives}
\index{trigonometry}\hypertarget{p-1848}{}%
One of the powerful themes in trigonometry comes from a very simple idea: locating a point on the unit circle.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.47\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_4_UnitCircle.pdf}
\caption{The unit circle and the definition of the sine and cosine functions.\label{F-2-4-UnitCircle}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-1849}{}%
Because each angle \(\theta\) in standard position corresponds to one and only one point \((x,y)\) on the unit circle, the \(x\)- and \(y\)-coordinates of this point are each functions of \(\theta\). In fact, this is the very definition of \(\cos(\theta)\) and \(\sin(\theta)\) i.e. \index{trigonometry!sine} \index{trigonometry!cosine} \(\cos(\theta)\) is the \(x\)-coordinate of the point on the unit circle corresponding to the angle \(\theta\), and \(\sin(\theta)\) is the \(y\)-coordinate. From this simple definition, all of trigonometry is founded. For instance, the Pythagorean Identity, \index{trigonometry!pythagorean identity}%
\begin{equation*}
\sin^2(\theta) + \cos^2(\theta) = 1\text{,}
\end{equation*}
is a restatement of the Pythagorean Theorem, applied to the right triangle shown above in \hyperref[F-2-4-UnitCircle]{Figure~\ref{F-2-4-UnitCircle}}.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1850}{}%
There are four other trigonometric functions, each defined in terms of the sine and/or cosine functions. \leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}The tangent function \index{trigonometry!tangent} is defined by \(\tan(\theta) = \frac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)}\);%
\item{}the cotangent function \index{trigonometry!cotangent} is its reciprocal: \(\cot(\theta) = \frac{\cos(\theta)}{\sin(\theta)}\).%
\item{}The secant function \index{trigonometry!secant} is the reciprocal of the cosine function, \(\sec(\theta) = \frac{1}{\cos(\theta)}\);%
\item{}and the cosecant function \index{trigonometry!cosecant} is the reciprocal of the sine function, \(\csc(\theta) = \frac{1}{\sin(\theta)}\).%
\end{itemize}
 These six trigonometric functions together offer us a wide range of flexibility in problems involving right triangles.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1851}{}%
Because we know the derivatives of the sine and cosine functions, we can now develop shortcut differentiation rules for the tangent, cotangent, secant, and cosecant functions. In \hyperref[PA-2-4]{Example~\ref{PA-2-4}} we will work through the steps to find the derivative of \(\tan(x)\).%
\begin{example}[]\label{PA-2-4}
\hypertarget{p-1852}{}%
Consider the function \(f(x) = \tan(x)\), and remember that \(\tan(x) = \frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1226}{}\hypertarget{p-1853}{}%
What is the domain of \(f\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1227}{}\hypertarget{p-1854}{}%
Use the quotient rule to show that one expression for \(f'(x)\) is%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \frac{\cos(x)\cos(x) + \sin(x)\sin(x)}{\cos^2(x)}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1228}{}\hypertarget{p-1855}{}%
What is the Pythagorean Identity? How can this identity be used to find a simpler form for \(f'(x)\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1229}{}\hypertarget{p-1856}{}%
Recall that \(\sec(x) = \frac{1}{\cos(x)}\). How can we express \(f'(x)\) in terms of the secant function?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1230}{}\hypertarget{p-1857}{}%
For what values of \(x\) is \(f'(x)\) defined? How does this set compare to the domain of \(f\)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-47}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1858}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1231}{}\hypertarget{p-1859}{}%
When is the denominator of \(f\) equal to \(0\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1232}{}\hypertarget{p-1860}{}%
Remember that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}\left[\frac{p(x)}{q(x)}\right]=\frac{p'(x)q(x)-p(x)q'(x)}{[q(x)]^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1233}{}\hypertarget{p-1861}{}%
The Pythagorean Identity comes from the right triangle shown earlier in \hyperref[F-2-4-UnitCircle]{Figure~\ref{F-2-4-UnitCircle}}.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1234}{}\hypertarget{p-1862}{}%
Remember that \(\cos^2(x)=[\cos(x)]^2\), and use the simpler form for \(f'(x)\) that you found in part (c).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1235}{}\hypertarget{p-1863}{}%
When is the denominator of \(f'\) equal to \(0\)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-80}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1864}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1236}{}\hypertarget{p-1865}{}%
\(x\neq \frac{n\pi}{2}\) for any odd integer \(n\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1237}{}\hypertarget{p-1866}{}%
\(f'(x)=\frac{(\cos(x))\cos(x)-\sin(x)(-\sin(x))}{(\cos(x))^2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1238}{}\hypertarget{p-1867}{}%
\(\sin^2(\theta)+\cos^2(\theta)=1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1239}{}\hypertarget{p-1868}{}%
\(f'(x)=\sec^2(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1240}{}\hypertarget{p-1869}{}%
\(x\neq \frac{n\pi}{2}\) for any odd integer \(n\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-106}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1870}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1241}{}\hypertarget{p-1871}{}%
Since \(\sin(x)\) is defined for every real value of \(x\) and \(\cos(x)\) is only equal to zero at odd integer multiples of \(\frac{\pi}2\), it follows that the quotient \(\tan(x)=\frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}\) is defined whenever \(x\neq \ldots,-\frac{3\pi}2,-\frac{\pi}2,\frac{\pi}2,\frac{3\pi}2,\ldots\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1242}{}\hypertarget{p-1872}{}%
Since \(f(x)=\tan(x)\) is the quotient of \(\sin(x)\) and \(\cos(x)\), then to differentiate \(f\) using the quotient rule we first need \(\frac{d}{dx}[\sin(x)]=\cos(x)\) and \(\frac{d}{dx}[\cos(x)]=-\sin(x)\). Then%
\begin{align*}
f'(x)=\mathstrut \amp \frac{d}{dx}\left[\frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}\right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac{\frac{d}{dx}[\sin(x)]\cos(x)-\sin(x)\frac{d}{dx}[\cos(x)]}{(\cos(x))^2}\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac{(\cos(x))\cos(x)-\sin(x)(-\sin(x))}{(\cos(x))^2}\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac{\cos(x)\cos(x)+\sin(x)\sin(x)}{\cos^2(x)}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1243}{}\hypertarget{p-1873}{}%
The Pythagorean Identity states that \(\sin^2(\theta)+\cos^2(\theta)=1\) for any real number \(\theta\). We can rewrite the form of \(f'\) found in part (b) as%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x)=\frac{\cos^2(x)+\sin^2(x)}{\cos^2(x)}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and use the Pythagorean Identity to reduce the numerator to \(1\). Thus a simpler expression for \(f'(x)\) is%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x)=\frac{1}{\cos^2(x)}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1244}{}\hypertarget{p-1874}{}%
Since \(\sec(x)=\frac{1}{\cos(x)}\), then%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x)=\frac{1}{\cos^2(x)}=\sec^2(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1245}{}\hypertarget{p-1875}{}%
Just like the original function \(f\), this derivative function \(f'\) can be expressed as a quotient, so its domain will be the values of \(x\) at which the numerator is defined and the denominator is nonzero. Since \(f'(x)=\frac{1}{\cos^2(x)}\), the numerator is always defined and the denominator is zero exactly when \(\cos(x)=0\), which occurs at odd integer multiples of \(\frac{\pi}2\). Thus the domain of \(f'\) consists of the values \(x\neq\frac{n\pi}{2}\), where \(n\) is an odd integer (positive or negative). This is the same as the domain of \(f\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.4.1 Derivatives of the Cotangent, Secant, and Cosecant functions}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Derivatives of the Cotangent, Secant, and Cosecant functions}]{Derivatives of the Cotangent, Secant, and Cosecant functions}\label{subsection-60}
\hypertarget{p-1876}{}%
In \hyperref[PA-2-4]{Example~\ref{PA-2-4}} we found that the derivative of the tangent function can be expressed in several ways, with its simplest form written in terms of the secant function. Next, we develop the derivative of the cotangent function.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1877}{}%
Let \(g(x) = \cot(x)\). To find \(g'(x)\), we observe that \(g(x) = \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)}\) and apply the quotient rule. Hence%
\begin{align*}
g'(x) =\mathstrut \amp  \frac{(-\sin(x))\sin(x) - \cos(x) \cos(x)}{\sin^2(x)}\\
=\mathstrut \amp  -\frac{\sin^2(x) + \cos^2(x)}{\sin^2(x)}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1878}{}%
Applying the Pythagorean Identity, we see that \(g'(x) = -\frac{1}{\sin^2(x)}\). Now recall that \(\csc(x) = \frac{1}{\sin(x)}\); it follows that we can express \(g'\) by the rule%
\begin{equation*}
g'(x) = -\csc^2(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1879}{}%
Note that neither \(g\) nor \(g'\) is defined when \(\sin(x) = 0\), which occurs at every integer multiple of \(\pi\). Hence we have the following rule.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1880}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Derivative of the Cotangent Function]\label{cotangent-rule}
\hypertarget{p-1881}{}%
\index{derivative!cotangent} For all real numbers \(x\) such that \(x \ne k\pi\), where \(k = 0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\),%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} [\cot(x)] = -\csc^2(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1882}{}%
Notice that the derivative of the cotangent function is very similar to the derivative of the tangent function we discovered in \hyperref[PA-2-4]{Example~\ref{PA-2-4}}.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1883}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Derivative of the Tangent Function]\label{tangent-rule}
\hypertarget{p-1884}{}%
\index{derivative!tangent} For all real numbers \(x\) such that \(x \ne \frac{(2k+1)\pi}{2}\), where \(k =0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\),%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} [\tan(x)] = \sec^2(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1885}{}%
In the next two examples, we develop the rules for differentiating the secant and cosecant functions.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-4-1}
\hypertarget{p-1886}{}%
Let \(h(x) = \sec(x)\) and recall that \(\sec(x) = \frac{1}{\cos(x)}\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1246}{}\hypertarget{p-1887}{}%
What is the domain of \(h\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1247}{}\hypertarget{p-1888}{}%
Use the quotient rule to develop a formula for \(h'(x)\) that is expressed completely in terms of \(\sin(x)\) and \(\cos(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1248}{}\hypertarget{p-1889}{}%
How can you use other relationships among trigonometric functions to write \(h'(x)\) only in terms of \(\tan(x)\) and \(\sec(x)\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1249}{}\hypertarget{p-1890}{}%
What is the domain of \(h'\)? How does this compare to the domain of \(h\)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-48}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1891}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1250}{}\hypertarget{p-1892}{}%
For what values of \(x\) is \(\cos(x) = 0\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1251}{}\hypertarget{p-1893}{}%
Don't forget that \(\frac{d}{dx}[1] = 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1252}{}\hypertarget{p-1894}{}%
Consider rewriting \(\frac{\sin(x)}{\cos^2(x)}\) as \(\frac{1}{\cos(x)} \cdot \frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1253}{}\hypertarget{p-1895}{}%
Observe that \(\cos(x)\) is still present in the denominator of \(h'(x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-81}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1896}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1254}{}\hypertarget{p-1897}{}%
All real numbers \(x\) such that \(x \ne \frac{(2k+1)\pi}{2}\), where \(k =0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1255}{}\hypertarget{p-1898}{}%
\(h'(x) = \frac{\sin(x)}{\cos^2(x)}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1256}{}\hypertarget{p-1899}{}%
\(h'(x) = \sec(x) \tan(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1257}{}\hypertarget{p-1900}{}%
\(h\) and \(h'\) have the same domain: all real numbers \(x\) such that \(x \ne \frac{(2k+1)\pi}{2}\), where \(k =0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-107}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1901}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1258}{}\hypertarget{p-1902}{}%
\(h(x) = \sec(x)\) is defined for all \(x\) for which \(\cos(x) \ne 0\). Hence the domain of \(h\) is all real numbers \(x\) such that \(x \ne \frac{(2k+1)\pi}{2}\), where \(k =0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1259}{}\hypertarget{p-1903}{}%
By the quotient rule,%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = \frac{0 - 1  (-\sin(x))}{\cos^2(x)} = \frac{\sin(x)}{\cos^2(x)}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1260}{}\hypertarget{p-1904}{}%
Observe that \(h'(x) = \frac{\sin(x)}{\cos^2(x)} = \frac{1}{\cos(x)} \cdot \frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}\), so%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = \sec(x) \tan(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1261}{}\hypertarget{p-1905}{}%
The derivative \(h'(x)\) is, like \(h(x)\), defined for all values of \(x\) for which \(\cos(x) \ne 0\). Therefore, \(h\) and \(h'\) have the same domain: all real numbers \(x\) such that \(x \ne \frac{(2k+1)\pi}{2}\), where \(k = 0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-4-2}
\hypertarget{p-1906}{}%
Let \(p(x) = \csc(x)\) and recall that \(\csc(x) = \frac{1}{\sin(x)}\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1262}{}\hypertarget{p-1907}{}%
What is the domain of \(p\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1263}{}\hypertarget{p-1908}{}%
Use the quotient rule to develop a formula for \(p'(x)\) that is expressed completely in terms of \(\sin(x)\) and \(\cos(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1264}{}\hypertarget{p-1909}{}%
How can you use other relationships among trigonometric functions to write \(p'(x)\) only in terms of \(\cot(x)\) and \(\csc(x)\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1265}{}\hypertarget{p-1910}{}%
What is the domain of \(p'\)? How does this compare to the domain of \(p\)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-49}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1911}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1266}{}\hypertarget{p-1912}{}%
For what values of \(x\) is \(\sin(x) = 0\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1267}{}\hypertarget{p-1913}{}%
Don't forget that \(\frac{d}{dx}[1] = 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1268}{}\hypertarget{p-1914}{}%
Consider rewriting \(\frac{\cos(x)}{\sin^2(x)}\) as \(\frac{1}{\sin(x)} \cdot \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1269}{}\hypertarget{p-1915}{}%
Observe that \(\sin(x)\) is still present in the denominator of \(h'(x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-82}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1916}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1270}{}\hypertarget{p-1917}{}%
All real numbers \(x\) such that \(x \neq k\pi\), where \(k = 0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1271}{}\hypertarget{p-1918}{}%
\(h'(x) = -\frac{\cos(x)}{\sin^2(x)}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1272}{}\hypertarget{p-1919}{}%
\(h'(x) = -\csc(x) \cot(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1273}{}\hypertarget{p-1920}{}%
\(p\) and \(p'\) have the same domain: all real numbers \(x\) such that \(x \ne k\pi\), where \(k = 0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-108}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1921}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1274}{}\hypertarget{p-1922}{}%
\(p(x) = \csc(x)\) is defined for all \(x\) for which \(\sin(x) \ne 0\). Hence the domain of \(h\) is all real numbers \(x\) such that \(x\neq k\pi\), where \(k = 0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1275}{}\hypertarget{p-1923}{}%
By the quotient rule,%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = \frac{0 - 1 \cdot (\cos(x))}{\sin^2(x)} = -\frac{\cos(x)}{\sin^2(x)}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1276}{}\hypertarget{p-1924}{}%
Observe that \(h'(x) = -\frac{\cos(x)}{\sin^2(x)} = -\frac{1}{\sin(x)} \cdot \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)}\), so%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = -\csc(x) \cot(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1277}{}\hypertarget{p-1925}{}%
The derivative \(p'(x)\) is, like \(p(x)\), defined for all values of \(x\) for which \(\sin(x) \ne 0\). Therefore, \(p\) and \(p'\) have the same domain: all real numbers \(x\) such that \(x \ne k\pi\), where \(k = 0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-1926}{}%
Using the quotient rule we have determined the derivatives of the tangent, cotangent, secant, and cosecant functions, expanding our overall library of functions we can differentiate. Observe that just as the derivative of any polynomial function is a polynomial, and the derivative of any exponential function is another exponential function, so it is that the derivative of any basic trigonometric function is another function that consists of basic trigonometric functions. This makes sense because all trigonometric functions are periodic, and hence their derivatives will be periodic, too.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1927}{}%
As always, the derivative retains all of its fundamental meaning, both as an instantaneous rate of change of the function under consideration and as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of that same function.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-4-3}
\hypertarget{p-1928}{}%
Answer each of the following questions. Where a derivative is requested, be sure to label the derivative function with its name using proper notation. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1278}{}\hypertarget{p-1929}{}%
Let \(f(x) = 5 \sec(x) - 2\csc(x)\). Find the slope of the tangent line to \(f\) at the point where \(x =\frac{\pi}{3}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1279}{}\hypertarget{p-1930}{}%
Let \(p(z) = z^2\sec(z) - z\cot(z)\). Find the instantaneous rate of change of \(p\) at the point where \(z = \frac{\pi}{4}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1280}{}\hypertarget{p-1931}{}%
Let \(h(t) = \displaystyle \frac{\tan (t)}{t^2+1} - 2e^t \cos(t)\). Find \(h'(t)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1281}{}\hypertarget{p-1932}{}%
Let \(g(r) = \displaystyle \frac{r \sec(r) }{5^r}\). Find \(g'(r)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1282}{}\hypertarget{p-1933}{}%
When a mass hangs from a spring and is set in motion, the object's position oscillates in such a way that the size of the oscillations decreases. This is usually called a \emph{damped oscillation}. Suppose that for a particular object, its displacement from equilibrium (where the object sits at rest) is modeled by the function%
\begin{equation*}
s(t) = \frac{15 \sin(t)}{e^t}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Assume that \(s\) is measured in inches and \(t\) in seconds. Sketch a graph of this function for \(t \ge 0\) to see how it represents the situation described. Then compute \(\frac{ds}{dt}\), state the units of this function, and explain what it tells you about the object's motion. Finally, compute and interpret \(s'(2)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-50}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1934}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1283}{}\hypertarget{p-1935}{}%
What rule(s) can help you determine \(f'(x)\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1284}{}\hypertarget{p-1936}{}%
Note that \(p\) is a sum of two functions. What rule is needed to differentiate each term in the sum?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1285}{}\hypertarget{p-1937}{}%
Observe that \(h\) is a sum of two functions; the first term in the sum is a quotient, while the second is a product.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1286}{}\hypertarget{p-1938}{}%
What is the overall structure of \(g\)? What is the algebraic structure of the numerator of \(g\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1287}{}\hypertarget{p-1939}{}%
Keep in mind that the derivative of position tells us the instantaneous velocity.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-83}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1940}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1288}{}\hypertarget{p-1941}{}%
\(10\sqrt{3} + \frac{4}{3}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1289}{}\hypertarget{p-1942}{}%
\(p'(\frac{\pi}{4}) = \frac{\pi}{2}\sqrt{2} + \frac{\pi^2}{16} \sqrt{2} - 1 + \frac{\pi}{2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1290}{}\hypertarget{p-1943}{}%
\(h'(t) = \frac{(t^2+1) \sec^2(t) - 2t \tan(t)}{(t^2 + 1)^2} - 2 e^t\cos(t) + 2e^t \sin(t)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1291}{}\hypertarget{p-1944}{}%
\(g'(r) = \frac{\sec(r)+r\sec(r)\tan(r) - r \sec(r)\ln(5)}{5^r}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1292}{}\hypertarget{p-1945}{}%
\(s'(2) = \frac{15\cos(2) - 15\sin(2)}{e^2} \approx -2.69\) inches per second.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-109}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1946}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1293}{}\hypertarget{p-1947}{}%
Using the sum and constant multiple rules along with the formulas for the derivatives of \(\sec(x)\) and \(\csc(x)\), we find that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = 5 \sec(x)\tan(x) + 2\csc(x)\cot(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Therefore, the slope of the tangent line to \(f\) at the point where \(x =\frac{\pi}{3}\) is given by%
\begin{align*}
f'\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) =\mathstrut \amp  5 \sec\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)\tan\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) + 2\csc\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)\cot\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)\\
=\mathstrut \amp 5 \cdot 2 \cdot \sqrt{3} + 2 \cdot \frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} = 10\sqrt{3} + \frac{4}{3}\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1294}{}\hypertarget{p-1948}{}%
By the sum rule and two applications of the product rule, we have%
\begin{align*}
p'(z) =\mathstrut \amp  \frac{d}{dz}[z^2\sec(z)] - \frac{d}{dz}[z\cot(z)]\\
=\mathstrut \amp  [2z\sec(z)+z^2 \sec(z) \tan(z)] - [\cot(z)+z(-\csc^2(z))]\\
=\mathstrut \amp  2z\sec(z) + z^2 \sec(z) \tan(z) - \cot(z) + z\csc^2(z)\text{.}
\end{align*}
Thus, the instantaneous rate of change of \(p\) at the point where \(z = \frac{\pi}{4}\) is%
\begin{align*}
p'\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) =\mathstrut \amp  2\cdot\frac{\pi}{4}\sec\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)^2 \sec\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \tan\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) - \cot\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) + \frac{\pi}{4}\csc^2\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\\
=\mathstrut \amp  2\cdot\frac{\pi}{4}\cdot\sqrt{2} + \frac{\pi^2}{16} \cdot\sqrt{2} - 1 + \frac{\pi}{4}\cdot2\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \frac{\pi}{2}\sqrt{2} + \frac{\pi^2}{16} \sqrt{2} - 1 + \frac{\pi}{2}\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1295}{}\hypertarget{p-1949}{}%
Using the sum and constant multiple rules, followed by the quotient rule on the first term and the product rule on the second, we find that%
\begin{align*}
h'(t) =\mathstrut \amp  \frac{d}{dt}\left[ \frac{\tan (t)}{t^2+1} \right] - 2\frac{d}{dt}\left[e^t \cos(t)\right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \frac{\sec^2(t) (t^2+1) - \tan(t) (2t)}{(t^2 + 1)^2} - 2(e^t\cos(t)+e^t(-\sin(t)))\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \frac{(t^2+1) \sec^2(t) - 2t \tan(t)}{(t^2 + 1)^2} - 2 e^t\cos(t) + 2e^t \sin(t)\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1296}{}\hypertarget{p-1950}{}%
Note that \(g\) is fundamentally a quotient, so we need to use the quotient rule. But the numerator of \(g\) is a product, so the product rule will be required to compute the derivative of the top function. Executing the quotient rule and proceeding, we find that%
\begin{align*}
g'(r) =\mathstrut \amp  \frac{\frac{d}{dr}[r \sec(r)]5^r - r\sec(r)\frac{d}{dr}\left[ 5^r\right] }{(5^r)^2}\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \frac{[\sec(r)+r \sec(r) \tan(r)]5^r - r\sec(r) \cdot 5^r \ln(5) }{(5^r)^2}\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \frac{\sec(r) + r \sec(r) \tan(r) - r \sec(r)\ln(5)}{5^r}\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1297}{}\hypertarget{p-1951}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_4_spring-mass.pdf}
\caption{The graph of \(y=s(t)\), where \(s(t)=\frac{15\sin(t)}{e^t}\) models the motion of a mass on a spring.\label{figure-88}}
\end{figure}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1952}{}%
By the quotient rule,%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{ds}{dt} = \frac{ 15 \cos(t)\cdot e^t - 15\sin(t) \cdot e^t}{(e^t)^2} = \frac{15\cos(t) - 15\sin(t)}{e^t}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
The function \(\frac{ds}{dt} = s'(t)\) measures the instantaneous vertical velocity, in inches per second, of the mass that is attached to the spring. In particular, \(s'(2) = \frac{15\cos(2) - 15\sin(2)}{e^2} \approx -2.69\) inches per second. This tells us that when precisely \(2\) seconds have passed, the mass is moving downward at an instantaneous rate of 2.69 inches per second.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.4.2 Summary}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Summary}]{Summary}\label{subsection-61}
\hypertarget{p-1953}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1954}{}%
\index{derivative!secant} \index{derivative!cosecant} The derivatives of the other four trigonometric functions are%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}[\tan(x)] = \sec^2(x), \ \ \frac{d}{dx}[\cot(x)] = -\csc^2(x)\text{,}
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}[\sec(x)] = \sec(x)\tan(x), \ \text{and}  \ \frac{d}{dx}[\csc(x)] = -\csc(x)\cot(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Each derivative exists and is defined on the same domain as the original function. For example, both the tangent function and its derivative are defined for all real numbers \(x\) such that \(x \ne \frac{(2k+1)\pi}{2}\), where \(k =0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\).%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1955}{}%
The four rules for the derivatives of the tangent, cotangent, secant, and cosecant can be used along with the rules for power functions, exponential functions, and the sine and cosine, as well as the sum, constant multiple, product, and quotient rules, to quickly differentiate a wide range of different functions.%
\end{itemize}
%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Exercises 2.4.3 Exercises}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Exercises}]{Exercises}\label{exercises-15}
\begin{exerciselist}
\item[1.]\hypertarget{ez-2-4-WW1}{}(A sum and product involving \(\tan x\))\space\space{}\item[2.]\hypertarget{ez-2-4-WW3}{}(A quotient involving \(\tan t\))\space\space{}\item[3.]\hypertarget{ez-2-4-WW4}{}(A quotient of trigonometric functions)\space\space{}\item[4.]\hypertarget{ez-2-4-WW5}{}(A quotient that involves a product)\space\space{}\item[5.]\hypertarget{ez-2-4-WW6}{}(Finding a tangent line equation)\space\space{}\item[6.]\hypertarget{exercise-128}{}(Oscillatory Motion)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-1956}{}%
An object moving vertically has its height at time \(t\) (measured in feet, with time in seconds) given by the function \(h(t) = 3 + \frac{2\cos(t)}{1.2^t}\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1300}{}\hypertarget{p-1957}{}%
What is the object's instantaneous velocity when \(t =2\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1301}{}\hypertarget{p-1958}{}%
What is the object's acceleration at the instant \(t = 2\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1302}{}\hypertarget{p-1959}{}%
Describe in everyday language the behavior of the object at the instant \(t = 2\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-84}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1960}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1303}{}\hypertarget{p-1961}{}%
\(h'(2) = \frac{-2\sin(2) - 2\cos(2) \ln(1.2)}{1.2^2} \approx -1.1575\) feet per second.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1304}{}\hypertarget{p-1962}{}%
\(h''(2) = \frac{\cos(2)(-2 + 2ln^2(1.2)) + 4\ln(1.2)\sin(2))}{1.2^2} \approx 1.0193\) feet per second per second.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1305}{}\hypertarget{p-1963}{}%
The object is falling and slowing down.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-110}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1964}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1306}{}\hypertarget{p-1965}{}%
The object's instantaneous velocity at \(t=2\) is given by \(h'(2)\). Since \(h(t) = 3 + \frac{2\cos(t)}{1.2^t}\), by the quotient rule we can determine that%
\begin{align*}
h'(t) &= \frac{1.2^t \cdot (-2\sin(t)) - 2\cos(t) \cdot 1.2^t \ln(1.2)}{(1.2^t)^2}\\
&= \frac{1.2^t (-2\sin(t) - 2\cos(t) \ln(1.2))}{(1.2^t)^2}\\
&= \frac{-2\sin(t) - 2\cos(t) \ln(1.2)}{1.2^t}\text{.}
\end{align*}
Thus, \(h'(2) = \frac{-2\sin(2) - 2\cos(2) \ln(1.2)}{1.2^2} \approx -1.1575\) feet per second is the instanateous (vertical) velocity of the object at \(t=2\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1307}{}\hypertarget{p-1966}{}%
To find the object's acceleration at \(t=2\), we compute \(h''(2)\). First, by the quotient rule,%
\begin{align*}
h''(t) &= \frac{1.2^t(-2\cos(t) + 2\sin(t) \ln(1.2)) - (-2\sin(t) - 2\cos(t) \ln(1.2))1.2^t \ln(1.2)}{(1.2^t)^2}\\
&= \frac{-2\cos(t) + 2\sin(t) \ln(1.2)) + 2\sin(t)\ln(1.2) + 2\cos(t) \ln^2(1.2)}{1.2^t}\\
&= \frac{\cos(t)(-2 + 2\ln^2(1.2)) + 4\ln(1.2)\sin(t))}{1.2^t}\text{.}
\end{align*}
Therefore, the acceleration at \(t = 2\) is \(h''(2) = \frac{\cos(2)(-2 + 2\ln^2(1.2)) + 4\ln(1.2)\sin(2))}{1.2^2} \approx 1.0193\) feet per second per second.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1308}{}\hypertarget{p-1967}{}%
At \(t=2\), the object is falling and slowing down. We know the object is falling because its velocity is negative, and slowing down because its negative velocity is increasing (due to \(h''(2)\) being positive) and thus getting less negative.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[7.]\hypertarget{exercise-129}{}(A product of trigonometric functions)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-1968}{}%
Let \(f(x) = \sin(x) \cot(x)\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1309}{}\hypertarget{p-1969}{}%
Use the product rule to find \(f'(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1310}{}\hypertarget{p-1970}{}%
True or false: for all real numbers \(x\), \(f(x) = \cos(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1311}{}\hypertarget{p-1971}{}%
Explain why the function that you found in (a) is almost the opposite of the sine function, but not quite. Hint: convert all of the trigonometric functions in (a) to sines and cosines, and work to simplify. Think carefully about the domain of \(f\) and the domain of \(f'\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-85}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1972}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1312}{}\hypertarget{p-1973}{}%
\(f'(x) = \sin(x) \cdot (-\csc^2(x)) + \cot(x) \cdot \cos(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1313}{}\hypertarget{p-1974}{}%
False.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1314}{}\hypertarget{p-1975}{}%
\(f'(x) = \frac{-\sin^2(x)}{\sin(x)} = -\sin(x)\) for \(x \ne \frac{\pi}{2} + k\pi\) for some integer value of \(k\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-111}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1976}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1315}{}\hypertarget{p-1977}{}%
Since \(f(x) = \sin(x) \cot(x)\), by the product rule we know that \(f'(x) = \sin(x) \cdot (-\csc^2(x)) + \cot(x) \cdot \cos(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1316}{}\hypertarget{p-1978}{}%
False. Since \(\cot(x) = \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)}\), we can write \(f(x) = \sin(x) \cdot \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)}\). From here, it is tempting to ``cancel'' the \(\sin(x)\) term in the numerator and denominator. However, note that because of the \(\sin(x)\) in the denominator, \(f\) is not defined for \(x = \frac{\pi}{2} + k\pi\) for any integer \(k\). In other words, the domain of \(f\) is all real numbers except odd multiples of \(\frac{\pi}{2}\). Thus, we can say that \(f(x) = \cos(x)\) for all real numbers except odd multiples of \(\frac{\pi}{2}\). But it is not the case that \(f(x) = \cos(x)\) for every value of \(x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1317}{}\hypertarget{p-1979}{}%
Taking our result from (a) and converting \(\csc(x)\) and \(\cot(x)\) to expressions involving the sine and cosine functions, we have%
\begin{align*}
f'(x) &= \sin(x) \cdot (-\csc^2(x)) + \cot(x) \cdot \cos(x)\\
&= \sin(x) \cdot \left(-\frac{1}{\sin^2(x)}\right) + \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)} \cdot \cos(x)
\end{align*}
Provided that \(x \ne \frac{\pi}{2} + k\pi\) for some integer value of \(k\), it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = -\frac{1}{\sin(x)} + \frac{\cos^2(x)}{\sin(x)} = \frac{\cos^2(x)-1}{\sin(x)}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
By the Pythagorean Identity, recall that \(\cos^2(x) + \sin^2(x) = 1\), and thus \(\cos^2(x)-1 = -\sin^2(x)\). Hence, for \(x \ne \frac{\pi}{2} + k\pi\) for some integer value of \(k\), we have \(f'(x) = \frac{-\sin^2(x)}{\sin(x)} = -\sin(x)\). Again, this equality holds only for \(x \ne \frac{\pi}{2} + k\pi\) for some integer value of \(k\) because those values of \(x\) are not in the domain of the original function \(f\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[8.]\hypertarget{exercise-130}{}(Combining Differentiation Rules)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-1980}{}%
Let \(p(z)\) be given by the rule%
\begin{equation*}
p(z) = \frac{z\tan(z)}{z^2\sec(z) + 1} + 3 e^z + 1\text{.}
\end{equation*}
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1318}{}\hypertarget{p-1981}{}%
Determine \(p'(z)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1319}{}\hypertarget{p-1982}{}%
Find an equation for the tangent line to \(p\) at the point where \(z = 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1320}{}\hypertarget{p-1983}{}%
At \(z = 0\), is \(p\) increasing, decreasing, or neither? Why?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-86}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1984}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1321}{}\hypertarget{p-1985}{}%
\(p'(z) = \frac{\left(z^2\sec(z) +1 \right)\left(z\sec^2(z)+\tan(z)\right) - z\tan(z) \left(z^2\sec(z)\tan(z)+2z\sec(z)\right)}{\left(z^2\sec(z) + 1\right)^2} +3e^z\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1322}{}\hypertarget{p-1986}{}%
\(y - 4 = 3(x-0)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1323}{}\hypertarget{p-1987}{}%
Increasing.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-112}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1988}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1324}{}\hypertarget{p-1989}{}%
We use the quotient, product, sum, and constant multiple rules to obtain%
\begin{align*}
p'(z) &= \frac{d}{dz}\left(\frac{z\tan(z)}{z^2\sec(z) + 1} + 3 e^z + 1\right)\\
&= \frac{d}{dz}\left(\frac{z\tan(z)}{z^2\sec(z) + 1}\right) + \frac{d}{dz} \left(3 e^z \right) + \frac{d}{dz}(1)\\
&= \frac{\left(z^2\sec(z) +1 \right)\frac{d}{dz}\left(z\tan(z)\right) - z\tan(z) \frac{d}{dz}\left(z^2\sec(z) + 1\right)}{\left(z^2\sec(z) + 1\right)^2} +3e^z\\
&= \frac{\left(z^2\sec(z) +1 \right)\left(z\sec^2(z)+\tan(z)\right) - z\tan(z) \left(z^2\sec(z)\tan(z)+2z\sec(z)\right)}{\left(z^2\sec(z) + 1\right)^2} +3e^z
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1325}{}\hypertarget{p-1990}{}%
We have \(p(0) = 0+3+1 = 4\) and \(p'(0) = 0+3=3\), so an equation for the tangent line to \(p\) at the point where \(z=0\) is \(y - 4 = 3(x-0)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1326}{}\hypertarget{p-1991}{}%
We found that \(p'(0) = 3\) is positive, so \(p\) is increasing at \(t=0\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{exerciselist}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Section 2.5 The Chain Rule}
\typeout{************************************************}
\section[{The Chain Rule}]{The Chain Rule}\label{sec-2-5-chain}
\begin{objectives}{Motivating Questions}\label{objectives-13}
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1992}{}%
What is a composite function and how do we recognize its structure algebraically?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-1993}{}%
Given a composite function \(C(x) = f(g(x))\) that is built from differentiable functions \(f\) and \(g\), how do we compute \(C'(x)\) in terms of \(f\), \(g\), \(f'\), and \(g'\)? What is the statement of the Chain Rule?%
\end{itemize}
\end{objectives}
\hypertarget{p-1994}{}%
In addition to learning how to differentiate a variety of basic functions, we have also been developing our ability to use rules to differentiate certain algebraic combinations of them.%
\begin{example}[]\label{chain-ex-1}
\hypertarget{p-1995}{}%
State the rule(s) used to find the derivative of each of the following combinations of \(f(x) = \sin(x)\) and \(g(x) = x^2\):%
\begin{equation*}
s(x) = 3x^2 - 5\sin(x)\text{,}
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{equation*}
p(x) = x^2 \sin(x), \text{and}
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{equation*}
q(x) = \frac{\sin(x)}{x^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-51}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1996}{}%
Start by rewriting each function as a specific combination of \(f\) and \(g\), and then ascertain what rules are necessary to find derivatives.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-87}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1997}{}%
Finding \(s'\) uses the sum and constant multiple rules, because \(s(x) = 3g(x) - 5f(x)\). Determining \(p'\) requires the product rule, because \(p(x) = g(x) \cdot f(x)\). To calculate \(q'\) we use the quotient rule, because \(q(x) =\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-113}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-1998}{}%
We first observe that \(f'(x)=\cos(x)\) and \(g'(x)=2x\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-1999}{}%
Since \(s(x)=3g(x)-5f(x)\), we will use the sum and constant multiple rules to find \(s'(x)\). Doing so, we find that%
\begin{align*}
s'(x)=\mathstrut \amp 3g'(x)-5f'(x)\\
=\mathstrut \amp 3(2x)-5(\cos(x))\\
=\mathstrut \amp 6x-5\cos(x)\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2000}{}%
Since \(p(x)=g(x)\cdot f(x)\), we will use the product rule to determine \(p'(x)\). Proceeding thus, we find%
\begin{align*}
p'(x)=\mathstrut \amp g'(x)f(x)+g(x)f'(x)\\
=\mathstrut \amp (2x)(\sin(x))+(x^2)(\cos(x))\\
=\mathstrut \amp 2x\sin(x)+x^2\cos(x)\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2001}{}%
Since \(q(x)=\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\), we will use the quotient rule to calculate \(q'(x)\). In doing so, we see that%
\begin{align*}
q'(x)=\mathstrut \amp \frac{f'(x)g(x)-f(x)g'(x)}{[g(x)]^2}\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac{(\cos(x))(x^2)-(\sin(x))(2x)}{(x^2)^2}\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac{x^2\cos(x)-2x\sin(x)}{x^4}\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac{x\cos(x)-2\sin(x)}{x^3}\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-2002}{}%
There is one more natural way to combine basic functions algebraically, and that is by \emph{composing} them. For instance, let's consider the function%
\begin{equation*}
C(x) = \sin(x^2)\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and observe that any input \(x\) passes through a \emph{chain} of functions. In the process that defines the function \(C(x)\), \(x\) is first squared, and then the sine of the result is taken. We can represent this using an arrow diagram \index{function!arrow diagram} as follows:%
\begin{equation*}
x \longrightarrow x^2 \longrightarrow \sin(x^2)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2003}{}%
It turns out we can express \(C\) in terms of the elementary functions \(f\) and \(g\) that were used above in \hyperref[chain-ex-1]{Example~\ref{chain-ex-1}}. Observe that \(x\) is the input for the function \(g\), and the result is then used as the input for \(f\). We write%
\begin{equation*}
C(x) = f(g(x)) = \sin(x^2)
\end{equation*}
and say that \(C\) is the \emph{composition} \index{composition} \index{function!composite function} of \(f\) and \(g\). We will refer to \(g\), the function that is first applied to \(x\), as the \emph{inner} function, while \(f\), the function that is applied to the result, as the \emph{outer} function.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2004}{}%
Given a composite function \(C(x) = f(g(x))\) that is built from differentiable functions \(f\) and \(g\), how do we compute \(C'(x)\) in terms of \(f\), \(g\), \(f'\), and \(g'\)? In the same way that the rate of change of a product of two functions, \(p(x) = f(x) \cdot g(x)\), depends on the behavior of both \(f\) and \(g\), it makes sense intuitively that the rate of change of a composite function \(C(x) = f(g(x))\) will also depend on some combination of \(f\) and \(g\) and their derivatives. The rule that describes how to compute \(C'\) in terms of \(f\) and \(g\) and their derivatives is called the \terminology{chain rule}.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2005}{}%
But before we can learn what the chain rule says and why it works, we first need to be comfortable decomposing composite functions so that we can correctly identify the inner and outer functions, as we did in the example above with \(C(x) = \sin(x^2)\).%
\begin{example}[]\label{PA-2-5}
\hypertarget{p-2006}{}%
For each function given below, identify its fundamental algebraic structure. In particular, is the given function a sum, product, quotient, or composition of basic functions? If the function is a composition of basic functions, state a formula for the inner function \(g\) and the outer function \(f\) so that the overall composite function can be written in the form \(f(g(x))\). If the function is a sum, product, or quotient of basic functions, use the appropriate rule to determine its derivative. \leavevmode%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1329}{}\hypertarget{p-2007}{}%
\(h(x) = \tan(2^x)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1330}{}\hypertarget{p-2008}{}%
\(p(x) = 2^x \tan(x)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1331}{}\hypertarget{p-2009}{}%
\(r(x) = (\tan(x))^2\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1332}{}\hypertarget{p-2010}{}%
\(m(x) = e^{\tan(x)}\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1333}{}\hypertarget{p-2011}{}%
\(w(x) = \sqrt{x} + \tan(x)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1334}{}\hypertarget{p-2012}{}%
\(z(x) = \sqrt{\tan(x)}\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-52}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2013}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1335}{}\hypertarget{p-2014}{}%
What is the input of tangent here?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1336}{}\hypertarget{p-2015}{}%
Try using the product rule.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1337}{}\hypertarget{p-2016}{}%
\((\tan(x))^2=\tan(x)\cdot\tan(x)\), but can also be written as a composition. How?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1338}{}\hypertarget{p-2017}{}%
Should \(e^x\) be the inner function or the outer function?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1339}{}\hypertarget{p-2018}{}%
The ``\(+\)'' indicates this is fundamentally a sum.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1340}{}\hypertarget{p-2019}{}%
What is the input of the square root function here?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-88}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2020}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1341}{}\hypertarget{p-2021}{}%
With \(g(x)=2^x\) and \(f(x)=\tan(x)\) we have \(h(x)=f(g(x))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1342}{}\hypertarget{p-2022}{}%
Use the product rule; \(p'(x)=2^x\ln(2)\tan(x)+2^x\sec^2(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1343}{}\hypertarget{p-2023}{}%
Use the product rule; \(r(x)=2\tan(x)\sec^2(x)\). Or, \(r(x)=f(g(x))\) when \(g(x)=\tan(x)\) and \(f(x)=x^2\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1344}{}\hypertarget{p-2024}{}%
\(m(x)=f(g(x))\) when \(g(x)=\tan(x)\) and \(f(x)=e^x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1345}{}\hypertarget{p-2025}{}%
Use the sum rule; \(w'(x)=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}+\sec^2(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1346}{}\hypertarget{p-2026}{}%
With \(g(x)=\tan(x)\) and \(f(x)=\sqrt{x}\), we have \(z(x)=f(g(x))\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-114}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2027}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1347}{}\hypertarget{p-2028}{}%
\(\tan(2^x)\) is the composition of \(\tan(x)\) and \(2^x\). Specifically, with \(f(x)=\tan(x)\), \(g(x)=2^x\), and \(h(x)=\tan(2^x)\), we can write \(h(x)=f(g(x))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1348}{}\hypertarget{p-2029}{}%
\(2^x\tan(x)\) is the product of \(2^x\) and \(\tan(x)\). Using the product rule to differentiate \(p(x)=2^x\tan(x)\), we end up with%
\begin{align*}
p'(x)=\mathstrut \amp \frac{d}{dx}\left[2^x\tan(x)\right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac{d}{dx}\left[2^x\right]\tan(x)+2^x\frac{d}{dx}\left[\tan(x)\right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp 2^x\ln(2)\tan(x)+2^x\sec^2(x)\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1349}{}\hypertarget{p-2030}{}%
\((\tan(x))^2\) is the composition of \(x^2\) and \(\tan(x)\). In particular, with \(f(x)=x^2\), \(g(x)=\tan(x)\), and \(r(x)=(\tan(x))^2\), we can write \(r(x)=f(g(x))\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2031}{}%
Alternatively, we can recognize \((\tan(x))^2\) as the product of \(\tan(x)\) with itself. Using the product rule to differentiate \(r(x)=(\tan(x))^2\), we find%
\begin{align*}
r'(x)=\mathstrut \amp \frac{d}{dx}\left[\tan(x)\tan(x)\right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac{d}{dx}\left[\tan(x)\right]\tan(x)+\tan(x)\frac{d}{dx}\left[\tan(x)\right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp (\sec^2(x))\tan(x)+\tan(x)(\sec^2(x))\\
=\mathstrut \amp 2\tan(x)\sec^2(x)\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1350}{}\hypertarget{p-2032}{}%
\(e^{\tan(x)}\) is the composition of \(e^x\) and \(\tan(x)\). Specifically, with \(f(x)=e^x\), \(g(x)=\tan(x)\), and \(m(x)=e^{\tan(x)}\), we can write \(m(x)=f(g(x))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1351}{}\hypertarget{p-2033}{}%
\(\sqrt{x}+\tan(x)\) is the sum of \(\sqrt{x}=x^{\frac{1}{2}}\) and \(\tan(x)\). Using the sum rule to find the derivative of \(w(x)=\sqrt{x}+\tan(x)\), we find%
\begin{align*}
w'(x)=\mathstrut \amp \frac{d}{dx}\left[\sqrt{x}+\tan(x)\right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac{d}{dx}\left[x^{\frac{1}{2}}\right]+\frac{d}{dx}\left[\tan(x)\right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac12x^{-\frac{1}{2}}+\sec^2(x)\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}+\sec^2(x)\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1352}{}\hypertarget{p-2034}{}%
\(\sqrt{\tan(x)}\) is the composition of \(\sqrt{x}\) and \(\tan(x)\). In particular, with \(f(x)=\sqrt{x}\), \(g(x)=\tan(x)\), and \(z(x)=\sqrt{\tan(x)}\), we can write \(z(x)=f(g(x))\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.5.1 The Chain Rule}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{The Chain Rule}]{The Chain Rule}\label{subsection-62}
\hypertarget{p-2035}{}%
Often a composite function cannot be written in an alternate algebraic form. For instance, the function \(C(x) = \sin(x^2)\) cannot be expanded or otherwise rewritten, so it presents no alternate approaches to taking the derivative. But some composite functions can be expanded or simplified, and these provide a way to explore how the chain rule works. One example of this was the function \(r(x)=(\tan(x))^2\) in \hyperref[PA-2-5]{Example~\ref{PA-2-5}}; another example is investigated below in \hyperref[ex-2-5-linear]{Example~\ref{ex-2-5-linear}}.%
\begin{example}[]\label{ex-2-5-linear}
\hypertarget{p-2036}{}%
Let \(f(x) = -4x + 7\) and \(g(x) = 3x - 5\). Determine a formula for \(C(x) = f(g(x))\) and compute \(C'(x)\). How is \(C'\) related to \(f\) and \(g\) and their derivatives?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-53}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2037}{}%
\(C\) is also linear.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-89}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2038}{}%
\(C(x)=-12x+27\) and \(C'(x)=-12\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-115}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2039}{}%
By the rules given for \(f\) and \(g\),%
\begin{align*}
C(x) =\mathstrut \amp  f(g(x))\\
=\mathstrut \amp  f(3x-5)\\
=\mathstrut \amp  -4(3x-5) + 7\\
=\mathstrut \amp  -12x + 20 + 7\\
=\mathstrut \amp  -12x + 27\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2040}{}%
Thus, \(C'(x) = -12\). Noting that \(f'(x) = -4\) and \(g'(x) = 3\), we observe that \(C'\) appears to be the product of \(f'\) and \(g'\).%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-2041}{}%
It may seem that \hyperref[ex-2-5-linear]{Example~\ref{ex-2-5-linear}} is too elementary to illustrate how to differentiate a composite function. Linear functions are the simplest of all functions, and composing linear functions yields another linear function. While this example does not illustrate the full complexity of a composition of nonlinear functions, at the same time we remember that any differentiable function is \emph{locally} linear, and thus any function with a derivative behaves like a line when viewed up close. The fact that the derivatives of the linear functions \(f\) and \(g\) are multiplied to find the derivative of their composition turns out to be a key insight.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2042}{}%
We now consider a composition involving a nonlinear function.%
\begin{example}[]\label{ex-2-5-double-angle}
\hypertarget{p-2043}{}%
Let \(C(x) = \sin(2x)\). Use the double angle identity to rewrite \(C\) as a product of basic functions, and use the product rule to find \(C'\). Rewrite \(C'\) in the simplest form possible.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-54}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2044}{}%
The double angle identity says \(\sin(2\theta)=2\sin(\theta)\cos(\theta)\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-90}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2045}{}%
\(C'(x)=2\cos(2x)\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-116}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2046}{}%
Using the double angle identity for the sine function, we write%
\begin{equation*}
C(x) = \sin(2x) = 2\sin(x)\cos(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2047}{}%
Applying the product rule and simplifying, we find%
\begin{equation*}
C'(x) = 2\left((\cos(x))\cos(x) + \sin(x)(-\sin(x))\right) = 2(\cos^2(x) - \sin^2(x))\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2048}{}%
Next, we recall that the double angle identity for the cosine function states%
\begin{equation*}
\cos(2x) = \cos^2(x) - \sin^2(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2049}{}%
Substituting this result into our expression for \(C'(x)\), we now have that%
\begin{equation*}
C'(x) = 2 \cos(2x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-2050}{}%
In \hyperref[ex-2-5-double-angle]{Example~\ref{ex-2-5-double-angle}}, if we let \(g(x) = 2x\) and \(f(x) = \sin(x)\), we observe that \(C(x) = f(g(x))\). Note that \(g'(x) = 2\) and \(f'(x) = \cos(x)\), so we can view the structure of \(C'(x)\) as%
\begin{equation*}
C'(x) = 2\cos(2x) = g'(x) f'(g(x))\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2051}{}%
In this example, as in the example involving linear functions, we see that the derivative of the composite function \(C(x) = f(g(x))\) is found by multiplying the derivatives of \(f\) and \(g\), but with \(f'\) evaluated at \(g(x)\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2052}{}%
Intuitively, it makes sense that these two quantities are involved in the rate of change of a composite function: if we ask how fast \(C\) is changing at a given \(x\) value, it clearly matters how fast \(g\) is changing at \(x\), as well as how fast \(f\) is changing at the value of \(g(x)\). It turns out that this structure holds for all differentiable functions\footnote{It is important to recognize that we have not proved the chain rule, instead we have given a reason you might believe the chain rule to be true.  A key component of mathematics is verifying one's intuition through formal proof.  We will omit the proof of the chain rule, but \textendash{} just like other differentiation rules \textendash{} the chain rule can be proved formally using the limit definition of the derivative.\label{fn-17}} as is stated in the chain rule.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2053}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Chain Rule]\label{chain-rule}
\hypertarget{p-2054}{}%
\index{chain rule} \index{derivative!chain rule} If \(g\) is differentiable at \(x\) and \(f\) is differentiable at \(g(x)\), then the composite function \(C\) defined by \(C(x) = f(g(x))\) is differentiable at \(x\) and%
\begin{equation*}
C'(x) = f'(g(x)) g'(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2055}{}%
As with the product and quotient rules, it is often helpful to think verbally about what the chain rule says: ``If \(C\) is a composite function defined by an outer function \(f\) and an inner function \(g\), then \(C'\) is given by the derivative of the outer function evaluated at the inner function, times the derivative of the inner function.''%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2056}{}%
It is helpful to clearly identify the inner function \(g\) and outer function \(f\), compute their derivatives individually, and then put all of the pieces together by the chain rule.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-105}
\hypertarget{p-2057}{}%
Use the chain rule to determine the derivative of the function%
\begin{equation*}
r(x) = (\tan(x))^2\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-55}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2058}{}%
We saw this function earlier in \hyperref[PA-2-5]{Example~\ref{PA-2-5}}.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-91}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2059}{}%
As we saw in \hyperref[PA-2-5]{Example~\ref{PA-2-5}}, \(r'(x)=2\tan(x)\sec^2(x)\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-117}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2060}{}%
The function \(r\) is composite, with inner function \(g(x) = \tan(x)\) and outer function \(f(x) = x^2\). Organizing the key information involving \(f\), \(g\), and their derivatives, we have%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)
{% begin: group for a single side-by-side
% set panel max height to practical minimum, created in preamble
\setlength{\panelmax}{0pt}
\ifdefined\panelboxAtabular\else\newsavebox{\panelboxAtabular}\fi%
\savebox{\panelboxAtabular}{%
\raisebox{\depth}{\parbox{1\linewidth}{\centering\begin{tabular}{lll}
\(f(x) = x^2\),&&\(g(x) = \tan(x)\),\tabularnewline[0pt]
\(f'(x) = 2x\),&&\(g'(x) = \sec^2(x)\),\tabularnewline[0pt]
\(f'(g(x)) = 2\tan(x)\).&&
\end{tabular}
}}}
\ifdefined\phAtabular\else\newlength{\phAtabular}\fi%
\setlength{\phAtabular}{\ht\panelboxAtabular+\dp\panelboxAtabular}

\setlength{\panelmax}{\maxof{\panelmax}{\phAtabular}}
\leavevmode%

% \tabcolsep change local to group
\setlength{\tabcolsep}{0\linewidth}
% @{} suppress \tabcolsep at extremes, so margins behave as intended
\par\medskip\noindent

% end: side-by-side as tabular
}% end: group for a single side-by-side
\par
\hypertarget{p-2061}{}%
Applying the chain rule, we find that%
\begin{equation*}
r'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x) = 2\tan(x) \sec^2(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-2062}{}%
As a side note, we remark that \(r(x)\) is usually written as \(\tan^2(x)\). This is common notation for powers of trigonometric functions: e.g. \(\cos^4(x)\), \(\sin^5(x)\), and \(\sec^2(x)\) are all composite functions, with the outer function a power function and the inner function a trigonometric one.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-5-1}
\hypertarget{p-2063}{}%
For each function given below, identify an inner function \(g\) and outer function \(f\) to write the function in the form \(f(g(x))\). Determine \(f'(x)\), \(g'(x)\), and \(f'(g(x))\), and then apply the chain rule to determine the derivative of the given function. \leavevmode%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1353}{}\hypertarget{p-2064}{}%
\(h(x) = \cos(x^4)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1354}{}\hypertarget{p-2065}{}%
\(p(x) = \sqrt{ \tan(x) }\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1355}{}\hypertarget{p-2066}{}%
\(s(x) = 2^{\sin(x)}\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1356}{}\hypertarget{p-2067}{}%
\(z(x) = \cot^5(x)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1357}{}\hypertarget{p-2068}{}%
\(m(x) = (\sec(x) + e^x)^9\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-56}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2069}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1358}{}\hypertarget{p-2070}{}%
The outer function is \(f(x) = \cos(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1359}{}\hypertarget{p-2071}{}%
The outer function is \(f(x) = \sqrt{x}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1360}{}\hypertarget{p-2072}{}%
The outer function is \(f(x) = 2^x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1361}{}\hypertarget{p-2073}{}%
The outer function is \(f(x) = x^5\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1362}{}\hypertarget{p-2074}{}%
The outer function is \(f(x) = x^9\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-92}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2075}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1363}{}\hypertarget{p-2076}{}%
\(h'(x) = -4x^3\sin(x^4)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1364}{}\hypertarget{p-2077}{}%
\(h'(x) = \frac{\sec^2(x)}{2\sqrt{\tan(x)}}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1365}{}\hypertarget{p-2078}{}%
\(h'(x) = 2^{\sin(x)}\ln(2)\cos(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1366}{}\hypertarget{p-2079}{}%
\(h'(x) = -5\cot^4(x) \csc^2(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1367}{}\hypertarget{p-2080}{}%
\(h'(x) = 9(\sec(x)+e^x)^8 (\sec(x)\tan(x) + e^x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-118}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2081}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1368}{}\hypertarget{p-2082}{}%
The outer function is \(f(x) = \cos(x)\) while the inner function is \(g(x) = x^4\). We know that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = -\sin(x),
g'(x) = 4x^3, \ \text{and}  \ f'(g(x)) = -\sin(x^4)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Hence by the chain rule,%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x) = -4x^3\sin(x^4)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1369}{}\hypertarget{p-2083}{}%
The outer function is \(f(x) = \sqrt{x}\) and the inner function is \(g(x) = \tan(x)\). We know that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}, g'(x) = \sec^2(x), \ \text{and}  \ f'(g(x)) = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{\tan(x)}}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Thus by the chain rule,%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x) = \frac{\sec^2(x)}{2\sqrt{\tan(x)}}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1370}{}\hypertarget{p-2084}{}%
The outer function is \(f(x) = 2^x\) while the inner function is \(g(x) = \sin(x)\). We know that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = 2^x \ln(2),
g'(x) = \cos(x), \ \text{and}  \ f'(g(x)) = 2^{\sin(x)}\ln(2)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Thus by the chain rule,%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x) = 2^{\sin(x)}\ln(2)\cos(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1371}{}\hypertarget{p-2085}{}%
The outer function is \(f(x) = x^5\) and the inner function is \(g(x) = \cot(x)\). We know that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = 5x^4, g'(x) = -\csc^2(x), \ \text{and}  \ f'(g(x)) = 5\cot^4(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Hence by the chain rule,%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x) = -5\cot^4(x) \csc^2(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1372}{}\hypertarget{p-2086}{}%
The outer function is \(f(x) = x^9\) and the inner function is \(g(x) = \sec(x) + e^x\). We know that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = 9x^8, g'(x) = \sec(x)\tan(x) + e^x, \ \text{and}  \ f'(g(x)) = 9(\sec(x)+e^x)^8\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Hence by the chain rule,%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x) = 9(\sec(x)+e^x)^8 (\sec(x)\tan(x) + e^x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.5.2 Using Multiple Rules Simultaneously}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Using Multiple Rules Simultaneously}]{Using Multiple Rules Simultaneously}\label{subsection-63}
\hypertarget{p-2087}{}%
The chain rule now joins the sum, constant multiple, product, and quotient rules in our collection of techniques for finding the derivative of a function through understanding its algebraic structure and the basic functions that constitute it. It takes practice to get comfortable applying multiple rules to differentiate a single function, but using proper notation and taking a few extra steps will help.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-107}
\hypertarget{p-2088}{}%
Find a formula for the derivative of \(h(t) = 3^{t^2 + 2t}\sec^4(t)\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2089}{}%
We first observe that \(h\) is the product of two functions: \(h(t) = a(t) \cdot b(t)\), where \(a(t) = 3^{t^2 + 2t}\) and \(b(t) = \sec^4(t)\). We will need to use the product rule to differentiate \(h\). And because \(a\) and \(b\) are composite functions, we will also need the chain rule. We therefore begin by computing \(a'(t)\) and \(b'(t)\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2090}{}%
Writing \(a(t) = f(g(t)) = 3^{t^2 + 2t}\) and finding the derivatives of \(f\) and \(g\) with respect to \(t\), we have%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)
{% begin: group for a single side-by-side
% set panel max height to practical minimum, created in preamble
\setlength{\panelmax}{0pt}
\ifdefined\panelboxAtabular\else\newsavebox{\panelboxAtabular}\fi%
\savebox{\panelboxAtabular}{%
\raisebox{\depth}{\parbox{1\linewidth}{\centering\begin{tabular}{lll}
\(f(t) = 3^t\),&&\(g(t) = t^2 + 2t\),\tabularnewline[0pt]
\(f'(t) = 3^t \ln(3)\),&&\(g'(t) = 2t+2\),\tabularnewline[0pt]
\(f'(g(t)) = 3^{t^2 + 2t}\ln(3)\).&&
\end{tabular}
}}}
\ifdefined\phAtabular\else\newlength{\phAtabular}\fi%
\setlength{\phAtabular}{\ht\panelboxAtabular+\dp\panelboxAtabular}
\settototalheight{\phAtabular}{\usebox{\panelboxAtabular}}
\setlength{\panelmax}{\maxof{\panelmax}{\phAtabular}}
\leavevmode%
% begin: side-by-side as tabular
% \tabcolsep change local to group
\setlength{\tabcolsep}{0\linewidth}
% @{} suppress \tabcolsep at extremes, so margins behave as intended
\par\medskip\noindent
\begin{tabular}{@{}*{1}{c}@{}}
\begin{minipage}[c][\panelmax][t]{1\linewidth}\usebox{\panelboxAtabular}\end{minipage}\end{tabular}\\
% end: side-by-side as tabular
}% end: group for a single side-by-side
\par
\hypertarget{p-2091}{}%
Thus by the chain rule, it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
a'(t) = f'(g(t))g'(t) = 3^{t^2 + 2t}\ln(3) (2t+2)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2092}{}%
Turning next to the function \(b\), we write \(b(t) = r(s(t)) = \sec^4(t)\) and find the derivatives of \(r\) and \(s\) with respect to \(t\).%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)

\savebox{\panelboxAtabular}{%
\raisebox{\depth}{\parbox{1\linewidth}{\centering\begin{tabular}{lll}
\(r(t) = t^4\),&&\(s(t) = \sec(t)\),\tabularnewline[0pt]
\(r'(t) = 4t^3\),&&\(s'(t) = \sec(t)\tan(t)\),\tabularnewline[0pt]
\(r'(s(t)) = 4\sec^3(t)\).&&
\end{tabular}
}}}
