}% end: group for a single side-by-side
\par
\hypertarget{p-2093}{}%
By the chain rule,%
\begin{equation*}

\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2094}{}%
Now we are finally ready to compute the derivative of the function \(h\). Recalling that \(h(t) = 3^{t^2 + 2t}\sec^4(t)\), by the product rule we have%
\begin{equation*}
h'(t) =  \frac{d}{dt}\left[3^{t^2 + 2t}\right]\sec^4(t)+3^{t^2 + 2t} \frac{d}{dt}\left[\sec^4(t)\right] \text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2095}{}%
From our work above with \(a\) and \(b\), we know the derivatives of \(3^{t^2 + 2t}\) and \(\sec^4(t)\). Therefore%
\begin{equation*}
h'(t) = 3^{t^2 + 2t}\ln(3) (2t+2)\sec^4(t)  + 3^{t^2 + 2t} 4\sec^4(t) \tan(t) \text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2096}{}%
The above calculation may seem tedious.  However, by breaking the function down into small parts and calculating derivatives of those parts separately, we are able to accurately calculate the derivative of the entire function.%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-5-2}
\hypertarget{p-2097}{}%
Differentiate each of the following functions. State the rule(s) you use, label relevant derivatives appropriately, and be sure to clearly identify your overall answer. \leavevmode%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1373}{}\hypertarget{p-2098}{}%
\(p(r) = 4\sqrt{r^6 + 2e^r}\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1374}{}\hypertarget{p-2099}{}%
\(m(v) = \sin(v^2) \cos(v^3)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1375}{}\hypertarget{p-2100}{}%
\(\displaystyle h(y) = \frac{\cos(10y)}{1+e^{4y}}\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1376}{}\hypertarget{p-2101}{}%
\(s(z) = 2^{z^2 \sec (z)}\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1377}{}\hypertarget{p-2102}{}%
\(c(x) = \sin\left(e^{x^2}\right)\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-57}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2103}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1378}{}\hypertarget{p-2104}{}%
Use the constant multiple rule first, followed by the chain rule.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1379}{}\hypertarget{p-2105}{}%
Observe that \(m\) is fundamentally a product of composite functions.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1380}{}\hypertarget{p-2106}{}%
Note that \(h\) is a quotient of composite functions.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1381}{}\hypertarget{p-2107}{}%
The function \(s\) is a composite function with outer function \(2^z\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1382}{}\hypertarget{p-2108}{}%
It is possible for a function to be a composite function with more than two functions in the chain.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-93}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2109}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1383}{}\hypertarget{p-2110}{}%
\(p'(r) = \frac{4(6r^5 + 2e^r)}{2\sqrt{r^6 + 2e^r}}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1384}{}\hypertarget{p-2111}{}%
\(m'(v) =  2v \cos(v^2)\cos(v^3)-3v^2 \sin(v^2)\sin(v^3)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1385}{}\hypertarget{p-2112}{}%
\(h'(y) = \frac{ [-10\sin(10y)](1+e^{4y}) - \cos(10y) [4e^{4y}]}{(1+e^{4y})^2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1386}{}\hypertarget{p-2113}{}%
\(s'(z) = 2^{z^2\sec(z)} \ln(2) [2z\sec(z)+z^2 \sec(z)\tan(z)]\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1387}{}\hypertarget{p-2114}{}%
\(c'(x) = \cos\left(e^{x^2}\right) \left[e^{x^2}\cdot 2x\right]\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-119}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2115}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1388}{}\hypertarget{p-2116}{}%
By the constant multiple rule, \(p'(r) = 4\frac{d}{dr}\left[\sqrt{r^6 + 2e^r}\right]\). Using the chain rule to complete the remaining derivative, we see that%
\begin{equation*}
p'(r) = 4 \frac{1}{2\sqrt{r^6 + 2e^r}} \frac{d}{dr}[r^6 + 2e^r] = \frac{4(6r^5 + 2e^r)}{2\sqrt{r^6 + 2e^r}}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1389}{}\hypertarget{p-2117}{}%
Observe that by the product rule,%
\begin{equation*}
m'(v) = \frac{d}{dv}[\sin(v^2)]\cos(v^3) +\sin(v^2) \frac{d}{dv}[\cos(v^3)] \text{.}
\end{equation*}
Applying the chain rule to differentiate \(\cos(v^3)\) and \(\sin(v^2)\), we see that%
\begin{align*}
m'(v) =\mathstrut \amp [\cos(v^2) \cdot 2v]\cos(v^3) + \sin(v^2) [-\sin(v^3) \cdot 3v^2]\\
=\mathstrut \amp  2v \cos(v^2)\cos(v^3)-3v^2 \sin(v^2)\sin(v^3)\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1390}{}\hypertarget{p-2118}{}%
By the quotient rule,%
\begin{equation*}
h'(y) = \frac{\frac{d}{dy}[\cos(10y)](1+e^{4y}) - \cos(10y) \frac{d}{dy}[1+e^{4y}]}{(1+e^{4y})^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Applying the chain rule to differentiate \(\cos(10y)\) and \(e^{4y}\), it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
h'(y) = \frac{ [-10\sin(10y)](1+e^{4y}) - \cos(10y) [4e^{4y}]}{(1+e^{4y})^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1391}{}\hypertarget{p-2119}{}%
By the chain rule, we have \(s'(z) = 2^{z^2\sec(z)} \ln(2) \frac{d}{dz}[z^2 \sec(z)]\). Then with the product rule, we find that%
\begin{equation*}
s'(z) = 2^{z^2\sec(z)} \ln(2) [2z\sec(z)+z^2 \sec(z)\tan(z)]\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1392}{}\hypertarget{p-2120}{}%
Here we have the composition of three functions, rather than just two. If we first apply the chain rule to the outermost function (the sine function), we find that%
\begin{equation*}
c'(x) = \cos\left(e^{x^2}\right) \frac{d}{dx}\left[e^{x^2}\right]\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Next we again apply the chain rule to find \(e^{x^2}\), using \(e^x\) as the outer function and \(x^2\) as the inner function. We end up with%
\begin{equation*}
c'(x) = \cos\left(e^{x^2}\right) \left[e^{x^2}\cdot 2x\right]\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-2121}{}%
The chain rule now adds substantially to our ability to compute derivatives. Whether we are finding the equation of the tangent line to a curve, the instantaneous velocity of a moving particle, or the instantaneous rate of change of a certain quantity, the chain rule is indispensable if the function under consideration is a composition.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-5-3}
\hypertarget{p-2122}{}%
Use known derivative rules (including the chain rule) as needed to answer each of the following questions. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1393}{}\hypertarget{p-2123}{}%
Find an equation for the tangent line to the curve \(y= \sqrt{e^x + 3}\) at the point where \(x=0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1394}{}\hypertarget{p-2124}{}%
If \(\displaystyle s(t) = \frac{1}{(t^2+1)^3}\) represents the position function of a particle moving horizontally along an axis at time \(t\) (where \(s\) is measured in inches and \(t\) in seconds), find the particle's instantaneous velocity at \(t=1\). Is the particle moving to the left or right at that instant?\footnote{You may assume that this axis is like a number line, with ``left'' being the negative direction, and ``right'' being the positive direction.\label{fn-18}}%
\item\hypertarget{li-1395}{}\hypertarget{p-2125}{}%
Suppose that \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\) are differentiable functions and that the following information about them is known:%
\begin{table}
\centering
\begin{tabular}{ccccc}\hrulethin
\(x\)&\(f(x)\)&\(f'(x)\)&\(g(x)\)&\(g'(x)\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(-1\)&\(2\)&\(-5\)&\(-3\)&\(4\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(2\)&\(-3\)&\(4\)&\(-1\)&\(2\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\end{tabular}
\caption{Data for functions \(f\) and \(g\).\label{table-12}}
\end{table}
\hypertarget{p-2126}{}%
If \(C(x)\) is a function given by the formula \(f(g(x))\), determine \(C'(2)\). In addition, if \(D(x)\) is the function \(f(f(x))\), find \(D'(-1)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-58}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2127}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1396}{}\hypertarget{p-2128}{}%
Let \(f(x) = \sqrt{e^x + 3}\). Find \(f'(x)\) and \(f'(0)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1397}{}\hypertarget{p-2129}{}%
Recall that \(s'(t)\) tells us the instantaneous velocity at time \(t\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1398}{}\hypertarget{p-2130}{}%
Since \(C(x) = f(g(x))\), it follows \(C'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)\). What is \(C'(2)\)? What is a formula for \(D'(x)\)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-94}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2131}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1399}{}\hypertarget{p-2132}{}%
\(y - 2 = \frac{1}{4}(x-0)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1400}{}\hypertarget{p-2133}{}%
\(s'(1) = -\frac{3}{8}\) inches per second, so the particle is moving left at the instant \(t = 1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1401}{}\hypertarget{p-2134}{}%
\(C'(2) = -10 \); \(D'(-1) = -20\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-120}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2135}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1402}{}\hypertarget{p-2136}{}%
Let \(f(x) = \sqrt{e^x + 3}\). By the chain rule, \(f'(x) = \frac{e^x}{2\sqrt{e^x + 3}}\), and thus \(f'(0) = \frac{1}{4}\). Note further that \(f(0) = \sqrt{1 + 3} = 2\). The tangent line is therefore the line through \((0,2)\) with slope \(\frac{1}{4}\), which is%
\begin{equation*}
y - 2 = \frac{1}{4}(x-0)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1403}{}\hypertarget{p-2137}{}%
Observe that \(s(t) = (t^2 + 1)^{-3}\), and thus by the chain rule, \(s'(t) = -3(t^2 + 1)^{-4}(2t)\). We therefore see that \(s'(1) = -\frac{6}{16} = -\frac{3}{8}\) inches per second, so the particle is moving left at the instant \(t = 1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1404}{}\hypertarget{p-2138}{}%
Since \(C(x) = f(g(x))\), it follows \(C'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)\). Therefore, \(C'(2) = f'(g(2))g'(2)\). From the given table, \(g(2) = -1\), so applying this result and using the additional given information,%
\begin{equation*}
C'(2) = f'(-1) g'(2) = (-5)(2) = -10\text{.}
\end{equation*}
For \(D(x) = f(f(x))\), the chain rule tells us that \(D'(x) = f'(f(x))f'(x)\), so \(D'(-1) = f'(f(-1))f'(-1)\). Using the given table, it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
D'(-1) = f'(2)f'(-1) = (4)(-5) = -20\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.5.3 The Composite Version of Basic Function Rules}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{The Composite Version of Basic Function Rules}]{The Composite Version of Basic Function Rules}\label{subsection-64}
\hypertarget{p-2139}{}%
As we gain more experience with differentiation, we will become more comfortable in simply writing down the derivative without taking multiple steps. This is particularly simple when the inner function is linear, since the derivative of a linear function is a constant.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-110}
\hypertarget{p-2140}{}%
Use the chain rule to differentiate each of the following composite functions whose inside function is linear:%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left[ (5x+7)^{10} \right] = 10(5x+7)^9 \cdot 5\text{,}
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left[ \tan(17x) \right] = 17\sec^2(17x), \ \text{and}
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left[ e^{-3x} \right] = -3e^{-3x}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-2141}{}%
More generally, an excellent exercise for getting comfortable with the derivative rules is as follows. First write down a list of all the basic functions whose derivatives we know, and list the derivatives. Then write a composite function with the inner function being an unknown function \(u(x)\) and the outer function being a basic function. Finally, write the chain rule for the composite function. The following example illustrates this for two different functions.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-111}
\hypertarget{p-2142}{}%
To determine%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}[\sin(u(x))]\text{,}
\end{equation*}
where \(u\) is a differentiable function of \(x\), we use the chain rule with the sine function as the outer function. Applying the chain rule, we find that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}[\sin(u(x))] = \cos(u(x)) \cdot u'(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
This rule is analogous to the basic derivative rule that \(\frac{d}{dx}[\sin(x)] = \cos(x)\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2143}{}%
Similarly, since \(\frac{d}{dx}[a^x] = a^x \ln(a)\) whenever \(a \gt 0\), it follows by the chain rule that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}[a^{u(x)}] = a^{u(x)} \ln(a) \cdot u'(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
This rule is analogous to the basic derivative rule that \(\frac{d}{dx}[a^{x}] = a^{x} \ln(a)\).%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.5.4 Summary}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Summary}]{Summary}\label{subsection-65}
\hypertarget{p-2144}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2145}{}%
A composite function is one where the input variable \(x\) first passes through one function, and then the resulting output passes through another. For example, the function \(h(x) = 2^{\sin(x)}\) is composite since \(x \longrightarrow \sin(x) \longrightarrow 2^{\sin(x)}\).%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2146}{}%
Given a composite function \(C(x) = f(g(x))\) where \(f\) and \(g\) are differentiable functions, the chain rule tells us that%
\begin{equation*}
C'(x) = f'(g(x)) g'(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{itemize}
%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Exercises 2.5.5 Exercises}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Exercises}]{Exercises}\label{exercises-16}
\begin{exerciselist}
\item[1.]\hypertarget{ez-2-5-WW1}{}(Mixing rules:  chain, product, sum)\space\space{}\item[2.]\hypertarget{ez-2-5-WW2}{}(Mixing rules:  chain and product)\space\space{}\item[3.]\hypertarget{ez-2-5-WW3}{}(Using the chain rule repeatedly)\space\space{}\item[4.]\hypertarget{ez-2-5-WW4}{}(Derivative involving arbitrary constants \(a\) and \(b\))\space\space{}\item[5.]\hypertarget{ez-2-5-WW5}{}(Chain rule with graphs)\space\space{}\item[6.]\hypertarget{ez-2-5-WW6}{}(Chain rule with function values)\space\space{}\item[7.]\hypertarget{ez-2-5-WW7}{}(A product involving a composite function)\space\space{}\item[8.]\hypertarget{exercise-138}{}(Using the chain rule to compare composite functions)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-2147}{}%
Consider the basic functions \(f(x) = x^3\) and \(g(x) = \sin(x)\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1407}{}\hypertarget{p-2148}{}%
Let \(h(x) = f(g(x))\). Find the exact instantaneous rate of change of \(h\) at the point where \(x = \frac{\pi}{4}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1408}{}\hypertarget{p-2149}{}%
Which function is changing most rapidly at \(x = 0.25\): \(h(x) = f(g(x))\) or \(r(x) = g(f(x))\)? Why?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1409}{}\hypertarget{p-2150}{}%
Let \(h(x) = f(g(x))\) and \(r(x) = g(f(x))\). Which of these functions has a derivative that is periodic? Why?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-95}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2151}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1410}{}\hypertarget{p-2152}{}%
\(h'\left( \frac{\pi}{4} \right) = \frac{3}{2\sqrt{2}}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1411}{}\hypertarget{p-2153}{}%
\(r'(0.25) = \cos(0.25^3) \cdot 3(0.25)^2 \approx 0.1875 \gt h'(0.25) = 3\sin^2(0.25) \cdot \cos(0.25) \approx 0.1779\); \(r\) is changing more rapidly.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1412}{}\hypertarget{p-2154}{}%
\(h'(x)\) is periodic; \(r'(x)\) is not.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-121}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2155}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1413}{}\hypertarget{p-2156}{}%
Since \(h(x) = f(g(x))\), by the chain rule we know that \(h'(x) = f'(g(x)) \cdot g'(x)\). Using the facts that \(f(x)=x^3\) and \(g(x) = \sin(x)\), it follows \(f'(x) = 3x^2\) and \(f'(g(x)) = 3\sin^2(x)\), and \(g'(x) = \cos(x)\). Therefore,%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = 3\sin^2(x) \cdot \cos(x)
\end{equation*}
and \(h'\left( \frac{\pi}{4} \right) = 3 \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \right)^2 \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{3}{2\sqrt{2}}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1414}{}\hypertarget{p-2157}{}%
Note that \(r'(x) = g'(f(x)) \cdot f'(x) = \cos(x^3) \cdot 3x^2\). Thus, we have \(r'(0.25) = \cos(0.25^3) \cdot 3(0.25)^2 \approx 0.1875\), while using our work from (a), \(h'(0.25) = 3\sin^2(0.25) \cdot \cos(0.25) \approx 0.1779\), so since \(|h'(0.25) \lt r'(0.25)|\), we see that \(r\) is changing more rapidly.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1415}{}\hypertarget{p-2158}{}%
We have observed in (a) and (b) that \(h'(x) = 3\sin^2(x) \cdot \cos(x)\) and \(r'(x) = \cos(x^3) \cdot 3x^2\). Because both parts of the product in \(h'(x)\) are periodic functions, \(h'(x)\) is periodic (with period \(2\pi\)). However, \(r'(x)\) is not periodic, since \(3x^2\) grows without bound as \(x\) increases.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[9.]\hypertarget{exercise-139}{}(Chain rule with an arbitrary function \(u\))\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-2159}{}%
Let \(u(x)\) be a differentiable function. For each of the following functions, determine the derivative. Each response will involve \(u\) and/or \(u'\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1416}{}\hypertarget{p-2160}{}%
\(p(x) = e^{u(x)}\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1417}{}\hypertarget{p-2161}{}%
\(q(x) = u(e^x)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1418}{}\hypertarget{p-2162}{}%
\(r(x) = \cot(u(x))\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1419}{}\hypertarget{p-2163}{}%
\(s(x) = u(\cot(x))\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1420}{}\hypertarget{p-2164}{}%
\(a(x) = u(x^4)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1421}{}\hypertarget{p-2165}{}%
\(b(x) = u^4(x)\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-96}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2166}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1422}{}\hypertarget{p-2167}{}%
\(p'(x) = e^{u(x)} \cdot u'(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1423}{}\hypertarget{p-2168}{}%
\(q'(x) = u'(e^x) \cdot e^x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1424}{}\hypertarget{p-2169}{}%
\(r'(x) = -\csc^2(u(x) \cdot u'(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1425}{}\hypertarget{p-2170}{}%
\(s'(x) = u'(\cot(x)) \cdot (-\csc^2(x))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1426}{}\hypertarget{p-2171}{}%
\(a'(x) = u'(x^4) \cdot 4x^3\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1427}{}\hypertarget{p-2172}{}%
\(b'(x) = 4(u(x))^3 \cdot u'(x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-122}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2173}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1428}{}\hypertarget{p-2174}{}%
By the chain rule, \(p'(x) = e^{u(x)} \cdot u'(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1429}{}\hypertarget{p-2175}{}%
By the chain rule, \(q'(x) = u'(e^x) \cdot e^x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1430}{}\hypertarget{p-2176}{}%
By the chain rule, \(r'(x) = -\csc^2(u(x) \cdot u'(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1431}{}\hypertarget{p-2177}{}%
By the chain rule, \(s'(x) = u'(\cot(x)) \cdot (-\csc^2(x))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1432}{}\hypertarget{p-2178}{}%
By the chain rule, \(a'(x) = u'(x^4) \cdot 4x^3\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1433}{}\hypertarget{p-2179}{}%
By the chain rule, \(b'(x) = 4(u(x))^3 \cdot u'(x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[10.]\hypertarget{exercise-140}{}(More on using the chain rule with graphs)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-2180}{}%
Let functions \(p\) and \(q\) be the piecewise linear functions given by their respective graphs in \hyperref[F-2-5-Ez3]{Figure~\ref{F-2-5-Ez3}}. Use the graphs to answer the following questions.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_1_Ez3.pdf}
\caption{The graphs of \(p\) (in blue) and \(q\) (in green).\label{F-2-5-Ez3}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-2181}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1434}{}\hypertarget{p-2182}{}%
Let \(C(x) = p(q(x))\). Determine \(C'(0)\) and \(C'(3)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1435}{}\hypertarget{p-2183}{}%
Find a value of \(x\) for which \(C'(x)\) does not exist. Explain your thinking.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1436}{}\hypertarget{p-2184}{}%
Let \(Y(x) = q(q(x))\) and \(Z(x) = q(p(x))\). Determine \(Y'(-2)\) and \(Z'(0)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-97}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2185}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1437}{}\hypertarget{p-2186}{}%
\(C'(0) = 0\) and \(C'(3) = -\frac{1}{2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1438}{}\hypertarget{p-2187}{}%
Consider \(C'(1)\). By the chain rule, we'd expect that \(C'(1) = p'(q(1)) \cdot q'(1)\), but we know that \(q'(1)\) does not exist since \(q\) has a corner point at \(x = 1\). This means that \(C'(1)\) does not exist either.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1439}{}\hypertarget{p-2188}{}%
Since \(Y(x) = q(q(x))\), the chain rule implies that \(Y'(x) = q'(q(x)) \cdot q'(x)\), and thus \(Y'(-2) = q'(q(-2)) \cdot q'(-2) = q'(-1) \cdot q'(-2)\). But \(q'(-1)\) does not exist, so \(Y'(-2)\) also fails to exist. Using \(Z(x) = q(p(x))\) and the chain rule, we have \(Z'(x) = q'(p(x)) \cdot p'(x)\). Therefore \(Z'(0) = q'(p(0)) \cdot p'(0) = q'(-0.5) \cdot p'(0) = 0 \cdot 0.5 = 0\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-123}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2189}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1440}{}\hypertarget{p-2190}{}%
By the chain rule, \(C'(x) = p'(q(x)) \cdot q'(x)\), so \(C'(0) = p'(q(0)) \cdot q'(0)\) and \(C'(3) = p'(q(3)) \cdot q'(3)\). From the graph, we see that \(q(0) = 2\), and thus \(C'(0) = p'(2) \cdot q'(0)\). Reading the slopes of the lines from the graph, it follows \(C'(0) = 2 \cdot 0 = 0\). Similarly, \(q(3) = 0\), so \(C'(3) = p'(0) \cdot q'(3) = \frac{1}{2} \cdot (-1) = -\frac{1}{2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1441}{}\hypertarget{p-2191}{}%
Consider \(C'(1)\). By the chain rule, we'd expect that \(C'(1) = p'(q(1)) \cdot q'(1)\), but we know that \(q'(1)\) does not exist since \(q\) has a corner point at \(x = 1\). This means that \(C'(1)\) does not exist either.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1442}{}\hypertarget{p-2192}{}%
Since \(Y(x) = q(q(x))\), the chain rule implies that \(Y'(x) = q'(q(x)) \cdot q'(x)\), and thus \(Y'(-2) = q'(q(-2)) \cdot q'(-2) = q'(-1) \cdot q'(-2)\). But \(q'(-1)\) does not exist, so \(Y'(-2)\) also fails to exist. Using \(Z(x) = q(p(x))\) and the chain rule, we have \(Z'(x) = q'(p(x)) \cdot p'(x)\). Therefore \(Z'(0) = q'(p(0)) \cdot p'(0) = q'(-0.5) \cdot p'(0) = 0 \cdot 0.5 = 0\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[11.]\hypertarget{exercise-141}{}(Applying the chain rule in a physical context)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-2193}{}%
If a spherical tank of radius 4 feet has \(h\) feet of water present in the tank, then the volume of water in the tank is given by the formula%
\begin{equation*}
V = \frac{\pi}{3} h^2(12-h)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1443}{}\hypertarget{p-2194}{}%
At what instantaneous rate is the volume of water in the tank changing with respect to the \emph{height} of the water at the instant \(h = 1\)? What are the units on this quantity?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1444}{}\hypertarget{p-2195}{}%
Now suppose that the height of water in the tank is being regulated by an inflow and outflow (e.g., a faucet and a drain) so that the height of the water at time \(t\) is given by the rule \(h(t) = \sin(\pi t) + 1\), where \(t\) is measured in hours (and \(h\) is still measured in feet). At what rate is the height of the water changing with respect to time at the instant \(t = 2\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1445}{}\hypertarget{p-2196}{}%
Continuing under the assumptions in (b), at what instantaneous rate is the volume of water in the tank changing with respect to \emph{time} at the instant \(t = 2\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1446}{}\hypertarget{p-2197}{}%
What are the main differences between the rates found in (a) and (c)? Include a discussion of the relevant units.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-98}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2198}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1447}{}\hypertarget{p-2199}{}%
\(\frac{dV}{dh} = \pi \left(8h-h^2 \right)\), cubic feet per foot.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1448}{}\hypertarget{p-2200}{}%
\(\frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{\pi}{3}\left[ 12 \cdot 2 (\sin(\pi t) + 1) \cdot \pi \cos(\pi t) - 3 (\sin(\pi t) + 1)^2 \cdot \pi \cos(\pi t) \right]\) cubic feet per hour.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1449}{}\hypertarget{p-2201}{}%
\(\left. \frac{dV}{dt} \right|_{t=0} = 7 \pi^2\) cubic feet per hour.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1450}{}\hypertarget{p-2202}{}%
In (a) we are determining the instantaneous rate at which the volume changes as we increase the height of the water in the tank, while in (c) we are finding the instantaneous rate at which volume changes as we increase time.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-124}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2203}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1451}{}\hypertarget{p-2204}{}%
We are asked to find \(\frac{dV}{dh}\) (the derivative of \(V\) with respect to the independent variable \(h\)) at the instant \(h = 1\). If we first expand \(V\) to write%
\begin{equation*}
V = \frac{\pi}{3}\left(12h^2 - h^3\right)
\end{equation*}
we find that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dV}{dh} = \frac{\pi}{3} \left(24h - 3h^2\right) = \pi \left(8h-h^2 \right)\text{,}
\end{equation*}
with units ``cubic feet per foot''.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1452}{}\hypertarget{p-2205}{}%
Now we want to find \(\frac{dV}{dt}\), the derivative of \(V\) with respect to the independent variable \(t\). Here we can write \(V\) as a function of \(t\) by writing \(V(t) = \frac{\pi}{3}\left(12(h(t))^2 - (h(t))^3\right)\), where \(h(t) = \sin(\pi t) + 1\). By the chain rule, it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{\pi}{3}\left( 12 \cdot 2 h(t) \cdot h'(t) - 3 (h(t))^2 \cdot h'(t) \right)
\end{equation*}
and hence using \(h(t) = \sin(\pi t) + 1\) and \(h'(t) = \pi \cos(\pi t)\),%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{\pi}{3}\left[ 12 \cdot 2 (\sin(\pi t) + 1) \cdot \pi \cos(\pi t) - 3 (\sin(\pi t) + 1)^2 \cdot \pi \cos(\pi t) \right]
\end{equation*}
with units ``cubic feet per hour''.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1453}{}\hypertarget{p-2206}{}%
Now we want to find \(\frac{dV}{dt}\) when \(t=0\). Using the result from part (b), we have%
\begin{equation*}
\left. \frac{dV}{dt} \right|_{t=0} = \frac{\pi}{3}\left[ 12 \cdot 2 (\sin(0) + 1) \cdot \pi \cos(0) - 3 (\sin(0) + 1)^2 \cdot \pi \cos(0) \right] = 7 \pi^2
\end{equation*}
cubic feet per hour.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1454}{}\hypertarget{p-2207}{}%
In (a) we are determining the instantaneous rate at which the volume changes as we increase the height of the water in the tank, while in (c) we are finding the instantaneous rate at which volume changes as we increase time. The first calculation is a direct one, while the second is more indirect, as it involves the composition of \(V\) with \(h\) as a function of time. In the latter case, both \(h\) and \(V\) are functions of time, which allows us to think not only of how \(V\) is changing as a function of \(h\), but also as a function of \(t\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{exerciselist}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Section 2.6 Derivatives of Inverse Functions}
\typeout{************************************************}
\section[{Derivatives of Inverse Functions}]{Derivatives of Inverse Functions}\label{sec-2-6-inverse}
\begin{objectives}{Motivating Questions}\label{objectives-14}
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2208}{}%
What is the derivative of the natural logarithm function?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2209}{}%
What are the derivatives of the inverse trigonometric functions \(\arcsin(x)\) and \(\arctan(x)\)?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2210}{}%
If \(g\) is the inverse of a differentiable function \(f\), how is \(g'\) computed in terms of \(f\), \(f'\), and \(g\)?%
\end{itemize}
\end{objectives}
\hypertarget{p-2211}{}%
Much of mathematics centers on the notion of function. Indeed, throughout our study of calculus we are investigating the behavior of functions, with a particular emphasis on how fast the output of the function changes in response to changes in the input. Because each function represents a process, a natural question to ask is whether or not such a process can be reversed. That is, if we know the output that results from the function, can we (uniquely) determine the input that led to it? And if we know how fast a particular process is changing, can we determine how fast the inverse process is changing?%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2212}{}%
One of the most important functions in all of mathematics is the natural exponential function \(f(x) = e^x\). Its inverse, the natural logarithm \(g(x) = \ln(x)\), is similarly important. One of our goals in this section is to learn how to differentiate the logarithm function. First, we review some of the basic concepts surrounding functions and their inverses in \hyperref[PA-2-6]{Example~\ref{PA-2-6}}.%
\begin{example}[]\label{PA-2-6}
\hypertarget{p-2213}{}%
The equation \(y = \frac{5}{9}(x-32)\) relates a temperature given in \(x\) degrees Fahrenheit to the corresponding temperature \(y\) measured in degrees Celsius. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1458}{}\hypertarget{p-2214}{}%
Write \(x\) (Fahrenheit temperature) in terms of \(y\) (Celsius temperature) by solving the equation \(y = \frac{5}{9}(x-32)\) for \(x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1459}{}\hypertarget{p-2215}{}%
Let \(C(x) = \frac{5}{9}(x-32)\) be the function that takes a Fahrenheit temperature as input and produces the equivalent Celsius temperature as output. In addition, let \(F(y)\) be the function that converts a temperature given in \(y\) degrees Celsius to the equivalent temperature \(F(y)\) measured in degrees Fahrenheit. Use your work in (a) to write a formula for \(F(y)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1460}{}\hypertarget{p-2216}{}%
Next consider the composite function defined by \(p(x) = F(C(x))\). Use the formulas for \(F\) and \(C\) to determine an expression for \(p(x)\) and simplify this expression as much as possible. What do you observe?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1461}{}\hypertarget{p-2217}{}%
Now, let \(r(y) = C(F(y))\). Use the formulas for \(F\) and \(C\) to determine an expression for \(r(y)\) and simplify this expression as much as possible. What do you observe?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1462}{}\hypertarget{p-2218}{}%
What is the value of \(C'(x)\)? of \(F'(y)\)? How do these values appear to be related?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-59}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2219}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1463}{}\hypertarget{p-2220}{}%
Start by multiplying both sides of the equation by \(\frac{9}{5}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1464}{}\hypertarget{p-2221}{}%
How should \(F(y)\) and \(x\) be related?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1465}{}\hypertarget{p-2222}{}%
How do the units of \(x\) compare to the units of \(p(x)\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1466}{}\hypertarget{p-2223}{}%
How do the units of \(y\) compare to the units of \(r(y)\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1467}{}\hypertarget{p-2224}{}%
The units on \(C'(x)\) are degrees Celsius per degree Fahrenheit; the units on \(F'(y)\) are degrees Fahrenheit per degree Celsius.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-99}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2225}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1468}{}\hypertarget{p-2226}{}%
\(x=\frac95y+32\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1469}{}\hypertarget{p-2227}{}%
\(F(y)=\frac95y+32\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1470}{}\hypertarget{p-2228}{}%
\(p(x)=x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1471}{}\hypertarget{p-2229}{}%
\(r(y)=y\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1472}{}\hypertarget{p-2230}{}%
\(C'(x)=\frac59\) is the reciprocal of \(F'(y)=\frac95\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-125}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2231}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1473}{}\hypertarget{p-2232}{}%
To solve the equation \(y=\frac59(x-32)\) for \(x\), we first multiply both sides by \(\frac95\) and then add \(32\):%
\begin{align*}
y=\mathstrut \amp \frac59(x-32)\\
\frac95y=\mathstrut \amp x-32 \\
\frac95y+32=\mathstrut \amp x\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1474}{}\hypertarget{p-2233}{}%
From the initial equation \(y=\frac59(x-32)\) that relates a temperature of \(x\) degrees Fahrenheit to the equivalent temperature \(y\) degrees Celsius, we have said that \(C(x)=y\). Similarly, our work in part (a) rewrote that equation into the form \(x=\frac95y+32\) demonstrating the same relation between a temperature of \(x\) degrees Fahrenheit and \(y\) degrees Celsius. It should be the case, then, that \(F(y)=x\). Thus a formula for \(F\) is%
\begin{equation*}
F(y)=\frac95y+32\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1475}{}\hypertarget{p-2234}{}%
In part (b), we said that \(C(x)=y\) and \(F(y)=x\). Based on this, it should be the case that%
\begin{equation*}
p(x)=F(C(x))=F(y)=x\text{,}
\end{equation*}
but we'll take a closer look to double check. Observe:%
\begin{align*}
p(x)=\mathstrut \amp F(C(x))\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac95C(x)+32\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac95\left(\frac59(x-32)\right)+32\\
=\mathstrut \amp (x-32)+32\\
=\mathstrut \amp x\text{.}
\end{align*}
To make sense of this, we notice that the function \(p\) takes a temperature \(x\), in degrees Fahrenheit, pushes it through the function \(C\) to convert it to \(C(x)\) degrees Celsius, and then pushes the result through the function \(F\) to convert it back into degrees Fahrenheit. Since \(F\) and \(C\) are each just converting the units of a given temperature, and the units of \(F(C(x))\) are the same as the units on \(x\), it is perfectly reasonable to end up with the equation \(x=F(C(x))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1476}{}\hypertarget{p-2235}{}%
The situation with \(r(y)=C(F(y))\) is analogous to that described in part (c). In part (b), we said that \(C(x)=y\) and \(F(y)=x\). Based on this, it should be the case that%
\begin{equation*}
r(y)=C(F(y))=C(x)=y\text{,}
\end{equation*}
but we'll take a closer look to double check. Observe:%
\begin{align*}
r(y)=\mathstrut \amp C(F(y))\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac59(F(y)-32)\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac59\left(\left(\frac95y+32\right)-32\right)\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac59\left(\frac95y\right)\\
=\mathstrut \amp y\text{.}
\end{align*}
To make sense of this, we notice that the function \(r\) takes a temperature \(y\), in degrees Celsius, pushes it through the function \(F\) to convert it to \(F(y)\) degrees Fahrenheit, and then pushes the result through the function \(C\) to convert it back into degrees Celsius. Since \(F\) and \(C\) are each just converting the units of a given temperature, and the units of \(C(F(y))\) are the same as the units on \(y\), it is perfectly reasonable to end up with the equation \(y=C(F(y))\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2236}{}%
From this and part (c), we deduce that \(C\) and \(F\) are a pair of \terminology{inverse functions}.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1477}{}\hypertarget{p-2237}{}%
Since \(C(x)=\frac59(x-32)\), we know that \(C'(x)=\frac59\) degrees Celsius per degree Fahrenheit. Likewise, since \(F(y)=\frac95y+32\), we know that \(F'(y)=\frac95\) degrees Fahrenheit per degree Celsius. We note that these values are reciprocals of each other, as might be expected from the units on each.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.6.1 Basic Facts about Inverse Functions}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Basic Facts about Inverse Functions}]{Basic Facts about Inverse Functions}\label{subsection-66}
\hypertarget{p-2238}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Inverse Functions]\label{assemblage-66}
\hypertarget{p-2239}{}%
A function \index{function!inverse function} \(f : A \to B\) is a rule that associates each element in the set \(A\) to one and only one element in the set \(B\). We call \(A\) the \terminology{domain} \index{domain} of \(f\) and \(B\) the \terminology{codomain} \index{codomain} of \(f\). If there exists a function \(g : B \to A\) such that \(g(f(a)) = a\) for every possible choice of \(a\) in the set \(A\) and \(f(g(b)) = b\) for every \(b\) in the set \(B\), then we say that \(g\) is the \terminology{inverse}  of \(f\).%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2240}{}%
We often use the notation \(f^{-1}\) (read ``\("f\)-inverse"'') to denote the inverse of \(f\). The inverse function undoes the work of \(f\). Indeed, if \(y = f(x)\), then%
\begin{equation*}
f^{-1}(y) = f^{-1}(f(x)) = x\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Thus, the equations \(y = f(x)\) and \(x = f^{-1}(y)\) say the same thing. The only difference between the two equations is \textemdash{} one is solved for \(x\), while the other is solved for \(y\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2241}{}%
Here we briefly remind ourselves of some key facts about inverse functions.%
\begin{note}[]\label{note-7}
\hypertarget{p-2242}{}%
For a function \(f : A \to B\), \leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2243}{}%
\(f\) has an inverse if and only if \(f\) is one-to-one\footnote{A function \(f\) is \terminology{one-to-one} \index{one-to-one} provided that no two distinct inputs lead to the same output.\label{fn-19}} and onto;\footnote{A function \(f\) is \terminology{onto} \index{onto} provided that every possible element of the codomain can be realized as an output of the function for some choice of input from the domain.\label{fn-20}}%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2244}{}%
Provided \(f^{-1}\) exists, the domain of \(f^{-1}\) is the codomain of \(f\), and the codomain of \(f^{-1}\) is the domain of \(f\);%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2245}{}%
\(f^{-1}(f(x)) = x\) for every \(x\) in the domain of \(f\) and \(f(f^{-1}(y)) = y\) for every \(y\) in the codomain of \(f\);%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2246}{}%
\(y = f(x)\) if and only if \(x = f^{-1}(y)\).%
\end{itemize}
%
\end{note}
\hypertarget{p-2247}{}%
The last fact reveals a special relationship between the graphs of \(f\) and \(f^{-1}\). If a point \((x,y)\) lies on the graph of \(y = f(x)\), then it is also true that \(x = f^{-1}(y)\), which means that the point \((y,x)\) lies on the graph of \(f^{-1}\). This shows us that the graphs of \(f\) and \(f^{-1}\) are the reflections of each other across the line \(y = x\), because this reflection is precisely the geometric action that swaps the coordinates in an ordered pair. In \hyperref[F-2-6-Inverse-Plot]{Figure~\ref{F-2-6-Inverse-Plot}} below, we see this illustrated by the graphs of \(y=f(x)\) and \(y=f^{-1}(x)\), where \(f(x) = 2^x\). The marked points \(\big(-1,\frac{1}{2}\big)\) and \(\big(\frac{1}{2},-1\big)\) highlight the reflection of the curves across the line \(y = x\).%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.47\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_6_InversePlot.pdf}
\caption{The graph of a function \(y = f(x)\) along with its inverse \(y = f^{-1}(x)\).\label{F-2-6-Inverse-Plot}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-2248}{}%
To close our review of important facts about inverses, we recall that the natural exponential function \(f(x) = e^x\) has an inverse function, namely the natural logarithm \(f^{-1}(y) = \ln(y)\). Thus, writing \(y = e^x\) is interchangeable with \(x = \ln(y)\), while also \(\ln(e^x) = x\) for every real number \(x\), and \(e^{\ln(y)} = y\) for every positive real number \(y\).%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.6.2 The Derivative of the Natural Logarithm Function}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{The Derivative of the Natural Logarithm Function}]{The Derivative of the Natural Logarithm Function}\label{subsection-67}
\hypertarget{p-2249}{}%
In what follows, we find a formula for the derivative of \(g(x) = \ln(x)\). To do so, we take advantage of the fact that we know the derivative of the natural exponential function, the inverse of \(g\). In particular, we know that writing \(g(x) = \ln(x)\) is equivalent to writing \(e^{g(x)} = x\). Now, we differentiate both sides of this equation and observe that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}\left[e^{g(x)}\right] = \frac{d}{dx}[x]\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2250}{}%
The righthand side is simply \(1\); by applying the chain rule to the left side, we find that%
\begin{equation*}
e^{g(x)} g'(x) = 1\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2251}{}%
Next we solve for \(g'(x)\) and get%
\begin{equation*}
g'(x) = \frac{1}{e^{g(x)}}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2252}{}%
Finally, we recall that \(g(x) = \ln(x)\), so \(e^{g(x)} = e^{\ln(x)} = x\). Thus%
\begin{equation*}
g'(x) = \frac{1}{x}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2253}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Derivative of the Natural Logarithm]\label{natural-log}
\hypertarget{p-2254}{}%
\index{derivative!logarithm} For all positive real numbers \(x\), \(\frac{d}{dx}[\ln(x)] = \frac{1}{x}\).%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2255}{}%
This rule for the natural logarithm function now joins our list of basic derivative rules. Note that this rule applies only to positive values of \(x\), as these are the only values for which \(\ln(x)\) is defined.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2256}{}%
Also notice that for the first time in our work, differentiating a basic function of a particular type has led to a function of a very different nature: the derivative of the natural logarithm is not another logarithm, nor even an exponential function, but rather a rational one.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2257}{}%
Derivatives of logarithms may now be computed in concert with all of the rules known to date. For instance, if \(f(t) = \ln(t^2 + 1)\), then by the chain rule, \(f'(t) = \frac{1}{t^2 + 1} \cdot 2t\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2258}{}%
There are interesting connections between the graphs of \(y=f(x)\) and \(y=f^{-1}(x)\), with \(f(x) = e^x\) and \(f^{-1}(x) = \ln(x)\).%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)
{% begin: group for a single side-by-side
% set panel max height to practical minimum, created in preamble
\setlength{\panelmax}{0pt}
\ifdefined\panelboxAp\else\newsavebox{\panelboxAp}\fi%
\savebox{\panelboxAp}{%
\raisebox{\depth}{\parbox{0.44\linewidth}{In \hyperref[F-2-6-Log-Exp]{Figure~\ref{F-2-6-Log-Exp}} on the right, we are reminded that since the natural exponential function has the property that its derivative is itself, the slope of the tangent to \(y = e^x\) is equal to the height of the curve at that point. For instance, at the point \(A = (\ln(0.5), 0.5)\), the slope of the tangent line is \(m_A = 0.5\), and at \(B = (\ln(5), 5)\), the tangent line's slope is \(m_B = 5\).}}}

% \tabcolsep change local to group
\setlength{\tabcolsep}{0.03\linewidth}
% @{} suppress \tabcolsep at extremes, so margins behave as intended
\par\medskip\noindent

&
\parbox[t]{0.5\linewidth}{\captionof{figure}{A graph of the function \(y = e^x\) along with its inverse, \(y = \ln(x)\), where both functions are viewed using the input variable \(x\).\label{F-2-6-Log-Exp}}
}\end{tabular}\\
% end: side-by-side as tabular
}% end: group for a single side-by-side
\par
\hypertarget{p-2260}{}%
At the corresponding points \(A'\) and \(B'\) on the graph of the natural logarithm function (which come from reflecting \(A\) and \(B\) across the line \(y = x\)), we know that the slope of the tangent line is the reciprocal of the \(x\)-coordinate of the point (since \(\frac{d}{dx}[\ln(x)] = \frac{1}{x}\)). Thus, at \(A' = (0.5, \ln(0.5))\), we have \(m_{A'} = \frac{1}{0.5} = 2\), and at \(B' = (5, \ln(5))\), \(m_{B'} = \frac{1}{5}\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2261}{}%
In particular, we observe that \(m_{A'} = \frac{1}{m_A}\) and \(m_{B'} = \frac{1}{m_B}\). This is not a coincidence, but in fact holds for any curve \(y = f(x)\) and its inverse, provided the inverse exists. This is due to the reflection of the graphs across the line \(y = x\): the reflection changes the roles of \(x\) and \(y\), thus reversing the rise and run, so the slope of the inverse function at the reflected point is the reciprocal of the slope of the original function.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-6-1}
\hypertarget{p-2262}{}%
For each function given below, find its derivative. \leavevmode%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1482}{}\hypertarget{p-2263}{}%
\(h(x) = x^2\ln(x)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1483}{}\hypertarget{p-2264}{}%
\(p(t) = \frac{\ln(t)}{e^t + 1}\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1484}{}\hypertarget{p-2265}{}%
\(s(y) = \ln(\cos(y) + 2)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1485}{}\hypertarget{p-2266}{}%
\(z(x) = \tan(\ln(x))\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1486}{}\hypertarget{p-2267}{}%
\(m(z) = \ln(\ln(z))\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-60}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2268}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1487}{}\hypertarget{p-2269}{}%
Is \(h\) a product, quotient, or composition of basic functions?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1488}{}\hypertarget{p-2270}{}%
Is \(p\) a product, quotient, or composition of basic functions?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1489}{}\hypertarget{p-2271}{}%
Is \(s\) a product, quotient, or composition of basic functions?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1490}{}\hypertarget{p-2272}{}%
Is \(z\) a product, quotient, or composition of basic functions?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1491}{}\hypertarget{p-2273}{}%
Is \(m\) a product, quotient, or composition of basic functions?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-100}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2274}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1492}{}\hypertarget{p-2275}{}%
\(h'(x) = 2x\ln(x)+x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1493}{}\hypertarget{p-2276}{}%
\(\displaystyle p'(t) = \frac{ \frac{1}{t}(e^t + 1) - \ln(t) e^t}{(e^t + 1)^2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1494}{}\hypertarget{p-2277}{}%
\(s'(y) = \frac{1}{\cos(y) + 2)} \cdot (-\sin(y))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1495}{}\hypertarget{p-2278}{}%
\(z'(x) = \frac{\sec^2(\ln(x))}{x}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1496}{}\hypertarget{p-2279}{}%
\(m'(z) = \frac{1}{z\ln(z)}\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-126}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2280}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1497}{}\hypertarget{p-2281}{}%
By the product rule,%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = 2x\ln(x)+x^2\cdot\frac{1}{x}  = 2x\ln(x)+x\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1498}{}\hypertarget{p-2282}{}%
By the quotient rule,%
\begin{equation*}
p'(t) = \frac{\frac{1}{t}(e^t + 1) - \ln(t) e^t}{(e^t + 1)^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1499}{}\hypertarget{p-2283}{}%
The chain rule tells us that%
\begin{equation*}
s'(y) = \frac{1}{\cos(y) + 2)} \cdot (-\sin(y))\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1500}{}\hypertarget{p-2284}{}%
Again using the chain rule,%
\begin{equation*}
z'(x) = \sec^2(\ln(x)) \cdot \frac{1}{x}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1501}{}\hypertarget{p-2285}{}%
Noting that \(m\) is composite with the natural logarithm function serving as both the inner and outer function, we find that%
\begin{equation*}
m'(z) = \frac{1}{\ln(z)} \cdot \frac{d}{dz}\left[\ln(z)\right]=\frac{1}{z\ln(z)}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.6.3 Inverse Trigonometric Functions and their Derivatives}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Inverse Trigonometric Functions and their Derivatives}]{Inverse Trigonometric Functions and their Derivatives}\label{subsection-68}
\hypertarget{p-2286}{}%
Trigonometric functions are periodic, so they fail to be one-to-one, and thus do not have inverse functions. However, we can restrict the domain of each trigonometric function so that it is one-to-one on that domain.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2287}{}%
For instance, consider the sine function on the domain \([-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}]\). Because no output of the sine function is repeated on this interval, the function is one-to-one and thus has an inverse. Thus, the function \(f(x) = \sin(x)\) with domain \(\big[-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\big]\) and codomain \([-1,1]\) has an inverse function \(f^{-1}\) such that%
\begin{equation*}
f^{-1} : [-1,1] \to \left[-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)
{% begin: group for a single side-by-side
% set panel max height to practical minimum, created in preamble
\setlength{\panelmax}{0pt}
\ifdefined\panelboxAp\else\newsavebox{\panelboxAp}\fi%
\savebox{\panelboxAp}{%
\raisebox{\depth}{\parbox{0.47\linewidth}{We call \(f^{-1}\) the \terminology{arcsine} \index{trigonometry!arcsine} (or inverse sine) function and write \(f^{-1}(y) = \arcsin(y)\). It is especially important to remember that%
\begin{equation*}
y = \sin(x) \ \ \text{and}  \ \ x = \arcsin(y)
\end{equation*}
say the same thing. ``The arcsine of \(y\)'' means ``the angle whose sine is \(y\).'' For example, \(\arcsin\big(\frac{1}{2}\big) = \frac{\pi}{6}\) means that \(\frac{\pi}{6}\) is the angle whose sine is \(\frac{1}{2}\), which is equivalent to writing \(\sin\big(\frac{\pi}{6}\big) = \frac{1}{2}\).}}}
\ifdefined\phAp\else\newlength{\phAp}\fi%
\setlength{\phAp}{\ht\panelboxAp+\dp\panelboxAp}
\settototalheight{\phAp}{\usebox{\panelboxAp}}
\setlength{\panelmax}{\maxof{\panelmax}{\phAp}}
\ifdefined\panelboxAimage\else\newsavebox{\panelboxAimage}\fi%
\begin{lrbox}{\panelboxAimage}
\includegraphics[width=0.47\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_6_arcsine.pdf}
\end{lrbox}
\ifdefined\phAimage\else\newlength{\phAimage}\fi%
\setlength{\phAimage}{\ht\panelboxAimage+\dp\panelboxAimage}
\settototalheight{\phAimage}{\usebox{\panelboxAimage}}
\setlength{\panelmax}{\maxof{\panelmax}{\phAimage}}

\par\medskip\noindent

\begin{minipage}[c][\panelmax][t]{0.47\linewidth}\usebox{\panelboxAimage}\end{minipage}\tabularnewline
&
\parbox[t]{0.47\linewidth}{\captionof{figure}{The graphs of \(y=f(x)\) (in blue) and its inverse \(y=f^{-1}(x)\) (in magenta), where \(f(x) = \sin(x)\) has been restricted to the domain \(\big[-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\big]\), and \(f^{-1}(x) = \arcsin(x)\).\label{F-2-6-arcsine}}
}\end{tabular}\\
% end: side-by-side as tabular
}% end: group for a single side-by-side
\par
\hypertarget{p-2289}{}%
Next, we determine the derivative of the arcsine function. Letting \(h(x) = \arcsin(x)\), our goal is to find \(h'(x)\). Since \(h(x)\) is the angle whose sine is \(x\), it is equivalent to write%
\begin{equation*}
\sin(h(x)) = x\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2290}{}%
Differentiating both sides of the previous equation, we have%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}[\sin(h(x))] = \frac{d}{dx}[x]\text{.}
\end{equation*}
The righthand side is simply \(1\), and by applying the chain rule to the left side, we end up with%
\begin{equation*}
\cos(h(x)) h'(x) = 1\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2291}{}%
Solving for \(h'(x)\), it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = \frac{1}{\cos(h(x))}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2292}{}%
Finally, we recall that \(h(x) = \arcsin(x)\), so the denominator of \(h'(x)\) is the function \(\cos(\arcsin(x))\), or in other words, ``the cosine of the angle whose sine is \(x\):''%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x)=\frac1{\cos(\arcsin(x))}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
A bit of right triangle trigonometry allows us to simplify this expression considerably.%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)
{% begin: group for a single side-by-side
% set panel max height to practical minimum, created in preamble
\setlength{\panelmax}{0pt}
\ifdefined\panelboxAp\else\newsavebox{\panelboxAp}\fi%
\savebox{\panelboxAp}{%
\raisebox{\depth}{\parbox{0.47\linewidth}{Let's say that \(\theta = \arcsin(x)\), so that \(\theta\) is the angle whose sine is \(x\). We can picture \(\theta\) as an angle in a right triangle with hypotenuse \(1\) and a vertical leg of length \(x\), as shown on the right in \hyperref[F-2-6-cosarcsin]{Figure~\ref{F-2-6-cosarcsin}}. By the Pythagorean Theorem, the length of the horizontal leg must be \(\sqrt{1-x^2}\).}}}
\ifdefined\phAp\else\newlength{\phAp}\fi%
\setlength{\phAp}{\ht\panelboxAp+\dp\panelboxAp}
\settototalheight{\phAp}{\usebox{\panelboxAp}}
\setlength{\panelmax}{\maxof{\panelmax}{\phAp}}

\end{lrbox}

\settototalheight{\phAimage}{\usebox{\panelboxAimage}}

% \tabcolsep change local to group
\setlength{\tabcolsep}{0.03\linewidth}
% @{} suppress \tabcolsep at extremes, so margins behave as intended
\par\medskip\noindent
\begin{tabular}{@{}*{2}{c}@{}}
\begin{minipage}[c][\panelmax][t]{0.47\linewidth}\usebox{\panelboxAp}\end{minipage}&
\begin{minipage}[c][\panelmax][t]{0.47\linewidth}\usebox{\panelboxAimage}\end{minipage}\tabularnewline
&
\parbox[t]{0.47\linewidth}{\captionof{figure}{The right triangle that corresponds to the angle \(\theta = \arcsin(x)\).\label{F-2-6-cosarcsin}}
}\end{tabular}\\
% end: side-by-side as tabular
}% end: group for a single side-by-side
\par
\hypertarget{p-2294}{}%
Now, because \(\theta = \arcsin(x)\), the expression for \(\cos(\arcsin(x))\) is equivalent to \(\cos(\theta)\). From the figure, \(\cos(\arcsin(x)) = \cos(\theta) = \sqrt{1-x^2}\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2295}{}%
Substituting this expression into our formula for \(h'(x)\), we have now shown that%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2296}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Derivative of the Inverse Sine]\label{inverse-sine}
\hypertarget{p-2297}{}%
\index{derivative!arcsine} For all real numbers \(x\) such that \(-1 \lt  x \lt  1\),%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}[\arcsin(x)] = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-6-2}
\hypertarget{p-2298}{}%
The following prompts in this example will lead you to develop the derivative of the inverse tangent function. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1502}{}\hypertarget{p-2299}{}%
Let \(r(x) = \arctan(x)\). Use the relationship between the arctangent and tangent functions to rewrite this equation using only the tangent function.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1503}{}\hypertarget{p-2300}{}%
Differentiate both sides of the equation you found in (a). Solve the resulting equation for \(r'(x)\) and write \(r'(x)\) as simply as possible in terms of a trigonometric function evaluated at \(r(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1504}{}\hypertarget{p-2301}{}%
Recall that \(r(x) = \arctan(x)\). Update your expression for \(r'(x)\) so that it only involves trigonometric functions and the independent variable \(x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1505}{}\hypertarget{p-2302}{}%
Introduce a right triangle with angle \(\theta\) so that \(\theta = \arctan(x)\). What are the three sides of the triangle?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1506}{}\hypertarget{p-2303}{}%
In terms of only \(x\) and \(1\), what is the value of \(\cos(\arctan(x))\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1507}{}\hypertarget{p-2304}{}%
Use the results of your work above to find an expression involving only \(1\) and \(x\) for \(r'(x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-61}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2305}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1508}{}\hypertarget{p-2306}{}%
Recall that for any function and its inverse, writing \(y = f^{-1}(x)\) is equivalent to writing \(f(y) = x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1509}{}\hypertarget{p-2307}{}%
Apply the chain rule to differentiate \(\tan(r(x))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1510}{}\hypertarget{p-2308}{}%
This question is only asking you to substitute the expression for \(r(x)\) into what you found in (b).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1511}{}\hypertarget{p-2309}{}%
Let the vertical leg of the triangle be \(x\). What must the horizontal leg be?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1512}{}\hypertarget{p-2310}{}%
Recall that the cosine of an angle is the length of the adjacent leg over the length of the hypotenuse.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1513}{}\hypertarget{p-2311}{}%
Note that \(\cos^2(\alpha) = (\cos(\alpha))^2\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-101}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2312}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1514}{}\hypertarget{p-2313}{}%
\(\tan(r(x)) = x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1515}{}\hypertarget{p-2314}{}%
\(r'(x) = \cos^2(r(x))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1516}{}\hypertarget{p-2315}{}%
\(r'(x) = \cos^2(\arctan(x))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1517}{}\hypertarget{p-2316}{}%
With \(\theta = \arctan(x)\),%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)
{% begin: group for a single side-by-side
% set panel max height to practical minimum, created in preamble
\setlength{\panelmax}{0pt}
\ifdefined\panelboxAimage\else\newsavebox{\panelboxAimage}\fi%
\begin{lrbox}{\panelboxAimage}
\includegraphics[width=0.33\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_6_cosarctan.pdf}
\end{lrbox}
\ifdefined\phAimage\else\newlength{\phAimage}\fi%
\setlength{\phAimage}{\ht\panelboxAimage+\dp\panelboxAimage}
\settototalheight{\phAimage}{\usebox{\panelboxAimage}}
\setlength{\panelmax}{\maxof{\panelmax}{\phAimage}}
\leavevmode%
% begin: side-by-side as tabular
% \tabcolsep change local to group
\setlength{\tabcolsep}{0\linewidth}
% @{} suppress \tabcolsep at extremes, so margins behave as intended
\par\medskip\noindent
\hspace*{0.335\linewidth}%
\begin{tabular}{@{}*{1}{c}@{}}
\begin{minipage}[c][\panelmax][t]{0.33\linewidth}\usebox{\panelboxAimage}\end{minipage}\end{tabular}\\
% end: side-by-side as tabular
}% end: group for a single side-by-side
\item\hypertarget{li-1518}{}\hypertarget{p-2317}{}%
\(\cos(\arctan(x)) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1519}{}\hypertarget{p-2318}{}%
\(r'(x) = \frac{1}{1+x^2}\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-127}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2319}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1520}{}\hypertarget{p-2320}{}%
Since \(r(x) = \arctan(x)\), it is equivalent to write \(\tan(r(x)) = x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1521}{}\hypertarget{p-2321}{}%
Differentiating, we have \(\frac{d}{dx}[\tan(r(x))] = \frac{d}{dx}[x]\), so%
\begin{equation*}
\sec^2(r(x)) r'(x) = 1\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and thus%
\begin{equation*}
r'(x) = \frac{1}{\sec^2(r(x))} = \cos^2(r(x))\text{,}
\end{equation*}
since \(\frac{1}{\sec(\alpha)} = \cos(\alpha)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1522}{}\hypertarget{p-2322}{}%
Since \(r(x) = \arctan(x)\), we now have that \(r'(x) = \cos^2(\arctan(x))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1523}{}\hypertarget{p-2323}{}%
Letting \(\theta = \arctan(x)\), it follows that we can view \(\theta\) as an angle in a right triangle with legs \(1\) and \(x\) (so that \(\tan(\theta) = \frac{x}{1}\), and thus by the Pythagorean Theorem, the triangle's hypotenuse is \(\sqrt{1+x^2}\), as shown below.%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)
{% begin: group for a single side-by-side
% set panel max height to practical minimum, created in preamble
\setlength{\panelmax}{0pt}
\ifdefined\panelboxAimage\else\newsavebox{\panelboxAimage}\fi%
\begin{lrbox}{\panelboxAimage}
\includegraphics[width=0.33\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_6_cosarctan.pdf}
\end{lrbox}
\ifdefined\phAimage\else\newlength{\phAimage}\fi%
\setlength{\phAimage}{\ht\panelboxAimage+\dp\panelboxAimage}
\settototalheight{\phAimage}{\usebox{\panelboxAimage}}
\setlength{\panelmax}{\maxof{\panelmax}{\phAimage}}
\leavevmode%
% begin: side-by-side as tabular
% \tabcolsep change local to group
\setlength{\tabcolsep}{0\linewidth}
% @{} suppress \tabcolsep at extremes, so margins behave as intended
\par\medskip\noindent
\hspace*{0.335\linewidth}%
\begin{tabular}{@{}*{1}{c}@{}}
\begin{minipage}[c][\panelmax][t]{0.33\linewidth}\usebox{\panelboxAimage}\end{minipage}\end{tabular}\\
% end: side-by-side as tabular
}% end: group for a single side-by-side
\item\hypertarget{li-1524}{}\hypertarget{p-2324}{}%
To evaluate \(\cos(\arctan(x))\), we use the right triangle developed in (d) and observe that%
\begin{equation*}
\cos(\arctan(x)) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1525}{}\hypertarget{p-2325}{}%
Finally, we recall that we know \(r'(x) = \cos^2(\arctan(x)) = \left( \cos(\arctan(x)) \right)^2\). Having established that \(\cos(\arctan(x)) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}\), we now have that%
\begin{equation*}
r'(x) = \frac{1}{1+x^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-2326}{}%
\index{derivative!arctangent} \begin{assemblage}[Derivative of the Inverse Tangent]\label{assemblage-69}
\hypertarget{p-2327}{}%
For all real numbers \(x\),%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}[\arctan(x)]=\frac1{1+x^2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2328}{}%
While derivatives for other inverse trigonometric functions can be established similarly, for now we limit ourselves to the arcsine and arctangent functions.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-2-6-3}
\hypertarget{p-2329}{}%
Determine the derivative of each of the following functions. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1526}{}\hypertarget{p-2330}{}%
\(\displaystyle f(x) = x^3 \arctan(x) + e^x \ln(x)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1527}{}\hypertarget{p-2331}{}%
\(\displaystyle p(t) = 2^{t\arcsin(t)}\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1528}{}\hypertarget{p-2332}{}%
\(\displaystyle h(z) = (\arcsin(5z) + \arctan(4-z))^{27}\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1529}{}\hypertarget{p-2333}{}%
\(\displaystyle s(y) = \cot(\arctan(y))\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1530}{}\hypertarget{p-2334}{}%
\(\displaystyle m(v) = \ln(\sin^2(v)+1)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1531}{}\hypertarget{p-2335}{}%
\(\displaystyle g(w) = \arctan\left( \frac{\ln(w)}{1+w^2} \right)\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-62}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2336}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1532}{}\hypertarget{p-2337}{}%
Use the sum rule, followed by the product rule on each term in the sum.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1533}{}\hypertarget{p-2338}{}%
Use the chain rule first. What rule is needed to differentiate \(t\arcsin(t)\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1534}{}\hypertarget{p-2339}{}%
Note that the chain rule is needed to differentiate \(\arcsin(5z)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1535}{}\hypertarget{p-2340}{}%
You can use right triangle trigonometry to simplify the function first.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1536}{}\hypertarget{p-2341}{}%
Use the chain rule twice.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1537}{}\hypertarget{p-2342}{}%
Think about the overall structure of this function.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-102}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2343}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1538}{}\hypertarget{p-2344}{}%
\(f'(x) = \left[3x^2\arctan(x)+x^3 \cdot \frac{1}{1+x^2}\right] + \left[e^x\ln(x)+e^x \cdot \frac{1}{x}\right]\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1539}{}\hypertarget{p-2345}{}%
\(p'(t) = 2^{t\arcsin(t)} \ln(2) \left[\arcsin(t)+t \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-t^2}}\right]\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1540}{}\hypertarget{p-2346}{}%
\(h'(z) = 27\left(\arcsin(5z) + \arctan(4-z)\right)^{26} \left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-(5z)^2}} \cdot 5 + \frac{1}{1+(4-z)^2} \cdot (-1) \right]\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1541}{}\hypertarget{p-2347}{}%
\(s'(y) = -\frac{1}{y^2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1542}{}\hypertarget{p-2348}{}%
\(m'(v) = \frac{1}{\sin^2(v)+1} \cdot \left[ 2\sin(v)\cos(v) \right]\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1543}{}\hypertarget{p-2349}{}%
\(g'(w) = \frac{1}{1+ \left( \frac{\ln(w)}{1+w^2} \right)^2} \cdot \left[ \frac{\frac{1}{w}(1+w^2) - \ln(w) 2w}{(1+w^2)^2} \right] \).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-128}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2350}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1544}{}\hypertarget{p-2351}{}%
By the sum rule followed by two applications of the product rule,%
\begin{align*}
f'(x) =\mathstrut \amp  \frac{d}{dx}[x^3 \arctan(x)] + \frac{d}{dx}[e^x \ln(x)]\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \left[3x^2\arctan(x)+x^3 \cdot \frac{1}{1+x^2}\right] + \left[e^x\ln(x)+e^x \cdot \frac{1}{x}\right]\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1545}{}\hypertarget{p-2352}{}%
Using the chain rule followed by the product rule,%
\begin{align*}
p'(t) =\mathstrut \amp  2^{t\arcsin(t)} \ln(2) \frac{d}{dt}[t\arcsin(t)]\\
=\mathstrut \amp  2^{t\arcsin(t)} \ln(2) \left[\arcsin(t)+t \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-t^2}}\right]\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1546}{}\hypertarget{p-2353}{}%
Applying the chain rule twice,%
\begin{align*}
h'(z) =\mathstrut \amp  27\big(\arcsin(5z) + \arctan(4-z)\big)^{26} \frac{d}{dz}\left[\arcsin(5z) + \arctan(4-z)\right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp  27\left(\arcsin(5z) + \arctan(4-z)\right)^{26} \left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-(5z)^2}} \cdot \frac{d}{dz}[5z] + \frac{1}{1+(4-z)^2} \cdot \frac{d}{dz}[4-z] \right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp  27\left(\arcsin(5z) + \arctan(4-z)\right)^{26} \left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-(5z)^2}} \cdot 5 + \frac{1}{1+(4-z)^2} \cdot (-1) \right]\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1547}{}\hypertarget{p-2354}{}%
Using right triangle trigonometry, it is straightforward to show that \(\cot(\arctan(y)) = \frac{1}{y}\). As such, \(s'(y) = -\frac{1}{y^2}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1548}{}\hypertarget{p-2355}{}%
By two applications of the chain rule (noting particularly that \(\sin^2(v) = (\sin(v))^2\), we have%
\begin{align*}
m'(v) =\mathstrut \amp  \frac{1}{\sin^2(v)+1} \cdot \frac{d}{dv} \left[ \sin^2(v) + 1 \right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp \frac{1}{\sin^2(v)+1}\cdot \left[2\sin(v)\frac{d}{dv}[\sin(v)]\right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \frac{1}{\sin^2(v)+1} \cdot \left[ 2\sin(v)\cos(v) \right]\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1549}{}\hypertarget{p-2356}{}%
By the chain rule followed by the quotient rule,%
\begin{align*}
g'(w) =\mathstrut \amp  \frac{1}{1+ \left( \frac{\ln(w)}{1+w^2} \right)^2} \cdot \frac{d}{dw} \left[ \frac{\ln(w)}{1+w^2} \right]\\
=\mathstrut \amp  \frac{1}{1+ \left( \frac{\ln(w)}{1+w^2} \right)^2} \cdot \left[ \frac{\frac{1}{w}(1+w^2) - \ln(w) 2w}{(1+w^2)^2} \right]\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.6.4 The Link Between the Derivative of a Function and the Derivative of its Inverse}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{The Link Between the Derivative of a Function and the Derivative of its Inverse}]{The Link Between the Derivative of a Function and the Derivative of its Inverse}\label{subsection-69}
\hypertarget{p-2357}{}%
Earlier, we saw in \hyperref[F-2-6-Log-Exp]{Figure~\ref{F-2-6-Log-Exp}} an interesting relationship between the slopes of tangent lines to the natural exponential and natural logarithm functions at points reflected across the line \(y = x\). In particular, we observed that at the point \((\ln(2), 2)\) on the graph of \(f(x) = e^x\), the slope of the tangent line is \(f'(\ln(2)) = 2\), while at the corresponding point \((2, \ln(2))\) on the graph of \(f^{-1}(x) = \ln(x)\), the slope of the tangent line is \((f^{-1})'(2) = \frac{1}{2}\), which is the reciprocal of \(f'(\ln(2))\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2358}{}%
That the two corresponding tangent lines have reciprocal slopes is not a coincidence. If \(f\) and \(g\) are differentiable inverse functions, then \(y = f(x)\) if and only if \(x = g(y)\), and thus \(f(g(x)) = x\) for every \(x\) in the domain of \(f^{-1}\). Differentiating both sides of this equation, we have%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} [f(g(x))] = \frac{d}{dx} [x]\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and by the chain rule,%
\begin{equation*}
f'(g(x)) g'(x) = 1\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2359}{}%
Solving for \(g'(x)\), we have \(g'(x) = \frac{1}{f'(g(x))}\). Here we see that the slope of the tangent line to the inverse function \(g\) at the point \((x,g(x))\) is precisely the reciprocal of the slope of the tangent line to the original function \(f\) at the point \((g(x),f(g(x))) = (g(x),x)\).%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_6_GenInv.pdf}
\caption{A graph of a function \(y = f(x)\) along with its inverse \(y = g(x) = f^{-1}(x)\).  Observe that the slopes of the two tangent lines are reciprocals of one another.\label{F-2-6-Gen-Inv}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-2360}{}%
To see this more clearly, consider the graph of the function \(y = f(x)\) shown above in \hyperref[F-2-6-Gen-Inv]{Figure~\ref{F-2-6-Gen-Inv}} along with its inverse \(y = g(x)\). Given a point \((a,b)\) that lies on the graph of \(f\), we know that \((b,a)\) lies on the graph of \(g\) because \(f(a) = b\) and \(g(b) = a\). Applying the rule that \(g'(x) = \frac{1}{f'(g(x))}\) to the value \(x = b\) yields the equation%
\begin{equation*}
g'(b) = \frac{1}{f'(g(b))} = \frac{1}{f'(a)}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
which is precisely what we see in the figure: the slope of the tangent line to \(g\) at \((b,a)\) is the reciprocal of the slope of the tangent line to \(f\) at \((a,b)\), since these two lines are reflections of one another across the line \(y = x\).  More generally, for any \(x\) in the domain of \(g'\), we have \(g'(x) = \frac{1}{f'(g(x))}\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2361}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Derivative of an Inverse Function]\label{inverse-function}
\hypertarget{p-2362}{}%
\index{derivative!inverse function} Suppose that \(f\) is a differentiable function with inverse \(f^{-1}\) and that \(f'(f^{-1}(x)) \ne 0\). Then%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}[f^{-1}(x)] = \frac{1}{f'(f^{-1}(x))}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2363}{}%
The rules we derived for \(\ln(x)\), \(\arcsin(x)\), and \(\arctan(x)\) are all just specific examples of this general property of the derivative of an inverse function. For example, with \(g(x) = \ln(x)\) and \(f(x) = e^x\), it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
g'(x) = \frac{1}{f'(g(x))} = \frac{1}{e^{\ln(x)}} = \frac{1}{x}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-116}
\hypertarget{p-2364}{}%
Suppose \(f\) is an invertible function described by \hyperref[ex-T-inv-val]{Table~\ref{ex-T-inv-val}} below.%
\begin{table}
\centering
\begin{tabular}{llllll}
\multicolumn{1}{lB}{\(x\)}&-2&-1&0&1&2\tabularnewline\hrulemedium
\multicolumn{1}{lB}{\(f(x)\)}&3&2&4&5&1\tabularnewline[0pt]
\multicolumn{1}{lB}{\(f'(x)\)}&1&2&5&2&4
\end{tabular}
\caption{Table of values describing \(f(x)\) and \(f'(x)\).\label{ex-T-inv-val}}
\end{table}
\hypertarget{p-2365}{}%
Then%
\begin{equation*}
\left. \frac{df^{-1}}{dx}\right\vert_{x=1}=\frac{1}{f'(f^{-1}(1))}.
\end{equation*}
Now, \(f^{-1}(1)=2\) and \(f'(2)=4\).  Therefore,%
\begin{equation*}
\left. \frac{df^{-1}}{dx}\right\vert_{x=1}=\frac{1}{f'(f^{-1}(1))}=\frac{1}{f'(2)}=\frac{1}{4}.
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.6.5 Summary}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Summary}]{Summary}\label{subsection-70}
\hypertarget{p-2366}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2367}{}%
For all positive real numbers \(x\), \(\frac{d}{dx}[\ln(x)] = \frac{1}{x}\).%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2368}{}%
For all real numbers \(x\) such that \(-1 \lt x \lt 1\), \(\frac{d}{dx}[\arcsin(x)] = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\). In addition, for all real numbers \(x\), \(\frac{d}{dx}[\arctan(x)] = \frac{1}{1+x^2}\).%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2369}{}%
If \(g\) is the inverse of a differentiable function \(f\), then for any point \(x\) in the domain of \(g'\), \(g'(x) = \frac{1}{f'(g(x))}\).%
\end{itemize}
%

\subsection[{Exercises}]{Exercises}\label{exercises-17}
\begin{exerciselist}
\item[1.]\hypertarget{ez-2-6-WW1}{}(Composite function involving logarithms and polynomials)\space\space{}\item[2.]\hypertarget{ez-2-6-WW2}{}(Composite function involving trigonometric functions and logarithms)\space\space{}\item[3.]\hypertarget{ez-2-6-WW3}{}(Product involving \(\arcsin(w)\))\space\space{}\item[4.]\hypertarget{ez-2-6-WW4}{}(Derivative involving \(\arctan(x)\))\space\space{}\item[5.]\hypertarget{ez-2-6-WW5}{}(Composite function from a graph)\space\space{}\item[6.]\hypertarget{ez-2-6-WW6}{}(Composite function involving an inverse trigonometric function)\space\space{}\item[7.]\hypertarget{ez-2-6-WW7}{}(Mixing rules: product, chain, and inverse trig)\space\space{}\item[8.]\hypertarget{ez-2-6-WW8}{}(Mixing rules: product and inverse trig)\space\space{}\item[9.]\hypertarget{exercise-150}{}(Mixing rules: chain, product, logarithms, and inverse trig)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-2370}{}%
Determine the derivative of each of the following functions. Use proper notation and clearly identify the derivative rules you use. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1553}{}\hypertarget{p-2371}{}%
\(f(x) = \ln(2\arctan(x) + 3\arcsin(x) + 5)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1554}{}\hypertarget{p-2372}{}%
\(r(z) = \arctan(\ln(\arcsin(z)))\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1555}{}\hypertarget{p-2373}{}%
\(q(t) = \arctan^2(3t) \arcsin^4(7t)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-1556}{}\hypertarget{p-2374}{}%
\(g(v) = \ln\left( \frac{\arctan(v)}{\arcsin(v) + v^2} \right)\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-103}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2375}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1557}{}\hypertarget{p-2376}{}%
\(f'(x) = \frac{1}{2\arctan(x) + 3\arcsin(x) + 5} \cdot \left(\frac{2}{1+x^2} + \frac{3}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\right)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1558}{}\hypertarget{p-2377}{}%
\(r'(z) = \frac{1}{1+\left(\ln(\arcsin(z))\right)^2} \cdot \left( \frac{1}{\arcsin(z)} \right) \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-z^2}}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1559}{}\hypertarget{p-2378}{}%
\(q'(t) = \arctan^2(3t) \cdot \left[4\arcsin^3(7t) \left( \frac{7}{\sqrt{1+(7t)^2}} \right)\right] + \arcsin^4(7t) \cdot \left[2\arctan(3t) \left(\frac{3}{1+(3t)^2}\right) \right]\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1560}{}\hypertarget{p-2379}{}%
\(g'(v) = \frac{1}{\frac{\arctan(v)}{\arcsin(v) + v^2}} \cdot \frac{(\arcsin(v) + v^2) \cdot \frac{1}{1+v^2} - \arctan(v) \cdot \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-v^2}} + 2v \right)}{(\arcsin(v) + v^2)^2} \)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-129}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2380}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1561}{}\hypertarget{p-2381}{}%
By the chain rule,%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \frac{1}{2\arctan(x) + 3\arcsin(x) + 5} \cdot \frac{d}{dx}\left( 2\arctan(x) + 3\arcsin(x) + 5\right)\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and by the sum and constant multiple rules, it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(x) = \frac{1}{2\arctan(x) + 3\arcsin(x) + 5} \cdot \left(\frac{2}{1+x^2} + \frac{3}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1562}{}\hypertarget{p-2382}{}%
By the chain rule applied to the outermost function,%
\begin{equation*}
r'(z) = \frac{1}{1+\left(\ln(\arcsin(z))\right)^2} \cdot \frac{d}{dz} \left( \ln(\arcsin(z)) \right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Applying the chain rule again to evaluate \(\frac{d}{dz} \left( \ln(\arcsin(z)) \right)\),%
\begin{equation*}
r'(z) = \frac{1}{1+\left(\ln(\arcsin(z))\right)^2} \cdot \left( \frac{1}{\arcsin(z)} \right) \cdot \frac{d}{dz}\left(\arcsin(z)\right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Finally, using the basic rule for \(\frac{d}{dz}\left(\arcsin(z)\right)\),%
\begin{equation*}
r'(z) = \frac{1}{1+\left(\ln(\arcsin(z))\right)^2} \cdot \left( \frac{1}{\arcsin(z)} \right) \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-z^2}}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1563}{}\hypertarget{p-2383}{}%
First, by the product rule,%
\begin{equation*}
q'(t) = \arctan^2(3t) \cdot \frac{d}{dt}\left(\arcsin^4(7t)\right) +  \arcsin^4(7t) \cdot \frac{d}{dt}\left(\arctan^2(3t)\right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Next, we recall that \(\arcsin^4(7t) = \left(\arcsin(7t)\right)^4\) and \(\arctan^2(3t) = \left( \arctan(3t) \right)^2\), and apply the chain rule to find the derivative of each of these functions to get%
\begin{equation*}
q'(t) = \arctan^2(3t) \cdot \left[4\arcsin^3(7t) \frac{d}{dt}\left( \arcsin(7t) \right)\right] +  \arcsin^4(7t) \cdot \left[2\arctan(3t) \frac{d}{dt}\left(\arctan(3t)\right) \right] \text{.}
\end{equation*}
Finally, applying the chain rule one more time to evaluate the remaining derivatives,%
\begin{equation*}
q'(t) = \arctan^2(3t) \cdot \left[4\arcsin^3(7t) \left( \frac{7}{\sqrt{1+(7t)^2}} \right)\right] +  \arcsin^4(7t) \cdot \left[2\arctan(3t) \left(\frac{3}{1+(3t)^2}\right) \right]\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1564}{}\hypertarget{p-2384}{}%
By the chain rule,%
\begin{equation*}
g'(v) = \frac{1}{ \frac{\arctan(v)}{\arcsin(v) + v^2} } \cdot \frac{d}{dv}\left[ \frac{\arctan(v)}{\arcsin(v) + v^2} \right]
\end{equation*}
Thus, by the quotient rule,%
\begin{equation*}
g'(v) = \frac{1}{\frac{\arctan(v)}{\arcsin(v) + v^2}} \cdot \frac{(\arcsin(v) + v^2) \cdot \frac{1}{1+v^2} - \arctan(v) \cdot \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-v^2}} + 2v \right)}{(\arcsin(v) + v^2)^2}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%

Because the original function passes through the point \((1,-1)\), the inverse function passes through \((-1,1)\). Moreover, since the tangent line to the original function at \((1,-1)\) has slope \(f'(1) \approx 2\), and the tangent line to the inverse function at \((-1,1)\) corresponds to the reflection of the original tangent line across the line \(y=x\), it follows that \(f'(-1) \approx 1/2\). This can also be deduced from the ``derivative of an inverse function'' rule, whereby \(f'(-1) = \frac{1}{f'(1)}\).%
