\typeout{Section 2.9 The Tangent Line Approximation}
\typeout{************************************************}
\section[{The Tangent Line Approximation}]{The Tangent Line Approximation}\label{sec-1-8-tan-line-approx}
\begin{objectives}{Motivating Questions}\label{objectives-17}
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2593}{}%
What is the formula for the general tangent line approximation to a differentiable function \(y = f(x)\) at the point \((a,f(a))\)?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2594}{}%
What is the principle of local linearity and what is the local linearization of a differentiable function \(f\) at a point \((a,f(a))\)?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2595}{}%
How does knowing just the tangent line approximation tell us information about the behavior of the original function itself near the point of approximation? How does knowing the second derivative's value at this point provide us additional knowledge of the original function's behavior?%
\end{itemize}
\end{objectives}
\hypertarget{p-2596}{}%
Among all functions, linear functions are simplest. One of the powerful consequences of a function \(y = f(x)\) being differentiable at a point \((a,f(a))\) is that up close the function \(y = f(x)\) is locally linear and looks like its tangent line at that point. In certain circumstances, this allows us to approximate the original function \(f\) with a simpler function \(L\) that is linear: this can be advantageous when we have limited information about \(f\) or when \(f\) is computationally or algebraically complicated. We will explore all of these situations in what follows.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2597}{}%
It is essential to recall that when \(f\) is differentiable at \(x = a\), the value of \(f'(a)\) provides the slope of the tangent line to \(y = f(x)\) at the point \((a,f(a))\). If we know both a point on the line and the slope of the line we can find the equation of the tangent line and write the equation in point-slope form.\footnote{Recall that a line with slope \(m\) that passes through \((x_0,y_0)\) has equation \(y - y_0 = m(x - x_0)\), and this is the \terminology{point-slope form} of the equation.\label{fn-24}}%
\begin{example}[]\label{PA-1-8}
\hypertarget{p-2598}{}%
Consider the function \(g(x) = -x^2+3x+2\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2599}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1696}{}\hypertarget{p-2600}{}%
Use the limit definition of the derivative to compute a formula for \(g'(x)\). Check your work using the derivative rules that have been developed throughout this chapter.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1697}{}\hypertarget{p-2601}{}%
Determine the slope of the tangent line to the graph of \(y = g(x)\) at the value \(x = 2\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1698}{}\hypertarget{p-2602}{}%
Compute \(g(2)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1699}{}\hypertarget{p-2603}{}%
Find an equation for the tangent line to the graph of \(y = g(x)\) at the point \((2,g(2))\). Write your result in point-slope form.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1700}{}\hypertarget{p-2604}{}%
 Sketch an accurate, labeled graph of \(y = g(x)\) on the interval \(-1\le x\le4\). On the same axes, sketch its tangent line at the point \((2,g(2))\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-68}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2605}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1701}{}\hypertarget{p-2606}{}%
Recall the limit definition of the derivative from \hyperref[C-1]{Chapter~\ref{C-1}}.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1702}{}\hypertarget{p-2607}{}%
How does the slope of the tangent line relate to the value of the derivative?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1703}{}\hypertarget{p-2608}{}%
Use the given formula for \(g\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1704}{}\hypertarget{p-2609}{}%
Use your answers to (b) and (c).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1705}{}\hypertarget{p-2610}{}%
\(g\) is quadratic, so its graph is a parabola (opening downward).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-115}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2611}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1706}{}\hypertarget{p-2612}{}%
\(g'(x)=-2x+3\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1707}{}\hypertarget{p-2613}{}%
\(g'(2)=-1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1708}{}\hypertarget{p-2614}{}%
\(g(2)=4\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1709}{}\hypertarget{p-2615}{}%
\(y-4=-1(x-2)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1710}{}\hypertarget{p-2616}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.4\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_9_intro_soln.jpg}
\caption{The graph of \(y=g(x)\) along with its tangent line \(L\) at the point \((2,4)\), where \(g(x)=-x^2+3x+2\).\label{figure-104}}
\end{figure}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-141}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2617}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1711}{}\hypertarget{p-2618}{}%
Since the limit definition of the derivative says that%
\begin{equation*}
g'(x)=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{g(x+h)-g(x)}{h}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
we first compute%
\begin{align*}
g(x+h)=\mathstrut \amp -(x+h)^2+3(x+h)+2\\
=\mathstrut \amp -(x^2+2xh+h^2)+3x+3h+2\\
=\mathstrut \amp -x^2-2xh-h^2+3x+3h+2\\
=\mathstrut \amp (-x^2+3x+2)-2xh-h^2+3h\\
=\mathstrut \amp g(x)-2xh-h^2+3h\text{.}
\end{align*}
Then we find that%
\begin{align*}
g'(x)=\mathstrut \amp \lim_{h\to0}\frac{g(x+h)-g(x)}{h}\\
=\mathstrut \amp \lim_{h\to0}\frac{(g(x)-2xh-h^2+3h)-g(x)}{h}\\
=\mathstrut \amp \lim_{h\to0}\frac{-2xh-h^2+3h}{h}\\
=\mathstrut \amp \lim_{h\to0}(-2x-h+3)\\
=\mathstrut \amp -2x+3\text{.}
\end{align*}
This agrees with the derivative we obtain by applying the power rule together with the sum and constant multiple rules.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1712}{}\hypertarget{p-2619}{}%
Since the slope of the tangent line at a point is the value of the derivative at that point, we have the slope as%
\begin{equation*}
g'(2)=-2(2)+3=-1\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1713}{}\hypertarget{p-2620}{}%
Evaluating \(g(x)\) at \(x=2\), we find%
\begin{equation*}
g(2)=-(2)^2+3(2)+2=4\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1714}{}\hypertarget{p-2621}{}%
Using the slope of \(-1\) that we found in part (b) together with the value \(g(2)=4\) found in (c), the tangent line to \(y=g(x)\) at \((2,4)\) is%
\begin{equation*}
y-4=-1(x-2)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1715}{}\hypertarget{p-2622}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.4\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_9_intro_soln.jpg}
\caption{The graph of \(y=g(x)\) along with its tangent line \(L\) at the point \((2,4)\), where \(g(x)=-x^2+3x+2\).\label{figure-105}}
\end{figure}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.9.1 The Tangent Line}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{The Tangent Line}]{The Tangent Line}\label{subsection-78}
\hypertarget{p-2623}{}%
Given a function \(f\) that is differentiable at \(x = a\), we know that we can determine the slope of the tangent line to \(y = f(x)\) at \((a,f(a))\) by computing \(f'(a)\). \begin{assemblage}[The Tangent Line]\label{assemblage-76}
\hypertarget{p-2624}{}%
The equation of the resulting tangent line \index{tangent line!equation} is given in point-slope form by%
\begin{equation*}
y - f(a) = f'(a)(x-a) \text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\begin{warning}[]\label{warning-3}
\hypertarget{p-2625}{}%
Note: there is a major difference between \(f(a)\) and \(f(x)\) in this context. The former is a constant that results from using the given fixed value of \(a\), while the latter is the general expression for the rule that defines the function. The same is true for \(f'(a)\) and \(f'(x)\): we must carefully distinguish between these expressions. Each time we find the tangent line, we need to evaluate the function and its derivative at a fixed \(a\)-value.%
\end{warning}
\hypertarget{p-2626}{}%
In \hyperref[F-1-8-TanLine]{Figure~\ref{F-1-8-TanLine}} below, we see the graph of a function \(f\) and its tangent line at the point \((a,f(a))\). Notice how when we zoom in we see the local linearity of \(f\) more clearly highlighted. The function and its tangent line are nearly indistinguishable up close. Local linearity can also be seen dynamically in the java applet at \href{http://gvsu.edu/s/6J}{http://gvsu.edu/s/6J}.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/1-8-TanLines.gif}
\caption{The graph of a function \(y = f(x)\) and its tangent line at the point \((a,f(a))\): at left, from a distance, and at right, up close. If we let \(L(x)=f'(a)(x-a)+f(a)\) denote the tangent line function, then we observe in the right image that for \(x\) near \(a\), \(f(x) \approx L(x)\).\label{F-1-8-TanLine}}
\end{figure}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.9.2 The Local Linearization}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{The Local Linearization}]{The Local Linearization}\label{subsection-79}
\hypertarget{p-2627}{}%
A slight change in perspective and notation will enable us to be more precise in discussing how the tangent line approximates \(f(x)\) near \(x = a\). By solving for \(y\), we can write the equation for the tangent line as%
\begin{equation*}
y = f'(a)(x-a) + f(a)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
This line is itself a function of \(x\). Replacing the variable \(y\) with the expression \(L(x)\), we have the following. \begin{assemblage}[Local Linearization]\label{assemblage-77}
\hypertarget{p-2628}{}%
We call%
\begin{equation*}
L(x) = f'(a)(x-a) + f(a)
\end{equation*}
the \terminology{local linearization of \(f\) \index{local linearization} \index{tangent line approximation} at the point \((a,f(a))\)}.%
\end{assemblage}
 In this notation, \(L(x)\) is nothing more than a "new name" for the tangent line. As we saw above, for \(x\) close to \(a\), \(f(x) \approx L(x)\). For this reason, \(L(x)\) is also called the \terminology{tangent line approximation to \(f\) at \((a,f(a))\)}.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-127}
\hypertarget{p-2629}{}%
Suppose that all we know about a function \(f\) is that its tangent line approximation at the point \((1,3)\) is given by \(L(x) = 3 - 2(x-1)\). To estimate a value of \(f(x)\) for \(x\) near \(1\), such as \(f(1.2)\), we can use the fact that \(f(1.2) \approx L(1.2)\). Hence%
\begin{equation*}
f(1.2) \approx L(1.2) = 3 - 2(1.2-1) = 3 - 2(0.2) = 2.6\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[Error in a Tangent Line Approximation]\label{example-128}
\hypertarget{p-2630}{}%
Consider the function \(p(t)=\ln(t)\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item\hypertarget{li-1716}{}\hypertarget{p-2631}{}%
Find the local linearization, \(L(t)\), of \(p\) at \(t=1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1717}{}\hypertarget{p-2632}{}%
Use the tangent line approximation from (a) to estimate the value of \(\ln(1.01)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1718}{}\hypertarget{p-2633}{}%
Use the tangent line approximation from (a) to estimate the value of \(\ln(1.3)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1719}{}\hypertarget{p-2634}{}%
\index{local linearization!error} \index{tangent line approximation!error} The error of an approximation is the difference between the true value and the estimated value. In particular, given a function \(f\) and its local linearization \(L(x)\) at \((a,f(a))\), we say the \terminology{error of the tangent line approximation} is%
\begin{align*}
E(x)\amp=f(x)-L(x)\\
\amp=f(x)-f(a)-f'(a)(x-a)\text{,}
\end{align*}
for values of \(x\) near \(a\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2635}{}%
Of the two estimates you found in (b) and (c), which do you expect to be more accurate? Why? Check your guess by calculating and comparing \(E(1.01)\) and \(E(1.3)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-69}{}\quad%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item\hypertarget{li-1720}{}\hypertarget{p-2636}{}%
Start by finding \(\frac{d}{dt}[\ln(t)]\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1721}{}\hypertarget{p-2637}{}%
By construction of \(L(t)\), we know that \(p(1.01)\approx L(1.01)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1722}{}\hypertarget{p-2638}{}%
Remember that \(p(1.3)\approx L(1.3)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1723}{}\hypertarget{p-2639}{}%
The approximation should be best close to \(t=1\). Note \(E(1)=0\) since \(p(1)=L(1)\).%
\end{enumerate}
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-116}{}\quad%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item\hypertarget{li-1724}{}\hypertarget{p-2640}{}%
\(L(t)=t-1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1725}{}\hypertarget{p-2641}{}%
\(\ln(1.01)\approx0.01\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1726}{}\hypertarget{p-2642}{}%
\(\ln(1.3)\approx0.3\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1727}{}\hypertarget{p-2643}{}%
We expect \(|E(1.3)|>|E(1.01)|\). Indeed, \(E(1.01)=\ln(1.01)-0.01\approx-0.00005\), whereas \(E(1.3)=\ln(1.3)-0.3\approx-0.0376\).%
\end{enumerate}
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-142}{}\quad%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item\hypertarget{li-1728}{}\hypertarget{p-2644}{}%
We start by computing \(p'(t)\), and then evaluating \(p(1)\) and \(p'(1)\). Since \(p(t)=\ln(t)\), the derivative is \(p'(t)=\frac1t\). Furthermore, we have \(p(1)=\ln(1)=0\) and \(p'(1)=\frac11=1\). Thus, the local linearization of \(p(t)=\ln(t)\) at the point \((1,0)\) is%
\begin{equation*}
L(t)=p(1)+p'(1)(t-1)=0+1(t-1)=t-1\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1729}{}\hypertarget{p-2645}{}%
Since we can use the tangent line approximation for \(p\) at \((1,0)\) to estimate output values of \(p\) at nearby points, it follows that \(p(1.01)\approx L(1.01)\). Thus we have%
\begin{equation*}
\ln(1.01)\approx0.01\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1730}{}\hypertarget{p-2646}{}%
Since we can use the tangent line approximation for \(p\) at \((1,0)\) to estimate output values of \(p\) at nearby points, it follows that \(p(1.3)\approx L(1.3)\). Thus we have%
\begin{equation*}
\ln(1.3)\approx0.3\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1731}{}\hypertarget{p-2647}{}%
Since \(1.3\) is farther away from the point of tangency \((t=1)\) than \(1.01\) is, we expect the estimate to be better for \(1.01\). We confirm this by computing the error at each point, finding that%
\begin{align*}
E(1.01)\amp=p(1.01)-L(1.01)\\
\amp=\ln(1.01)-0.01\\
\amp\approx-0.0000497,\\
\text{and} \ \ E(1.3)\amp=p(1.3)-L(1.3)\\
\amp=\ln(1.3)-0.3\\
\amp\approx-0.0376357\text{.}
\end{align*}
As expected, the error grew as the point moved farther from the initial point of tangency.%
\end{enumerate}
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-2648}{}%
We emphasize that \(L(x)\) is simply a new name for the tangent line function. Using this new notation and our observation that \(L(x) \approx f(x)\) for \(x\) near \(a\), it follows that we can write%
\begin{equation*}
f(x) \approx f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) \ \text{for}  \  x \ \text{near}  \ a\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-1-8-1}
\hypertarget{p-2649}{}%
Suppose it is known that for a given differentiable function \(y = g(x)\), its local linearization at the point where \(a = -1\) is given by \(L(x) = -2 + 3(x+1)\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1732}{}\hypertarget{p-2650}{}%
Compute the values of \(L(-1)\) and \(L'(-1)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1733}{}\hypertarget{p-2651}{}%
What must be the values of \(g(-1)\) and \(g'(-1)\)? Why?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1734}{}\hypertarget{p-2652}{}%
Do you expect the value of \(g(-1.03)\) to be greater than or less than the value of \(g(-1)\)? Why?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1735}{}\hypertarget{p-2653}{}%
Use the local linearization to estimate the value of \(g(-1.03)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1736}{}\hypertarget{p-2654}{}%
Suppose that you also know that \(g''(-1) = 2\). What does this tell you about the graph of \(y = g(x)\) at \(x = -1\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1737}{}\hypertarget{p-2655}{}%
For \(x\) near \(-1\), sketch the graph of the local linearization \(y = L(x)\) as well as a possible graph of \(y = g(x)\). %
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-70}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2656}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1738}{}\hypertarget{p-2657}{}%
Use the formula for \(L\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1739}{}\hypertarget{p-2658}{}%
Recall that the form of the local linearization is \(L(x) = g(a) + g'(a)(x-a)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1740}{}\hypertarget{p-2659}{}%
Is the function \(g\) increasing or decreasing at \(a = -1\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1741}{}\hypertarget{p-2660}{}%
Remember that \(g(-1.03) \approx L(-1.03)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1742}{}\hypertarget{p-2661}{}%
What does the second derivative tell you about the shape of a curve?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1743}{}\hypertarget{p-2662}{}%
Use your work above.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-117}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2663}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1744}{}\hypertarget{p-2664}{}%
\(L(-1) = -2\); \(L'(-1) = 3\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1745}{}\hypertarget{p-2665}{}%
\(g(-1) = -2\); \(g'(-1) = 3\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1746}{}\hypertarget{p-2666}{}%
We expect \(g(-1.03)\lt g(-1)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1747}{}\hypertarget{p-2667}{}%
\(g(-1.03) \approx L(-1.03) = -2.09\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1748}{}\hypertarget{p-2668}{}%
\(g\) is concave up at \(x=-1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1749}{}\hypertarget{p-2669}{}%
The illustration below shows a possible graph of \(y = g(x)\) near \(x = -1\), along with the tangent line \(y = L(x)\) through \((-1, g(-1))\).%

\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-143}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2670}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1750}{}\hypertarget{p-2671}{}%
Using the formula for \(L\), we see that \(L(-1) = -2\). Furthermore, since \(L'(x) = 3\), we have \(L'(-1) = 3\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1751}{}\hypertarget{p-2672}{}%
Since%
\begin{equation*}
L(x) = g(-1) + g'(-1)(x+1) = -2 + 3(x+1)\text{,}
\end{equation*}
we see \(g(-1) = -2\) and \(g'(-1) = 3\). Alternatively, we could observe that the value and slope of \(g\) must match the value and slope of \(L\) at the point of tangency.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1752}{}\hypertarget{p-2673}{}%
Because \(g'(-1) = 3\) is positive, we know that \(g\) is increasing at \(x = -1\). Then since \(-1.03\lt-1\), we expect \(g(-1.03)\lt g(-1)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1753}{}\hypertarget{p-2674}{}%
Observe that \(g(-1.03) \approx L(-1.03) = -2 + 3(-1.03+1) = -2 - 0.09 = -2.09\). As conjectured in (c), this value is less than \(g(-1)=-2\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1754}{}\hypertarget{p-2675}{}%
Since \(g''(-1) > 0\), we know \(g\) is concave up at \(x = -1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1755}{}\hypertarget{p-2676}{}%
In the figure below, we use the results of our previous work to generate the plot shown, which is a possible graph of \(y = g(x)\) near \(x = -1\), along with the tangent line \(y = L(x)\) through \((-1, g(-1))\). Notice that at \(x=-1\), the graph of \(y=g(x)\) is increasing and concave up, as discussed.%

\hypertarget{p-2677}{}%
\index{tangent line approximation!properties} \index{local linearization!properties} In \hyperref[act-1-8-1]{Example~\ref{act-1-8-1}}, we saw that the local linearization \(L\) is a linear function that shares two important values with the function \(f\) that it is derived from. In particular, \leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}because \(L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)\), it follows that \(L(a) = f(a)\); and%
\item{}because \(L\) is a linear function, its derivative is its slope. Hence, \(L'(x) = f'(a)\) for every value of \(x\), and specifically \(L'(a) = f'(a)\).%
\end{itemize}
 Therefore, we see that \(L\) is a linear function that has both the same value and the same slope as the function \(f\) at the point \((a,f(a))\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2678}{}%
Thus, if we know the linear approximation \(y = L(x)\) for a function \(f\), we know the original function's value and its slope at the point of tangency. What remains unknown, however, is the shape of the function \(f\) at the point of tangency. There are essentially four possibilities, as shown below in \hyperref[F-1-8-Options]{Figure~\ref{F-1-8-Options}}.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/1_8_Options.pdf}
\caption{Four possible graphs for a nonlinear differentiable function (in blue) and how it can be situated relative to its tangent line (in green) at a point. Note that these cases correspond to a tangent line with positive slope. There are four similar possibilities when the slope of the tangent line is negative or zero.\label{F-1-8-Options}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-2679}{}%
These possible shapes result from the fact that there are three options for the value of the second derivative: either \(f''(a) \lt 0\), \(f''(a) = 0\), or \(f''(a) \gt 0\). \leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}If \(f''(a) \gt 0\), then we know the graph of \(f\) is concave up, and we see the first possibility on the left, where the tangent line lies entirely below the curve.%
\item{}If \(f''(a) \lt 0\), then \(f\) is concave down and the tangent line lies above the curve, as shown in the second image.%
\item{}If \(f''(a) = 0\) and \(f''\) changes sign at \(x = a\), the concavity of the graph will change, and we will see either the third or fourth image.\footnote{It is possible that \(f''(a) = 0\) but \(f''\) does not change sign at \(x = a\), in which case the graph will look like one of the first two options.\label{fn-25}}%
\item{}A fifth option (which is not very interesting) can occur if the function \(f\) itself is linear, so that \(f''(x)=0\) and \(f(x) = L(x)\) for all values of \(x\).%
\end{itemize}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2680}{}%
The plots in \hyperref[F-1-8-Options]{Figure~\ref{F-1-8-Options}} highlight yet another important thing that we can learn from the concavity of the graph near the point of tangency: whether the tangent line lies above or below the curve itself. This is key because it tells us whether or not the tangent line approximation's values will be too large or too small in comparison to the true value of \(f\). For instance, in the leftmost plot in \hyperref[F-1-8-Options]{Figure~\ref{F-1-8-Options}} where \(f''(a) > 0\), we know that \(L(x) \le f(x)\) for all values of \(x\) near \(a\) because the tangent line falls below the curve.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-1-8-2}
\hypertarget{p-2681}{}%
This example concerns a function \(f(x)\) about which the following information is known: \leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2682}{}%
\(f\) is a differentiable function defined at every real number \(x\),%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2683}{}%
\(f(2) = -1\),%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2684}{}%
The graph of \(y = f'(x)\) is given below in \hyperref[F-1-8-Act2]{Figure~\ref{F-1-8-Act2}}.%
\end{itemize}
%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.4\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2_9_deriv-graph.jpg}
\caption{A graph of \(y = f'(x)\).\label{F-1-8-Act2}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-2685}{}%
Your task is to determine as much information as possible about \(f\) (especially near the value \(a = 2\)) by responding to the questions below. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1765}{}\hypertarget{p-2686}{}%
Find a formula for the tangent line approximation, \(L(x)\), to \(f\) at the point \((2,-1)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1766}{}\hypertarget{p-2687}{}%
Use the tangent line approximation to estimate the value of \(f(2.07)\). Show your work carefully and clearly.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1767}{}\hypertarget{p-2688}{}%
Sketch a graph of \(y = f''(x)\); label it appropriately.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1768}{}\hypertarget{p-2689}{}%
Is the slope of the tangent line to \(y = f(x)\) increasing, decreasing, or neither when \(x = 2\)? Explain.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1769}{}\hypertarget{p-2690}{}%
Sketch a possible graph of \(y = f(x)\) near \(x = 2\). Include a sketch of \(y=L(x)\) (found in part (a)). Explain how you know the graph of \(y = f(x)\) looks like you have drawn it.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1770}{}\hypertarget{p-2691}{}%
Does your estimate in (b) over- or under-estimate the true value of \(f(2.07)\)? Why?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-71}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2692}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1771}{}\hypertarget{p-2693}{}%
Find the value of \(f'(2)\) from the given graph of \(y=f'(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1772}{}\hypertarget{p-2694}{}%
Remember that \(f(2.07) \approx L(2.07)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1773}{}\hypertarget{p-2695}{}%
\(f''(x)\) is the derivative of \(f'(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1774}{}\hypertarget{p-2696}{}%
Is \(f'\) increasing, decreasing, or neither when \(x = 2\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1775}{}\hypertarget{p-2697}{}%
Draw \(y = L(x)\) first. Then think about options for \(f\) relative to the graph of \(L\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1776}{}\hypertarget{p-2698}{}%
Does the tangent line at \(x=2\) lie above or below the graph of \(y = f(x)\) at \(x=2.07\)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-118}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2699}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1777}{}\hypertarget{p-2700}{}%
\(L(x) = -1 + 2(x-2)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1778}{}\hypertarget{p-2701}{}%
\(f(2.07) \approx L(2.07) = -0.86\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1779}{}\hypertarget{p-2702}{}%
See the rightmost image in \hyperlink{part-1-8-Act2-ans-e}{part~e} below.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1780}{}\hypertarget{p-2703}{}%
Neither.%
\item\hypertarget{part-1-8-Act2-ans-e}{}\hypertarget{p-2704}{}%
The leftmost image below shows a possible graph of \(y = f(x)\) near \(x = 2\), along with the tangent line \(y = L(x)\) through \((2, f(2))\).%

\item\hypertarget{li-1782}{}\hypertarget{p-2705}{}%
It is an overestimate.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-144}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2706}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1783}{}\hypertarget{p-2707}{}%
Since \(f(2) = -1\) and \(f'(2) = 2\), we have \(L(x) = -1 + 2(x-2)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1784}{}\hypertarget{p-2708}{}%
Using our work in (a), \(f(2.07) \approx L(2.07) = -1 + 2(2.07-2) = -1 + 2\cdot 0.07 = -0.86\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1785}{}\hypertarget{p-2709}{}%
See the rightmost image in \hyperlink{part-1-8-Act2-soln-e}{part~e} below.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1786}{}\hypertarget{p-2710}{}%
The slope of the tangent line to \(y = f(x)\) is increasing for \(x \lt 2\) because \(y = f'(x)\) is an increasing function on this interval. Similarly, for \(x > 2\), the slope of the tangent line to \(y = f(x)\) is decreasing. Right at \(x = 2\), the slope of the tangent line to \(y = f(x)\) is neither increasing nor decreasing. This can also be seen in the sketch of \(y=f''(x)\), where we have \(f''(x)\) decreasing with a root at \(2\) (so \(f''\) is positive to the left and negative to the right of \(x=2\)).%
\item\hypertarget{part-1-8-Act2-soln-e}{}\hypertarget{p-2711}{}%
The leftmost image below shows a possible graph of \(y = f(x)\) near \(x = 2\), along with the tangent line \(y = L(x)\) through \((2, f(2))\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2712}{}%
Note that \(y = f(x)\) is concave up for \(x \lt 2\) since \(f'\) is increasing on that interval, and \(y = f(x)\) is concave down for \(x > 2\) since \(f'\) is decreasing there. Hence \(y = f(x)\) changes from concave up to concave down right at \(x = 2\), which is also the point near 2 where the graph of \(y = f(x)\) is steepest.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2713}{}%
We also observe that \(f\) is decreasing for \(x \lt 0\) and \(x\gt4\) since \(f'\) is negative on those intervals. Likewise, \(f\) is increasing for \(0\lt x\lt 4\) because \(f'\) is positive on that interval.%

\item\hypertarget{li-1788}{}\hypertarget{p-2714}{}%
As noted in part (e), the function \(f\) is concave down for \(x>2\). Consequently, the tangent line approximation for \(f\) at \(x=2\) lies above the graph of \(y=f(x)\) to the right of this point. In other words, \(L(2.07)\gt f(2.07)\), and our estimate in (b) was an overestimate for the true value of \(f(2.07)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-2715}{}%
The idea that a differentiable function looks linear and can be well-approximated by a linear function is an important one that is widely applied in calculus. For example, it is possible to develop an effective algorithm to estimate the zeroes of a function by approximating the function with its local linearization. Local linearity also helps us to make further sense of certain challenging limits. For instance, the limit%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x}
\end{equation*}
is indeterminate, because both its numerator and denominator tend to 0. While there is no algebra that we can do to simplify \(\frac{\sin(x)}{x}\), it is straightforward to show that the linearization of \(f(x) = \sin(x)\) at the point \((0,0)\) is given by \(L(x) = x\). Hence \(\sin(x)\approx x\) for values of \(x\) near 0, and therefore%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{\sin(x)}{x} \approx \frac{x}{x} = 1
\end{equation*}
near \(x=0\). This makes plausible the fact that%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x} = 1\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.9.3 Summary}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Summary}]{Summary}\label{subsection-80}
\hypertarget{p-2716}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2717}{}%
The tangent line to a differentiable function \(y = f(x)\) at the point \((a,f(a))\) is given in point-slope form by the equation%
\begin{equation*}
y - f(a) = f'(a)(x-a)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2718}{}%
The principle of local linearity tells us that if we zoom in on a point where a function \(y = f(x)\) is differentiable, the function will be indistinguishable from its tangent line. That is, a differentiable function looks linear when viewed up close. We rename the tangent line to be the function \(y = L(x)\), where \(L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)\). Thus, \(f(x) \approx L(x)\) for all \(x\) near \(x = a\).%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2719}{}%
If we know the tangent line approximation \(L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)\) to a function \(f\), then because \(L(a) = f(a)\) and \(L'(a) = f'(a)\), we also know the values of both the function and its derivative at the point where \(x = a\). In other words, the linear approximation tells us the height and slope of the original function. If in addition we know the value of \(f''(a)\), we then know whether the tangent line lies above or below the graph of \(y = f(x)\), depending on the concavity of \(f\).%
\end{itemize}
%

\item[1.]\hypertarget{ez-1-8-WW2}{}(Approximating \(\sqrt{x}\))\space\space{}\item[2.]\hypertarget{ez-1-8-WW4}{}(Local Linearization of a Graph)\space\space{}\item[3.]\hypertarget{ez-1-8-WW5}{}(Estimating With the Local Linearization)\space\space{}\item[4.]\hypertarget{ez-1-8-WW6}{}(Predicting Behavior From the Local Linearization)\space\space{}\item[5.]\hypertarget{exercise-175}{}(Using the Local Linearization to Analyze a Function)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-2720}{}%
A certain function \(y=p(x)\) has its local linearization at \(a = 3\) given by \(L(x) = -2x + 5\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1792}{}\hypertarget{p-2721}{}%
What are the values of \(p(3)\) and \(p'(3)\)? Why?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1793}{}\hypertarget{p-2722}{}%
Estimate the value of \(p(2.79)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1794}{}\hypertarget{p-2723}{}%
Suppose that \(p''(3) = 0\) and you know that \(p''(x) \lt 0\) for \(x \lt 3\). Is your estimate in (b) too large or too small?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1795}{}\hypertarget{p-2724}{}%
Suppose that \(p''(x) \gt 0\) for \(x \gt 3\). Use this fact and the additional information above to sketch an accurate graph of \(y = p(x)\) near \(x = 3\). Include a sketch of \(y = L(x)\) in your work.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-119}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2725}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1796}{}\hypertarget{p-2726}{}%
\(p(3) = -1\) and \(p'(3) = -2\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1797}{}\hypertarget{p-2727}{}%
\(p(2.79) \approx -0.58\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1798}{}\hypertarget{p-2728}{}%
Too large.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1799}{}% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)

\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-145}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2729}{}%

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1800}{}\hypertarget{p-2730}{}%
Since the value and slope of the tangent line match the value and slope of the function at the point of tangency, we know \(p(3) = L(3) = -1\) and \(p'(3) = L'(3) = -2\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1801}{}\hypertarget{p-2731}{}%
Using the local linearization, \(p(2.79) \approx L(2.79) = -2(2.79) + 5 = -0.58\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1802}{}\hypertarget{p-2732}{}%
Since \(p''(x) \lt 0\) for \(x \lt 3\), we know that \(p\) is concave down for \(x \lt 3\). This means to the left of the point of tangency at \(x = 3\), the tangent line lies above the curve, and thus the estimate in (b) is too large.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1803}{}\hypertarget{p-2733}{}%
In the following figure, we see a possible function \(p\) that matches the value and slope of the tangent line at the point \((3,-1)\) and that is concave down to the left of \(x=3\) and concave up to the right.%

\item[6.]\hypertarget{exercise-176}{}(Using the Local Linearization with Physical Context)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-2734}{}%
A potato is placed in an oven, and the potato's temperature \(F\) (in degrees Fahrenheit) at various points in time is taken and recorded in the following table. Time \(t\) is measured in minutes.%
\begin{table}
\centering
\begin{tabular}{ll}\hrulethin
\(t\)&\(F(t)\)\tabularnewline\hrulemedium
\(0\)&\(70\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(15\)&\(180.5\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(30\)&\(251\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(45\)&\(296\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(60\)&\(324.5\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(75\)&\(342.8\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(90\)&\(354.5\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\end{tabular}
\caption{Temperature data for the potato.\label{table-14}}
\end{table}
\hypertarget{p-2735}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1804}{}\hypertarget{p-2736}{}%
Use a central difference to estimate \(F'(60)\). Use this estimate as needed in subsequent questions.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1805}{}\hypertarget{p-2737}{}%
Find the local linearization \(y = L(t)\) to the function \(y = F(t)\) at the point where \(a = 60\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1806}{}\hypertarget{p-2738}{}%
Determine an estimate for \(F(63)\) by employing the local linearization.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1807}{}\hypertarget{p-2739}{}%
Do you think your estimate in (c) is too large or too small? Why?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-120}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2740}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1808}{}\hypertarget{p-2741}{}%
\(F'(60)\approx 1.56\) degrees per minute.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1809}{}\hypertarget{p-2742}{}%
\(L(t) \approx 1.56(t-60)+324.5\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1810}{}\hypertarget{p-2743}{}%
\(F(63)\approx L(63)\approx = 329.18\) degrees F.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1811}{}\hypertarget{p-2744}{}%
Overestimate.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-146}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2745}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1812}{}\hypertarget{p-2746}{}%
The central difference approximation with \(h=15\) gives%
\begin{equation*}
F'(60)\approx \frac{F(75)-F(45)}{30}=\frac{342.8-296}{30}=1.56
\end{equation*}
degrees per minute.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1813}{}\hypertarget{p-2747}{}%
The local linearization at \(a=60\) is \(L(t)=F'(60)(t-60)+F(60)\approx 1.56(t-60)+324.5\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1814}{}\hypertarget{p-2748}{}%
Using the linearization from (b), \(F(63)\approx L(63)\approx 1.56(3)+324.5=329.18\) degrees F.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1815}{}\hypertarget{p-2749}{}%
Since the values of \(F(t)\) given in the table appear to be increasing at a decreasing rate, it follows that the graph of \(F\) is concave down. This implies that near \(t=60\), the graph of \(L(t)\) (the tangent line to \(F\) at \(t=60)\) lies above the graph of \(F\). Therefore, the approximation given in part (c) is probably an overestimate.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[7.]\hypertarget{exercise-177}{}(Local Linearity and the Position of a Moving Object)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-2750}{}%
An object moving along a straight line path has a differentiable position function \(y = s(t)\); \(s(t)\) measures the object's position relative to the origin at time \(t\). It is known that at time \(t = 9\) seconds, the object's position is \(s(9) = 4\) feet (i.e., 4 feet to the right of the origin). Furthermore, the object's instantaneous velocity at \(t = 9\) is \(-1.2\) feet per second, and its acceleration at the same instant is \(0.08\) feet per second per second. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1816}{}\hypertarget{p-2751}{}%
Use local linearity to estimate the position of the object at \(t = 9.34\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1817}{}\hypertarget{p-2752}{}%
Is your estimate likely too large or too small? Why?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1818}{}\hypertarget{p-2753}{}%
In everyday language, describe the behavior of the moving object at \(t = 9\). Is it moving toward the origin or away from it? Is its velocity increasing or decreasing?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-121}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2754}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1819}{}\hypertarget{p-2755}{}%
\(s(9.34) \approx L(9.34) = 3.592\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1820}{}\hypertarget{p-2756}{}%
underestimate.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1821}{}\hypertarget{p-2757}{}%
The object is slowing down as it moves toward toward its starting position at \(t=4\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-147}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2758}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1822}{}\hypertarget{p-2759}{}%
The linearization \(L\) of \(s\) at \(t=a\) is \(L(t) = s(a) + s'(a)(t-a)\). With the information we have we can find the linearization of \(s\) at \(t=9\), using the facts that \(s(9) = 4\) and \(s'(9) = -1.2\). Thus, the linearization of \(s\) at \(t=9\) is \(L(t) = 4 - 1.2(t-9)\). One use of the linearization is that for \(t\) close to \(9\), \(L(t)\) can provide a good approximation to \(s(t)\). So%
\begin{equation*}
s(9.34) \approx L(9.34) = 4-1.2(0.34) = 3.592\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-1823}{}\hypertarget{p-2760}{}%
Since \(s''(4) = 0.08\) is positive, we know that the graph of \(s\) is concave up at \(t=4\). This means that the linearization of \(s\) at \(t=4\) lies below the graph of \(s\) and so \(L(9.34)\) is an underestimate to \(s(9.34)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1824}{}\hypertarget{p-2761}{}%
Given that \(s'(4)\) is negative, the object is moving back toward its original position. The fact that \(s''(4)\) is positive means that the velocity of the object is increasing at \(t=4\). This means that the object is actually slowing down as it moves toward toward its starting position at \(t=4\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[8.]\hypertarget{exercise-178}{}(Estimating a Function Through its Derivative)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-2762}{}%
For a certain function \(f\), its derivative is known to be \(f'(x) = (x-1)e^{-x^2}\). Note that you do not know a formula for \(y = f(x)\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1825}{}\hypertarget{p-2763}{}%
At what \(x\)-value(s) is \(f'(x) = 0\)? Justify your answer algebraically, but include a graph of \(f'\) to support your conclusion.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1826}{}\hypertarget{p-2764}{}%
Reasoning graphically, for what intervals of \(x\)-values is \(f''(x) \gt 0\)? What does this tell you about the behavior of the original function \(f\)? Explain.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1827}{}\hypertarget{p-2765}{}%
Assuming that \(f(2) = -3\), estimate the value of \(f(1.88)\) by finding and using the tangent line approximation to \(f\) at \(x=2\). Is your estimate larger or smaller than the true value of \(f(1.88)\)? Justify your answer.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-122}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2766}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1828}{}\hypertarget{p-2767}{}%
\(x=1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1829}{}\hypertarget{p-2768}{}%
On \(-0.37 \lt x \lt 1.37\); \(f\) is concave up.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1830}{}\hypertarget{p-2769}{}%
\(f(1.88) \approx 0.02479\), and this estimate is larger than the true value of \(f(1.88)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-148}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2770}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1831}{}\hypertarget{p-2771}{}%
Since \(e\) raised to any power is always positive (and thus never \(0\)), it follows that the only value that makes \(f'(x) = (x-1)e^{-x^2} = 0\) is \(x=1\). This is confirmed by plotting \(f'\) where we only see the graph cross the \(x\)-axis at \(x=1\) (though we do see the graph approach the \(x\)-axis) as \(x\) increases or decreases without bound).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1832}{}\hypertarget{p-2772}{}%
We know that \(f''(x) \gt 0\) wherever \(f'\) is increasing. From the graph of \(f'\), we see that \(f'\) is increasing approximately on the interval \(-0.37 \lt x \lt 1.37\), and thus \(f\) is concave up on this interval.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1833}{}\hypertarget{p-2773}{}%
The tangent line approximation at \(a = 2\) is \(L(x) = f(2) + f'(2)(x-2) \approx 0.0182 + -0.05495(x-2)\). Thus, \(f(1.88) \approx L(1.88) \approx 0.0182 + -0.05495(1.88-2) = 0.02479\). Since \(f''(x) \lt 0\) at and around \(x = 2\), \(f\) is concave down there, and therefore the tangent line lies above the curve. This makes our estimate larger than the true value of \(f(1.88)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{exerciselist}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Section 2.10 The Mean Value Theorem}
\typeout{************************************************}
\section[{The Mean Value Theorem}]{The Mean Value Theorem}\label{sec-2-10-MVT}
\begin{objectives}{Motivating Questions}\label{objectives-18}
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2774}{}%
Can we use \emph{global} information about a function (for instance, the average rate of change) to say anything about the \emph{local} behavior of the function (such as the instantaneous rate of change)?%
\end{itemize}
\end{objectives}
\hypertarget{p-2775}{}%
When you know how a function behaves at every point, you know quite a lot about that function. This is the whole idea behind plotting points on a coordinate plane in order to determine what the graph of a function looks like. Indeed, given enough local information about a function, we can describe it very well globally. However, the opposite is not generally true. Suppose, for instance, that you know the graph of \(y=f(x)\) is a parabola. Knowing that, can you determine the value of \(f(3)\)? The answer, of course, is that you do not have enough information.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2776}{}%
In general, global information is not enough to determine local information. In other words, knowing how a function behaves overall is not usually enough to say anything about how the function behaves at a specific point. However, there are some exceptions to this generalization. One such special case is the \terminology{mean value theorem}.%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.10.1 The Mean Value Theorem}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{The Mean Value Theorem}]{The Mean Value Theorem}\label{subsection-81}
\begin{example}[]\label{example-131}
\hypertarget{p-2777}{}%
Suppose it took you exactly three quarters of an hour to drive the \(59\) miles from Lincoln, Nebraska to Omaha, Nebraska.  Is it possible that you drove less than \(75\) miles per hour the entire trip?%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2778}{}%
Since \(59\) miles were driven in \(\frac34\) hours, the average speed (i.e. average rate of change) on the trip was%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{59\text{ miles}}{\frac34\text{ hours}}=\frac{59\cdot4}3\approx78.67\text{ mph}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Because this is an average, our intuition tells us that at some point on the trip the car must have been going at least as fast as \(78.67\) miles per hour. This is precisely what the mean value theorem addresses.%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-2779}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[The Mean Value Theorem]\label{assemblage-78}
\hypertarget{p-2780}{}%
\index{mean value theorem} Let \(f\) be a function that is continuous on the closed interval \([a,b]\) and differentiable on the open interval \((a,b)\). Then there exists a number \(c\), with \(a\lt c \lt b\), such that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(c)=\dfrac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}.
\end{equation*}
In other words, \(f(b)-f(a)=f'(c)(b-a)\).%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2781}{}%
While a proof of the mean value theorem is beyond the scope of this textbook, it is worth rephrasing the theorem in a way that is perhaps more clear. The mean value theorem essentially states that given any two points on a continuous curve, there is a point somewhere in the middle at which the line tangent to the curve is parallel to the secant line that connects the two points. A geometric representation of this is illustrated below in \hyperref[mvt]{Figure~\ref{mvt}}.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.6\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2-10-MVT2.jpg}
\caption{A geometric representation of the Mean Value Theorem. The blue curve is the graph of \(y=f(t)\), where \(f\) is some function that is continuous on \([a,b]\) and differentiable on \((a,b)\). The secant line connecting the points \((a,f(a))\) and \((b,f(b))\) is shown in black and has slope \(\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\). There appears to be at least one point, \(c\), between \(a\) and \(b\) at which the slope of the tangent line (shown in red) is precisely the same as the slope of the secant line.\label{mvt}}
\end{figure}
\begin{example}[]\label{example-132}
\hypertarget{p-2782}{}%
Consider the function \(f(x)=2x^3-x\) on the interval \([1,3]\). Find a value of \(c\) on the interval \((1,3)\) such that%
\begin{equation*}
f'(c)=\frac{f(3)-f(1)}{3-1}.
\end{equation*}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-72}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2783}{}%
Use differentiation rules to find the derivative, then evaluate at \(x=c\) and solve for \(c\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-123}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2784}{}%
\(c=\sqrt{\frac{13}{3}}\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-149}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2785}{}%
We start by evaluating the function at the endpoints of the interval, finding that%
\begin{equation*}
f(3)=2(27)-3=51, \quad \text{and} \quad f(1)=2(1)-1=1\text{.}
\end{equation*}
So we are trying to find \(c\) in the interval \((1,3)\) such that \(f'(c)=\frac{51-1}{3-1}=25.\)%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2786}{}%
Using the power rule and the sum rule, we have that \(f'(x)=6x^2-1\), so \(f'(c)=6c^2-1\). Solving the equation \(6c^2-1=25\), we find that \(c=\pm\sqrt{\frac{13}{3}}\). Since we are looking only on the interval \((1,3)\),  the value we want is \(c=+\sqrt{\frac{13}{3}}\approx2.082\).%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 2.10.2 Consequences of the Mean Value Theorem}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Consequences of the Mean Value Theorem}]{Consequences of the Mean Value Theorem}\label{subsection-82}
\hypertarget{p-2787}{}%
The mean value theorem has several important consequences that confirm some intuitive ideas that you may already hold. First, the \terminology{increasing function theorem} establishes that continuous functions with a positive derivative on an interval are increasing on that interval.  More formally,%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2788}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[The Increasing Function Theorem]\label{assemblage-79}
\hypertarget{p-2789}{}%
Suppose that \(f\) is continuous on \(a \leq x \leq b\) and differentiable on \(a \lt x \lt b\). \leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}If \(f'(x)>0\) on \(a \lt x \lt b\), then \(f\) is increasing on \(a \leq x \leq  b\).%
\item{}If \(f'(x) \geq 0\) on \(a \lt x \lt b\), then \(f\) is non-decreasing on \(a \leq x \leq  b\).%
\end{itemize}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2790}{}%
This theorem is demonstrated in \hyperref[ift]{Figure~\ref{ift}}. When the slope of the tangent line is positive for all \(x\) values on a given interval, we see that the function is increasing.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.6\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/2-10-increasingfunction.gif}
\caption{A geometric representation of the increasing function theorem. The blue curve is the graph of \(y=f(t)\), where \(f\) is some function that is continuous on \([a,b]\) and differentiable on \((a,b)\). The tangent lines are positive where the function is increasing.\label{ift}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-2791}{}%
We can also state that a function with a derivative equal to zero on an interval is constant on that interval.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2792}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Constant Function Theorem]\label{assemblage-80}
\hypertarget{p-2793}{}%
Suppose that \(f\) is continuous on \(a \leq x \leq b\) and differentiable on \(a \lt x \lt b\).  If \(f '(x) = 0\) on \(a \lt x \lt b\), then \(f\) is constant on \(a \leq x \leq b\). Equivalently, if \(f\) is \emph{not} constant everywhere on \([a,b]\), then there is some point \(c\) on the interval \((a,b)\) at which \(f'(c)\neq0\).%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2794}{}%
The following example will provide some intuition for the constant function theorem.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-133}
\hypertarget{p-2795}{}%
Suppose a car is being driven with cruise control set to \(55\) miles per hour, and that the drive continues for \(30\) minutes. Thinking of the car's velocity (in miles per hour) as a function of time (in minutes), the instantaneous rate of change of velocity (i.e., the instantaneous acceleration) at each minute of the drive is \(0\) miles per hour per minute. In terms of function notation, we have \(v=f(t)\) denoting the velocity as a function of time, and \(a=f'(t)\) denoting the acceleration as the derivative of velocity, with \(f'(t)=0\) for each \(0\lt t\lt30\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2796}{}%
Suppose now that the car approaches a red light, leading the driver to turn off cruise control in order to slow down and eventually stop. However, cruise control is only off for \(15\) seconds before the light turns green again, at which point the driver resets the cruise control and regains a speed of \(55\) mph within a further \(15\) seconds. When cruise control was turned off, the car slowed down a little bit before returning to cruising speed. Consequently, the instantaneous acceleration was nonzero during that \(30\) second period. In other words, when the (velocity) function is not constant over an interval, its derivative (acceleration) is nonzero on that same interval.%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-2797}{}%
We have one final result that can be used to formalize another intuitive idea.  The \terminology{racetrack principle} argues that if two objects begin at the same place and the same time and one is traveling faster than the other, then the faster object will be ahead of the slower object.  Formally, we write the principle in terms of functions.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2798}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[The Racetrack Principle]\label{assemblage-81}
\hypertarget{p-2799}{}%
Suppose that \(g\) and \(h\) are continuous on \(a \leq x \leq b\) and differentiable on \(a\lt x\lt b\), and that \(g'(x) \leq h'(x)\) for \(a\lt x \lt b\). \leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}If \(g(a)=h(a)\), then \(g(x) \leq h(x)\) for \(a \leq x \leq b\).%
\item{}If \(g(b)=h(b)\), then \(g(x) \geq h(x)\) for \(a \leq x \leq b\).%
\end{itemize}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-134}
\hypertarget{p-2800}{}%
Erica and Mason want to race each other down the street. After choosing start and finish lines, they get set to race. Starting together, Erica runs faster than Mason the entire time. Because of this, Erica is ahead of Mason for the whole race and reaches the finish line first.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2801}{}%
Now suppose that Mason wants a rematch, but he isn't willing to play fair this time. Mason and Erica line up at the starting line, but Mason takes an early start. Erica again runs faster than Mason the entire time, and they reach the finish line together. This means Erica spent the race catching up to Mason, who was ahead of her for the whole race.%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{example-135}
\hypertarget{p-2802}{}%
Use the racetrack principle to show that \(\ln(x)\leq x-1\) for all \(x\geq 1.\) Is the statement also true for all \(0\lt x \leq 1\)?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-73}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2803}{}%
Compare function values at \(x=1\). How do the derivatives compare on the interval in question?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-124}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2804}{}%
\(\ln(x)\le x-1\) for every positive value of \(x\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-150}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2805}{}%
Set \(g(x)=\ln(x)\) and \(h(x)=x-1\). Both functions are continuous on \([1,\infty)\) and differentiable on \((1,\infty)\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2806}{}%
We take the derivative of each function:%
\begin{equation*}
g'(x)=\frac{1}{x},
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x)=1.
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2807}{}%
Since ``\(x\ge1\)'' and ``\(\frac1x\le1\)'' are equivalent statements, we thus have \(g'(x)\leq h'(x)\) for all \(x\geq 1\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2808}{}%
Comparing function values when \(x=1\), we see that \(g(1)=\ln(1)=0\) and \(h(1)=1-1=0\). Therefore the racetrack principle says \(g(x)\leq h(x)\) (i.e. \(\ln(x)\leq x-1 \)) for all \(x\geq 1\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2809}{}%
Similarly, if we consider values \(0\lt x \leq 1\), we have that \(g'(x)\geq h'(x)\). Since \(g(1)=h(1)\), we have that \(h(x)\geq g(x)\) or \(x-1\geq \ln(x)\) for all \(0\lt x\leq 1\). Note that we have to be careful in applying the racetrack principle here, since \(\ln(x)\) is not continuous (because it's undefined) at \(x=0\). But we can choose the lower bound of the interval to be any positive number less than \(1\), and then take the limit as that number approaches \(0\) to obtain the result.%
\end{example}

\typeout{Chapter 3 Using Derivatives}
\typeout{************************************************}
\chapter[{Using Derivatives}]{Using Derivatives}\label{C-3}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Section 3.1 Using Derivatives to Identify Extreme Values}
\typeout{************************************************}
\section[{Using Derivatives to Identify Extreme Values}]{Using Derivatives to Identify Extreme Values}\label{sec-3-1-tests}
\begin{objectives}{Motivating Questions}\label{objectives-19}
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2810}{}%
What are the critical numbers of a function \(f\) and how are they connected to identifying the most extreme values the function achieves?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2811}{}%
How does the first derivative of a function reveal important information about the behavior of the function, including the function's extreme values?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2812}{}%
How can the second derivative of a function be used to help identify extreme values of the function?%
\end{itemize}
\end{objectives}
\hypertarget{p-2813}{}%
In many different settings, we are interested in knowing where a function achieves its least and greatest values. These can be important in applications \textendash{} such as identifying a point at which maximum profit or minimum cost occurs \textendash{} or in theory such as characterizing the behavior of a function or of a family of related functions.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2814}{}%
Consider the simple and familiar example of a parabolic function such as \(s(t) = -16t^2 + 32t + 48\) (shown on the left of \hyperref[F-3-1-Intro]{Figure~\ref{F-3-1-Intro}} below) that represents the height of an object tossed vertically: its maximum value occurs at the vertex of the parabola and represents the greatest height the object reaches. This maximum value is an especially important point on the graph, the point at which the curve changes from increasing to decreasing.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2815}{}%
\index{maximum!global} \index{maximum!absolute} \index{minimum!global} \index{minimum!absolute} \begin{assemblage}[Global (Absolute) Maximum and Minimum]\label{assemblage-82}
\hypertarget{p-2816}{}%
Given a function \(f\), we say that \(f(c)\) is a \terminology{global (or absolute) maximum} of \(f\) provided that \(f(c) \ge f(x)\) for all \(x\) in the domain of \(f\). Similarly, we call \(f(c)\) a \terminology{global (or absolute) minimum} of \(f\) whenever \(f(c) \le f(x)\) for all \(x\) in the domain of \(f\).%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2817}{}%
Consider, for example, the graph of \(y=g(x)\) on the right of \hyperref[F-3-1-Intro]{Figure~\ref{F-3-1-Intro}} below. The function \(g\) has a global maximum of \(g(c)\), but \(g\) does not appear to have a global minimum, as the graph of \(g\) seems to decrease without bound. Note that the point \((c,g(c))\) marks a fundamental change in the behavior of \(g\) as \(g\) changes from increasing to decreasing; similar things happen at both \((a,g(a))\) and \((b,g(b))\), although these points are not global minima or maxima.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/3_1_Intro.pdf}
\caption{On the left, the graph of \(y=s(t)\), where \(s(t) = -16t^2 + 24t + 32\) is a parabola whose vertex is \(\left(\frac{3}{4}, 41\right)\); on the right, the graph of \(y=g(x)\), where \(g\) is a function that demonstrates several high and low points.\label{F-3-1-Intro}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-2818}{}%
\index{maximum!local} \index{maximum!relative} \index{minimum!local} \index{minimum!relative} \begin{assemblage}[Local (Relative) Maximum and Minimum]\label{assemblage-83}
\hypertarget{p-2819}{}%
We say that \(f(c)\) is a \terminology{local (or relative) maximum} of \(f\) provided that \(f(c) \ge f(x)\) for all \(x\) near \(c\). Likewise, \(f(c)\) is called a \terminology{local (or relative) minimum} of \(f\) whenever \(f(c) \le f(x)\) for all \(x\) near \(c\).%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2820}{}%
For example, returning to the right half of \hyperref[F-3-1-Intro]{Figure~\ref{F-3-1-Intro}} above, \(g\) has a relative minimum of \(g(b)\) at the point \((b,g(b))\) and a relative maximum of \(g(a)\) at \((a,g(a))\). We have already identified the global maximum of \(g\) as \(g(c)\); it can also be considered a relative maximum. Another piece of terminology to be familiar with is that any maximum or minimum may also be called an \terminology{extreme value} \index{extreme value} of \(f\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2821}{}%
We would like to use calculus ideas to identify and classify key function behavior, including the location of relative extrema. Of course, if we are given a graph of a function, it is often straightforward to locate these important behaviors visually. We see this below in \hyperref[PA-3-1]{Example~\ref{PA-3-1}}.%
\begin{example}[]\label{PA-3-1}
\hypertarget{p-2822}{}%
Consider the function \(h\) given by the graph in \hyperref[F-3-1-PA1]{Figure~\ref{F-3-1-PA1}} below. Use the graph to answer each of the following questions.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/3_1_PA1.pdf}
\caption{The graph of \(y=h(x)\) on the interval \([-3,3]\).\label{F-3-1-PA1}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-2823}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1842}{}\hypertarget{p-2824}{}%
Identify all of the values of \(c\) for which \(h(c)\) is a local maximum of \(h\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1843}{}\hypertarget{p-2825}{}%
Identify all of the values of \(c\) for which \(h(c)\) is a local minimum of \(h\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1844}{}\hypertarget{p-2826}{}%
Does \(h\) have a global maximum on the interval \([-3,3]\)? If so, what is the value of this global maximum?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1845}{}\hypertarget{p-2827}{}%
Does \(h\) have a global minimum on the interval \([-3,3]\)? If so, what is its value?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1846}{}\hypertarget{p-2828}{}%
Identify all values of \(c\) for which \(h'(c) = 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1847}{}\hypertarget{p-2829}{}%
Identify all values of \(c\) for which \(h'(c)\) does not exist.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1848}{}\hypertarget{p-2830}{}%
True or false: every relative maximum and minimum of \(h\) occurs at a point where \(h'(c)\) is either zero or does not exist.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1849}{}\hypertarget{p-2831}{}%
True or false: at every point where \(h'(c)\) is zero or does not exist, \(h\) has a relative maximum or minimum.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-74}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2832}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1850}{}\hypertarget{p-2833}{}%
Start by looking for \(x\)-values where the graph switches from increasing to decreasing. Are there any other points that might work?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1851}{}\hypertarget{p-2834}{}%
Start by looking for \(x\)-values where the graph switches from decreasing to increasing. Are there any other points that might work?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1852}{}\hypertarget{p-2835}{}%
Is there a highest point on the graph?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1853}{}\hypertarget{p-2836}{}%
Is there a lowest point on the graph?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1854}{}\hypertarget{p-2837}{}%
Remember that horizontal lines have a slope of \(0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1855}{}\hypertarget{p-2838}{}%
Think back to earlier chapters. What characteristics of \(h\) or its graph might make it nondifferentiable at a certain point?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1856}{}\hypertarget{p-2839}{}%
Compare your answers to (a) and (b) with those to (e) and (f).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1857}{}\hypertarget{p-2840}{}%
Compare your answers to (a) and (b) with those to (e) and (f).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-125}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2841}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1858}{}\hypertarget{p-2842}{}%
\(c=-2\) and \(c=1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1859}{}\hypertarget{p-2843}{}%
\(c=0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1860}{}\hypertarget{p-2844}{}%
\(h(1)=2\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1861}{}\hypertarget{p-2845}{}%
\(h(-3)=-3\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1862}{}\hypertarget{p-2846}{}%
\(c=-2.5\) and \(c=1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1863}{}\hypertarget{p-2847}{}%
\(c=-2\), \(c=0\), and \(c=1.5\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1864}{}\hypertarget{p-2848}{}%
True.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1865}{}\hypertarget{p-2849}{}%
False.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-151}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2850}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1866}{}\hypertarget{p-2851}{}%
The graph shows that \(h(x)\le-1=h(-2)\) for every \(x\) near \(-2\) and \(h(x)\le2=h(1)\) for every \(x\) near \(1\). We notice that these are points where \(h\) switches from increasing to decreasing. Since there are no other points on the graph where the \(y\)-coordinate is larger than everything nearby, it follows that the only local maxima of \(h\) on this domain occur at \(c=-2\) and \(c=1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1867}{}\hypertarget{p-2852}{}%
The graph shows that \(h(x)\ge-2=h(0)\) for every \(x\) near \(0\), a point where \(h\) switches from decreasing to increasing. Since this is the only point shown where this occurs, we say that the only local minimum of \(h\) on this domain occurs at \(c=0\). %
\item\hypertarget{li-1868}{}\hypertarget{p-2853}{}%
The highest point shown on the graph is the point \((1,2)\). Since \(h\) is continuous on \([-3,3]\), we don't have to worry about any points on the interval being higher and not showing up on the displayed grid. Hence we say the global maximum of \(h\) on the interval \([-3,3]\) is \(2\) and occurs at \(x=1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1869}{}\hypertarget{p-2854}{}%
The lowest point shown on the graph is the point \((-3,-3)\). Again, since \(h\) is continuous on \([-3,3]\), we don't have to worry about any points on the interval being lower and not showing up in the window that is displayed. Thus we say the global minimum of \(h\) on the interval \([-3,3]\) is \(-3\) and occurs at \(x=-3\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2855}{}%
It is worth noting that this was not a point that we found as a local minimum. The difference is that here we are restricting our focus to the interval that is shown, effectively cutting off the graph at its endpoints. Earlier, when we were looking for relative minima, we made the assumption that the graph of \(y=h(x)\) continues outside of the depicted interval by following the trends displayed and continuing downward on both sides.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1870}{}\hypertarget{p-2856}{}%
When looking for points \((c,h(c))\) at which \(h'(c)=0\), we are looking for points of horizontal tangency. The graph flattens out at \((-2.5,-2)\) and \((1,2)\), but nowhere else\footnote{Note that at \((1.5,1)\) it looks as though the graph is flat to the right of this point. However, the derivative is undefined here because of the cusp, so this is not a point of horizontal tangency\label{fn-26}}. Thus \(h'(c)=0\) exactly when \(c=-2.5\) and \(c=1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1871}{}\hypertarget{p-2857}{}%
Recall that \(h'(c)\) only exists when all of the following are true: %
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2858}{}%
\(h(c)\) is defined,%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2859}{}%
\(\lim_{x\to c}h(x)\) exists,%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2860}{}%
\(\lim_{x\to c}h(x)=h(c)\), and%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-2861}{}%
\(\lim_{a\to0}\frac{h(c+a)-h(c)}a\) exists.%
\end{itemize}
 Assuming \(h\) is continuous at \(c\) (i.e. the first three points hold), the main consequence of the final point is that a corner or a cusp at \((c,h(c))\) makes \(h\) nondifferentiable at \(c\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2862}{}%
With all this in mind, we can say that \(h'(c)\) does not exist at \(c=-2\), \(c=0\), or \(c=1.5\) because \(h\) has a cusp at these points. %
\item\hypertarget{li-1876}{}\hypertarget{p-2863}{}%
This is true. Every relative extremum of \(h\) occurs at a point where \(h'(c)\) is either zero or does not exist.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1877}{}\hypertarget{p-2864}{}%
This is false. Some points at which \(h'(c)\) is zero or undefined are not relative extrema. In particular, \(h'(-2.5)\) is zero, but the graph is non-decreasing near \((-2.5,-2)\). Similarly, \(h'(1.5)\) is undefined, but the graph is non-increasing near \((1.5,1)\). Neither of these points is a local maximum or minimum.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 3.1.1 Critical Points and the First Derivative Test}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Critical Points and the First Derivative Test}]{Critical Points and the First Derivative Test}\label{subsection-83}
\leavevmode%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/3_1_extremes.pdf}
\caption{From left to right: a function with a relative maximum where its derivative is zero; a function with a relative maximum where its derivative is undefined; a function with neither a maximum nor a minimum at a point where its derivative is zero; a function with a relative minimum where its derivative is zero; and a function with a relative minimum where its derivative is undefined.\label{F-3-1-extremes}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-2865}{}%
Suppose a function \(f\) is continuous on an open interval \((a,b)\). If \(f\) has a relative maximum at some number \(c\) in this interval, then \(f\) must be increasing in some interval just before \(c\) and decreasing in some interval just after \(c\).  These intervals could be quite small.  Conversely, if \(f\) is increasing in an interval just before \(c\) and decreasing in an interval just after \(c\), then \(f\) must have a relative maximum at \(c\). The natural analogue holds for relative minima: if \(f\) has a relative minimum at some number \(c\) in this interval, then \(f\) is decreasing in some interval just before \(c\) and increasing just after \(c\).  Conversely, if \(f\) is decreasing in some interval just before \(c\) and decreasing in an interval just after \(c\), then \(f\) must have a relative minimum at \(c\). (See \hyperref[F-3-1-extremes]{Figure~\ref{F-3-1-extremes}} above.) There are only two possible ways for these changes in behavior to occur: either \(f'(c) = 0\) or \(f'(c)\) is undefined. Because these values of \(c\) are so important, we call the point \((c,f(c))\) a critical point.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2866}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Critical Point]\label{assemblage-84}
\hypertarget{p-2867}{}%
We say that a function \(f\) has a \terminology{critical point} \index{critical point} at \((c,f(c))\) provided that \(c\) is in the domain of \(f\), and \(f'(c) = 0\) or \(f'(c)\) is undefined. When \((c,f(c))\) is a critical point, we say that \(c\) is a \terminology{critical number} \index{critical number} of the function, or that \(f(c)\) is a \terminology{critical value}. \index{critical value}%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2868}{}%
Critical points are the only possible locations where the function \(f\) may have relative\footnote{Absolute extrema occur only at critical points \emph{or at endpoints for functions defined on a fixed domain}.\label{fn-27}} extrema. Note that not every critical point produces a maximum or minimum; in the middle graph of \hyperref[F-3-1-extremes]{Figure~\ref{F-3-1-extremes}}, the function pictured there has a horizontal tangent line at the noted point, but the function is increasing before and increasing after, so the critical point does not yield a maximum or minimum. Two other such points appeared earlier in \hyperref[F-3-1-PA1]{Figure~\ref{F-3-1-PA1}} of \hyperref[PA-3-1]{Example~\ref{PA-3-1}}.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2869}{}%
The first derivative test summarizes how sign changes in the first derivative (which can only occur at critical numbers) indicate the presence of a local maximum or minimum for a given function.%
\begin{assemblage}[First Derivative Test]\label{First-D-Test}
\hypertarget{p-2870}{}%
\index{first derivative test} If \(p\) is a critical number of a continuous function \(f\) that is differentiable near \(p\) (except possibly at \(x = p\)), then \(f\) has a relative maximum at \(p\) if and only if \(f'\) changes sign from positive to negative at \(p\), and \(f\) has a relative minimum at \(p\) if and only if \(f'\) changes sign from negative to positive at \(p\).%
\end{assemblage}
\begin{example}[]\label{Ex-f-from-f-prime}
\hypertarget{p-2871}{}%
Let \(f\) be a function whose derivative is given by the formula \(f'(x) = e^{-2x}(3-x)(x+1)^2\). Determine all critical numbers of \(f\) and decide whether a relative maximum, relative minimum, or neither occurs at each.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-75}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2872}{}%
When is \(f'(x)=0\)? What else do you need to look for?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-126}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2873}{}%
\(-1\) is a critical number that is not a relative extremum. \(3\) is a local maximum.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-152}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2874}{}%
Since we already have \(f'(x)\) written in factored form, it is straightforward to find the critical numbers of \(f\). Because \(f'(x)\) is defined for all values of \(x\), we need only determine where \(f'(x) = 0\). From the equation%
\begin{equation*}
e^{-2x}(3-x)(x+1)^2 = 0
\end{equation*}
and the zero product property\footnote{The zero product property says that if \(ab=0\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are expressions representing real numbers (e.g. \(a=(3-x)\), where \(x\) is a real number), then it must be the case that \(a=0\) or \(b=0\) (or both).\label{fn-28}}, it follows that \(x = 3\) and \(x = -1\) are critical numbers of \(f\). (There is no value of \(x\) that makes \(e^{-2x} = 0\).)%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2875}{}%
Next, to apply the first derivative test, we'd like to know the sign of \(f'(x)\) at inputs near the critical numbers. Because the critical numbers are the only locations at which \(f'\) can change sign, it follows that the sign of the derivative is the same on each of the intervals created by the critical numbers: for instance, the sign of \(f'\) must be the same for every \(x \lt -1\). What this means is that we can choose (carefully) where to evaluate the derivative in order to ascertain its sign on a given interval. Since \(f'(-1.000001)\) and \(f'(-2)\) must have the same sign, we may as well evaluate \(f'(x)\) at \(-2\) to figure out the sign of \(f'\) for \(x\lt -1\). We create a first derivative sign chart (displayed below, with explanation following) to summarize the sign of \(f'\) on the relevant intervals, along with the corresponding behavior of \(f\).%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.65\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/3_1_signchart.pdf}
\caption{The first derivative sign chart for a function \(f\) whose derivative is given by the formula \(f'(x) = e^{-2x}(3-x)(x+1)^2\).\label{F-3-1-signchart}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-2876}{}%
To produce the first derivative sign chart in \hyperref[F-3-1-signchart]{Figure~\ref{F-3-1-signchart}}, we start by marking the critical numbers \(-1\) and \(3\) on the number line. We then identify the sign of each factor of \(f'(x)\) at one selected point in each interval. The intervals in this example are \(x\lt-1\), \(-1\lt x\lt3\), and \(x\gt3\); we will choose \(x=-2\), \(x=0\), and \(x=5\) for our selected points. The process with \(x=-2\) is laid out below:%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2877}{}%
For \(x \lt -1\), we use the value \(x=-2\) to determine the sign of \(e^{-2x}\), \((3-x)\), and \((x+1)^2\). We note that \(e^{-2x}\) is positive regardless of the value of \(x\), \((x+1)^2\) is positive whenever it is nonzero \textemdash{} which is everywhere within the intervals of interest since we intentionally plucked out the zeros \textemdash{} and that \((3-x)\) is also positive at \(x = -2\). Hence each of the three terms in \(f'\) is positive, and we indicate this by writing ``\(+++\)'' above the interval \(x\lt-1\). Taking the product of three positive terms results in a positive value for \(f'\), so we denote the sign of \(f'\) by a ``\(+\)'' above the appropriate interval in the chart. Finally, since \(f'\) is positive on that interval, we know that \(f\) is increasing, so we write ``INC'' to represent the behavior of \(f\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2878}{}%
In a similar fashion, we find that \(f'\) is positive (because \(3-(0)\gt0\) and the other terms are also still positive) and \(f\) is increasing on \(-1 \lt x \lt 3\), and that \(f'\) is negative (because \(3-(5)\lt0\) but the other terms are still positive) and \(f\) is decreasing for \(x \gt 3\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-2879}{}%
Now we look for critical numbers at which \(f'\) changes sign. In this example, \(f'\) changes sign only at \(x = 3\), from positive to negative, so \(f\) has a relative maximum at \(x = 3\). Although \(f\) has a critical number at \(x = -1\), since \(f\) is increasing both before and after \(x = -1\), \(f\) has neither a minimum nor a maximum at \(x = -1\).%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{act-3-1-1}
\hypertarget{p-2880}{}%
Suppose \(g\) is a function that is continuous for every value of \(x \neq 2\), and whose first derivative is \(g'(x) = \frac{(x+4)(x-1)^2}{x-2}\). Further, assume that it is known that \(g\) has a vertical asymptote at \(x = 2\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1878}{}\hypertarget{p-2881}{}%
Determine all critical numbers of \(g\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1879}{}\hypertarget{p-2882}{}%
By developing a carefully labeled first derivative sign chart, decide whether \(g\) has as a local maximum, local minimum, or neither at each critical number.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1880}{}\hypertarget{p-2883}{}%
Does \(g\) have a global maximum? Does \(g\) have a global minimum? Justify your claims.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1881}{}\hypertarget{p-2884}{}%
What is the value of \(\lim_{x \to \infty} g'(x)\)? What does the value of this limit tell you about the long-term behavior of \(g\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1882}{}\hypertarget{p-2885}{}%
Sketch a possible graph of \(y = g(x)\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-76}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2886}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1883}{}\hypertarget{p-2887}{}%
For which \(x\) is \(g'(x) = 0\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-1884}{}\hypertarget{p-2888}{}%
Note that \((x-1)^2\) is positive for all \(x \ne 1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1885}{}\hypertarget{p-2889}{}%
Use your first derivative sign chart from (b).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1886}{}\hypertarget{p-2890}{}%
Try expanding the numerator before evaluating the limit.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1887}{}\hypertarget{p-2891}{}%
Think carefully about the information from the sign chart found in (b). Your answers to part (c) and (d) should also support your graph.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-127}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-2892}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-1888}{}\hypertarget{p-2893}{}%
\(x = -4\) or \(x = 1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1889}{}\hypertarget{p-2894}{}%
\(g\) has a local maximum at \(x = -4\) and neither a max nor min at \(x = 1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1890}{}\hypertarget{p-2895}{}%
\(g\) does not have a global minimum; it is unclear (at this point in our work) if \(g\) increases without bound, so we can't say for certain whether or not \(g\) has a global maximum.%
\item\hypertarget{li-1891}{}\hypertarget{p-2896}{}%
\(\lim_{x \to \infty} g'(x) = \infty\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-1892}{}\hypertarget{p-2897}{}%
A possible graph of \(g\) is the following.%

% end: side-by-side as tabular
