Hence we can not only conclude that \(g\) is always increasing for \(x \lt \frac{1}{b}\) and decreasing for \(x \gt \frac{1}{b}\), but also that \(g\) has a global maximum at \(\big(\frac{1}{b}, g\big(\frac{1}{b}\big)\big)\) and no local minimum. The first derivative sign chart for \(g\) is shown below in \hyperref[F-3-2-signchartg]{Figure~\ref{F-3-2-signchartg}}.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/3_2_signchartg.pdf}
\caption{The first derivative sign chart for \(g(x) = axe^{-bx}\).\label{F-3-2-signchartg}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-3450}{}%
We turn next to analyzing the concavity of \(g\). With \(g'(x) = ae^{-bx}-abxe^{-bx}\), we differentiate to find that%
\begin{equation*}
g''(x) = ae^{-bx}(-b)-ab\left(e^{-bx}+xe^{-bx}(-b)\right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3451}{}%
Combining like terms and factoring, we now have%
\begin{equation*}
g''(x) = ab^2xe^{-bx} - 2abe^{-bx} = abe^{-bx}(bx - 2)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3452}{}%
We observe that \(abe^{-bx}\) is always positive, and thus the sign of \(g''\) depends on the sign of \((bx-2)\), which is zero when \(x = \frac{2}{b}\). Since \(b\) is positive, the value of \((bx-2)\) is negative for \(x \lt \frac{2}{b}\) and positive for \(x \gt \frac{2}{b}\). The sign chart for \(g''\) is shown below in \hyperref[F-3-2-signchartg2]{Figure~\ref{F-3-2-signchartg2}}. Thus, \(g\) is concave down for all \(x \lt \frac{2}{b}\) and concave up for all \(x \gt \frac{2}{b}\).%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/3_2_signchartg2.pdf}
\caption{The second derivative sign chart for \(g(x) = axe^{-bx}\).\label{F-3-2-signchartg2}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-3453}{}%
Finally, we analyze the long-term behavior of \(g\) by considering two limits. First, we note that%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{x \to \infty} g(x) = \lim_{x \to \infty} axe^{-bx} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{ax}{e^{bx}}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3454}{}%
This limit has indeterminate form \(\frac{\infty}{\infty}\), so with our current tools, we can not evaluate the limit algebraically. We can, however, reason that \(ax\) is linear while \(e^{bx}\) is exponential, and conclude that because exponential growth is so much more rapid than linear growth, we expect the limiting value to be zero. A more rigorous answer will be possible following \hyperref[sec-2-8-LHR]{Section~\ref{sec-2-8-LHR}}, but for now we can also use graphical evidence\footnote{A good tool to use here is \href{http://www.desmos.com/calculator/vvscoo435h}{desmos.com}.\label{fn-35}} to support the claim that \(\lim_{x\to\infty}g(x)=0\). We do so by examining the graphs of several different functions in this family, noting that each has a horizontal asymptote of \(y=0\) as \(x\to\infty\).  In the other direction,%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{x \to -\infty} g(x) = \lim_{x \to -\infty} axe^{-bx} = -\infty\text{,}
\end{equation*}
because \(ax \to -\infty\) and \(e^{-bx} \to \infty\) as \(x \to -\infty\). Hence, as we move left on its graph, \(g\) decreases without bound, while as we move to the right, \(g(x) \to 0\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3455}{}%
All of this information now helps us produce the graph of a typical member of this family of functions without using a graphing utility (and without choosing particular values for \(a\) and \(b\)), as shown in \hyperref[F-3-2-SurgeFam]{Figure~\ref{F-3-2-SurgeFam}} below.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/3_2_SurgeFam.pdf}
\caption{The graph of \(g(x) = axe^{-bx}\).\label{F-3-2-SurgeFam}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-3456}{}%
Note that the value of \(b\) controls the horizontal location of the global maximum and the inflection point, as neither depends on \(a\). The value of \(a\) affects the vertical stretch of the graph. For example, the global maximum occurs at the point \(\big(\frac{1}{b}, g\big(\frac{1}{b}\big)\big) = \big(\frac{1}{b}, \frac{a}{b}e^{-1}\big)\), so the larger the value of \(a\), the greater the value of the global maximum.%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-3457}{}%
The work we've completed in \hyperref[Ex-3-2-1]{Example~\ref{Ex-3-2-1}} can often be replicated for other families of functions that depend on parameters. Normally we are most interested in determining all critical numbers, a first derivative sign chart, a second derivative sign chart, and the limit of the function as \(x \to \infty\). Throughout, we prefer to work with the parameters as arbitrary constants. In addition, we can experiment with some particular values of the parameters present to reduce the algebraic complexity of our work. What follows are several key examples where we see that the values of the parameters substantially affect the behavior of individual functions within a given family.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-3-2-1}
\hypertarget{p-3458}{}%
Consider the family of functions defined by \(p(x) = x^3 - ax\), where \(a \ne 0\) is an arbitrary constant. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2243}{}\hypertarget{p-3459}{}%
Find \(p'(x)\) and determine the critical numbers of \(p\). How many critical numbers does \(p\) have?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2244}{}\hypertarget{p-3460}{}%
Construct a first derivative sign chart for \(p\). What can you say about the overall behavior of \(p\) if the constant \(a\) is positive? Why? What if the constant \(a\) is negative? In each case, describe the relative extrema of \(p\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2245}{}\hypertarget{p-3461}{}%
Find \(p''(x)\) and construct a second derivative sign chart for \(p\). What does this tell you about the concavity of \(p\)? What role does \(a\) play in determining the concavity of \(p\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2246}{}\hypertarget{p-3462}{}%
Without using a graphing utility, sketch and label typical graphs of \(p(x)\) for the cases where \(a\gt 0\) and \(a \lt 0\). Label all inflection points and local extrema.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2247}{}\hypertarget{p-3463}{}%
Finally, use a graphing utility to test your observations above by entering and plotting the function \(p(x) = x^3 - ax\) for at least four different values of \(a\). Write several sentences to describe your overall conclusions about how the behavior of \(p\) depends on \(a\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-91}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3464}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2248}{}\hypertarget{p-3465}{}%
When solving \(p'(x) = 0\), think about two possible cases: when \(a\gt 0\) and when \(a \lt 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2249}{}\hypertarget{p-3466}{}%
Remember that any quadratic function can be zero at most two times. How does the graph of \(y = 3x^2 - a\) look?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2250}{}\hypertarget{p-3467}{}%
Don't forget that \(\frac{d}{dx}[a] = 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2251}{}\hypertarget{p-3468}{}%
Think about how the graph of a typical cubic polynomial behaves.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-154}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3469}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2252}{}\hypertarget{p-3470}{}%
\(p\) has two critical numbers \(\left(x = \pm \sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\right)\) whenever \(a \gt 0\) and no critical numbers when \(a \lt 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2253}{}\hypertarget{p-3471}{}%
When \(a \lt 0\), \(p\) is always increasing and has no relative extreme values. When \(a\gt 0\), \(p\) has a relative maximum at \(x = -\sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\) and a relative minimum at \(x = +\sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2254}{}\hypertarget{p-3472}{}%
\(p\) is concave down for \(x \lt 0\) and \(p\) is concave up for \(x\gt 0\), making \(x = 0\) an inflection point.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2255}{}\hypertarget{p-3473}{}%
On the left, \(a\lt0\); on the right, \(a\gt0\).%

\item\hypertarget{li-2256}{}\hypertarget{p-3474}{}%
See \href{http://www.desmos.com/calculator/2x1j8cwozg}{desmos.com} for additional graph samples. As \(a\) decreases towards \(-\infty\), the graph of \(y=p(x)\) looks more and more linear. As \(a\) increases towards \(\infty\), the two bumps on the graph get more pronounced.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-181}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3475}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2257}{}\hypertarget{p-3476}{}%
We first note that \(p'(x) = 3x^2 - a\), so to find critical numbers we set \(p'(x) = 0\) and solve for \(x\). This leads to the equation \(3x^2 - a = 0\), which implies%
\begin{equation*}
x^2 = \frac{a}{3}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
If \(a \gt 0\), then the solutions to this equation are \(x = \pm \sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\); if \(a \lt  0\), then the equation has no solution. Hence, \(p\) has two critical numbers \(\left(x = \pm \sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\right)\) whenever \(a \gt 0\) and no critical numbers when \(a \lt  0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2258}{}\hypertarget{p-3477}{}%
For the case when \(a \lt 0\), we observe that \(p'(x) = 3x^2 - a\) is positive for every value of \(x\), and thus \(p\) is always increasing and has no relative extreme values. (There are no critical numbers to place on the first derivative sign chart, and \(p'\) is always positive.) For the case when \(a\gt 0\), we observe that \(p'(x) = 3x^2 - a\) is a concave up parabola with zeros at \(x = -\sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\) and \(x = +\sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\). It follows that for \(x \lt -\sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\), \(p'(x)\gt 0\) (so \(p\) is increasing); for \(-\sqrt{\frac{a}{3}} \lt x \lt \sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\), \(p'(x)\gt 0\) (so \(p\) is decreasing); and for \(x\gt \sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\), \(p'(x)\gt 0\) (so \(p\) is again increasing). In this situation, we see that \(p\) has a relative maximum at \(x = -\sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\) and a relative minimum at \(x = +\sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2259}{}\hypertarget{p-3478}{}%
Since \(p'(x) = 3x^2 - a\) and \(a\) is constant, it follows that \(p''(x) = 6x\). Note that \(p''(x) = 0\) when \(x = 0\) and that \(p''(x) \lt 0\) for \(x \lt 0\) and \(p''(x)\gt 0\) for \(x\gt 0\). Hence \(p\) is concave down for \(x \lt 0\) and \(p\) is concave up for \(x\gt 0\), making \(x = 0\) an inflection point.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2260}{}\hypertarget{p-3479}{}%
Below, we show the two possible situations. At left, for the case when \(a \lt 0\) and \(p\) is always increasing with an inflection point at \(x = 0\), and at right for when \(a\gt 0\) and \(p\) has a relative maximum at \(x = -\sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\) and a relative minimum at \(x = +\sqrt{\frac{a}{3}}\), again with an inflection point at \(x = 0\). Note, too, that \(p\) has its \(x\)-intercepts at \(x = \pm \sqrt{a}\).%

\item\hypertarget{li-2261}{}\hypertarget{p-3480}{}%
See \href{http://www.desmos.com/calculator/2x1j8cwozg}{desmos.com} for additional graph samples. We note that as \(a\) gets increasingly negative, the graph of \(y=p(x)\) gets steeper near the origin, tending more and more toward a linear shape (which it never achieves). Conversely, as \(a\) gets increasingly positive, the two bumps on the graph get more and more pronounced.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{act-3-2-2}
\hypertarget{p-3481}{}%
Consider the two-parameter family of functions of the form \(h(x) = a(1-e^{-bx})\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are positive real numbers. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2262}{}\hypertarget{p-3482}{}%
Find the first derivative and the critical numbers of \(h\). Use these to construct a first derivative sign chart and determine for which values of \(x\) the function \(h\) is increasing and decreasing.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2263}{}\hypertarget{p-3483}{}%
Find the second derivative and build a second derivative sign chart. For which values of \(x\) is a function in this family concave up? Concave down?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2264}{}\hypertarget{p-3484}{}%
What is the value of \(\lim_{x \to \infty} a(1-e^{-bx})\)? What about \(\lim_{x \to -\infty} a(1-e^{-bx})\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2265}{}\hypertarget{p-3485}{}%
How does changing the value of \(b\) affect the shape of the curve?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2266}{}\hypertarget{p-3486}{}%
Without using a graphing utility, sketch the graph of a typical member of this family. Write several sentences to describe the overall behavior of a typical function \(h\) and how this behavior depends on \(a\) and \(b\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-92}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3487}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2267}{}\hypertarget{p-3488}{}%
Expand to write \(h(x) = a - ae^{-bx}\) before differentiating.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2268}{}\hypertarget{p-3489}{}%
Remember that \(e^{-bx}\) is always positive (hence, never zero), regardless of the value of \(x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2269}{}\hypertarget{p-3490}{}%
Recall that \(e^{-x} \to 0\) as \(x \to \infty\) and \(e^{-x} \to \infty\) as \(x \to -\infty\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2270}{}\hypertarget{p-3491}{}%
Consider how \(b\) affects the value of \(h'(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2271}{}\hypertarget{p-3492}{}%
Use your work in (a)-(d).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-155}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3493}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2272}{}\hypertarget{p-3494}{}%
\(h\) is an always increasing function.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2273}{}\hypertarget{p-3495}{}%
\(h\) is always concave down.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2274}{}\hypertarget{p-3496}{}%
\(\lim_{x \to \infty} a(1-e^{-bx}) = a\), and \(\lim_{x \to -\infty} a(1-e^{-bx}) = -\infty\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2275}{}\hypertarget{p-3497}{}%
If \(b\) is large and \(x\) is close to zero, \(h'(x)\) is relatively large near \(x = 0\), and the curve's slope will quickly approach zero as \(x\) increases. If \(b\) is small, the graph is less steep near \(x = 0\) and its slope goes to zero less quickly as \(x\) increases.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2276}{}% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)

\setlength{\tabcolsep}{0\linewidth}
% @{} suppress \tabcolsep at extremes, so margins behave as intended
\par\medskip\noindent
\hspace*{0.25\linewidth}%
\begin{tabular}{@{}*{1}{c}@{}}
\begin{minipage}[c][\panelmax][t]{0.5\linewidth}\usebox{\panelboxAimage}\end{minipage}\end{tabular}\\
% end: side-by-side as tabular
}% end: group for a single side-by-side
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-182}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3498}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2277}{}\hypertarget{p-3499}{}%
Since \(h(x) = a - ae^{-bx}\), we have by the constant multiple and chain rules that%
\begin{equation*}
h'(x) = -ae^{-bx}(-b) = abe^{-bx}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Since \(a\) and \(b\) are positive constants and \(e^{-bx} \gt 0\) for all \(x\), we see that \(h'(x)\) is never zero (nor undefined), and indeed \(h'(x) \gt 0\) for all \(x\). Hence \(h\) is an always increasing function.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2278}{}\hypertarget{p-3500}{}%
Because \(h'(x) = abe^{-bx}\), we have that \(h''(x) = abe^{-bx}(-b) = -ab^2e^{-bx}\). As with \(h'\), we recognize that \(a\), \(b^2\), and \(e^{-bx}\) are always positive, and thus \(h''(x) = -ab^2e^{-bx} \lt 0\) for all values of \(x\), making \(h\) always concave down.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2279}{}\hypertarget{p-3501}{}%
As \(x \to \infty\), \(e^{-bx} \to 0\). Thus,%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{x \to \infty} a(1-e^{-bx}) = \lim_{x \to \infty} (a - ae^{-bx}) = a - 0 = a\text{.}
\end{equation*}
This shows that \(h\) has a horizontal asymptote at \(y = a\) as we move rightward on its graph. As \(x \to -\infty\), \(e^{-bx} \to \infty\). Thus,%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{x \to -\infty} a(1-e^{-bx}) = \lim_{x \to -\infty} (a - ae^{-bx}) = -\infty\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-2280}{}\hypertarget{p-3502}{}%
Noting that \(h'(x) = abe^{-bx}\), we see that if we consider different values of \(b\), the slope of the graph changes. If \(b\) is large and \(x\) is close to zero, \(h'(x) \approx ab\) (since \(e^0 = 1\)), so \(h'(x)\) is relatively large near \(x = 0\). At the same time, for large \(b\), \(e^{-bx}\) approaches zero quickly as \(x\) increases, so the curve's slope will quickly approach zero as \(x\) increases. If \(b\) is small, the graph is less steep near \(x = 0\) and its slope goes to zero less quickly as \(x\) increases.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2281}{}\hypertarget{p-3503}{}%
Observing that \(h(0) = 0\) and \(\lim_{x \to \infty} h(x) = a\), along with the facts that \(h\) is always increasing and always concave down, we see that a typical member of this family looks like the following graph.%

\begin{example}[]\label{act-3-2-3}
\hypertarget{p-3504}{}%
Let \(L(t) = \frac{A}{1+ce^{-kt}}\), where \(A\), \(c\), and \(k\) are all positive real numbers. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2282}{}\hypertarget{p-3505}{}%
Observe that we can equivalently write \(L(t) = A(1+ce^{-kt})^{-1}\). Find \(L'(t)\) and explain why \(L\) has no critical numbers. Is \(L\) always increasing or always decreasing? Why?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2283}{}\hypertarget{p-3506}{}%
Given the fact that%
\begin{equation*}
L''(t) = Ack^2e^{-kt} \frac{ce^{-kt}-1}{(1+ce^{-kt})^3}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
find all values of \(t\) such that \(L''(t) = 0\) and then construct a second derivative sign chart. For which values of \(t\) is a function in this family concave up?  Concave down?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2284}{}\hypertarget{p-3507}{}%
What is the value of \(\lim_{t \to \infty} \frac{A}{1+ce^{-kt}}\)? \(\lim_{t \to -\infty} \frac{A}{1+ce^{-kt}}\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2285}{}\hypertarget{p-3508}{}%
Find the value of \(L(t)\) at the inflection point found in (b).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2286}{}\hypertarget{p-3509}{}%
Without using a graphing utility, sketch the graph of a typical member of this family. Write several sentences to describe the overall behavior of a typical function \(L\) and how this behavior depends on the values of the parameters \(A\), \(c\), and \(k\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2287}{}\hypertarget{p-3510}{}%
Explain why it is reasonable to think that the function \(L(t)\) models the growth of a population over time, in a setting where the surrounding environment cannot support a population larger than \(A\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-93}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3511}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2288}{}\hypertarget{p-3512}{}%
Use the chain rule, treating \(A\), \(c\), and \(k\) as constants.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2289}{}\hypertarget{p-3513}{}%
Note that the only way \(L''(t) = 0\) is if \(ce^{-kt}-1 = 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2290}{}\hypertarget{p-3514}{}%
Remember that \(e^{-t} \to 0\) as \(t \to \infty\) and \(e^{-t} \to \infty\) as \(t \to -\infty\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2291}{}\hypertarget{p-3515}{}%
Note that at the inflection point \(t_0\), we have \(ce^{-kt_0}=1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2292}{}\hypertarget{p-3516}{}%
Think about horizontal asymptotes, where \(L\) is increasing and decreasing, and concavity.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2293}{}\hypertarget{p-3517}{}%
Intuitively, if an environment can only support a population of a certain size, how should the population be growing when it is well below the limit? When it is approaching the limit? Does this intuition describe what you found to be true for \(L\)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-156}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3518}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2294}{}\hypertarget{p-3519}{}%
\(L\) is an always increasing function.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2295}{}\hypertarget{p-3520}{}%
\(L\) is concave up for all \(t \lt -\frac{1}{k} \ln \big(\frac{1}{c}\big)\) and concave down for all \(t\gt-\frac1k\ln\big(\frac1c\big)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2296}{}\hypertarget{p-3521}{}%
\(\lim_{t \to \infty} \frac{A}{1+ce^{-kt}} = A\), and%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{t \to -\infty} \frac{A}{1+ce^{-kt}} = 0\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-2297}{}\hypertarget{p-3522}{}%
The inflection point on the graph of \(L\) is \(\big( -\frac{1}{k} \ln \big(\frac{1}{c}\big), \frac{A}{2}\big)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2298}{}% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)

\item\hypertarget{li-2299}{}\hypertarget{p-3523}{}%
The population grows rapidly at first, but its growth rate decreases to near zero as the population approaches the limiting size of \(A\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-183}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3524}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2300}{}\hypertarget{p-3525}{}%
By the chain rule and treating \(A\), \(c\), and \(k\) as constants, we find that%
\begin{equation*}
L'(t) = A(-1)(1+ce^{-kt})^{-2} ce^{-kt}(-k) = Acke^{-kt}(1+ce^{-kt})^{-2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Since \(A\), \(c\), and \(k\) are all positive and \(e^{-kt} \gt 0\) for all values of \(t\), it is apparent that \(L'(t)\) is never zero (nor undefined), and indeed is positive for every value of \(t\). Thus, \(L\) is an always increasing function.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2301}{}\hypertarget{p-3526}{}%
Given that%
\begin{equation*}
L''(t) = Ack^2e^{-kt} \frac{ce^{-kt}-1}{(1+ce^{-kt})^3}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
the only way \(L''(t) = 0\) is if \(ce^{-kt}-1 = 0\). Solving \(ce^{-kt}-1 = 0\) for \(t\), we first write \(e^{-kt} = \frac{1}{c}\). Taking the natural logarithm of both sides yields \(-kt = \ln\big(\frac{1}{c}\big)\), so that%
\begin{equation*}
t = -\frac{1}{k} \ln \left(\frac{1}{c}\right)
\end{equation*}
is the only value of \(t\) for which \(L''(t) = 0\). Now, observe that since \(ce^{-kt} \to 0\) as \(t \to \infty\) and \(ce^{-kt}\to\infty\) as \(t\to-\infty\), it follows that the quantity \(ce^{-kt} - 1\) will be positive to the left of where it is zero and negative to the right of where it is zero. Since this is the only term in \(L''(t)\) that can change sign, it follows that \(L''(t) \gt 0\) for \(t \lt  -\frac{1}{k} \ln \big(\frac{1}{c}\big)\) and \(L''(t) \lt 0\) for \(t \gt -\frac{1}{k} \ln \big(\frac{1}{c}\big)\), making \(L\) concave up to the left of the noted inflection point and concave down thereafter.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2302}{}\hypertarget{p-3527}{}%
Recalling that \(e^{-kt} \to 0\) as \(t \to \infty\), we observe that%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{t \to \infty} \frac{A}{1+ce^{-kt}} = \frac{A}{1+0} = A\text{,}
\end{equation*}
so \(L\) has a horizontal asymptote of \(y = A\) as \(t \to \infty\). On the other hand, since \(e^{-kt} \to \infty\) as \(t \to -\infty\), this causes the denominator of \(L\) to grow without bound (while the numerator remains constant), and therefore%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{t \to -\infty} \frac{A}{1+ce^{-kt}} = 0\text{,}
\end{equation*}
which means \(L\) has a horizontal asymptote of \(y = 0\) as \(t \to -\infty\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2303}{}\hypertarget{p-3528}{}%
From (b), we know that \(t = -\frac{1}{k} \ln \big(\frac{1}{c}\big)\) is the location of the inflection point of \(L\). We evaluate \(L\big( -\frac{1}{k} \ln \big(\frac{1}{c}\big) \big)\),\footnote{If you prefer to evaluate the function without this apparent ``shortcut'', be careful with parentheses as you plug in and evaluate. In particular, notice that we do indeed have \(ce^{-k\left[-\frac{\ln(\frac{1}{c})}{k}\right]}=ce^{k\frac{\ln(\frac{1}{c})}{k}}=ce^{\ln(\frac{1}{c})}=c(\frac{1}{c})=1\). The remainder of the calculation should match what is shown below.\label{fn-36}} recalling that at this \(t\)-value we have the equality \(ce^{-kt}=1\), thus%
\begin{equation*}
L\left( -\frac{1}{k} \ln \left(\frac{1}{c}\right) \right) = \frac{A}{1+1} = \frac{A}{2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Thus, the inflection point on the graph of \(L\) is located at  \(\big( -\frac{1}{k} \ln \big(\frac{1}{c}\big), \frac{A}{2}\big)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2304}{}\hypertarget{p-3529}{}%
We have shown that \(L\) is an always increasing function that has horizontal asymptotes at \(y =0\) and \(y = A\), as well as an inflection point at \(\big( -\frac{1}{k} \ln \big(\frac{1}{c}\big), \frac{A}{2}\big)\), which we note lies vertically halfway between the asymptotes. In addition, we see that \(L(0) = \frac{A}{1+c}\). The combination of all of this information shows us that a typical graph in this family of functions is given by the following figure.%

\end{enumerate}

\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 3.4.2 Summary}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Summary}]{Summary}\label{subsection-92}
\hypertarget{p-3531}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3532}{}%
Given a family of functions that depends on one or more parameters, we can often accurately describe the shape of the function in terms of the parameters by investigating how critical numbers and locations where the second derivative is zero depend on the values of these parameters.%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3533}{}%
In particular, just as we can creat first and second derivative sign charts for a single function, we can often do so for entire families of functions where critical numbers and possible inflection points depend on arbitrary constants. These sign charts then reveal where members of the family are increasing or decreasing, concave up or concave down, and help us to identify relative extrema and inflection points.%
\end{itemize}
%

%

\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-157}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3539}{}%

\(x = 0\) and \(x = \frac{2a}{3}\).%

\item\hypertarget{li-2315}{}\hypertarget{p-3542}{}%

\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-184}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3543}{}%

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2316}{}\hypertarget{p-3544}{}%
Writing \(p(x) = x^3 - ax^2 = x^2(x-a)\), we see that \(p(x) = 0\) at \(x=0\) and \(x=a\). Further, since \(x^2 \ge 0\) for all \(x\), we note that \(p(x) \le 0\) whenever \(x \lt a \) and \(p(x) \gt 0\) for all \(x \gt a\). A typical such function is plotted below.%

\item\hypertarget{li-2317}{}\hypertarget{p-3545}{}%
To find the critical numbers of \(p\), we first compute \(p'(x)\). Treating \(a\) as constant, we have \(p'(x) = 3x^2 - 2ax = x(3x - 2a)\). Thus, setting \(p'(x) = 0\), we find that \(x(3x-2a) = 0\) and thus \(x = 0\) and \(x = \frac{2a}{3}\) are the critical numbers of \(p\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2318}{}\hypertarget{p-3546}{}%
Observe that \(p''(x) = 6x - 2a\) and thus \(p''(x) = 0\) implies that \(x = \frac{a}{2}\). Since \(p''(x)\) is linear with positive slope, we see that \(p''(x)\) changes sign from negative to positive at \(x = \frac{a}{2}\), and thus \(p\) is concave down for \(x \lt \frac{a}{2}\) and concave up for \(x \gt \frac{a}{2}\) and \(x = \frac{a}{2}\) is the only inflection point of \(p\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2319}{}\hypertarget{p-3547}{}%
There is always a critical number of \(p\) at \(x = 0\). But the other critical number at \(x = \frac{2a}{3}\) and the inflection point at \(x = \frac{a}{3}\) both obviously depend directly on \(a\): as we increase the value of \(a\), both the location of the critical number and the inflection point move to the right along with \(a\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[9.]\hypertarget{exercise-218}{}(Analyzing families of functions)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-3548}{}%
Let \(q(x) = \frac{e^{-x}}{x-c}\) be a one-parameter family of functions where \(c \gt 0\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2320}{}\hypertarget{p-3549}{}%
Explain why \(q\) has a vertical asymptote at \(x = c\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2321}{}\hypertarget{p-3550}{}%
Determine \(\lim_{x \to \infty} q(x)\) and \(\lim_{x \to -\infty} q(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2322}{}\hypertarget{p-3551}{}%
Compute \(q'(x)\) and find all critical numbers of \(q\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2323}{}\hypertarget{p-3552}{}%
Construct a first derivative sign chart for \(q\) and determine whether each critical number leads to a local minimum, local maximum, or neither for the function \(q\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2324}{}\hypertarget{p-3553}{}%
Sketch a typical member of this family of functions with important behaviors clearly labeled.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-158}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3554}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2325}{}\hypertarget{p-3555}{}%
\(x=c\) is a vertical asymptote because \(\lim_{x \to c^+} \frac{e^{-x}}{x-c} = \infty\) and \(\lim_{x \to c^-} \frac{e^{-x}}{x-c} = -\infty\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2326}{}\hypertarget{p-3556}{}%
\(\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{e^{-x}}{x-c} = 0\); \(\lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{e^{-x}}{x-c} = -\infty\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2327}{}\hypertarget{p-3557}{}%
The only critical number for \(q\) is \(x=c-1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2328}{}\hypertarget{p-3558}{}%
When \(x \lt c-1\), \(q'(x) \gt 0\); when \(x \gt c-1\), \(q'(x) \lt 0\); \(q\) has a local maximum at \(x = c-1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2329}{}% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)

%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-185}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3559}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2330}{}\hypertarget{p-3560}{}%
The value of the numerator at \(x=c\) is \(e^{-c} \ne 0\), while the value of the denominator is \(0\) at \(x=c\). Thus, \(\lim_{x \to c^+} \frac{e^{-x}}{x-c} = \infty\) and \(\lim_{x \to c^-} \frac{e^{-x}}{x-c} = -\infty\). This makes the line \(x=c\) a vertical asymptote for \(q\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2331}{}\hypertarget{p-3561}{}%
We can write \(q(x)\) as \(q(x) = \frac{1}{(x-c)e^x}\) and thus see the denominator increases without bound as \(x \to \infty\). Therefore, \(\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{e^{-x}}{x-c} = 0\). This makes the line \(y=0\) a horizontal asymptote for \(q\). As \(x \to -\infty\), \(e^{-x}\) increases without bound, while \((x-c)\) decreases without bound. Thus, \(q\) has an indeterminate form as \(x \to -infty\). Applying L'Hopital's Rule gives us%
\begin{equation*}
\lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{e^{-x}}{x-c} = \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{-e^{-x}}{1} = -\infty\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-2332}{}\hypertarget{p-3562}{}%
Using \(q(x) = \frac{1}{(x-c)e^x}\), the quotient and product rules along with algebraic simplification show that%
\begin{equation*}
q'(x) = -\frac{(x-c)e^x + e^x}{(x-c)^2\left(e^x\right)^2} = -\frac{x-c+1}{(x-c)^2e^x}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
The function \(q\) has critical points in its domain where \(q'(x) = 0\) or \(q'(x)\) doesn't exist. Note that \(q'(x)\) is undefined at \(x=c\), but \(c\) is not in the domain of mq. Thus, the only critical points of \(q\) occur when \(q'(x)=0\). The only way the fraction \(q'(x)\) can be \(0\) is if the numerator is \(0\). Since \(x-c+1=0\) when \(x=c-1\), the only critical number for \(q\) is \(x=c-1\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2333}{}\hypertarget{p-3563}{}%
The values of the exponential function \(e^x\) and the quadratic \((x-c)^2\) are positive for \(x \neq c\), so the sign of \(q'(x) = -\frac{x-c+1}{(x-c)^2e^x}\) depends entirely on the sign of \(x-(c-1)\). When \(x \lt c-1\) we see that \(q'(x) \gt 0\) and when \(x \gt c-1\) we have \(q'(x) \lt 0\). Thus, \(q\) is increasing on \((-\infty,
c-1)\) and is decreasing on \((c-1,c)\), so it follows that \(q(c-1)\) is a relative maximum value. This value is a local maximum, since the value of \(q\) can be made as large as we like as shown in part (b).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2334}{}\hypertarget{p-3564}{}%
We've shown that a typical member of the family of functions given by \(q(x) = \frac{1}{(x-c)e^x}\) has a vertical asymptote at \(x = c\) and a critical number at which a local maximum occurs one unit to the left of \(c\) at \(x = c-1\). A typical such graph is shown below. Note how \(q\) is increasing and decreasing according to our earlier work in (d).%

\item[10.]\hypertarget{exercise-219}{}(Analyzing families of functions)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-3565}{}%
Let \(E(x) = e^{-\frac{(x-m)^2}{2s^2}}\), where \(m\) is any real number and \(s\) is a positive real number. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2335}{}\hypertarget{p-3566}{}%

\item\hypertarget{li-2336}{}\hypertarget{p-3567}{}%
Construct a first derivative sign chart for \(E\) and classify each critical number of the function as a local minimum, local maximum, or neither.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2337}{}\hypertarget{p-3568}{}%
It can be shown that \(E''(x)\) is given by the formula%
\begin{equation*}
E''(x) = e^{-\frac{(x-m)^2}{2s^2}} \left(\frac{(x-m)^2 - s^2}{s^4} \right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Find all values of \(x\) for which \(E''(x) = 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2338}{}\hypertarget{p-3569}{}%
Determine \(\lim_{x \to \infty} E(x)\) and \(\lim_{x \to -\infty} E(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2339}{}\hypertarget{p-3570}{}%
Construct a labeled graph of a typical function \(E\) that clearly shows how important points on the graph of \(y = E(x)\) depend on \(m\) and \(s\).%
\end{enumerate}
%

\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-159}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3571}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2340}{}\hypertarget{p-3572}{}%
\(x = m\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2341}{}\hypertarget{p-3573}{}%
\(E\) is increasing for \(x \lt m\) and decreasing for \(x \gt m\), with a local maximum at \(x = m\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2342}{}\hypertarget{p-3574}{}%

\item\hypertarget{li-2343}{}\hypertarget{p-3575}{}%
\(\lim_{x \to \infty} E(x) = \lim_{x \to -\infty} E(x) = 0\).%

\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-186}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3576}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2345}{}\hypertarget{p-3577}{}%
Treating \(m\) and \(s\) as constants, by the chain rule,%
\begin{equation*}
E'(x) = e^{-\frac{(x-m)^2}{2s^2}} \cdot \frac{d}{dx}\left[ -\frac{(x-m)^2}{2s^2} \right] = e^{-\frac{(x-m)^2}{2s^2}} \cdot \left[ -\frac{2(x-m)}{2s^2} \right]
\end{equation*}
Note that \(E'(x)\) is defined for every value of \(x\), thus the only critical numbers occur where \(E'(x) = 0\). Since \(e\) raised to any power is never zero, the only way that \(E'(x) = 0\) is for \(\left[ -\frac{2(x-m)}{2s^2} \right] = 0\), which implies that \(x = m\). Thus, \(x = m\) is the only critical number of \(E\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2346}{}\hypertarget{p-3578}{}%
As we noted in (a), \(x = m\) is the only critical number of \(E\). More over, since \(e\) to any power is always positive, the sign of \(E'(x)\) depends entirely on the expression \(-\frac{2(x-m)}{2s^2} = -\frac{1}{2}(x-m)\). This linear function of \(x\) has negative slope, and thus is positive for \(x \lt m\) and negative for \(x \gt m\), and thus \(E'(x)\) is positive for \(x \lt m\) and negative for \(x \gt m\). Therefore, \(E\) is increasing for \(x \lt m\) and decreasing for \(x \gt m\), with a local maximum at \(x = m\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2347}{}\hypertarget{p-3579}{}%
From the given formula for \(E''(x)\) and our knowledge that \(e\) to any power is positive, the only way \(E''(x) = 0\) is for%
\begin{equation*}
\left(\frac{(x-m)^2 - s^2}{s^4} \right) = 0\text{,}
\end{equation*}
which implies that \((x-m)^2 = s^2\), and therefore \(x-m = \pm s\), or \(x = m \pm s\). These are the two values for which \(E''(x) = 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2348}{}\hypertarget{p-3580}{}%
As \(x \to \pm \infty\), we know that the quadratic function \(-\frac{(x-m)^2}{2s^2}\) must decrease without bound because the quadratic function opens down. Thus, the power to which we are raising \(e\) in the formula for \(E(x)\) is decreasing without bound, which means that \(E(x)\) must approach \(0\) since raising \(e\) to more and more negative numbers drives the result to \(0\). Thus, \(\lim_{x \to \infty} E(x) = \lim_{x \to -\infty} E(x) = 0\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2349}{}\hypertarget{p-3581}{}%
We've shown that \(E\) has a single critical number at \(x = m\) and two potential points of inflection at \(x = m \pm s\), as well as that \(E(x) \to 0\) as \(x \to \pm \infty\). All of these properties are reflected in the following figure.%

\typeout{Section 3.5 Related Rates}
\typeout{************************************************}
\section[{Related Rates}]{Related Rates}\label{sec-3-5-rel-rates}
\begin{objectives}{Motivating Questions}\label{objectives-23}
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3582}{}%
If two quantities that are related, such as the radius and volume of a spherical balloon, are both changing as implicit functions of time, how are their rates of change related? That is, how does the relationship between the values of the quantities affect the relationship between their respective derivatives with respect to time?%
\end{itemize}
\end{objectives}
\hypertarget{p-3583}{}%
In most of our applications of the derivative so far, we have been interested in the instantaneous rate at which one variable, perhaps called \(y\), changes with respect to another, perhaps called \(x\), leading us to compute and interpret \(\frac{dy}{dx}\). We next consider situations where several variable quantities are related, but where each quantity is implicitly a function of time, which will be represented by the variable \(t\). Through knowing how the quantities are related, we will be interested in determining how their respective rates of change with respect to time are related.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3584}{}%
For example, suppose that air is being pumped into a spherical balloon so that its volume increases at a constant rate. Since the balloon's volume and radius are related, we ought to be able to discover how fast the radius is changing by knowing how fast the volume is changing.  Can we determine how fast the radius of the balloon is increasing  when the balloon is a certain size? We explore a scenario of this type in \hyperref[PA-3-5]{Example~\ref{PA-3-5}}.%
\begin{example}[]\label{PA-3-5}
\hypertarget{p-3585}{}%
A spherical balloon with diameter \(d\) is being inflated at a constant rate of 20 cubic inches per second.  How fast is the radius of the balloon changing at the instant the balloon's diameter is 12 inches? Is the radius changing more rapidly when \(d = 12\) or when \(d = 16\)? Why? These questions have been broken up into the following parts to guide you through the solution process.%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2351}{}\hypertarget{p-3586}{}%
Recall that the volume of a sphere of radius \(r\) is \(V = \frac{4}{3} \pi r^3\). Note that in the setting of this problem, \emph{both} \(V\) and \(r\) are changing as \(t\) (time) changes, and thus both \(V\) and \(r\) may be viewed as implicit functions of \(t\), with respective derivatives \(\frac{dV}{dt}\) and \(\frac{dr}{dt}\). Differentiate both sides of the equation \(V = \frac{4}{3} \pi r^3\) with respect to \(t\) to find a formula for \(\frac{dV}{dt}\) that depends on both \(r\) and \(\frac{dr}{dt}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2352}{}\hypertarget{p-3587}{}%
By differentiating the volume function with respect to \emph{time}, we have  ``related the rates'' of change of \(V\) and \(r\). Recall that the problem statement tells us that the balloon is being inflated at a constant \emph{rate} of 20 cubic inches per second. Is this rate the value of \(\frac{dr}{dt}\) or \(\frac{dV}{dt}\)? Why?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2353}{}\hypertarget{p-3588}{}%
Note that when the diameter of the balloon is 12 inches, we know the value of the radius.  In the formula you found in (a) for \(\frac{dV}{dt}\), substitute the values we know for the relevant quantities and solve for the remaining unknown quantity. How fast is the radius changing at the instant \(d = 12\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2354}{}\hypertarget{p-3589}{}%
How is the situation different when \(d = 16\)? When is the radius changing more rapidly, when \(d = 12\) or when \(d = 16\)?%
\end{enumerate}
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-94}{}\quad%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2355}{}\hypertarget{p-3590}{}%
Remember that we need to apply the chain rule to the right side of the equation to differentiate \(r\) with respect to \(t\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2356}{}\hypertarget{p-3591}{}%
Look at the units.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2357}{}\hypertarget{p-3592}{}%
Use your answer to part (b) to help fill in all missing information. Only one variable should be left.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2358}{}\hypertarget{p-3593}{}%
Which radius results in a larger rate? Note that this question asks about the rate of change of the radius, not of the volume.%
\end{enumerate}
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-160}{}\quad%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2359}{}\hypertarget{p-3594}{}%
\(\frac{dV}{dt}=4\pi r^2\frac{dr}{dt}.\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-2360}{}\hypertarget{p-3595}{}%
\(\frac{dV}{dt}=20\) cubic inches per second.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2361}{}\hypertarget{p-3596}{}%
\(20=4\pi (6)^2 \frac{dr}{dt},\) so \(\frac{dr}{dt}=\frac{5}{36\pi}\) inches per second when the diameter is 12 inches.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2362}{}\hypertarget{p-3597}{}%
\(\frac{dr}{dt}=\frac{5}{64\pi}\) inches per second when the diameter is 16 inches. Thus, the radius is changing more rapidly when the diameter is 12 inches.%
\end{enumerate}
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-187}{}\quad%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2363}{}\hypertarget{p-3598}{}%
Starting with the equation \(V=\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\), we differentiate both sides with respect to \(t\). We need to use the chain rule to differentiate the right side of the equation since \(r\) is really \(r(t)\), a function of \(t\). So, the equation we have is really \(V(t)=\frac{4}{3}\pi [r(t)]^3\). Differentiating with respect to \(t\) we have%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dV}{dt}=4\pi r^2\frac{dr}{dt}.
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-2364}{}\hypertarget{p-3599}{}%
Since the units are cubic inches per second, this is a volume rate. So, \(\frac{dV}{dt}=20\) cubic inches per second.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2365}{}\hypertarget{p-3600}{}%
Since \(\frac{dV}{dt}=20\) and \(r=6\) when \(d=12\), we have \(20=4\pi(6)^2\frac{dr}{dt}\). So, \(\frac{dr}{dt}=\frac{5}{36\pi}\) inches per second.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2366}{}\hypertarget{p-3601}{}%
Doing the same thing as in part (c), we find that \(\frac{dr}{dt}=\frac{5}{64\pi}\) inches per second when the diameter is \(16\) inches (so \(r=8\)). This number is smaller than the one calculated in part (c), so the radius is changing more rapidly when the diameter is \(12\) inches. Intuitively, this makes sense since the balloon's volume is growing at a constant rate: as the balloon grows, a small change in the radius will have a larger impact on the change in volume; equivalently, the same change in volume corresponds to a smaller change in the radius when the balloon is large.%
\end{enumerate}
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 3.5.1 Related Rates Problems}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Related Rates Problems}]{Related Rates Problems}\label{subsection-93}
\hypertarget{p-3602}{}%
In problems where two or more quantities can be related to one another and all of the variables involved are implicit functions of time, \(t\), we are often interested in examining how their rates are related; we call these \terminology{related rates} problems. \index{related rates} Once we have an equation establishing the relationship among the variables, we differentiate implicitly with respect to time to find connections among the rates of change.%
\begin{example}[]\label{Ex-3-5-FallingSand}
\hypertarget{p-3603}{}%
Sand is being dumped by a conveyor belt onto a pile so that the sand forms a right circular cone, as pictured below in \hyperref[F-3-5-ConeEx]{Figure~\ref{F-3-5-ConeEx}}. As sand falls from the conveyor belt, several features of the sand pile will change: the volume (\(V\)) of the pile will grow, the height (\(h\)) will increase, and the radius (\(r\)) will get bigger, too. All of these quantities are related to one another, and the rate at which each is changing is related to the rate at which sand falls from the conveyor.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/3_5_ConeEx.pdf}
\caption{A conical pile of sand.\label{F-3-5-ConeEx}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-3604}{}%
Find an equation relating the rates at which the volume, radius, and height each change with respect to time.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-95}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3605}{}%
Recall that the volume of a right circular cone is%
\begin{equation*}
V=\frac13\pi r^2h\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Remember that all of \(V\), \(r\), and \(h\) are functions of \(t\). You will need the chain rule (among others) to differentiate.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-161}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3606}{}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dV}{dt}=\frac23\pi rh\frac{dr}{dt}+\frac13\pi r^2\frac{dh}{dt}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-188}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3607}{}%
We begin by identifying which variables are changing and how they are related. In this problem, we observe that the radius and height of the pile are related to its volume by the standard equation for the volume of a cone,%
\begin{equation*}
V = \frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 h\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3608}{}%
Viewing each of \(V\), \(r\), and \(h\) as functions of \(t\), we differentiate implicitly to arrive at an equation that relates their respective rates of change. Taking the derivative of each side of the equation with respect to \(t\), we find%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dt}[V] = \frac{d}{dt}\left[\frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 h\right]\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3609}{}%
On the left, \(\frac{d}{dt}[V]\) is simply \(\frac{dV}{dt}\). On the right, the situation is more complicated, as both \(r\) and \(h\) are implicit functions of \(t\). Hence we need the product and chain rules. We find that\footnote{Note particularly how we are using ideas from \hyperref[sec-2-7-implicit]{Section~\ref{sec-2-7-implicit}} on implicit differentiation. There we found that when \(y\) is an implicit function of \(x\), \(\frac{d}{dx}[y^2] = 2y \frac{dy}{dx}\). The same principles are applied here when we compute \(\frac{d}{dt}[r^2] = 2r \frac{dr}{dt}\).\label{fn-37}}%
\begin{align*}
\frac{dV}{dt} &=  \frac{d}{dt}\left[\frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 h\right]\\
&=  \frac{1}{3} \pi \frac{d}{dt}\big[r^2\big]h + \frac{1}{3} \pi r^2\frac{d}{dt}[h]\\
&=  \frac{1}{3} \pi 2r\frac{dr}{dt}h + \frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 \frac{dh}{dt}\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3610}{}%
Thus, the equation%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{2}{3} \pi rh \frac{dr}{dt}+ \frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 \frac{dh}{dt}
\end{equation*}
relates the rates of change of \(V\), \(h\), and \(r\) with respect to time.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3611}{}%
If we are given sufficient additional information, we may then find the value of one or more of these rates of change at a specific point in time.%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{Ex-3-5-MoreSand}
\hypertarget{p-3612}{}%
In the setting of \hyperref[Ex-3-5-FallingSand]{Example~\ref{Ex-3-5-FallingSand}}, suppose we also know the following: (a) sand falls from the conveyor in such a way that the height of the pile is always half the radius, and (b) sand falls from the conveyor belt at a constant rate of 10 cubic feet per minute. How fast is the height of the sandpile changing at the moment the radius is 4 feet?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-96}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3613}{}%
Use your equation from \hyperref[Ex-3-5-FallingSand]{Example~\ref{Ex-3-5-FallingSand}} that says%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dV}{dt} =  \frac{2}{3} \pi rh \frac{dr}{dt}+\frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 \frac{dh}{dt}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Alternatively, you may try substituting \(h=\frac12r\) into the conical volume formula \(V=\frac13\pi r^2h\) and retaking the derivative (you would not need the product rule this time, but would still need the chain rule).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-162}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3614}{}%
When the radius is \(4\) feet, the height is changing at a rate of \(\frac{5}{8\pi}\approx0.199\) feet per minute.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-189}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3615}{}%
First, we note that we want to know the value of \(\frac{dh}{dt}\) when \(r=4\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3616}{}%
The information that the height is always half the radius tells us that for all values of \(t\), \(h = \frac{1}{2}r\). Differentiating with respect to \(t\), it follows that \(\frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{1}{2} \frac{dr}{dt}\). These relationships enable us to relate \(\frac{dV}{dt}\) to just one of \(r\) or \(h\). Substituting the expressions involving \(r\) and \(\frac{dr}{dt}\) for \(h\) and \(\frac{dh}{dt}\),\footnote{Note that even though we are looking for the rate at which the height changes, the information we know involves the radius, so it is easier to first solve things in terms of \(r\) and \(\frac{dr}{dt}\) and then transition back to \(\frac{dh}{dt}\). Also, observe that \textemdash{} rather than substituting expressions into the formula for \(\frac{dV}{dt}\) \textemdash{} we could instead substitute into the formula for \(V\) and recalculate the derivative. Doing so would yield \(V=\frac13\pi r^2\big(\frac12r\big)=\frac16\pi r^3\) and \(\frac{dV}{dt}=\frac12\pi r^2\frac{dr}{dt}\), which is the same relation that we have below.\label{fn-38}} we now have that%
\begin{align*}
\frac{dV}{dt}\amp=\frac23\pi rh\frac{dr}{dt}+\frac13\pi r^2\frac{dh}{dt}\\
\amp = \frac{2}{3} \pi r \left(\frac{1}{2}r \right) \frac{dr}{dt}+\frac13\pi r^2\left(\frac12\frac{dr}{dt}\right)\\
\amp=\frac12\pi r^2\frac{dr}{dt}\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3617}{}%
Since sand falls from the conveyor at the constant rate of 10 cubic feet per minute, the value of \(\frac{dV}{dt}\), the rate at which the volume of the sand pile changes, is \(\frac{dV}{dt} = 10\) ft\(^3\)/min. We are interested in how fast the height of the pile is changing at the instant when \(r = 4\), so we substitute \(r = 4\), \(\frac{dV}{dt} = 10\), and \(\frac{dr}{dt}=\left.\frac{dr}{dt}\right|_{r=4}\) into our equation above to find%
\begin{equation*}
10 = \frac{1}{2} \pi (4)^2 \left. \frac{dr}{dt} \right|_{r=4}= 8\pi \left. \frac{dr}{dt} \right|_{r=4}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3618}{}%
Only the value of \(\left. \frac{dr}{dt} \right|_{r=4}\) remains unknown;  solving, we find%
\begin{equation*}
\left. \frac{dr}{dt} \right|_{r=4} = \frac{10}{8\pi} \approx 0.39789 \ \text{ft/min}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Recall that we were interested in how fast the \emph{height} of the pile was changing at this instant, so we want to know \(\frac{dh}{dt}\) when \(r = 4\). Since \(\frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{1}{2} \frac{dr}{dt}\) for all values of \(t\), it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
\left. \frac{dh}{dt} \right|_{r=4} =\frac12\left.\frac{dr}{dt}\right|_{r=4}= \frac{5}{8\pi} \approx 0.19894 \ \text{ft/min}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-3619}{}%
In \hyperref[Ex-3-5-MoreSand]{Example~\ref{Ex-3-5-MoreSand}}, it is important to note the difference between the notations \(\frac{dr}{dt}\) and \(\left. \frac{dr}{dt} \right|_{r=4}\). The former represents the rate of change of \(r\) with respect to \(t\) at an arbitrary value of \(t\), while the latter is the rate of change of \(r\) with respect to \(t\) at a particular moment, the moment when \(r = 4\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3620}{}%
Our work with both of the sandpile problems above is similar in many ways to our approach in \hyperref[PA-3-5]{Example~\ref{PA-3-5}}, and these steps are typical of most related rates problems. In certain ways, they also resemble work we do in applied optimization problems, and here we summarize the main approach for consideration in subsequent problems.%
\begin{note}[]\label{note-8}
\hypertarget{p-3621}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3622}{}%
Identify the quantities in the problem that are changing and choose clearly defined variable names for them. Draw one or more figures that clearly represent the situation.%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3623}{}%
Determine all rates of change that are known or given and identify the rate(s) of change to be found.%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3624}{}%
Find an equation that relates the variables whose rates of change are known to those variables whose rates of change are to be found.%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3625}{}%
Differentiate implicitly with respect to \(t\) to relate the rates of change of the involved quantities.%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3626}{}%
Evaluate the derivatives and variables at the information relevant to the instant at which a certain rate of change is sought. Use proper notation to identify when a derivative is being evaluated at a particular instant, such as \(\left. \frac{dr}{dt} \right|_{r=4}\) or \(r'(4)\).%
\end{itemize}
%
\end{note}
\hypertarget{p-3627}{}%
When identifying variables and drawing a picture, it is important to think about the dynamic ways in which the quantities change. Sometimes a sequence of pictures can be helpful; for some pictures that can be easily modified as applets built in Geogebra, see the following links,\footnote{We again refer to the work of Prof.~Marc Renault of Shippensburg University, found at \href{http://gvsu.edu/s/5p}{http://gvsu.edu/s/5p}.\label{fn-39}} which represent \leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3628}{}%
how a circular oil slick's area grows as its radius increases (\href{http://gvsu.edu/s/9n}{http://gvsu.edu/s/9n});%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3629}{}%
how the location of the base of a ladder and its height along a wall change as the ladder slides (\href{http://gvsu.edu/s/9o}{http://gvsu.edu/s/9o});%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3630}{}%
how the water level changes in a conical tank as it fills with water at a constant rate (\href{http://gvsu.edu/s/9p}{http://gvsu.edu/s/9p}; compare to the problem in \hyperref[act-3-5-1]{Example~\ref{act-3-5-1}} below); and%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-3631}{}%
how a skateboarder's shadow changes as he moves past a lamppost (\href{http://gvsu.edu/s/9q}{http://gvsu.edu/s/9q}).%
\end{itemize}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3632}{}%
Drawing well-labeled diagrams and envisioning how different parts of the figure change is a key part of understanding related rates problems and being successful at solving them.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-3-5-1}
\hypertarget{p-3633}{}%
A water tank has the shape of an inverted circular cone (point down) with a base of radius 6 feet and a depth of 8 feet. Suppose that water is being pumped into the tank at a constant instantaneous rate of 4 cubic feet per minute. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2376}{}\hypertarget{p-3634}{}%
Draw a picture of the conical tank, including a sketch of the water level at a point in time when the tank is not yet full. Say that \(r\) is the radius of the water's surface and \(h\) is the depth of the water at a given time, \(t\),  and label these variables on your figure.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2377}{}\hypertarget{p-3635}{}%
What equation relates the radius and height of the water, and why?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2378}{}\hypertarget{p-3636}{}%
Determine an equation that relates the volume of water in the tank at time \(t\) to the depth \(h\) of the water at that time.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2379}{}\hypertarget{p-3637}{}%
Through differentiation, find an equation that relates the instantaneous rate of change of water volume with respect to time to the instantaneous rate of change of water depth at time \(t\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2380}{}\hypertarget{p-3638}{}%
Find the instantaneous rate at which the water level is rising when the water in the tank is 3 feet deep.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2381}{}\hypertarget{p-3639}{}%
When is the water rising most rapidly: at \(h = 3\), \(h = 4\), or \(h = 5\)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-97}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3640}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2382}{}% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)

\begin{lrbox}{\panelboxAimage}
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/3_5_Act1Soln.pdf}
\end{lrbox}
\ifdefined\phAimage\else\newlength{\phAimage}\fi%
\setlength{\phAimage}{\ht\panelboxAimage+\dp\panelboxAimage}
\settototalheight{\phAimage}{\usebox{\panelboxAimage}}
\setlength{\panelmax}{\maxof{\panelmax}{\phAimage}}

\item\hypertarget{li-2394}{}\hypertarget{p-3653}{}%
Letting \(r\) represent the water's radius at time \(t\) and \(h\) the water's depth, we see the following situation:%

\item\hypertarget{li-2395}{}\hypertarget{p-3654}{}%
Observe that the right triangle with legs of length \(h\) and \(r\) is \terminology{similar} to the right triangle with legs of length \(8\) and \(6\), respectively, based on how the water assumes the shape of the tank. Thus \(\frac{r}{h} = \frac{6}{8}\), so that \(r = \frac{3}{4}h\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2396}{}\hypertarget{p-3655}{}%
Since the water in the tank always takes the shape of a circular cone, the volume of water in the tank at time \(t\) is given by \(V = \frac{1}{3}\pi r^2 h\). Because we have established that \(r = \frac{3}{4}h\), it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
V = \frac{1}{3}\pi \left( \frac{3}{4}h \right)^2 h = \frac{3}{16} \pi h^3\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-2397}{}\hypertarget{p-3656}{}%
Differentiating with respect to \(t\), we now find%
\begin{equation}
\frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{9}{16} \pi h^2 \frac{dh}{dt}\text{,}\label{watervolume}
\end{equation}
which relates the rates of change of \(V\) and \(h\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2398}{}\hypertarget{p-3657}{}%
It is given in the problem setting that water is entering the tank at a rate of 4 cubic feet per minute, hence \(\frac{dV}{dt} = 4\), and we are interested in the rate of change of the water's depth when \(h = 3\). Substituting these values into Equation~\hyperref[watervolume]{(\ref{watervolume})}, we find that%
\begin{equation*}
4 =  \frac{9}{16} \pi (3)^2 \left. \frac{dh}{dt} \right|_{h=3}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
so that \(\left. \frac{dh}{dt} \right|_{h=3} = \frac{64}{81\pi} \approx 0.2515\) feet per minute.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2399}{}\hypertarget{p-3658}{}%
Note that we can solve Equation~\hyperref[watervolume]{(\ref{watervolume})} for \(\frac{dh}{dt}\). Doing so with the substitution of the constant rate \(\frac{dV}{dt}=4\), we find that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dh}{dt}=\frac{64}{9\pi h^2}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
so \(\frac{dh}{dt}\) is inversely proportional to \(h^2\). In other words, \(\frac{dh}{dt}\) will be decreasing as \(h^2\) increases (which is when \(h\) increases, since \(h\gt0\)). Thus, the water is rising faster at a depth of 3 feet than at a depth of 4 or 5 feet. We can also see this by calculating \(h'(4)\) and \(h'(5)\) and comparing these values to our answer from (e).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-3659}{}%
Recognizing which geometric relationships are relevant in a given problem is often the key to finding the function to optimize. For instance, although the problem in \hyperref[act-3-5-1]{Example~\ref{act-3-5-1}} is about a conical tank, the most important fact is that there are two similar right triangles involved. In another setting, we might use the Pythagorean Theorem to relate the legs of the triangle. But in the conical tank, the fact that the water fills the tank so that that the ratio of radius to depth is constant turns out to be the important relationship. In other situations where a changing angle is involved, trigonometric functions may provide the means to find relationships among various parts of the triangle.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-3-5-2}
\hypertarget{p-3660}{}%
A television camera is positioned 4000 feet from the base of a rocket launching pad. The angle of elevation of the camera has to change at the correct rate in order to keep the rocket in sight. In addition, the auto-focus of the camera has to take into account the increasing distance between the camera and the rocket. We assume that the rocket rises vertically.\footnote{A similar problem is discussed and pictured dynamically at \href{http://gvsu.edu/s/9t}{http://gvsu.edu/s/9t}. Exploring the applet at the link will be helpful to you in answering the questions that follow.\label{fn-40}} \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2400}{}\hypertarget{p-3661}{}%
Draw a figure that summarizes the given situation. What parts of the picture are changing? What parts are constant? Introduce appropriate variables to represent the quantities that are changing.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2401}{}\hypertarget{p-3662}{}%
Find an equation that relates the camera's angle of elevation to the height of the rocket, and then find an equation that relates the instantaneous rate of change of the camera's elevation angle to the instantaneous rate of change of the rocket's height (where all rates of change are with respect to time).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2402}{}\hypertarget{p-3663}{}%
Find an equation that relates the distance from the camera to the rocket to the rocket's height, as well as an equation that relates the instantaneous rate of change of distance from the camera to the rocket to the instantaneous rate of change of the rocket's height (where all rates of change are with respect to time).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2403}{}\hypertarget{p-3664}{}%
Suppose that the rocket's speed is 600 ft/sec at the instant it has risen 3000 feet. How fast is the distance from the television camera to the rocket changing at that moment? If the camera is following the rocket, how fast is the camera's angle of elevation changing at that same moment?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2404}{}\hypertarget{p-3665}{}%
If from an elevation of 3000 feet onward the rocket continues to rise at 600 feet/sec, will the rate of change of distance with respect to time be greater when the elevation is 4000 feet than it was at 3000 feet, or less? Why?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-98}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3666}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2405}{}\hypertarget{p-3667}{}%
Let \(\theta\) represent the camera angle and note that one leg of the right triangle is constant. Which two are changing?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2406}{}\hypertarget{p-3668}{}%
Think trigonometrically.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2407}{}\hypertarget{p-3669}{}%
Think like Pythagoras.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2408}{}\hypertarget{p-3670}{}%
Use the facts that \(h = 3000\) and \(\left.\frac{dh}{dt}\right|_{h=3000} = 600\) in your preceding work (assuming \(h\) denotes the height of the rocket).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2409}{}\hypertarget{p-3671}{}%
You can answer this question intuitively or by changing the value of \(h\) in your work in (d).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-164}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3672}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2410}{}% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)

\item\hypertarget{li-2411}{}\hypertarget{p-3673}{}%
\(\frac{dh}{dt} = 4000 \sec^2 (\theta) \frac{d\theta}{dt}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2412}{}\hypertarget{p-3674}{}%
\(h \frac{dh}{dt} = z \frac{dz}{dt}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2413}{}\hypertarget{p-3675}{}%
\(\left. \frac{dz}{dt} \right|_{h=3000} = 360\) feet per second; \(\left. \frac{d\theta}{dt} \right|_{h=3000} = \frac{12}{125} \) radians per second.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2414}{}\hypertarget{p-3676}{}%
\(\left.\frac{dz}{dt}\right|_{h=4000}\gt\left.\frac{dz}{dt}\right|_{h=3000}\).%

%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-191}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3677}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2415}{}\hypertarget{p-3678}{}%
Letting \(\theta\) be the camera's elevation angle, \(h\) the rocket's height, and \(z\) the distance from the camera to the rocket, we have the following situation at a given point in time:%

% \tabcolsep change local to group

\par\medskip\noindent
\hspace*{0.3\linewidth}%
\begin{tabular}{@{}*{1}{c}@{}}
\begin{minipage}[c][\panelmax][t]{0.4\linewidth}\usebox{\panelboxAimage}\end{minipage}\end{tabular}\\
% end: side-by-side as tabular
}% end: group for a single side-by-side
\item\hypertarget{li-2416}{}\hypertarget{p-3679}{}%
To relate \(\theta\) and \(h\), observe that the tangent function is a good choice since \(\tan(\theta) = \frac{h}{4000}\), so that%
\begin{equation*}
h = 4000 \tan(\theta)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Differentiating implicitly with respect to \(t\), we find that%
\begin{equation}
\frac{dh}{dt} = 4000 \sec^2 (\theta) \frac{d\theta}{dt}\text{.}\label{rocketanglerates}
\end{equation}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-2417}{}\hypertarget{p-3680}{}%
To relate \(z\) and \(h\), the Pythagorean Theorem is natural to consider. This tells us%
\begin{equation*}
h^2 + (4000)^2 = z^2\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Differentiating both sides implicitly with respect to \(t\), it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
2h \frac{dh}{dt} = 2z \frac{dz}{dt}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and thus%
\begin{equation}
h \frac{dh}{dt} = z \frac{dz}{dt}\text{.}\label{rocketrates}
\end{equation}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-2418}{}\hypertarget{p-3681}{}%
Using the given fact that the rocket's speed is 600 ft/sec at the instant it has risen 3000 feet, we know that \(\left. \frac{dh}{dt} \right|_{h=3000} = 600\). Note further in the triangle that when \(h = 3000\), use of the Pythagorean Theorem yields \(z=5000\). Substituting this information  into Equation~\hyperref[rocketrates]{(\ref{rocketrates})} from (c), we find that%
\begin{equation*}
3000 \cdot 600 = 5000 \cdot \left. \frac{dz}{dt} \right|_{h=3000}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Solving for \(\left. \frac{dz}{dt} \right|_{h=3000}\) gives us%
\begin{equation*}
\left. \frac{dz}{dt} \right|_{h=3000} = \frac{1800}{5} = 360 \ \text{feet/sec}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
To answer the question about how fast the camera angle is changing, we use the same information but now in Equation~\hyperref[rocketanglerates]{(\ref{rocketanglerates})}, from (b).  Observe that when \(h = 3000\),  it follows that \(\cos(\theta) = \frac{4}{5}\), so \(\sec(\theta) = \frac{5}{4}\). Thus%
\begin{equation*}
600 = 4000 \cdot \frac{25}{16} \left. \frac{d\theta}{dt} \right|_{h=3000}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and hence%
\begin{equation*}
\left. \frac{d\theta}{dt} \right|_{h=3000} = \frac{6 \cdot 16}{40 \cdot 25} = \frac{12}{125} \ \text{radians per second}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-2419}{}\hypertarget{p-3682}{}%
Recalling that \(h \frac{dh}{dt} = z \frac{dz}{dt}\), it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dz}{dt} = \frac{h}{z} \frac{dh}{dt}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Using this equation when \(h = 3000\) and \(\frac{dh}{dt} = 600\) led us to conclude that \(\left. \frac{dz}{dt} \right|_{h=3000} = \frac{3}{5} \cdot 600 = 360\) feet/sec. If we instead use \(h = 4000\), it follows that \(z = 4000\sqrt{2}\), so that%
\begin{equation*}
\left. \frac{dz}{dt} \right|_{h=4000} = \frac{4}{4\sqrt{2}} \cdot 600 \approx 424.26 \ \text{feet/sec}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Indeed, \(\frac{dz}{dt}\) is an increasing function of \(h\) \textemdash{} provided that \(\frac{dh}{dt}\) is constant \textemdash{} because we can write \(z = \sqrt{h^2 + 4000^2}\), making%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dz}{dt} = \frac{h}{\sqrt{h^2 + 4000^2}} \frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{h}{\sqrt{h^2 + 4000^2}} 600\text{.}
\end{equation*}
It is straightforward to verify that \(\frac{h}{\sqrt{h^2 + 4000^2}}\) is an increasing function of \(h\); hence any constant multiple of it is as well.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-3683}{}%
In addition to finding instantaneous rates of change at particular points in time, we can often make more general observations about how particular rates themselves will change over time. For instance, when a conical tank is filling with water at a constant rate, it seems obvious that the depth of the water should increase more slowly over time. Note how carefully we must phrase the relationship: we mean to say that while the depth, \(h\), of the water is increasing, its rate of change, \(\frac{dh}{dt}\), is decreasing (both as a function of \(t\) and as a function of \(h\)). We make this observation by solving the equation that relates the various rates for one particular rate, without substituting any particular values for known variables or rates. For instance, in the conical tank problem in \hyperref[act-3-5-1]{Example~\ref{act-3-5-1}}, we established that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{9}{16} \pi h^2 \frac{dh}{dt}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and hence%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{16}{9\pi h^2} \frac{dV}{dt}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3684}{}%
Provided that \(\frac{dV}{dt}\) is constant, it is immediately apparent that as \(h\) gets larger, \(\frac{dh}{dt}\) will get smaller but remain positive. Hence, the depth of the water is increasing at a decreasing rate.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-3-5-3}
\hypertarget{p-3685}{}%
As pictured in the applet at~\href{http://gvsu.edu/s/9q}{http://gvsu.edu/s/9q}, a skateboarder who is 6 feet tall (while on the skateboard) rides under a 15 foot tall lamppost at a constant rate of 3 feet per second. We are interested in understanding how fast the length of his shadow is changing at various points in time. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2420}{}\hypertarget{p-3686}{}%
Draw an appropriate right triangle that represents a snapshot in time of the skateboarder, lamppost, and his shadow. Let \(x\) denote the horizontal distance from the base of the lamppost to the skateboarder and \(s\) represent the length of his shadow. Label these quantities, as well as the skateboarder's height and the lamppost's height on the diagram.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2421}{}\hypertarget{p-3687}{}%
Observe that the skateboarder and the lamppost represent parallel line segments in the diagram, and thus similar triangles are present. Use similar triangles to establish an equation that relates \(x\) and \(s\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2422}{}\hypertarget{p-3688}{}%
Use your work in (b) to find an equation that relates \(\frac{dx}{dt}\) and \(\frac{ds}{dt}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2423}{}\hypertarget{p-3689}{}%
At what rate is the length of the skateboarder's shadow increasing at the instant the skateboarder is 8 feet from the lamppost?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2424}{}\hypertarget{p-3690}{}%
As the skateboarder's distance from the lamppost increases, is his shadow's length increasing at an increasing rate, increasing at a decreasing rate, or increasing at a constant rate?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2425}{}\hypertarget{p-3691}{}%
Which is moving more rapidly: the skateboarder or the tip of his shadow? Explain, and justify your answer.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-99}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3692}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2426}{}\hypertarget{p-3693}{}%
Note that the lengths of the legs of the right triangle will be \(15\) for the vertical one and \(x + s\) for the horizontal one.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2427}{}\hypertarget{p-3694}{}%
The small triangle formed by the skateboarder and his shadow, with legs \(6\) and \(s\), is similar to the large triangle that has the lamppost as one of its legs.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2428}{}\hypertarget{p-3695}{}%
Simplify the equation in (b) as much as possible before differentiating implicitly with respect to \(t\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2429}{}\hypertarget{p-3696}{}%
Find \(\left. \frac{ds}{dt} \right|_{x=8}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2430}{}\hypertarget{p-3697}{}%
Does the equation that relates \(\frac{dx}{dt}\) and \(\frac{ds}{dt}\) involve \(x\)? Is \(\frac{dx}{dt}\) changing or constant?%
\item\hypertarget{li-2431}{}\hypertarget{p-3698}{}%
Let \(y\) represent the location of the tip of the shadow, so that \(y = x + s\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-165}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3699}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2432}{}% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)

\item\hypertarget{li-2433}{}\hypertarget{p-3700}{}%
\(3s = 2x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2434}{}\hypertarget{p-3701}{}%

\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-192}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3705}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-2438}{}\hypertarget{p-3706}{}%
The given information leads us to construct the following diagram:%

\item\hypertarget{li-2439}{}\hypertarget{p-3707}{}%
The two right triangles shown in the diagram in (a) are similar: the small triangle is formed by the skateboarder and his shadow, and has legs of length \(6\) and \(s\); the large triangle is formed by the lampost and the distance from the post to the shadow's tip, and has legs of length \(15\) and \(x+s\). Similarity gives us that the ratios of leg lengths are equal, so we have%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{s}{6} = \frac{s+x}{15}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Simplifying yields \(15s = 6s + 6x\), or%
\begin{equation*}
3s = 2x\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-2440}{}\hypertarget{p-3708}{}%
Differentiating with respect to \(t\), it is immediate that%
\begin{equation*}
3 \frac{ds}{dt} = 2\frac{dx}{dt}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-2441}{}\hypertarget{p-3709}{}%
Since \(\frac{ds}{dt} = \frac{2}{3} \frac{dx}{dt}\), and \(\frac{dx}{dt} = 3\), it follows that \(\frac{ds}{dt} = 2\) for every value of \(t\) (and \(x\)). Thus, \(\left. \frac{ds}{dt} \right|_{x=8} = 2\) feet per second.%
\item\hypertarget{li-2442}{}\hypertarget{p-3710}{}%
Because \(\frac{ds}{dt}\) is constant, the shadow's length is increasing at a constant rate (irrespective of the distance from the skateboarder to the lamppost).%
\item\hypertarget{li-2443}{}\hypertarget{p-3711}{}%
Let \(y\) represent the location of the tip of the shadow, so that \(y = x + s\). Observe that we can now compute \(\frac{dy}{dt}\) in terms of \(\frac{dx}{dt}\) and \(\frac{ds}{dt}\), with%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dy}{dt} = \frac{dx}{dt} + \frac{ds}{dt} = 3 + 2 = 5
\end{equation*}
feet per second, and hence the tip of the shadow is moving more rapidly than the skateboarder himself.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3712}{}%
Even though the shadow's length is growing slower than the skateboarder is moving, the tip of the shadow is moving both due to growth and due to the skateboarder's movement, giving us the faster rate.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-3713}{}%
 In most of the examples thus far, we provided guided instruction to build a solution in a step-by-step way. For the closing example and the following exercises, most of the detailed work is left to the reader.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-3-5-4}
\hypertarget{p-3714}{}%
A baseball diamond is square and measures \(90\) feet on each side. A batter hits a ball along the third base line and runs to first base. At what rate is the distance between the ball and first base changing when the ball is halfway to third base, if at that instant the ball is traveling \(100\) feet/sec? At what rate is the distance between the ball and the runner changing at the same instant, if the runner is at that point one-eigth of the way to first base and running at \(30\) feet/sec?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-100}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3715}{}%
Draw some pictures! Label everything you know with a constant, and everything that is changing with a variable and a corresponding rate of change (with respect to time, \(t\)). For the instant in question, you will also want to write down the values of the variables at that instant and identify what quantities you need to find.  Note that the basepaths meet at right angles.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-166}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-3716}{}%
Let \(x\) denote the position of the ball (as a distance from home plate) at time \(t\) and \(z\) the distance from the ball to first base, as pictured below.%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)
{% begin: group for a single side-by-side
% set panel max height to practical minimum, created in preamble
\setlength{\panelmax}{0pt}
\ifdefined\panelboxAimage\else\newsavebox{\panelboxAimage}\fi%
\begin{lrbox}{\panelboxAimage}
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/3_5_Act4Soln1.pdf}
\end{lrbox}
\ifdefined\phAimage\else\newlength{\phAimage}\fi%
\setlength{\phAimage}{\ht\panelboxAimage+\dp\panelboxAimage}
\settototalheight{\phAimage}{\usebox{\panelboxAimage}}
\setlength{\panelmax}{\maxof{\panelmax}{\phAimage}}
\leavevmode%
% begin: side-by-side as tabular
% \tabcolsep change local to group
\setlength{\tabcolsep}{0\linewidth}
% @{} suppress \tabcolsep at extremes, so margins behave as intended
\par\medskip\noindent
\hspace*{0.25\linewidth}%
\begin{tabular}{@{}*{1}{c}@{}}
\begin{minipage}[c][\panelmax][t]{0.5\linewidth}\usebox{\panelboxAimage}\end{minipage}\end{tabular}\\
% end: side-by-side as tabular
}% end: group for a single side-by-side
\par
\hypertarget{p-3717}{}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\left. \frac{dz}{dt} \right|_{x = 45} = \frac{100}{\sqrt{5}} \approx 44.7214 \ \text{ft/sec} \text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-3718}{}%
Let \(r\) be the runner's position (as a distance from home plate) at time \(t\) and let \(s\) be the distance between the runner and the ball, as pictured.%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)
{% begin: group for a single side-by-side
% set panel max height to practical minimum, created in preamble
\setlength{\panelmax}{0pt}
\ifdefined\panelboxAimage\else\newsavebox{\panelboxAimage}\fi%
\begin{lrbox}{\panelboxAimage}
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/3_5_Act4Soln2.pdf}
\end{lrbox}
\ifdefined\phAimage\else\newlength{\phAimage}\fi%
\setlength{\phAimage}{\ht\panelboxAimage+\dp\panelboxAimage}
\settototalheight{\phAimage}{\usebox{\panelboxAimage}}
