\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 5.5.1 Reversing the Chain Rule: First Steps}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Reversing the Chain Rule: First Steps}]{Reversing the Chain Rule: First Steps}\label{subsection-133}
\hypertarget{p-5263}{}%
Whenever \(f\) is a familiar function whose antiderivative is known and \(u(x)\) is a linear function, it is  straightforward to antidifferentiate a function of the form%
\begin{equation*}
h(x) = f(u(x))\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-209}
\hypertarget{p-5264}{}%
The following example will demonstrate how to determine the general antiderivative of%
\begin{equation*}
h(x) = (5x-3)^6\text{.}
\end{equation*}
We can check the result by differentiating.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5265}{}%
For this composite function, the outer function \(f\) is \(f(u) = u^6\), while the inner function is \(u(x) = 5x - 3\). Since the antiderivative of \(f\) is \(F(u) = \frac{1}{7}u^7+C\), we see that the antiderivative of \(h\) is%
\begin{equation*}
H(x) = \frac{1}{7} (5x-3)^7 \cdot \frac{1}{5} + C = \frac{1}{35} (5x-3)^7 + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5266}{}%
The inclusion of the constant \(\frac{1}{5}\) is essential precisely because the derivative of the inner function is \(u'(x) = 5\). Indeed, if we now compute \(H'(x)\), we find by the Chain Rule (and Constant Multiple Rule) that%
\begin{equation*}
H'(x) = \frac{1}{35} \cdot 7(5x-3)^6 \cdot 5 = (5x-3)^6 = h(x)\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and thus \(H\) is indeed the general antiderivative of \(h\).%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-5267}{}%
Hence, in the special case where the outer function is familiar and the inner function is linear, we can antidifferentiate composite functions according to the following rule.%
\begin{assemblage}\label{assemblage-111}
\hypertarget{p-5268}{}%
If \(h(x) = f(ax + b)\) and \(F\) is a known algebraic antiderivative of \(f\), then the general antiderivative of \(h\) is given by%
\begin{equation*}
H(x) = \frac{1}{a} F(ax+b) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
\hypertarget{p-5269}{}%
It is useful to have shorthand notation that indicates the instruction to find an antiderivative. Thus, in a similar way to how the notation%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left[ f(x) \right]
\end{equation*}
represents the derivative of \(f(x)\) with respect to \(x\), we use the notation of the \emph{indefinite integral}, \index{indefinite integral}%
\begin{equation*}
\int f(x) \, dx
\end{equation*}
to represent the general antiderivative of \(f\) with respect to \(x\). Returning to the earlier example with \(h(x) = (5x-3)^6\), we can rephrase the relationship between \(h\) and its antiderivative \(H\) through the notation%
\begin{equation*}
\int (5x-3)^6 \, dx = \frac{1}{35} (5x-6)^7 + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5270}{}%
When we find an antiderivative, we will often say that we \emph{evaluate an indefinite integral}. \index{indefinite integral!evaluate} Just as the notation \(\frac{d}{dx} [ \Box ]\) means ``find the derivative with respect to \(x\) of \(\Box\),'' the notation \(\int \Box \, dx\) means ``find a function of \(x\) whose derivative is \(\Box\).''%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-5-3-1}
\hypertarget{p-5271}{}%
Evaluate each of the following indefinite integrals. Check each antiderivative that you find by differentiating. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3403}{}\hypertarget{p-5272}{}%
\(\int \sin(8-3x) \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3404}{}\hypertarget{p-5273}{}%
\(\int \sec^2 (4x) \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3405}{}\hypertarget{p-5274}{}%
\(\int \frac{1}{11x - 9} \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3406}{}\hypertarget{p-5275}{}%
\(\int \csc(2x+1) \cot(2x+1) \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3407}{}\hypertarget{p-5276}{}%
\(\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-16x^2}}\, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3408}{}\hypertarget{p-5277}{}%
\(\int 5^{-x}\, dx\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-142}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5278}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3409}{}\hypertarget{p-5279}{}%
Think \(\int \sin(u) \, du\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3410}{}\hypertarget{p-5280}{}%
Think \(\int \sec^2 (u) \, du\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3411}{}\hypertarget{p-5281}{}%
Think \(\int \frac{1}{u}\, du\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3412}{}\hypertarget{p-5282}{}%
Think \(\int \csc(u) \cot(u) \, du\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3413}{}\hypertarget{p-5283}{}%
Think \(\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-u^2}} \, du\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3414}{}\hypertarget{p-5284}{}%
Think \(\int 5^{u} \, du\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-238}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5285}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3415}{}\hypertarget{p-5286}{}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\int \sin(8-3x) \, dx = -\frac{1}{3} (-\cos(8-3x)) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3416}{}\hypertarget{p-5287}{}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\int \sec^2 (4x) \, dx = \frac{1}{4} \tan(4x) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3417}{}\hypertarget{p-5288}{}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\int \frac{1}{11x - 9} \, dx = \frac{1}{11} \ln|11x - 9| + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3418}{}\hypertarget{p-5289}{}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\int \csc(2x+1) \cot(2x+1) \, dx = -\frac{1}{2}\cot(2x+1) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3419}{}\hypertarget{p-5290}{}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-16x^2}}\, dx = \frac{1}{4} \arcsin(4x) + C
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3420}{}\hypertarget{p-5291}{}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\int 5^{-x}\, dx = -\frac{1}{\ln(5)}5^{-x} + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-268}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5292}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3421}{}\hypertarget{p-5293}{}%
Since \(u=8-3x\) is linear and \(\int \sin(u) \, du = -\cos(u) + C\), it follows that \(\int \sin(8-3x) \, dx = -\frac{1}{3} (-\cos(8-3x)) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3422}{}\hypertarget{p-5294}{}%
Since \(4x\) is linear and \(\int \sec^2(u) \, du = \tan(u) + C \), we see \(\int \sec^2 (4x) \, dx = \frac{1}{4} \tan(4x) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3423}{}\hypertarget{p-5295}{}%
Using the fact that \(\int \frac{1}{u} \, du = \ln |u| + C\), we have \(\int \frac{1}{11x - 9} \, dx = \frac{1}{11} \ln|11x - 9| + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3424}{}\hypertarget{p-5296}{}%
We know \(\int \csc(u) \cot(u) \, du = -\cot(u) + C\), so \(\int \csc(2x+1) \cot(2x+1) \, dx = -\frac{1}{2}\cot(2x+1) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3425}{}\hypertarget{p-5297}{}%
Observe that \(\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-u^2}}\, dx = \arcsin(u) + C\), and thus viewing \(16x^2 = (4x)^2\), we see that \(\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-16x^2}}\, dx = \frac{1}{4} \arcsin(4x) + C\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3426}{}\hypertarget{p-5298}{}%
Since \(\int 5^{u}\, du = \frac{1}{\ln(5)}5^u + C\), we have that \(\int 5^{-x}\, dx = -\frac{1}{\ln(5)}5^{-x} + C\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 5.5.2 Reversing the Chain Rule: \(u\)-substitution}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Reversing the Chain Rule: \(u\)-substitution}]{Reversing the Chain Rule: \(u\)-substitution}\label{subsection-134}
\index{\(u\)-substitution}\hypertarget{p-5299}{}%
A natural question arises from our recent work: what happens when the inner function is not linear? For example, can we find antiderivatives of such functions as%
\begin{equation*}
g(x) = x e^{x^2} \ \text{and}  \ h(x) = e^{x^2}?
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5300}{}%
It is important to remember that differentiation and antidifferentiation are almost-inverse processes (that they are not is due to the \(+C\) that arises when antidifferentiating). This almost-inverse relationship enables us to take any known derivative rule and rewrite it as a corresponding rule for an indefinite integral. For example, since%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left[x^5\right] = 5x^4\text{,}
\end{equation*}
we can equivalently write%
\begin{equation*}
\int 5x^4 \, dx = x^5 + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5301}{}%
Recall that the Chain Rule states that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left[ f(g(x)) \right] = f'(g(x)) \cdot g'(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5302}{}%
Restating this relationship in terms of an indefinite integral,%
\begin{equation}
\int f'(g(x)) g'(x) \, dx = f(g(x))+C\text{.}\label{E-usubst}
\end{equation}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5303}{}%
\hyperref[E-usubst]{Equation~(\ref{E-usubst})} tells us that if we can view a given function as \(f'(g(x)) g'(x)\) for some appropriate choices of \(f\) and \(g\), then we can antidifferentiate the function by reversing the Chain Rule. Note that both \(g(x)\) and \(g'(x)\) appear in the form of \(f'(g(x)) g'(x)\); we will sometimes say that we seek to \emph{identify a function-derivative pair} \index{function-derivative pair} (\(g(x)\) and \(g'(x)\)) when trying to apply the rule in \hyperref[E-usubst]{Equation~(\ref{E-usubst})}.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5304}{}%
If we can identify a function-derivative pair, we will introduce a new variable \(u\) to represent the function \(g(x)\). With \(u = g(x)\), it follows in Leibniz notation that \(\frac{du}{dx} = g'(x)\), so that in terms of differentials\footnote{If we recall from the definition of the derivative that \(\frac{du}{dx} \approx \frac{\Delta{u}}{\Delta{x}}\) and use the fact that \(\frac{du}{dx} = g'(x)\), then we see that \(g'(x) \approx \frac{\Delta{u}}{\Delta{x}}\). Solving for \(\Delta u\), \(\Delta u \approx g'(x) \Delta x\). It is this last relationship that, when expressed in ``differential'' notation enables us to write \(du = g'(x) \, dx\) in the change of variable formula.\label{fn-54}}, \(du = g'(x)\, dx\). Now converting the indefinite integral to a new one in terms of \(u\), we have%
\begin{equation*}
\int f'(g(x)) g'(x) \, dx = \int f'(u) \,du\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5305}{}%
Provided that \(f'\) is an elementary function whose antiderivative is known, we can easily evaluate the indefinite integral in \(u\), and then go on to determine the desired overall antiderivative of \(f'(g(x)) g'(x)\). We call this process \emph{\(u\)-substitution}, and summarize the rule as follows:%
\begin{assemblage}[Method of Substitution]\label{assemblage-112}
\hypertarget{p-5306}{}%
With the substitution \(u = g(x)\),%
\begin{equation*}
\int f'(g(x)) g'(x) \, dx = \int f'(u) \,du = f(u) + C = f(g(x)) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
This method is often referred to as \terminology{\(u \)-substitution.}%
\end{assemblage}
\hypertarget{p-5307}{}%
To see \(u\)-substitution at work, we consider the following example.%
\begin{example}[]\label{Ex-5-3-usub}
\hypertarget{p-5308}{}%
Evaluate the indefinite integral%
\begin{equation*}
\int x^3 \cdot \sin (7x^4 + 3) \, dx
\end{equation*}
and check the result by differentiating.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-143}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5309}{}%
Let \(u=7x^4+3\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-239}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5310}{}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\int x^3 \cdot \sin (7x^4 + 3) \, dx=-\frac{1}{28}\cos(7x^4+3)+C
\end{equation*}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-269}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5311}{}%
We can make two algebraic observations regarding the integrand, \(x^3 \cdot \sin (7x^4 + 3)\). First, \(\sin (7x^4 + 3)\) is a composite function; as such, we know we'll need a more sophisticated approach to antidifferentiating. Second, \(x^3\) is almost the derivative of \(7x^4 + 3\); the only issue is a missing constant. Thus, \(x^3\) and \((7x^4 + 3)\) are nearly a function-derivative pair. Furthermore, we know the antiderivative of \(f(u) = \sin(u)\). The combination of these observations suggests that we can evaluate the given indefinite integral by reversing the chain rule through \(u\)-substitution.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5312}{}%
Letting \(u\) represent the inner function of the composite function \(\sin (7x^4 + 3)\), we have \(u = 7x^4 + 3\), and thus \(\frac{du}{dx} = 28x^3\). In differential notation, it follows that \(du = 28x^3 \, dx\), and thus \(x^3 \, dx = \frac{1}{28} \, du\). The original indefinite integral may be slightly rewritten as%
\begin{equation*}
\int \sin (7x^4 + 3) \cdot x^3 \, dx\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and so by substituting \(u\) for \(7x^4 + 3\) and \(\frac{1}{28} \, du\) for \(x^3 \, dx\), it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
\int \sin (7x^4 + 3) \cdot x^3 \, dx = \int \sin(u) \cdot \frac{1}{28} \, du\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5313}{}%
Now we may evaluate the easier integral in \(u\), and then replace \(u\) by the expression \(7x^4 + 3\). Doing so, we find%
\begin{align*}
\int \sin (7x^4 + 3) \cdot x^3 \, dx &= \int \sin(u) \cdot \frac{1}{28} \, du\\
&= \frac{1}{28} \int \sin(u) \, du\\
&= \frac{1}{28} (-\cos(u)) + C\\
&= -\frac{1}{28} \cos(7x^4 + 3) + C\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5314}{}%
To check our work, we observe by the Chain Rule that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left[ -\frac{1}{28}\cos(7x^4 + 3) \right] = -\frac{1}{28} \cdot (-1)\sin(7x^4 + 3) \cdot 28x^3 = \sin(7x^4 + 3) \cdot x^3\text{,}
\end{equation*}
which is indeed the original integrand.%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 5.5.2.1 A Cautionary Tale}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsubsection[{A Cautionary Tale}]{A Cautionary Tale}\label{subsection-135}
\hypertarget{p-5315}{}%
The \(u\)-substitution worked because the function multiplying \(\sin (7x^4 + 3)\) was \(x^3\). If instead that function was \(x^2\) or \(x^4\), the substitution process would not have worked. This is one of the primary challenges of antidifferentiation: slight changes in the integrand make tremendous differences. For instance, we can use \(u\)-substitution with \(u = x^2\) and \(du = 2xdx\) to find that%
\begin{align*}
\int xe^{x^2} \, dx &=  \int e^u \cdot \frac{1}{2} \, du\\
&= \frac{1}{2} \int e^u \, du\\
&= \frac{1}{2} e^u + C\\
&= \frac{1}{2} e^{x^2} + C\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5316}{}%
However, for the similar indefinite integral%
\begin{equation*}
\int e^{x^2} \, dx\text{,}
\end{equation*}
the \(u\)-substitution \(u = x^2\) is no longer possible because the factor of \(x\) is missing. Hence, part of the lesson of \(u\)-substitution is just how specialized the process is: it only applies to situations where, up to a missing constant, the integrand is the result of applying the Chain Rule to a different, related function.%
\begin{assemblage}[Finding Antiderivatives using Substitution]\label{assemblage-113}
\hypertarget{p-5317}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5318}{}%
Find two functions within the integrand that form (up to a possible missing constant) a function-derivative pair;%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5319}{}%
Make a substitution and convert the integral to one involving \(u\) and \(du\);%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5320}{}%
Evaluate the new integral in \(u\);%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5321}{}%
Convert the resulting function of \(u\) back to a function of \(x\) by using your earlier substitution;%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5322}{}%
Check your work by differentiating the function of \(x\). You should come up with the original integrand.%
\end{itemize}
%
\end{assemblage}
\begin{example}[]\label{act-5-3-2}
\hypertarget{p-5323}{}%
Evaluate each of the following indefinite integrals by using a \(u \)-substitution. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3432}{}\hypertarget{p-5324}{}%
\(\int \frac{x^2}{5x^3+1} \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3433}{}\hypertarget{p-5325}{}%
\(\int e^x \sin(e^x) \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3434}{}\hypertarget{p-5326}{}%
\(\int \frac{\cos(\sqrt{x})}{\sqrt{x}} \, dx\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-144}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5327}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3435}{}\hypertarget{p-5328}{}%
Note that \(5x^3 + 1\) and \(15x^2\) form a function-derivative pair.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3436}{}\hypertarget{p-5329}{}%
Recall that \(e^{x}\) is its own derivative.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3437}{}\hypertarget{p-5330}{}%
Observe that \(x^{-\frac{1}{2}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-240}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5331}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3438}{}\hypertarget{p-5332}{}%
\(\int \frac{x^2}{5x^3+1} \, dx = \frac{1}{15} \ln|5x^3 + 1| + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3439}{}\hypertarget{p-5333}{}%
\(\int e^x \sin(e^x) \, dx = -\cos(e^x) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3440}{}\hypertarget{p-5334}{}%
\(\int \frac{\cos(\sqrt{x})}{\sqrt{x}} \, dx = 2\sin(\sqrt{x}) + C\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-270}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5335}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3441}{}\hypertarget{p-5336}{}%
Since \(5x^3 + 1\) and \(15x^2\) form a function-derivative pair, we let \(u=5x^3+1\), and observe that \(du=15x^2dx\), and thus \(x^2dx=\frac{1}{15}du\). Applying this substitution, integrating, and substituting back,%
\begin{equation*}
\int \frac{x^2}{5x^3+1} \, dx = \int \frac{\frac{1}{15}du}{u} = \frac{1}{15} \ln|u| + C = \frac{1}{15} \ln|5x^3 + 1| + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3442}{}\hypertarget{p-5337}{}%
Because \(\frac{d}{dx}[e^x] = e^x\), if we let \(u=e^x\), it follows \(du = e^x dx\). Substituting and integrating,%
\begin{equation*}
\int e^x \sin(e^x) \, dx = \int \sin(u) \, du = -\cos(u) + C = -\cos(e^x) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3443}{}\hypertarget{p-5338}{}%
Let \(u = \sqrt{x}\), so that \(du = \frac{1}{2}x^{-\frac{1}{2}}dx = \frac{dx}{2\sqrt{x}}\). We observe that \(\frac{dx}{\sqrt{x}} = 2 du\), and thus%
\begin{equation*}
\int \frac{\cos(\sqrt{x})}{\sqrt{x}}~dx = \int 2 \cos(u) \, du = 2\sin(u) + C = 2\sin(\sqrt{x}) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 5.5.3 Evaluating Definite Integrals via \(u\)-substitution}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Evaluating Definite Integrals via \(u\)-substitution}]{Evaluating Definite Integrals via \(u\)-substitution}\label{subsection-136}
\hypertarget{p-5339}{}%
We have introduced \(u\)-substitution as a means to evaluate indefinite integrals of functions that can be written, up to a constant multiple, in the form \(f(g(x))g'(x)\). This same technique can be used to evaluate definite integrals involving such functions, though we need to be careful with the corresponding limits of integration. Consider, for instance, the definite integral%
\begin{equation*}
\int_2^5 xe^{x^2} \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5340}{}%
Whenever we write a definite integral, it is implicit that the limits of integration correspond to the variable of integration. To be more explicit, observe that%
\begin{equation*}
\int_2^5 xe^{x^2} \, dx = \int_{x=2}^{x=5} xe^{x^2} \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5341}{}%
When we execute a \(u\)-substitution, we change the \emph{variable} of integration; it is essential to note that this also changes the \emph{limits} of integration. For instance, with the substitution \(u = x^2\) and \(du = 2x \, dx\), it also follows that when \(x = 2\), \(u = 2^2 = 4\), and when \(x = 5\), \(u = 5^2 = 25\). Thus, under the change of variables of \(u\)-substitution, we now have%
\begin{align*}
\int_{x=2}^{x=5} xe^{x^2} \, dx    &= \int_{u=4}^{u=25} e^{u} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \, du\\
&= \left. \frac{1}{2}e^u \right|_{u=4}^{u=25}\\
&= \frac{1}{2}e^{25} - \frac{1}{2}e^4\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5342}{}%
Alternatively, we could consider the related indefinite integral \(\int xe^{x^2} \, dx\), find the antiderivative \(\frac{1}{2}e^{x^2}\) through \(u\)-substitution, and then evaluate the original definite integral. With that method, we'd have%
\begin{align*}
\int_{2}^{5} xe^{x^2} \, dx    &= \left. \frac{1}{2}e^{x^2} \right|_{2}^{5}\\
&= \frac{1}{2}e^{25} - \frac{1}{2}e^4\text{,}
\end{align*}
which is, of course, the same result.%
\begin{assemblage}[Two Methods to Evaluate a Definite Integral with \(u \)-substitution]\label{assemblage-114}
\hypertarget{p-5343}{}%
To evaluate the definite integral \(\int_a^b h(x) \, dx \) while using a \(u \)-substitution, there are two different methods to apply the \hyperref[FTC_2]{Fundamental Theorem of Calculus~}. Either method is correct. They are summarized below: \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\Alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3444}{}\hypertarget{p-5344}{}%
Change the limits to the corresponding \(u \)-values. Then find the antiderivative with respect to \(u\) and evaluate it according to the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, using the limits corresponding to \(u \).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3445}{}\hypertarget{p-5345}{}%
Start with the indefinite integral \(\int h(x) \, dx \) and find an antiderivative with respect to \(x \).  Make sure your resulting expression is in terms of \(x \). Then evaluate it according to the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, using the limits corresponding to \(x \).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{assemblage}
\begin{example}[]\label{act-5-3-3}
\hypertarget{p-5346}{}%
Evaluate each of the following definite integrals exactly through an appropriate \(u\)-substitution. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3446}{}\hypertarget{p-5347}{}%
\(\int\limits_1^2 \frac{x}{1 + 4x^2} \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3447}{}\hypertarget{p-5348}{}%
\(\int\limits_0^1 e^{-x} (2e^{-x}+3)^{9} \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3448}{}\hypertarget{p-5349}{}%
\(\int\limits_{2/\pi}^{4/\pi} \frac{\cos\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)}{x^{2}} \,dx\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-145}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5350}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3449}{}\hypertarget{p-5351}{}%
Let \(u = 1+4x^2\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3450}{}\hypertarget{p-5352}{}%
\((2e^{-x}+3)\) and \(e^{-x}\) form a function-derivative pair%
\item\hypertarget{li-3451}{}\hypertarget{p-5353}{}%
\(\frac{d}{dx}\left[\frac{1}{x}\right] = -\frac{1}{x^2}\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-241}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5354}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3452}{}\hypertarget{p-5355}{}%
%
\begin{gather*}
\int\limits_{x=1}^{x=2} \frac{x}{1 + 4x^2} \, dx = \frac{1}{8} (\ln(17) - \ln(5))\text{.}
\end{gather*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3453}{}\hypertarget{p-5356}{}%
%
\begin{gather*}
\int\limits_0^1 e^{-x} (2e^{-x}+3)^{9} \, dx = -\frac{1}{20}(2e^{-1}+3)^{10} + \frac{1}{20}(2e^{0}+3)^{10}\text{.}
\end{gather*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3454}{}\hypertarget{p-5357}{}%
%
\begin{gather*}
\int\limits_{2/\pi}^{4/\pi} \frac{\cos\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)}{x^{2}} \,dx = 1 - \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\text{.}
\end{gather*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-271}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5358}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3455}{}\hypertarget{p-5359}{}%
Let \(u = 1+4x^2\), so \(du=8x dx\) and \(xdx = \frac{1}{8} du\). Note that \(x=1\) implies \(u=5\) and \(x=2\) implies \(u=17\). Thus using method A.,%
\begin{gather*}
\int\limits_{x=1}^{x=2} \frac{x}{1 + 4x^2} \, dx = \frac{1}{8} \int\limits_{u=5}^{u=17} \frac{du}{u} = \left. \frac{1}{8} \ln|u| \right|_5^{17} = \frac{1}{8} (\ln(17) - \ln(5))\text{.}
\end{gather*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3456}{}\hypertarget{p-5360}{}%
We'll use method B., so first consider the corresponding indefinite integral, \(\int e^{-x} (2e^{-x}+3)^{9} \, dx\), and let \(u=2e^{-x}+3\) so that \(du = -2e^{-x}dx\). We see \(e^{-x}dx = -\frac{1}{2}du\), and thus \(\int e^{-x} (2e^{-x}+3)^{9} \, dx = -\frac{1}{2} \int u^9 \, du = -\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{10} u^{10} + C = -\frac{1}{20}(2e^{-x}+3)^{10}\). Applying this antiderivative to the definite integral, we see that%
\begin{align*}
\int\limits_0^1 e^{-x} (2e^{-x}+3)^{9} \, dx &= \left. -\frac{1}{20}(2e^{-x}+3)^{10} \right|_0^1 \\
&= -\frac{1}{20}(2e^{-1}+3)^{10} + \frac{1}{20}(2e^{0}+3)^{10}.
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3457}{}\hypertarget{p-5361}{}%
Using method B. and using the substitution \(u=\frac{1}{x}\), it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
\int \frac{\cos\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)}{x^{2}} \,dx = -\int \cos(u) \, du = -\sin(u) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Hence,%
\begin{equation*}
\int\limits_{\frac{2}{\pi}}^{\frac{4}{\pi}} \frac{\cos\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)}{x^{2}} \,dx = \left.-\sin\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) \right|_{\frac{2}{\pi}}^{\frac{4}{\pi}} = -\sin(\frac{\pi}{4} + \sin(\frac{\pi}{2}) = 1 - \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{example-214}
\hypertarget{p-5362}{}%
Show the two definite integrals are equal by using a substitution. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3458}{}\hypertarget{p-5363}{}%
\(\int_0^{10} 10x \, dx= \frac{1}{10} \int_0^{100} u \, du \)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3459}{}\hypertarget{p-5364}{}%
\(2\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} x \sin(2x) \, dx= \frac{1}{2} \int_{\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\pi} u\sin(u) \, du \)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-146}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5365}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3460}{}\hypertarget{p-5366}{}%
Start with the left hand side of the equation and use the substitution \(u=10x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3461}{}\hypertarget{p-5367}{}%
Start with the left hand side of the equation and use the substitution \(u=2x \).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-272}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5368}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3462}{}\hypertarget{p-5369}{}%
Start with the left hand side of the equation and use the substitution \(u=10x\). (We could have started with the right hand side and use the substitution \(x=\frac{u}{10}\).) Then \(du= 10 \, dx \), so \(\frac{du}{10}=dx \). The new limits will be \(u=10(0)=0 \) and \(u=10(10)=100\). Using this substitution, we can find that the original integral  transforms to the desired integral%
\begin{gather*}
\int_0^{10} 10x \, dx =\int_{0}^{100} u \, \frac{du}{10}= \frac{1}{10} \int_{0}^{100} u \, du 
\end{gather*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3463}{}\hypertarget{p-5370}{}%
Start with the left hand side of the equation and use the substitution \(u=2x\). (We could have started with the right hand side and use the substitution \(x=\frac{u}{2}\).) Then \(du= 2 \, dx \), so \(\frac{du}{2}=dx \). The new limits will be \(u=2(\frac{\pi}{4})=\frac{\pi}{2} \) and \(u=2(\frac{\pi}{2})=\pi\). We also need to rearrange the equation for the substitution to write \(x \) in terms of \(u \), so we also need \(x=\frac{u}{2} \). Using this substitution, we can find that the original integral  transforms to the desired integral%
\begin{gather*}
2\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} x \sin(2x) \, dx =2\int_{\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\pi} \frac{u}{2} \sin(u)\, \frac{du}{2}= \frac{1}{2} \int_{\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\pi} u \sin(u) \, du .
\end{gather*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 5.5.4 Summary}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Summary}]{Summary}\label{subsection-137}
\hypertarget{p-5371}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5372}{}%
To find algebraic formulas for antiderivatives of more complicated algebraic functions, we need to think carefully about how we can reverse known differentiation rules. To that end, it is essential that we understand and recall known derivatives of basic functions, as well as the standard derivative rules.%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5373}{}%
The indefinite integral provides notation for antiderivatives. When we write ``\(\int f(x) \, dx\),'' we mean ``the general antiderivative of \(f\).''  In particular, if we have functions \(f\) and \(F\) such that \(F' = f\), the following two statements say the exact thing:%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx}[F(x)] = f(x) \ \text{and}  \ \int f(x) \, dx = F(x) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
That is, \(f\) is the derivative of \(F\), and \(F\) is an antiderivative of \(f\).%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5374}{}%
The technique of \(u\)-substitution helps us to evaluate indefinite integrals of the form \(\int f(g(x))g'(x) \, dx\) through the substitutions \(u = g(x)\) and \(du = g'(x) \, dx\), so that%
\begin{equation*}
\int f(g(x))g'(x) \, dx = \int f(u) \, du\text{.}
\end{equation*}
A key part of choosing the expression in \(x\) to be represented by \(u\) is the identification of a function-derivative pair. To do so, we often look for an ``inner'' function \(g(x)\) that is part of a composite function, while investigating whether \(g'(x)\) (or a constant multiple of \(g'(x)\)) is present as a multiplying factor of the integrand.%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5375}{}%
There are two methods to use \(u\)-substitution with a definite integral. In one method, first find the general antiderivative in terms of \(x \) and use the bounds of integration corresponding to \(x \) when using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. For the other method, change the bounds of integration  to correspond to \(u \) as a step of a \(u\)-substitution, integrate with respect to \(u \), and use the bounds corresponding to \(u \) when using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.%
\end{itemize}
%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Exercises 5.5.5 Exercises}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Exercises}]{Exercises}\label{exercises-37}
\begin{exerciselist}
\item[1.]\hypertarget{ex-5-5-WW0}{}(Practice the steps of the method of substitution)\space\space{}\item[2.]\hypertarget{ez-5-3-WW1}{}(Product involving a 4th power polynomial)\space\space{}\item[3.]\hypertarget{ez-5-3-WW2}{}(Product involving \(\sin(x^6)\))\space\space{}\item[4.]\hypertarget{ez-5-3-WW3}{}(Fraction involving \(\ln^9(x)\))\space\space{}\item[5.]\hypertarget{ez-5-3-WW4}{}(Fraction involving \(e^{5 x}\))\space\space{}\item[6.]\hypertarget{ez-5-3-WW5}{}(Fraction involving \(e^{5 \sqrt{y}}\))\space\space{}\item[7.]\hypertarget{ez-5-3-WW6}{}(Definite integral involving \(e^{-\cos(q)}\))\space\space{}\item[8.]\hypertarget{exercise-329}{}(Working with negative exponents)\space\space{}\item[9.]\hypertarget{exercise-330}{}(Product involving \(\sin(9\sin(t)) \))\space\space{}\item[10.]\hypertarget{exercise-331}{}(Fraction involving \(\sin(9/x) \))\space\space{}\item[11.]\hypertarget{exercise-332}{}(Fraction involving sums of exponential functions)\space\space{}\item[12.]\hypertarget{exercise-333}{}(Integral involving a rational function)\space\space{}\item[13.]\hypertarget{exercise-334}{}(Integral of a partial fraction)\space\space{}\item[14.]\hypertarget{exercise-335}{}(Find the value of a definite integral based on another)\space\space{}\item[15.]\hypertarget{exercise-336}{}(Using the method of substitution to derive some other trignonometric antiderivative rules)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-5376}{}%
This problem centers on finding antiderivatives for the basic trigonometric functions other than \(\sin(x)\) and \(\cos(x)\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3468}{}\hypertarget{p-5377}{}%
Consider the indefinite integral \(\int \tan(x) \, dx\). By rewriting the integrand as \(\tan(x) = \frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}\) and identifying an appropriate function-derivative pair, make a \(u\)-substitution and hence evaluate \(\int \tan(x) \, dx\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3469}{}\hypertarget{p-5378}{}%
In a similar way, evaluate \(\int \cot(x) \, dx\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3470}{}\hypertarget{p-5379}{}%
Consider the indefinite integral%
\begin{equation*}
\int \frac{\sec^2(x) + \sec(x) \tan(x)}{\sec(x) + \tan(x)} \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Evaluate this integral using the substitution \(u = \sec(x) + \tan(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3471}{}\hypertarget{p-5380}{}%
Simplify the integrand in (c) by factoring the numerator. What is a far simpler way to write the integrand?%
\item\hypertarget{li-3472}{}\hypertarget{p-5381}{}%
Combine your work in (c) and (d) to determine \(\int \sec(x) \, dx\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3473}{}\hypertarget{p-5382}{}%
Using (c)-(e) as a guide, evaluate \(\int \csc(x) \, dx\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-242}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5383}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3474}{}\hypertarget{p-5384}{}%
\(\int \tan(x) \, dx = \ln\left(|\sec(x)|\right) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3475}{}\hypertarget{p-5385}{}%
\(\int \cot(x) \, dx = -\ln\left(|\csc(x)|\right) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3476}{}\hypertarget{p-5386}{}%
\(\int \frac{\sec^2(x) + \sec(x) \tan(x)}{\sec(x) + \tan(x)} \, dx = \ln\left(|\sec(x) + \tan(x)|\right) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3477}{}\hypertarget{p-5387}{}%
\(\frac{\sec^2(x) + \sec(x) \tan(x)}{\sec(x) + \tan(x)} = \sec(x)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3478}{}\hypertarget{p-5388}{}%
\(\int \sec(x) \, dx = \ln\left(|\sec(x) + \tan(x)|\right) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3479}{}\hypertarget{p-5389}{}%
\(\int \csc(x) \, dx = -\ln\left(|\csc(x) + \cot(x)|\right) + C\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-273}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5390}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3480}{}\hypertarget{p-5391}{}%
We let \(u = \cos(x)\), so \(du = -\sin(x) \ dx\). This change of variable transforms the integral into one we can integrate as follows:%
\begin{align*}
\int \tan(x) \, dx &= \int \frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)} \ dx\\
&= -\int \frac{1}{u} \ du\\
&= -\ln(|u|) + C\\
&= -\ln(|\cos(x)| + C\\
&= \ln\left(|\cos(x)|^{-1}\right) + C\\
&= \ln\left(|\sec(x)|\right) + C\text{.}
\end{align*}
Note that we used the property of the logarithm that \(p \ln (z) = \ln(z^p)\) as well as the fact that \(\frac{1}{\cos(x)} = \sec(x)\) in order to simplify the result.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3481}{}\hypertarget{p-5392}{}%
We let \(u = \sin(x)\), so \(du = \cos(x) \ dx\). This change of variable transforms the integral into one we can integrate as follows:%
\begin{align*}
\int \cot(x) \, dx &= \int \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)} \ dx\\
&= \int \frac{1}{u} \ du\\
&= \ln(|u|) + C\\
&= \ln(|\sin(x)| + C\\
&= -\ln\left(|\sin(x)|^{-1}\right) + C\\
&= -\ln\left(|\csc(x)|\right) + C\text{.}
\end{align*}
Note that here we used the fact that \(\ln(z) = (-1)(-1)\ln(z) = (-1) \ln(z^{-1})\) in order to simplify the result.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3482}{}\hypertarget{p-5393}{}%
We let \(u = \sec(x) + \tan(x)\), so it follows that \(du = \left(\sec(x)\tan(x)+\sec^2(x)\right) \ dx\). This change of variable shows that the basic structure of the integrand is simple and can be integrated as follows:%
\begin{align*}
\int \frac{\sec^2(x) + \sec(x) \tan(x)}{\sec(x) + \tan(x)} \, dx &= \int \frac{1}{u} \ du\\
&= \ln(|u|) + C\\
&= \ln\left(|\sec(x) + \tan(x)|\right) + C\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3483}{}\hypertarget{p-5394}{}%
The numerator of \(\frac{\sec^2(x) + \sec(x) \tan(x)}{\sec(x) + \tan(x)}\) can be rewritten by removing the common factor of \(\sec(x)\) to obtain%
\begin{equation*}
\sec(x)\left(\sec(x) + \tan(x)\right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
The integrand can then be simplified to%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{\sec^2(x) + \sec(x) \tan(x)}{\sec(x) + \tan(x)} = \frac{\sec(x)\left(\sec(x) + \tan(x)\right)}{\sec(x) + \tan(x)} = \sec(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3484}{}\hypertarget{p-5395}{}%
Using the results of (c) and (d), we see that%
\begin{equation*}
\int \sec(x) \, dx = \int \frac{\sec^2(x) + \sec(x) \tan(x)}{\sec(x) + \tan(x)} \, dx = \ln\left(|\sec(x) + \tan(x)|\right) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3485}{}\hypertarget{p-5396}{}%
Following (c)-(e) we can evaluate \(int \csc(x) \, dx\) as follows. First, rewrite \(\csc(x)\) by multiplying by \(1 = \frac{\csc(x) + \cot(x)}{\csc(x) + \cot(x)}\), so that%
\begin{equation*}
\int \csc(x) \, dx = \int \frac{\csc(x)\left(\csc(x) + \cot(x)\right)}{\csc(x) + \cot(x)} \, dx = \int \frac{\csc^2(x) + \csc(x) \cot(x)}{\csc(x) + \cot(x)} \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Now we evaluate the last integral in the preceding equation with the substitution \(u = \csc(x) + \cot(x)\). Then \(du = -\left(\csc(x)\cot(x)+\csc^2(x)\right) \ dx\). This change of variable transforms the integral so that we can integrate:%
\begin{align*}
\int \frac{\csc^2(x) + \csc(x) \cot(x)}{\csc(x) + \cot(x)} \, dx &= - \int \frac{1}{u} \ dx\\
&= -\ln(|u|) + C\\
&= -\ln\left(|\csc(x) + \cot(x)|\right) + C\text{.}
\end{align*}
Connecting the equalities we have established in our work, we have shown that%
\begin{equation*}
\int \csc(x) \, dx = -\ln\left(|\csc(x) + \cot(x)|\right) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[16.]\hypertarget{exercise-337}{}(Integral of \(\sec(x) \))\space\space{}\item[17.]\hypertarget{exercise-338}{}(Products involoving \(\sec(x) \) and \(\tan(x) \))\space\space{}\item[18.]\hypertarget{exercise-339}{}(Definite integral of \(\tan(8 t) \))\space\space{}\item[19.]\hypertarget{exercise-340}{}(Integrals of \(\tan(5 x) \) and \(\sec(5x) \))\space\space{}\item[20.]\hypertarget{exercise-341}{}(A clever substitution)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-5397}{}%
Consider the indefinite integral \(\int x \sqrt{x-1} \, dx\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3486}{}\hypertarget{p-5398}{}%
At first glance, this integrand may not seem suited to substitution due to the presence of \(x\) in separate locations in the integrand. Nonetheless, using the composite function \(\sqrt{x-1}\) as a guide, let \(u = x-1\). Determine expressions for both \(x\) and \(dx\) in terms of \(u\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3487}{}\hypertarget{p-5399}{}%
Convert the given integral in \(x\) to a new integral in \(u\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3488}{}\hypertarget{p-5400}{}%
Evaluate the integral in (b) by noting that \(\sqrt{u} = u^{\frac{1}{2}}\) and observing that it is now possible to rewrite the integrand in \(u\) by expanding through multiplication.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3489}{}\hypertarget{p-5401}{}%
Evaluate each of the integrals \(\int x^2 \sqrt{x-1} \, dx\) and \(\int x \sqrt{x^2 - 1} \, dx\). Write a paragraph to discuss the similarities among the three indefinite integrals in this problem and the role of substitution and algebraic rearrangement in each.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-243}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5402}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3490}{}\hypertarget{p-5403}{}%
\(\int x \sqrt{x-1} \, dx = \int (u+1) \sqrt{u} \, du\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3491}{}\hypertarget{p-5404}{}%
\(\int x \sqrt{x-1} \, dx = \frac{2}{5} (x-1)^{\frac{5}{2}} + \frac{2}{3} (x-1)^{\frac{3}{2}} + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3492}{}\hypertarget{p-5405}{}%
\(\int x^2 \sqrt{x-1} \, dx = \frac{2}{7} (x-1)^{\frac{7}{2}} + \frac{4}{5} (x-1)^{\frac{5}{2}} + \frac{2}{3} (x-1)^{\frac{3}{2}} + C\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5406}{}%
\(\int x \sqrt{x^2 - 1} \, dx = \frac{1}{3} (x^2-1)^{\frac{3}{2}} + C\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-274}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5407}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3493}{}\hypertarget{p-5408}{}%
Letting \(u = x-1\), we find that \(x = u+1\) and thus \(dx = du\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3494}{}\hypertarget{p-5409}{}%
Using the change of variables in (a),%
\begin{equation*}
\int x \sqrt{x-1} \, dx = \int (u+1) \sqrt{u} \, du\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3495}{}\hypertarget{p-5410}{}%
Using the fact that \(\sqrt{u} = u^{\frac{1}{2}}\) and distributing, we can evaluate the integral as follows:%
\begin{align*}
\int x \sqrt{x-1} \, dx &= \int (u+1) u^{\frac{1}{2}} \, du\\
&= \int \left(u^{\frac{3}{2}} + u^{\frac{1}{2}} \right) \, du\\
&= \frac{2}{5} u^{\frac{5}{2}} + \frac{2}{3} u^{\frac{3}{2}} + C\\
&= \frac{2}{5} (x-1)^{\frac{5}{2}} + \frac{2}{3} (x-1)^{\frac{3}{2}} + C\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3496}{}\hypertarget{p-5411}{}%
First, for \(\int x^2 \sqrt{x-1} \, dx\), we let \(u = x-1\) so that \(x = u+1\) and \(dx = du\). From there, our work is very similar to what we did in (b):%
\begin{align*}
\int x^2 \sqrt{x-1} \, dx &= \int (u+1)^2 u^{\frac{1}{2}} \, du\\
&= \int \left(u^2 + 2u + 1 \right) u^{\frac{1}{2}} \, du\\
&= \int \left(u^{\frac{5}{2}} + 2u^{\frac{3}{2}} + u^{\frac{1}{2}} \right) \, du\\
&= \frac{2}{7} u^{\frac{7}{2}} + \frac{4}{5} u^{\frac{5}{2}} + \frac{2}{3} u^{\frac{3}{2}} + C\\
&= \frac{2}{7} (x-1)^{\frac{7}{2}} + \frac{4}{5} (x-1)^{\frac{5}{2}} + \frac{2}{3} (x-1)^{\frac{3}{2}} + C\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5412}{}%
For \(\int x \sqrt{x^2 - 1} \, dx\), despite the fact that the integral looks remarkably similar, the situation is quite different. We observe that with \(u = x^2 - 1\), it follows \(du = 2x \, dx\), so we have a standard function-derivative pair. Noting that \(x \, dx = \frac{1}{2} \, du\), it follows that%
\begin{align*}
\int x \sqrt{x^2 - 1} \, dx &= \int \sqrt{u} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \, du\\
&= \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3}u^{\frac{3}{2}} + C\\
&= \frac{1}{3} u^{\frac{3}{2}} + C\\
&= \frac{1}{3} (x^2-1)^{\frac{3}{2}} + C\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5413}{}%
In the situation where we have \((x-a)\) under a square root and a polynomial outside the square root, the substitution \(u = x-a\) will allow us to convert the integrand into an expression we can integrate by changing the form of the radical from \(\sqrt{x-a}\) to \(\sqrt{u}\). From there we are able to distribute and integrate an expression that is essentially a sum of (fractional) powers of \(u\). In the situation where a polynomial of degree higher than \(1\) (such as \(x^2 - 1\)) is under the radical, we likely have to be fortunate enough to have the derivative of said polynomial (up to a constant) outside the radical in order to be able to integrate, as we were in the last example.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[21.]\hypertarget{exercise-342}{}(Fractions involving a square root or trigonometric functions)\space\space{}\item[22.]\hypertarget{exercise-343}{}(Definite integral with a clever substitution)\space\space{}\item[23.]\hypertarget{exercise-344}{}(Product involving trigonometric functions and square roots)\space\space{}\item[24.]\hypertarget{exercise-345}{}(Integral involving a square root of a linear expression)\space\space{}\item[25.]\hypertarget{exercise-346}{}(Re-writing a function in order to use substitution)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-5414}{}%
Consider the indefinite integral \(\int \sin^3(x) \, dx\). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3497}{}\hypertarget{p-5415}{}%
Explain why the substitution \(u = \sin(x)\) will not work to help evaluate the given integral.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3498}{}\hypertarget{p-5416}{}%
Recall the Fundamental Trigonometric Identity, which states that \(\sin^2(x) + \cos^2(x) = 1\). By observing that \(\sin^3(x) = \sin(x) \cdot \sin^2(x)\), use the Fundamental Trigonometric Identity to rewrite the integrand as the product of \(\sin(x)\) with another function.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3499}{}\hypertarget{p-5417}{}%
Explain why the substitution \(u = \cos(x)\) now provides a possible way to evaluate the integral in (b).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3500}{}\hypertarget{p-5418}{}%
Use your work in (a)-(c) to evaluate the indefinite integral \(\int \sin^3(x) \, dx\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3501}{}\hypertarget{p-5419}{}%
Use a similar approach to evaluate \(\int \cos^3(x) \, dx\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-244}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5420}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3502}{}\hypertarget{p-5421}{}%
We don't have a function-derivative pair.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3503}{}\hypertarget{p-5422}{}%
\(\sin^3(x) = \sin(x) (1-\cos^2(x))\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3504}{}\hypertarget{p-5423}{}%
\(u = \cos(x)\) and \(du = -\sin(x) \, dx\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3505}{}\hypertarget{p-5424}{}%
\(\int \sin^3(x) \, dx = \frac{1}{3}\cos^3(x) - \cos(x) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3506}{}\hypertarget{p-5425}{}%
\(\int \cos^3(x) \, dx = \sin(x) - \frac{1}{3}\sin^3(x) + C\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-275}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5426}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3507}{}\hypertarget{p-5427}{}%
If we let \(u = \sin(x)\), then \(du = \cos(x) \, dx\). Since there is no cosine function present in the integrand, we don't have the needed function-derivative pair present in order to transform the integral into one we can evaluate.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3508}{}\hypertarget{p-5428}{}%
Using the Fundamental Trigonometric Identity, we observe that \(\sin^2(x) = 1-\cos^2(x)\), and thus%
\begin{equation*}
\sin^3(x) = \sin(x) \cdot \sin^2(x) = \sin(x) (1-\cos^2(x))\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3509}{}\hypertarget{p-5429}{}%
By our work in (b), we see that \(\int \sin^3(x) \, dx = \int \sin(x) (1-\cos^2(x)) \, dx\), and in this integral we have the function-derivative pair that corresponds to \(u = \cos(x)\) and \(du = -\sin(x) \, dx\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3510}{}\hypertarget{p-5430}{}%
Using this substitution and evaluating the resulting integral,%
\begin{align*}
\int \sin^3(x) \, dx &= \int \sin(x) (1-\cos^2(x)) \, dx\\
&= \int (-1)(1-u^2) \, du\\
&= \int (u^2-1) \, du\\
&= \frac{1}{3}u^3 - u + C\\
&= \frac{1}{3}\cos^3(x) - \cos(x) + C\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3511}{}\hypertarget{p-5431}{}%
Here we observe that \(\cos^3(x) = \cos(x) \cdot \cos^2(x) = \cos(x) (1-\sin^2(x))\), so letting \(u = \sin(x)\) and thus \(du = \cos(x) \, dx\), we have%
\begin{align*}
\int \cos^3(x) \, dx &= \int \cos(x) (1-\sin^2(x)) \, dx\\
&= \int (1-u^2) \, du\\
&= u - \frac{1}{3}u^3 + C\\
&= \sin(x) - \frac{1}{3}\sin^3(x) + C\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item[26.]\hypertarget{exercise-347}{}(Fraction involving \(\sin(4t-1) \))\space\space{}\item[27.]\hypertarget{exercise-348}{}(An integral that requires rewriting before integrating)\space\space{}\item[28.]\hypertarget{exercise-349}{}(Power Consumption)\space\space{}\hypertarget{p-5432}{}%
For the town of Mathland, MI, residential power consumption has shown certain trends over recent years. Based on data reflecting average usage, engineers at the power company have modeled the town's rate of energy consumption by the function%
\begin{equation*}
r(t) = 4 + \sin(0.263t + 4.7) + \cos(0.526t+9.4)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5433}{}%
Here, \(t\) measures time in hours after midnight on a typical weekday, and \(r\) is the rate of consumption in megawatts\footnote{The unit \emph{megawatt} is itself a rate, which measures energy consumption per unit time. A \emph{megawatt-hour} is the total amount of energy that is equivalent to a constant stream of 1 megawatt of power being sustained for 1 hour.\label{fn-55}} at time \(t\). Units are critical throughout this problem. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3512}{}\hypertarget{p-5434}{}%
Sketch a carefully labeled graph of \(r(t)\) on the interval [0,24] and explain its meaning. Why is this a reasonable model of power consumption?%
\item\hypertarget{li-3513}{}\hypertarget{p-5435}{}%
Without calculating its value, explain the meaning of \(\int_0^{24} r(t) \, dt\). Include appropriate units on your answer.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3514}{}\hypertarget{p-5436}{}%
Determine the exact amount of energy Mathland consumes in a typical day.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3515}{}\hypertarget{p-5437}{}%
What is Mathland's average rate of power consumption in a given 24-hour period? What are the units on this quantity?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-245}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5438}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3516}{}\hypertarget{p-5439}{}%
The model is reasonable because it appears to be periodic and the rate of consumption seems to peak at the times of day where people are most active in their homes.%

\item\hypertarget{li-3517}{}\hypertarget{p-5440}{}%
The total power consumed in \(24\) hours, measured in megawatt-hours.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3518}{}\hypertarget{p-5441}{}%
\(\int_0^{24} r(t) \, dt \approx 95.7809 \) megawatts of power used in \(24\) hours.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3519}{}\(\displaystyle r_{\operatorname{AVG} [0,24]} \approx 3.99087\) megawatts.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-276}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5442}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3520}{}\hypertarget{p-5443}{}%
In the following plot, we see that the model is reasonable because it appears to be periodic and repeats every \(24\) hours, as well as that the rate of consumption seems to peak at the times of day where people are most active in their homes: around \(7\) a.m. and around \(5\) p.m.%

\item\hypertarget{li-3521}{}\hypertarget{p-5444}{}%
The meaning of \(\int_0^{24} r(t) \, dt\) is the total power consumed in \(24\) hours, measured in megawatt-hours. This is because \(r(t)\) is measured in megawatts and \(\triangle t\) in hours, and thus in the Riemann sum that corresponds to the definite integral, the terms in the sum of the form \(r(t) \cdot \triangle t\) have units ``megawatt-hours''. Moreover, by integrating the rate of power consumption we get the total change in power consumed.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3522}{}\hypertarget{p-5445}{}%
In a typical day, we know that Mathland consumes \(\int_0^{24} r(t) \, dt\) megawatt-hours of power, and thus we seek to evaluate the integral%
\begin{equation*}
\int_0^{24} r(t) \, dt = \int_0^{24} \left[ 4 + \sin(0.263t + 4.7) + \cos(0.526t+9.4) \right] \, dt\text{.}
\end{equation*}
To do so, we use the subtitutions \(u = 0.263t + 4.7\) (so \(du = 0.263 \, dt\)) and \(w = 0.526t + 9.4\) (so \(dw = 0.526 \, dt\)) to help us antidifferentiate the two trigonometric expressions, and thus we find that%
\begin{equation*}
\int \sin(0.263t + 4.7) \, dt = \frac{1}{0.263} \int \sin(u) \, du = -\frac{1}{0.263} \cos(u) = -\frac{1}{0.263} \cos(0.263t + 4.7)
\end{equation*}
and%
\begin{equation*}
\int \cos(0.526t + 9.4) \, dt = \frac{1}{0.526} \int \cos(w) \, dw = \frac{1}{0.526} \sin(w) = \frac{1}{0.526} \sin(0.526t + 9.4)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Putting this all together and using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, we have%
\begin{align*}
\int_0^{24} r(t) \, dt &= \left. 4t -\frac{1}{0.263} \cos(0.263t + 4.7) + \frac{1}{0.526} \sin(0.526t + 9.4) \right|_0^{24}\\
&= \left[ 4 \cdot 24 -\frac{1}{0.263} \cos(0.263 \cdot 24 + 4.7) + \frac{1}{0.526} \sin(0.526 \cdot 24 + 9.4) \right] - \left[ -\frac{1}{0.263} \cos(4.7) + \frac{1}{0.526} \sin(9.4) \right]\\
&\approx 95.7809
\end{align*}
megawatts of power used in \(24\) hours.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3523}{}We know that the average value of the rate function \(r\) on \([0,24]\) is%
\begin{equation*}
\displaystyle r_{\operatorname{AVG} [0,24]}  = \frac{1}{24-0} \int_{0}^{24} r(t) \, dt\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Thus, by our work in (c), we have that%
\begin{equation*}
\displaystyle r_{\operatorname{AVG} [0,24]}  \approx \frac{1}{24} \cdot 95.7809 = 3.99087
\end{equation*}
which is measured in megawatts.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{exerciselist}

\typeout{Section 5.6 Integration by Parts}
\typeout{************************************************}
\section[{Integration by Parts}]{Integration by Parts}\label{sec-5-6-parts}
\begin{objectives}{Motivating Questions}\label{objectives-35}
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5446}{}%
How do we evaluate indefinite integrals that involve products of basic functions such as \(\int x \sin(x) \, dx\) and \(\int x e^x \, dx\)?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5447}{}%
In the last section, we learned how to reverse the chain rule. How do we reverse other rules of differentiation? In this section, we'll tackle this question for the product rule of differentiation.%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5448}{}%
What is the method of integration by parts and how can we consistently apply it to integrate products of basic functions?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5449}{}%
How does the algebraic structure of functions guide us in identifying \(u\) and \(dv\) in using integration by parts?%
\end{itemize}
\end{objectives}
\hypertarget{p-5450}{}%
In \hyperref[sec-5-5-substitution]{Section~\ref{sec-5-5-substitution}}, we learned the technique of \(u\)-substitution for evaluating indefinite integrals. For example, the indefinite integral \(\int x^3 \sin(x^4) \, dx\) is perfectly suited to \(u\)-substitution, because one factor is a composite function and the other factor is the derivative (up to a constant) of the inner function. Recognizing the algebraic structure of a function can help us to find its antiderivative.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5451}{}%
Next we consider integrands with a different elementary algebraic structure: a product of basic functions. For instance, suppose we are interested in evaluating the indefinite integral%
\begin{equation*}
\int x \sin(x) \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5452}{}%
The integrand is the product of the basic functions \(f(x) = x\) and \(g(x) = \sin(x)\). We know that it is relatively complicated to compute the derivative of the product of two functions, so we should expect that antidifferentiating a product should be similarly involved. Intuitively, we expect that evaluating \(\int x \sin(x) \, dx\) will involve somehow reversing the Product Rule.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5453}{}%
To that end, in \hyperref[PA-5-4]{Example~\ref{PA-5-4}} we refresh our understanding of the Product Rule and then investigate some indefinite integrals that involve products of basic functions.%
\begin{assemblage}[The Product Rule of Differentiation]\label{assemblage-115}
\hypertarget{p-5454}{}%
In \hyperref[sec-2-3-prod-quot]{Section~\ref{sec-2-3-prod-quot}}, we developed the Product Rule and studied how it is employed to differentiate a product of two functions. In particular, recall that if \(f\) and \(g\) are differentiable functions of \(x\), then%
\begin{gather*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left[ f(x) \cdot g(x)  \right] = f(x) \cdot g'(x) + g(x) \cdot f'(x) \text{.}
\end{gather*}
%
\end{assemblage}
\begin{example}[]\label{PA-5-4}
\hypertarget{p-5455}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3528}{}\hypertarget{p-5456}{}%
For each of the following functions, use the Product Rule to find the function's derivative. Be sure to label each derivative by name (e.g., the derivative of \(g(x)\) should be labeled \(g'(x)\)).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5457}{}%
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3529}{}\hypertarget{p-5458}{}%
\(g(x) = x\sin(x)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3530}{}\hypertarget{p-5459}{}%
\(h(x) = xe^x\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3531}{}\hypertarget{p-5460}{}%
\(p(x) = x\ln(x)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3532}{}\hypertarget{p-5461}{}%
\(q(x) = x^2 \cos(x)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3533}{}\hypertarget{p-5462}{}%
\(r(x) = e^x \sin(x)\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
 %
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3534}{}\hypertarget{p-5463}{}%
\(g'(x)=x\cos(x) + \sin(x) \)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3535}{}\hypertarget{p-5464}{}%
\(h'(x)=xe^x + e^x \)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3536}{}\hypertarget{p-5465}{}%
\(p'(x)=1+ \ln(x) \)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3537}{}\hypertarget{p-5466}{}%
\(q'(x)=-x^2 \sin(x) + 2x\cos(x) \)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3538}{}\hypertarget{p-5467}{}%
\(r'(x)=e^x \cos(x) + e^x \sin(x) \)%
\end{enumerate}
 %
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3539}{}\hypertarget{p-5468}{}%
%
\begin{align*}
g'(x)&=x\cdot \frac{d}{dx}[\sin(x)] + \sin(x)\cdot \frac{d}{dx} [x] \\
&=x \cos(x)+ \sin(x) 
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3540}{}\hypertarget{p-5469}{}%
%
\begin{align*}
h'(x)&=x \cdot \frac{d}{dx}[e^x] + e^x \cdot \frac{d}{dx} [x] \\
&=xe^x + e^x 
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3541}{}\hypertarget{p-5470}{}%
%
\begin{align*}
p'(x)&=x \cdot \frac{d}{dx}[\ln(x)] + \ln(x) \cdot \frac{d}{dx} [x] \\
&=\frac{x}{x} + \ln (x) \\
&=1+ \ln(x) 
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3542}{}\hypertarget{p-5471}{}%
%
\begin{align*}
q'(x)&=x^2\cdot \frac{d}{dx} [\cos(x)] + \cos(x) \cdot \frac{d}{dx}[x^2] \\
&=-x^2 \sin(x) + 2x\cos(x) 
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3543}{}\hypertarget{p-5472}{}%
%
\begin{align*}
r'(x)&=e^x \cdot \frac{d}{dx}[\sin(x)] + \sin(x) \cdot \frac{d}{dx} [e^x] \\
&=e^x \cos(x) + e^x \sin(x) 
\end{align*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3544}{}\hypertarget{p-5473}{}%
Use your work in (a) to help you evaluate the following indefinite integrals. Use differentiation to check your work. %
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3545}{}\hypertarget{p-5474}{}%
\(\int xe^x + e^x \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3546}{}\hypertarget{p-5475}{}%
\(\int e^x(\sin(x) + \cos(x)) \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3547}{}\hypertarget{p-5476}{}%
\(\int 2x\cos(x) - x^2 \sin(x) \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3548}{}\hypertarget{p-5477}{}%
\(\int x\cos(x) + \sin(x) \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3549}{}\hypertarget{p-5478}{}%
\(\int 1 + \ln(x) \, dx\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
 \hypertarget{p-5479}{}%
How do the integrands in part (b) compare to the answers in part (a)? What relationship holds between \(h(x)\) from part a) ii. and the integrand from part b) i.?%
 %
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3550}{}\hypertarget{p-5480}{}%
\(\int xe^x + e^x \, dx = xe^x + C\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3551}{}\hypertarget{p-5481}{}%
\(\int e^x(\sin(x) + \cos(x)) \, dx=e^x \sin(x) + C\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3552}{}\hypertarget{p-5482}{}%
\(\int 2x\cos(x) - x^2 \sin(x) \, dx =x^2 \cos(x) + C\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3553}{}\hypertarget{p-5483}{}%
\(\int x\cos(x) + \sin(x) \, dx=x\sin(x) + C\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3554}{}\hypertarget{p-5484}{}%
\(\int 1 + \ln(x) \, dx = x\ln(x) + C \)%
\end{enumerate}
 %
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3555}{}\hypertarget{p-5485}{}%
Since the derivative of \(xe^x \) is \(xe^x + e^x \), then \(xe^x +C\) is the general antiderivative of \(xe^x + e^x \). Thus, we know that \(\int xe^x + e^x \, dx = xe^x + C\). We can check our answer by differentiating \(xe^x \), which we did in part a), to make sure we get the integrand, \(xe^x + e^x \).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3556}{}\hypertarget{p-5486}{}%
Since the derivative of \(e^x \sin(x) \) is \(e^x(\sin(x) + \cos(x)) \), then \(e^x\sin(x) +C\) is the general antiderivative of \(e^x(\sin(x) + \cos(x)) \). Thus, we know that \(\int e^x(\sin(x) + \cos(x)) \, dx=e^x \sin(x) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3557}{}\hypertarget{p-5487}{}%
Since the derivative of \(x^2\cos(x) \) is \(2x\cos(x) -x^2\sin(x) \), then \(x^2\cos(x)+C\) is the general antiderivative of \(2x\cos(x)-x^2\sin(x) \). Thus, we know that \(\int 2x\cos(x) - x^2 \sin(x) \, dx =x^2 \cos(x) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3558}{}\hypertarget{p-5488}{}%
Since the derivative of \(x\sin(x) \) is \(x\cos(x) + \sin(x) \), then \(x\sin(x) +C\) is the general antiderivative of \(x\cos(x)+ \sin(x) \). Thus, we know that \(\int x\cos(x) + \sin(x) \, dx=x\sin(x) + C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3559}{}\hypertarget{p-5489}{}%
Since the derivative of \(x\ln(x) \) is \(1+\ln(x) \), then \(x\ln(x) +C\) is the general antiderivative of \(1+ \ln(x) \). Thus, we know that \(\int 1 + \ln(x) \, dx = x\ln(x) + C \).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-5490}{}%
Observe that the examples in part (b) work nicely because of the derivatives you were asked to  calculate in part (a). Each integrand in part (b) is precisely the result of differentiating one of the products of basic functions found in part (a). To see what happens when an integrand is still a product but not necessarily the result of differentiating a product of functions, we consider how to evaluate%
\begin{equation*}
\int x\cos(x) \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{example}[]\label{PA-5-4-2}
\hypertarget{p-5491}{}%
Follow the steps outlined below to evlauate \(\int x\cos(x) \, dx \). \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3560}{}\hypertarget{p-5492}{}%
First, observe that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left[ x\sin(x) \right] = x\cos(x) + \sin(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Integrating both sides indefinitely and using the fact that the integral of a sum is the sum of the integrals, we find that%
\begin{equation*}
\int \left(\frac{d}{dx} \left[ x\sin(x) \right] \right) \, dx = \int  x\cos(x) \, dx +  \int \sin(x) \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
In this last equation, evaluate the indefinite integral on the left side of the equation as well as the rightmost indefinite integral on the right side of the equation.%
 \hypertarget{p-5493}{}%
From the \hyperref[sec-5-4-FTC2]{Second Fundamental Theorem of Calculus~\ref{sec-5-4-FTC2}}, we know that \(\int \frac{d}{dx} \left[x\sin(x) \right] =x\sin(x) + C_1 \) where \(C_1 \) is any constant. We also know that \(\int \sin(x) \, dx = -\cos(x) + C_2 \) where \(C_2 \) is any constant. Thus, we obtain the following equation:%
\begin{gather*}
x\sin(x) + C_1 = \int x \cos(x) \, dx - \cos(x) + C_2
\end{gather*}
%
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3561}{}\hypertarget{p-5494}{}%
In the most recent equation from (i.), solve the equation for the expression \(\int x \cos(x) \, dx\).%
 \hypertarget{p-5495}{}%
%
\begin{align*}
\int x \cos(x) \, dx&= x\sin(x) + \cos(x) + C_1-C_2 \\
\int x \cos(x) \, dx &= x\sin(x) + \cos(x) + C 
\end{align*}
where \(C\) is any constant.%
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3562}{}\hypertarget{p-5496}{}%
For which product of basic functions have you now found the antiderivative?%
 \hypertarget{p-5497}{}%
We found the antiderivative of the product of the functions \(x \) and \(\cos(x) \).%
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 5.6.1 Reversing the Product Rule: Integration by Parts}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Reversing the Product Rule: Integration by Parts}]{Reversing the Product Rule: Integration by Parts}\label{subsection-138}
\index{integration by parts}\hypertarget{p-5498}{}%
\hyperref[PA-5-4-2]{Example~\ref{PA-5-4-2}} provides a clue to the general technique known as Integration by Parts, which comes from reversing the Product Rule. Recall that the Product Rule states that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left[ f(x) g(x) \right] = f(x) g'(x) + g(x)  f'(x)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5499}{}%
Integrating both sides of this equation indefinitely with respect to \(x\), we find%
\begin{equation}
\int \frac{d}{dx} \left[ f(x)  g(x) \right] \, dx = \int f(x) g'(x) \, dx + \int g(x)  f'(x) \, dx\text{.}\label{E-intprod}
\end{equation}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5500}{}%
On the left side of \hyperref[E-intprod]{Equation~(\ref{E-intprod})}, we have the indefinite integral of the derivative of a function. Temporarily omitting the constant that may arise, we have%
\begin{equation}
f(x)  g(x) = \int f(x) g'(x) \, dx + \int g(x)  f'(x) \, dx\text{.}\label{E-intprod2}
\end{equation}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5501}{}%
We solve for the first indefinite integral on the left to generate the rule%
\begin{equation}
\int f(x) g'(x) \, dx  = f(x)  g(x) -  \int g(x)  f'(x) \, dx\text{.}\label{E-IBP1}
\end{equation}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5502}{}%
Often we express \hyperref[E-IBP1]{Equation~(\ref{E-IBP1})} in terms of the variables \(u\) and \(v\), where \(u = f(x)\) and \(v = g(x)\). In differential notation, \(du = f'(x) \, dx\) and \(dv = g'(x) \, dx\), so we can state the rule for \emph{Integration by Parts} in its most common form as follows:%
\begin{assemblage}[Integration by Parts Formula]\label{assemblage-116}
\hypertarget{p-5503}{}%
If \(u=f(x) \) and \(v=g(x) \), then \(du=f'(x) \, dx\) and \(dv=g'(x) \, dx \). Then we can change \hyperref[E-IBP1]{Equation~(\ref{E-IBP1})} to the following equation:%
\begin{equation*}
\int u \, dv  = uv -  \int v \, du\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
\hypertarget{p-5504}{}%
A way to remember the integration by parts formula is the following picture:%
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/5_6_Parts_Figure.svg}
\hypertarget{p-5505}{}%
Here, the curve \((u(x), v(x))\) cuts a rectangle in half. There are two ways to compute the area of the rectangle: \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3563}{}The first is the usual length times height. The length of the rectangle is \(u\), and the height is \(v\), so the area of the rectangle is \(uv\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3564}{}The other way to find the area of the rectangle is to add the area under the curve and above the curve. The area under the curve comes from integrated \(v(x)\) with respect to the horizontal axis (the \(u\)-axis), so the area under the curve is \(\int v du\). Similarly, the area above the curve is integrated with respect to the vertical axis, so its area is \(\int u dv\). Summing these gives the total area of the rectangle is \(\int u dv + \int v du \).%
\end{enumerate}
 Comparing the two methods tells us that \(uv = \int u dv + \int v du \), and rearranging this expression gives the integration by parts formula.%
\begin{assemblage}[Method of Integration by Parts]\label{assemblage-117}
\hypertarget{p-5506}{}%
To apply integration by parts to evaluate an indefinite integral, perform the following steps: \leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5507}{}%
Look for a product of basic functions that we can identify as \(u\) and \(dv\). We need to antidifferentiate \(dv \) to find \(v\), so keep this in mind when picking \(u\) and \(dv \).%
\item{}Once \(u, v, du, \) and \(dv \) have been identified, apply the integration by parts formula.%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-5508}{}%
If evaluating \(\int v \, du\) is not more difficult than evaluating \(\int u \, dv\), then this substitution usually proves to be fruitful.%
\end{itemize}
 Note: there are some exceptions where \(\int v\, du \) is just as difficult as \(\int u \, dv \) but integration by parts is still helpful. We cover those cases in \hyperref[IBP-MT]{Using Integration by Parts Multiple Times~\ref{IBP-MT}}.%
\end{assemblage}
\hypertarget{p-5509}{}%
To demonstrate this method, we consider the following example.%
\begin{example}[]\label{Ex-5-4-IBP}
\hypertarget{p-5510}{}%
Evaluate the indefinite integral%
\begin{equation*}
\int x\cos(x) \, dx
\end{equation*}
using integration by parts.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-282}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5511}{}%
When we use integration by parts, we have a choice for \(u\) and \(dv\). In this problem, we can either let \(u = x\) and \(dv = \cos(x) \, dx\), or let \(u = \cos(x)\) and \(dv = x \, dx\). While there is not a universal rule for how to choose \(u\) and \(dv\), a good guideline is this: do so in a way that \(\int v \, du\) is at least as simple as the original problem \(\int u \, dv\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5512}{}%
This leads us to choose\footnote{Observe that if we considered the alternate choice, and let \(u = \cos(x)\) and \(dv = x \, dx\), then \(du = -\sin(x) \, dx\) and \(v = \frac{1}{2}x^2\), from which we would write \(\int x\cos(x) \, dx = \frac{1}{2}x^2 \cos(x) - \int \frac{1}{2}x^2 (-\sin(x)) \, dx\). Thus we have replaced the problem of integrating \(x \cos(x)\) with that of integrating \(\frac{1}{2}x^2 \sin(x)\); the latter is clearly more complicated, which shows that this alternate choice is not as helpful as the first choice.\label{fn-56}}\(u = x\) and \(dv = \cos(x) \, dx\), from which it follows that \(du = 1 \, dx\) and \(v = \sin(x)\). With this substitution, the rule for integration by parts tells us that%
\begin{equation*}
\int x \cos(x) \, dx = x \sin(x) - \int \sin(x) \cdot 1 \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5513}{}%
All that remains to do is evaluate the (simpler) integral \(\int \sin(x) \cdot 1 \, dx\). Doing so, we find%
\begin{equation*}
\int x \cos(x) \, dx = x \sin(x) - (-\cos(x)) + C = x\sin(x) + \cos(x) + C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Observe that when we get to the final stage of evaluating the last remaining antiderivative, it is at this step that we include the integration constant, \(+C\).%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-5514}{}%
The general technique of integration by parts involves trading one integral for another since it converts the problem of evaluating \(\int u \, dv\) to that of evaluating \(\int v \, du\). It is therefore important that our choice of \(u\) and \(v\) make the problem easier instead of harder! In \hyperref[Ex-5-4-IBP]{Example~\ref{Ex-5-4-IBP}}, the original integral to evaluate was \(\int x \cos(x) \,dx\), and through the substitution provided by integration by parts, we were instead able to evaluate \(\int \sin(x) \cdot 1 \, dx\). Note that the original function \(x\) was replaced by its derivative, while \(\cos(x)\) was replaced by its antiderivative.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-5-4-1}
\hypertarget{p-5515}{}%
Evaluate each of the following indefinite integrals. Check each antiderivative that you find by differentiating. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3568}{}\hypertarget{p-5516}{}%
\(\int te^{-t} \, dt\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3569}{}\hypertarget{p-5517}{}%
\(\int 4x \sin(3x) \, dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3570}{}\hypertarget{p-5518}{}%
\(\int z \sec^2(z) \,dz\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3571}{}\hypertarget{p-5519}{}%
\(\int x \ln(x) \, dx\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-148}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5520}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3572}{}\hypertarget{p-5521}{}%
Try \(u=t\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3573}{}\hypertarget{p-5522}{}%
Let \(dv=\sin(3x)dx\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-3574}{}\hypertarget{p-5523}{}%
Remember that \(\int \sec^2(z) \,dz = \tan(z)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3575}{}\hypertarget{p-5524}{}%
Note that \(\ln(x) \, dx\) has a simple derivative to work with.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-248}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5525}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3576}{}\hypertarget{p-5526}{}%
\(\int t e^{-t} dt = -te^{-t} - e^{-t} +C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3577}{}\hypertarget{p-5527}{}%
\(\int 4x \sin(3x) dx = -\dfrac{4}{3} x \cos(3x) + \frac{4}{9} \sin(3x) + C \).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3578}{}\hypertarget{p-5528}{}%
\(\int z \sec^2(z) dz = z \tan(z) + \ln |\cos(z)| + C \).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3579}{}\hypertarget{p-5529}{}%
\(\int x\ln(x) dx = \frac{1}{2}x^2 \ln(x) - \frac{1}{4}x^2 + C \).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-283}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5530}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3580}{}\hypertarget{p-5531}{}%
Using \(u = t\) and \(dv = e^{-t} dt\), we obtain \(du = dt\) and \(v = -e^{-t}\). So%
\begin{align*}
\int t e^{-t} dt \amp = -te^{-t} + \int e^{-t} dt\\
\amp = -te^{-t} - e^{-t} + C
\end{align*}
We check using differentiation as follows:%
\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dt} \left( -te^{-t} - e^{-t} + C \right) \amp = \left( t e^{-t} - e^{-t} \right) + e^{-t}\\
\amp = te^{-t}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3581}{}\hypertarget{p-5532}{}%
Using \(u = 4x\) and \(dv = \sin(3x) dx\), we obtain \(du = 4 dx\) and \(v = -\dfrac{1}{3} \cos(3x)\). So%
\begin{align*}
\int 4x \sin(3x) dx \amp = -\dfrac{4}{3} x \cos(3x) + \dfrac{4}{3} \int \cos(3x) dx\\
\amp = -\dfrac{4}{3} x \cos(3x) + \frac{4}{9} \sin(3x) + C
\end{align*}
We check using differentiation as follows:%
\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left( -\dfrac{4}{3} x \cos(3x) + \frac{4}{9} \sin(3x) + C \right) \amp =  4x \sin(3x) - \frac{4}{3} \cos(3x)  + \frac{4}{3} \cos(3x)\\
\amp = 4x \sin(3x)
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3582}{}\hypertarget{p-5533}{}%
Using \(u = z\) and \(dv = \sec^2(z) dz\), we obtain \(du = dz\) and \(v = \tan(z)\). So%
\begin{align*}
\int z \sec^2(z) dz \amp = z \tan(z) - \int \tan(z) \,dz\\
\int z \sec^2(z) dz \amp = z \tan(z) - \int \frac{\sin(z)}{\cos(z)} \,dz\\
\amp = z \tan(z) + \ln |\cos(z)| + C
\end{align*}
We check using differentiation as follows:%
\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dz} \left( z \tan(z) + \ln |\cos(z)| + C \right) \amp = z\sec^2(z) + \tan(z) - \frac{\sin(z)}{\cos(z)}\\
\amp = z\sec^2(z) + \tan(z) - \tan(z)\\
\amp = z \sec^2(z)
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3583}{}\hypertarget{p-5534}{}%
Using \(u = \ln(x)\) and \(dv = x dx\), we obtain \(du = \dfrac{1}{x} dx\) and \(v = \dfrac{1}{2}x^2\). So%
\begin{align*}
\int x\ln(x) dx \amp = \frac{1}{2}x^2 \ln(x) - \frac{1}{2} \int x dx\\
\amp = \frac{1}{2}x^2 \ln(x) - \frac{1}{4}x^2 + C
\end{align*}
We check using differentiation as follows:%
\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dx} \left( \frac{1}{2}x^2 \ln(x) - \frac{1}{4}x^2 + C \right) \amp = \frac{1}{2}x + x \ln(x) - \frac{1}{2} x\\
\amp = x \ln(x)
\end{align*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 5.6.2 Some Subtleties with Integration by Parts}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Some Subtleties with Integration by Parts}]{Some Subtleties with Integration by Parts}\label{subsection-139}
\hypertarget{p-5535}{}%
Sometimes integration by parts is not an obvious choice, but the technique is appropriate nonetheless. Integration by parts allows us to replace one function in a product with its derivative while replacing the other with its antiderivative. For instance, consider evaluating%
\begin{equation*}
\int \arctan(x) \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5536}{}%
Initially, this problem seems ill-suited to integration by parts, since there does not appear to be a product of functions present. But if we note that \(\arctan(x) = \arctan(x) \cdot 1\), and realize that we know the derivative of \(\arctan(x)\) as well as the antiderivative of \(1\), we see the possibility for the substitution \(u = \arctan(x)\) and \(dv = 1 \, dx\). We explore this substitution further in \hyperref[act-5-4-2]{Example~\ref{act-5-4-2}}.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5537}{}%
In a related problem, consider \(\int t^3 \sin(t^2) \, dt\). Observe that there is a composite function present in \(\sin(t^2)\), which normally suggests \(u\)-substitution, but there is not an obvious function-derivative pair, as we have \(t^3\) (rather than simply \(t\)) multiplying \(\sin(t^2)\). In this problem we use both \(u\)-substitution and integration by parts. First we write \(t^3 = t \cdot t^2\) and consider the indefinite integral%
\begin{equation*}
\int t \cdot t^2 \cdot \sin(t^2) \, dt\text{.}
\end{equation*}
We let \(z = t^2\) so that \(dz = 2t \, dt\), and thus \(t \, dt = \frac{1}{2} \, dz\). (We are using the variable \(z\) to perform a ``\(z\)-substitution'' first so that we may then apply integration by parts.) Under this \(z\)-substitution, we now have%
\begin{equation*}
\int t \cdot t^2 \cdot \sin(t^2) \, dt = \int z \cdot \sin(z) \cdot \frac{1}{2} \, dz\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5538}{}%
The resulting integral can be evaluated by parts. This, too, is explored further in \hyperref[act-5-4-2]{Example~\ref{act-5-4-2}}.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-5539}{}%
These problems show that we sometimes must think creatively in choosing the variables for substitution in integration by parts, and that we may need to use substitution for an additional change of variables.%
\begin{example}[]\label{act-5-4-2}
\hypertarget{p-5540}{}%
Evaluate each of the following indefinite integrals, using the provided hints. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3584}{}\hypertarget{p-5541}{}%
Evaluate \(\int \arctan(x) \, dx\) by using Integration by Parts with the substitution \(u = \arctan(x)\) and \(dv = 1 \, dx\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3585}{}\hypertarget{p-5542}{}%
Evaluate \(\int \ln(z) \,dz\). Consider a similar substitution to the one in (a).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3586}{}\hypertarget{p-5543}{}%
Use the substitution \(z = t^2\) to transform the integral \(\int t^3 \sin(t^2) \, dt\) to a new integral in the variable \(z\), and evaluate that new integral by parts.%
\item\hypertarget{li-3587}{}\hypertarget{p-5544}{}%
Evaluate \(\int s^5 e^{s^3} \, ds\) using an approach similar to that described in (c).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3588}{}\hypertarget{p-5545}{}%
Evaluate \(\int e^{2t} \cos(e^t) \, dt\). You will find it helpful to note that \(e^{2t} = e^t \cdot e^t\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-249}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5546}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3589}{}\hypertarget{p-5547}{}%
\(\int{\arctan(x) dx} = x\arctan(x) - \frac{1}{2} \ln \left( 1 + x^2 \right) + C \).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3590}{}\hypertarget{p-5548}{}%
\(\int \ln(z) dz = z \ln(z) - z + C \).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3591}{}\hypertarget{p-5549}{}%
\(\int t^3 \sin(t^2) dt = \frac{1}{2} \left( -t^2 \cos\left(t^2 \right) + \sin\left(t^2\right) \right) +C\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3592}{}\hypertarget{p-5550}{}%
\(\int s^5 e^{s^3} ds = \frac{1}{3} \left( s^3 e^{s^3} - e^{s^3} \right) + C \).%
\item\hypertarget{li-3593}{}\hypertarget{p-5551}{}%
\(\int e^{2t} \cos\left( e^t \right) dt = e^t \sin \left( e^t \right) + \cos \left( e^t \right) + C \).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-284}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-5552}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-3594}{}\hypertarget{p-5553}{}%
We use integration by parts with \(u = \arctan(x)\) and \(dv = dx\). So \(du = \dfrac{1}{1+x^2}dx\) and \(v = x\).%
\begin{align*}
\int{\arctan(x) dx} \amp = uv - \int{v du}\\
\amp = x\arctan(x) - \int\frac{x}{1+x^2} dx
\end{align*}
For the integral in the last equation, use the substitution \(z = 1+x^2\) and \(dz = 2x\, dx\).%
\begin{align*}
\int \arctan(x) dx  \amp = x\arctan(x) -\int\frac{x}{1+x^2} dx\\
\amp = x\arctan(x) - \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{1}{z} dz\\
\amp = x\arctan(x) - \frac{1}{2} \ln(z) + C\\
\amp = x\arctan(x) - \frac{1}{2} \ln \left( 1 + x^2 \right) + C
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3595}{}\hypertarget{p-5554}{}%
Using \(u = \ln(z)\) and \(dv = dz\), we obtain \(du = \dfrac{1}{z} dz\) and \(v = z\). So%
\begin{align*}
\int \ln(z) dz \amp = z \ln(z) - \int dz\\
\amp = z \ln(z) - z + C
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3596}{}\hypertarget{p-5555}{}%
Using \(z = t^2\), we obtain \(dz = 2t dt\) and \(\dfrac{1}{2} dz = t dt\). So%
\begin{align*}
\int t^3 \sin(t^2) dt \amp = \int t^2 \sin(t^2) \cdot t dt\\
\amp = \int z \sin(z) \frac{1}{2} dz\\
\amp = \frac{1}{2} \int z \sin(z) dz
\end{align*}
Now using integration by parts with \(u = z\) and \(dv = \sin(z) dz\), we obtain \(du = dz\) and \(v = -\cos(z)\). So%
\begin{align*}
\int t^3 \sin(t^2) dt \amp = \frac{1}{2} \int z \sin(z) dz\\
\amp = \frac{1}{2} \left( -z \cos(z) + \int \cos(z) dz \right)\\
\amp = \frac{1}{2} \left( -z \cos(z) + \sin(z) \right) + C
\end{align*}
Finally, we use \(z = t^2\) and obtain%
\begin{equation*}
\int t^3 \sin(t^2) dt = \frac{1}{2} \left( -t^2 \cos\left(t^2 \right) + \sin\left(t^2\right) \right) +C\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-3597}{}\hypertarget{p-5556}{}%
Use a substitution with \(z = s^3\) and \(dz = 3s^2 ds\).%
