\par
\hypertarget{p-6802}{}%
We can use the symmetry of the unit circle to find this second angle. By symmetry, the magnitudes of the two angles shown below are equal. Thus, \(\theta=-0.927\) is another angle that satisfies \(\cos(\theta) = 0.6\).%

\begin{example}[]\label{example-278}
\hypertarget{p-6804}{}%
Find the polar coordinates of a point with the Cartesian coordinates%
\begin{equation*}
(x,y)=\left(-4\sqrt{2},4\sqrt{2}\right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-368}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6805}{}%
Let's start by plotting the point \((x,y)=\big(-4\sqrt{2},4\sqrt{2}\big)\) on a graph and using the Pythagorean theorem to find the corresponding radius of the point. We get that%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)
{% begin: group for a single side-by-side
% set panel max height to practical minimum, created in preamble
\setlength{\panelmax}{0pt}

\begin{align*}
r^2 \amp= x^2 + y^2 \\
\\
r^2 \amp= \big(-4\sqrt{2}\big)^2 + \big(4\sqrt{2}\big)^2 \\
\\
r^2 \amp= 32 + 32 \\
\\
r^2 \amp= 64 \\
\\
r \amp= 8 \text{.}
\end{align*}
}}}

% end: side-by-side as tabular

\par
\hypertarget{p-6807}{}%
Now that we know the radius, we can find the angle using any of the three trigonometric relationships. Keep in mind that there may be more than one solution when solving for \(\theta\) and we will need to consider the quadrant that our \((x,y)\) point is in to decide which solution to use.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6808}{}%
Using the sine function, we get that%
\begin{equation*}
\sin(\theta) = \frac{y}{r} = \frac{4\sqrt{2}}{8}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6809}{}%
Since \(y=\sqrt{2}/2\) corresponds to a common angle on the unit circle, we can find an exact value for \(\theta\). The two angles that have a sine value of \(\sqrt{2}/2\) on the unit circle are%
\begin{equation*}
\theta=\frac{\pi}{4} \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \theta=\frac{3\pi}{4}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6810}{}%
Since the point \((x,y)=\big(-4\sqrt{2},4\sqrt{2}\big)\) is located in Quadrant II, we can determine that \(\theta=3\pi/4\). Thus, the polar coordinates are%
\begin{equation*}
(r,\theta)=\left(8, \frac{3\pi}{4}\right)\text{.}
\end{equation*}

\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 6.3.2 Examples of Graphs in Polar Coordinates}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Examples of Graphs in Polar Coordinates}]{Examples of Graphs in Polar Coordinates}\label{subsection-171}
\hypertarget{p-6811}{}%
Any equation written in Cartesian coordinates can be converted to one in polar coordinates and vice-versa. In practice, it makes sense to use the representation that is most natural for the application, or the one which is simpler to express. For example, the unit circle of radius 1 about the origin may be expressed in Cartesian coordinates using the equation%
\begin{equation*}
x^2 + y^2 = 1. 
\end{equation*}
Since the points on the circle are precisely those points at distance \(r \) from the origin, in polar coordinates the equation may be written as%
\begin{equation*}
r = 1. 
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6812}{}%
Algebraically, we can see that this is correct by substituting \(x = r \cos(\theta) \) and \(y = r \sin(\theta) \) into the original equation to obtain%
\begin{equation*}
x^2 + y^2 = 1 
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{equation*}
r^2 \cos^2(\theta) + r^2 \sin^2(\theta) = 1 
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{equation*}
r^2\big( \cos^2(\theta) + \sin^2(\theta) \big) = 1 \text{.}
\end{equation*}
Using the trig identity \(\cos^2(\theta) + \sin^2(\theta) =1 \), this becomes%
\begin{equation*}
r^2 = 1 \text{.}
\end{equation*}
Since \(r\) denotes the length of the radius to the point, it follows that \(r\gt0\); hence, \(r = 1. \)%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6813}{}%
We now look at some special families of graphs in polar coordinates.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-279}
\hypertarget{p-6814}{}%
One interesting family of graphs in polar coordinates are the \terminology{rose graphs}. These are curves of the form%
\begin{equation*}
r = a \cos (n \theta) 
\end{equation*}
or%
\begin{equation*}
r = a \sin (n \theta), 
\end{equation*}
where \(n \) is a positive integer and \(a \gt 0 \).%
\par

\typeout{Subsection 6.3.3 Calculating Area using Polar Coordinates}

\subsection[{Calculating Area using Polar Coordinates}]{Calculating Area using Polar Coordinates}\label{subsection-172}
\hypertarget{p-6823}{}%
First consider a circle of radius \(r \) as shown in the image below. \includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/6_3_Sector_Area.pdf}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6824}{}%
To find the area of a sector with angle \(\theta\), we calculate the fraction of the area of the sector compared to the area of the circle. Thus,%
\begin{equation*}
\text{Area of Sector}   = \frac{\theta}{2\pi} (\pi r^2)  = \frac{1}{2}r^2 \theta \text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6825}{}%
To find regions of more general shapes, we will consider slicing them into thin regions and approximating the areas of those regions with sectors.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-281}
\hypertarget{p-6826}{}%
Consider the function \(f(\theta)=\cos(2\theta)\) and the region given by the graph of \(r=f(\theta)\) on the interval \(0 \leq \theta \leq 2 \pi\) (shown below).%
\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/6_3_Noncircular_Sector_Area.pdf}
\hypertarget{p-6827}{}%
How would we approximate the area of this region? Our normal strategy would be to cut the region into rectangles and take a Riemann sum of the areas of those rectangles, but because we are working in polar coordinates, it is more natural to approximate the region with the sectors of a circle. One such sector is drawn on the image. That sector has an angle of \(\Delta \theta\) and a radius of \(f(\theta_i)\), so%
\begin{equation*}
\text{area}_{\text{slice}} \approx \text{area}_{\text{sector}}= \frac 12 (f(\theta_i))^2 \Delta \theta \text{.}
\end{equation*}
Taking the Riemann sum and taking the limit as \(\Delta \theta \rightarrow 0 \), we get that the area of the region is given by the integral \(\int_\alpha^\beta \frac 12 (f(\theta))^2 \, d \theta \).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6828}{}%
For this particular function, the area contained by \(r=f(\theta)\) on the interval \(0\le\theta\le2\pi\) is thus%
\begin{equation*}
\int^{2\pi}_0\frac12\cos^2(2\theta)\,d\theta=\frac{\pi}2\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-6829}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Area in Polar Coordinates]\label{assemblage-141}
\hypertarget{p-6830}{}%
For a curve \(r = f(\theta) \) where \(f(\theta) \ge 0 \), the \terminology{area} between the origin and the curve \(f(\theta) \) from \(\alpha\) to \(\beta \) is%
\begin{equation*}
\text{Area} = \frac{1}{2} \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} f(\theta)^2 \ d\theta \text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-282}
\hypertarget{p-6831}{}%
Consider the Archimedean spiral given by \(r=\theta\). Find the area traced out in the first loop of the spiral (from \(\theta=0\) to \(\theta=2\pi\)).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-188}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6832}{}%
Apply the formula in ``Area in Polar Coordinates''.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-314}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6833}{}%
\(A=\frac{4}{3} \pi^3 \).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-371}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6834}{}%
Since \(r=f(\theta)=\theta\), then by the "Area in Polar Coordinates" formula,%
\begin{align*}
A\amp= \frac 12 \int_{\theta=0}^{\theta=2\pi}\theta^2 \, d \theta \\
\amp=\left. \frac 16 \theta^3 \right |_{\theta=0}^{\theta=2\pi}\\
\amp= \frac{4}{3} \pi^3 \text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{example-283}
\hypertarget{p-6835}{}%
Consider the rose given by \(r=\sin(4\theta)\). Find the area traced out by the rose (the entire rose is traced out from \(\theta=0\) to \(\theta=2\pi\)).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-189}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6836}{}%
Apply the formula in ``Area in Polar Coordinates'' and the trig identity \(\sin^2(x)=\frac 1 2 - \frac 1 2 \cos(2x)\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-315}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6837}{}%
\(A= \frac \pi 2 \).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-372}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6838}{}%
Since \(r=f(\theta)=\sin(4\theta)\), then by the "Area in Polar Coordinates" formula,%
\begin{align*}
A\amp= \frac 12 \int_{\theta=0}^{\theta=2\pi}\big(\sin(4\theta)\big)^2 \, d \theta\\
\amp= \frac 12 \int_{\theta=0}^{\theta=2\pi}\left(\frac 1 2 -\frac 1 2\cos (8 \theta)\right) \, d \theta \\
\amp=\left. \frac 12 \left(\frac 1 2\theta - \frac 1 {16} \sin(8 \theta)\right) \right |_{\theta=0}^{\theta=2\pi}\\
\amp= \frac \pi 2 \text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{example-284}
\hypertarget{p-6839}{}%
Let \(f(\theta)=\theta\) and \(g(\theta)=\pi-\theta\), and consider the shark-fin shaped region traced out by the two Archimedean spirals \(r=f(\theta)\) and \(r=g(\theta)\) and the \(x\)-axis (shown below). \includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/6_3_Sharkfin_Figure.pdf}
 \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4368}{}\hypertarget{p-6840}{}%
Find the \((r,\theta)\)- and \((x,y)\)-coordinates of the point where the curves meet.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4369}{}\hypertarget{p-6841}{}%
In \hyperref[sec-6-1-area]{Section~\ref{sec-6-1-area}}, we approximated areas by taking either vertical or horizontal rectangles whose two ends were on different curves bounding the region. Would that method work to find the area of the shark-fin region? If so, set up and evaluate the integrals. If not, explain why not.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4370}{}\hypertarget{p-6842}{}%
In order to find the area of the shark fin, we will first find two other areas, then combine our answers. Set up and evaluate an integral that gives the area of the region bounded by \(r=f(\theta)\) and the \(y\)-axis.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4371}{}\hypertarget{p-6843}{}%
In order to find the area of the shark fin, we will first find two other areas, then combine our answers. Set up and evaluate an integral that gives the area of the region bounded by \(r=g(\theta)\), the \(y\)-axis, and the \(x\)-axis.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4372}{}\hypertarget{p-6844}{}%
Combine your answers to the previous parts to find the area of the shark-fin shaped region.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-190}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6845}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4373}{}\hypertarget{p-6846}{}%
Solve the equation \(f(\theta)=r=g(\theta)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4374}{}\hypertarget{p-6847}{}%
Neither vertical nor horizontal rectangles would produce an easy integral.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4375}{}\hypertarget{p-6848}{}%
Apply the formula in ``Area in Polar Coordinates''.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4376}{}\hypertarget{p-6849}{}%
Apply the formula in ``Area in Polar Coordinates''.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4377}{}\hypertarget{p-6850}{}%
How can you combine the regions in parts (c) and (d) to make the shark-fin shaped region?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-316}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6851}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4378}{}\hypertarget{p-6852}{}%
\((r,\theta)=\big(\frac \pi 2,\frac \pi 2\big)\). \((x,y)=\big(0, \frac \pi 2\big)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4379}{}\hypertarget{p-6853}{}%
Neither vertical nor horizontal rectangles would produce an easy integral.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4380}{}\hypertarget{p-6854}{}%
\(A=\frac{\pi^3}{48}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4381}{}\hypertarget{p-6855}{}%
\(A=\frac{7\pi^3}{48}\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4382}{}\hypertarget{p-6856}{}%
\(A=\frac{\pi^3}{8}\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-373}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6857}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4383}{}\hypertarget{p-6858}{}%
The curves meet when \(f(\theta)=r=g(\theta)\), so when \(\theta=\pi-\theta\), which is at \(\theta=\frac \pi 2\). Plugging back into \(f(\theta)\) or \(g(\theta)\) gives that \(r= \frac \pi 2\). Thus the \((r,\theta)\)-coordinates are \(\big(\frac \pi 2,\frac \pi 2\big)\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6859}{}%
The \((x,y)\)-coordinates can be found by \(x=r \cos(\theta)\), \(y=r \sin(\theta)\), so \((x,y)=\big(0, \frac \pi 2\big)\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4384}{}\hypertarget{p-6860}{}%
Neither vertical nor horizontal rectangles would produce an easy integral. For vertical rectangles, near the \(y\)-axis, both ends of the rectangles would be on the curve \(r=f(\theta)\), which would make the integral hard to set up and evaluate. For horizontal rectangles, near the top of the region, both ends of the rectangles would be on the curve \(r=g(\theta)\), which would make the integral hard to set up and evaluate.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4385}{}\hypertarget{p-6861}{}%
This region goes from \(\theta=0\) to \(\theta= \frac \pi 2\), so its area is given by%
\begin{align*}
A\amp= \frac 1 2 \int_0^{\frac \pi 2} (f(\theta))^2 \, d \theta \\
\amp= \frac 1 2 \int_0^{\frac \pi 2} \theta^2 \, d \theta \\
\amp= \left. \frac 1 6 \theta^3  \right|_0^{\frac \pi 2} \\
\amp=\frac{\pi^3}{48}\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4386}{}\hypertarget{p-6862}{}%
This region goes from \(\theta=0\) to \(\theta= \frac \pi 2\), so its area is given by%
\begin{align*}
A\amp= \frac 1 2 \int_0^{\frac \pi 2} (g(\theta))^2 \, d \theta \\
\amp= \frac 1 2 \int_0^{\frac \pi 2} (\pi-\theta)^2 \, d \theta \\
\amp= \left. \frac {-1} 6 (\pi-\theta)^3  \right|_0^{\frac \pi 2} \\
\amp= \left(\frac{-\pi}{48}\right)+ \frac{\pi^3}{6}\\
\amp=\frac{7\pi^3}{48}\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4387}{}\hypertarget{p-6863}{}%
The shark-fin shaped region is made from the region in (d) minus the region in (c), so its area is%
\begin{equation*}
A= \frac{7\pi^3}{48}-\frac{\pi^3}{48}= \frac{\pi^3}{8}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 6.3.4 Slope and Arc Length with Polar Coordinates}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Slope and Arc Length with Polar Coordinates}]{Slope and Arc Length with Polar Coordinates}\label{subsection-173}
\hypertarget{p-6864}{}%
We can think of a curve \(r = f(\theta) \) in terms of \(x \) and \(y\) by using \(x = r \cos(\theta) \) and \(y = r\sin(\theta) \). In this way, the curve may be seen as being parametrized by \(\theta \). Thus, we may use the formulas for slope and arc length of parametric equations to obtain formulas for slope and arc length in polar coordinates.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6865}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Slope in Polar Coordinates]\label{assemblage-142}
\hypertarget{p-6866}{}%
The \terminology{slope} of a curve \(r = f(\theta) \) is%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{\big(\frac{dy}{d\theta}\big)}{\big(\frac{dx}{d\theta}\big)} \text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6867}{}%
\begin{assemblage}[Arc Length in Polar Coordinates]\label{assemblage-143}
\hypertarget{p-6868}{}%
The \terminology{arc length} of the curve \(r = f(\theta) \), where \(x = r \cos(\theta) \) and \(y = r\sin(\theta) \), is%
\begin{equation*}
\text{Arc Length} = \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} \sqrt{\left(\frac{dx}{d \theta} \right)^2 + \left(\frac{dy}{d \theta}\right)^2 } \, d\theta\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-285}
\hypertarget{p-6869}{}%
Let \(f(\theta)=2\theta+3\), and consider the Archimedean spiral given by the equation \(r=f(\theta)\) for \(0 \leq \theta \leq 2 \pi\). The spiral is shown below. \includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/6_3_Arc_Length_Spiral_Figure.pdf}
 \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4388}{}\hypertarget{p-6870}{}%
The point labelled "A" is at \(\theta=3 \pi/4\). Find the \((x,y)\)-coordinates of A and the slope of the tangent line there.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4389}{}\hypertarget{p-6871}{}%
The point labelled "B" is at \(\theta=7 \pi/4\). Find the \((x,y)\)-coordinates of B and the slope of the tangent line there.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4390}{}\hypertarget{p-6872}{}%
Find the length of the piece of the spiral in the third quadrant. (You may wish to use a computer or calculator to numerically evaluate the integral.)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-191}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6873}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4391}{}\hypertarget{p-6874}{}%
You will need to evaluate \(\frac{dx}{d\theta}\) and \(\frac{dy}{d\theta}\) at \(A\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4392}{}\hypertarget{p-6875}{}%
You will need to evaluate \(\frac{dx}{d\theta}\) and \(\frac{dy}{d\theta}\) at \(B\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4393}{}\hypertarget{p-6876}{}%
Find \(\frac{dx}{d\theta}\) and \(\frac{dy}{d\theta}\) and use the arc length formula in "Arc Length in Polar Coordinates".%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-317}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6877}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4394}{}\hypertarget{p-6878}{}%
\(\frac{dy}{dx} \approx 0.588\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4395}{}\hypertarget{p-6879}{}%
\(\frac{dy}{dx} \approx 0.7499\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4396}{}\hypertarget{p-6880}{}%
Arc Length \(\approx 17.33\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-374}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6881}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4397}{}\hypertarget{p-6882}{}%
Since \(r=2 \theta+3\), \(x=r \cos(\theta)\), and \(y=r \sin(\theta)\), and \(\theta=\frac{3\pi}4\) at A, then%
\begin{equation*}
r=\frac{3 \pi}{2}+3,\\
x= \left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}+3 \right)\left(-\frac{\sqrt 2}2\right) \approx -5.45, \text{ and}\\
y= \left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}+3 \right)\left(\frac{\sqrt 2}2\right) \approx 5.45\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Now to find \(\frac{dy}{dx}\) we write%
\begin{equation*}
x= r \cos(\theta)=(2 \theta+3) \cos(\theta)\\
y= r \sin(\theta)=(2 \theta+3) \sin(\theta).
\end{equation*}
Thus, taking \(\frac{d}{d\theta}[x]\) and \(\frac{d}{d\theta}[y]\) and applying the product rule, we get%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dx}{d\theta} = 2\cos(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(-\sin(\theta))\\
\frac{dy}{d\theta} = 2\sin(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(\cos(\theta))\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Finally, plugging in \(\theta= \frac{3 \pi}{4}\) gives%
\begin{align*}
\frac{dy}{dx}= \frac{\left(\frac{dy}{d\theta}\right)}{\left(\frac{dx}{d\theta}\right)} 
\amp= \frac{2\sin(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(\cos(\theta))}{2\cos(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(-\sin(\theta))}\\
\amp\approx 0.588\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4398}{}\hypertarget{p-6883}{}%
Since \(r=2 \theta+3\), \(x=r \cos(\theta)\), and \(y=r \sin(\theta)\), and \(\theta=\frac{7\pi}4\) at B, then%
\begin{equation*}
r=\frac{7 \pi}{2}+3,\\
x= \left(\frac{7 \pi}{2}+3 \right)(\frac{\sqrt 2}2) \approx 9.89, \text{ and}\\
y= \left(\frac{7 \pi}{2}+3 \right)(-\frac{\sqrt 2}2) \approx -9.89\text{.}
\end{equation*}
We note that%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{2\sin(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(\cos(\theta))}{2\cos(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(-\sin(\theta))}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
as in part (a). Thus, plugging in \(\theta=\frac{7\pi}4\) gives%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dy}{dx}\approx0.7499\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4399}{}\hypertarget{p-6884}{}%
Note that the third quadrant is from \(\theta= \pi\) to \(\theta= \frac{3\pi}2\). Using our computations from part (a), we know that %
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dx}{d\theta} = 2\cos(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(-\sin(\theta))\\
\frac{dy}{d\theta} = 2\sin(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(\cos(\theta))\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Now, plugging into the arc length formula for a parametric equation, we get that%
\begin{equation*}
\text{Arc Length} = \int_\pi^{\frac{3\pi}{2}} \sqrt{ \left( \frac{dx}{d\theta}\right)^2+\left( \frac{dx}{d\theta}\right)^2} d \theta \\
= \int_\pi^{\frac{3\pi}{2}} \sqrt{ \left( 2\cos(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(-\sin(\theta))\right)^2+\left( 2\sin(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(\cos(\theta))\right)^2} d \theta \\
\approx 17.33\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 6.3.5 Summary}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Summary}]{Summary}\label{subsection-174}
\hypertarget{p-6885}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-6886}{}%
To find the area of a region bounded by a polar curve, we think of the region as being sliced up into thin circle sectors. The exact area of the region bounded by \(r=f(\theta)\) between \(\theta=\alpha\) and \(\theta=\beta\) is%
\begin{equation*}
\text{Area}= \frac 12 \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} (f(\theta))^2 \, d \theta\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-6887}{}%
To find the area of a region bounded by two polar curves, we subtract the smaller area from the larger one. If the two curves are \(r=f(\theta)\) and \(r=g(\theta)\), where \(f(\theta)\geq g(\theta)\), between \(\theta=\alpha\) and \(\theta=\beta\), then the exact area is%
\begin{equation*}
\text{Area}= \frac 12 \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} (f(\theta))^2 \, d \theta-\frac 12 \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} (g(\theta))^2 \, d \theta
= \frac 12 \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} (f(\theta))^2-(g(\theta))^2 \, d \theta\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-6888}{}%
To compute slope and arc length of a curve in polar coordinates, we treat the curve as a parametric function of \(\theta\) and use the parametric slope and arc length formulae:%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{\big(\frac{dy}{d\theta}\big)}{\big(\frac{dx}{d\theta}\big)} \text{,}
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{equation*}
\text{Arc Length} = \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} \sqrt{\left(\frac{dx}{d \theta} \right)^2 + \left(\frac{dy}{d \theta}\right)^2 } \, d\theta\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{itemize}
%

\typeout{Section 6.4 Density, Mass, and Center of Mass}
\typeout{************************************************}
\section[{Density, Mass, and Center of Mass}]{Density, Mass, and Center of Mass}\label{sec-6-4-mass}
\begin{objectives}{Motivating Questions}\label{objectives-43}
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\hypertarget{p-6897}{}%
How are mass, density, and volume related?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-6898}{}%
How is the mass of an object with varying density computed?%
\item{}\hypertarget{p-6899}{}%
What is is the center of mass of an object, and how are definite integrals used to compute it?%
\end{itemize}
\end{objectives}
\hypertarget{p-6900}{}%
Studying the units of the integrand and variable of integration helps us understand the meaning of a definite integral. For instance, if \(v(t)\) is the velocity of an object moving along an axis, measured in feet per second, and \(t\) measures time in seconds, then both the definite integral and its Riemann sum approximation,%
\begin{equation*}
\int_a^b v(t) \, dt \approx \sum_{i=1}^n v(t_i) \Delta t\text{,}
\end{equation*}
have units given by the product of the units of \(v(t)\) and \(t\):%
\begin{equation*}
\text{(feet/sec)} \cdot \text{(sec)} = \text{feet}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Thus, \(\int_a^b v(t) \, dt\) measures the total change in position of the moving object in feet.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6901}{}%
Unit analysis will be particularly helpful to us in what follows.%
\begin{example}[]\label{PA-6-3}
\hypertarget{p-6902}{}%
In each of the following scenarios, we consider the distribution of a quantity along an axis. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4408}{}\hypertarget{p-6903}{}%
Suppose that the function \(c(x) = 200 + 100 e^{-0.1x}\) models the density of traffic on a straight road, measured in cars per mile, where \(x\) is the number of miles east of a major interchange, and consider the definite integral%
\begin{equation*}
\int_0^2 (200 + 100 e^{-0.1x}) \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4409}{}\hypertarget{p-6904}{}%
What are the units of the product \(c(x) \cdot \Delta x\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-4410}{}\hypertarget{p-6905}{}%
What are the units of the definite integral and its Riemann sum approximation given by%
\begin{equation*}
\int_0^2 c(x) \, dx \approx \sum_{i=1}^n c(x_i) \Delta x?
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4411}{}\hypertarget{p-6906}{}%
Evaluate the definite integral \(\int_0^2 c(x) \, dx = \int_0^2 \left(200 + 100 e^{-0.1x}\right) \, dx\) and write one sentence to explain the meaning of the value you find.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4412}{}\hypertarget{p-6907}{}%
On a 6 foot long shelf filled with books, the function \(B\) models the distribution of the weight of the books, in pounds per inch, where \(x\) is the number of inches from the left end of the bookshelf. Let \(B(x)\) be given by the rule \(B(x) = 0.5 + \frac{1}{(x+1)^2}\). %
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4413}{}\hypertarget{p-6908}{}%
What are the units of the product \(B(x) \cdot \Delta x\)?%
\item\hypertarget{li-4414}{}\hypertarget{p-6909}{}%
What are the units of the definite integral and its Riemann sum approximation given by%
\begin{equation*}
\int_{12}^{36} B(x) \, dx \approx \sum_{i=1}^n B(x_i) \Delta x?
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4415}{}\hypertarget{p-6910}{}%
Evaluate the definite integral \(\int_{0}^{72} B(x) \, dx = \int_0^{72} \left(0.5 + \frac{1}{(x+1)^2}\right) \, dx\) and write one sentence to explain the meaning of the value you find.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-375}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6911}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4416}{}\hypertarget{p-6912}{}%
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4417}{}\hypertarget{p-6913}{}%
Since \(c(x)\) has units of cars per mile, and \(\Delta x\) has units of miles, then \(c(x) \cdot \Delta x\) has units of cars.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4418}{}\hypertarget{p-6914}{}%
From the answer to the previous part, \(c(x) \cdot \Delta x\) has units of cars, so the summation and integral will be the sum of things with units of cars, and therefore also have units of cars.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4419}{}\hypertarget{p-6915}{}%
Using the exponent rule for integrating:%
\begin{equation*}
\int_0^2 c(x) \, dx = \int_0^2 \left(200 + 100 e^{-0.1x}\right) \, dx
= \left. 200x -1000e^{-0.1x} \right |_0^2\\
= (200(2) - 1000e^{-0.1(2)}) - (200(0)-1000e^{-0.1(0)})=581
\end{equation*}
This represents that, on the two mile stretch of road, there are 581 cars.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4420}{}\hypertarget{p-6916}{}%
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4421}{}\hypertarget{p-6917}{}%
Since \(B(x)\) has units of pounds per inch, and \(\Delta x\) has units of inches, then \(B(x) \cdot \Delta x\) has units of pounds.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4422}{}\hypertarget{p-6918}{}%
From the answer to the previous part, \(B(x) \cdot \Delta x\) has units of pounds, so the summation and integral will be the sum of things with units of pounds, and therefore also have units of pounds.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4423}{}\hypertarget{p-6919}{}%
Using a power rule, we get that%
\begin{equation*}
\int_{0}^{72} B(x) \, dx = \int_0^{72} \left(0.5 + \frac{1}{(x+1)^2}\right) \, dx\\
= \left. 0.5 x -\frac{1}{x+1} \right |_0^{72} \\
= \left(0.5(72) - \frac{1}{72+1} \right)-\left(0.5(0)- \frac1{0+1} \right)=36.986
\end{equation*}
This represents that, on the 72 inches of book shelf, there are 36.986 pounds of books.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 6.4.1 Density}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Density}]{Density}\label{subsection-175}
\index{density}\hypertarget{p-6920}{}%
The \emph{mass} \index{mass} of an object, typically measured in metric units such as grams or kilograms, is a measure of the amount of material in the object. The \emph{density} of an object measures the distribution of mass per unit volume. For instance, if a brick has mass 3 kg and volume 0.002 m\(^3\), then the density of the brick is%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{3 \mbox{kg} }{0.002 \mbox{m} ^3} = 1500 \frac{\mbox{kg} }{\mbox{m} ^3}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6921}{}%
As another example, the mass density of water is 1000 kg/m\(^3\). Each of these relationships demonstrate the following general principle.%
\begin{assemblage}[Density Formula]\label{assemblage-144}
\hypertarget{p-6922}{}%
For an object of constant density \(d\), with mass \(m\) and volume \(V\),%
\begin{equation*}
d = \frac{m}{V}, \ \text{or}  \ m = d \cdot V\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
\hypertarget{p-6923}{}%
But what happens when the density is not constant?%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6924}{}%
The formula \(m = d \cdot V\) is reminiscent of two other equations that we have used in our work: for a body moving in a fixed direction, distance = rate \(\cdot\) time, and, for a rectangle, its area is given by \(A = l \cdot w\). These formulas hold when the principal quantities involved, such as the rate the body moves and the height of the rectangle, are \emph{constant}. When these quantities are not constant, we have turned to the definite integral for assistance. By working with small slices on which the quantity of interest (such as velocity) is approximately constant, we can use a definite integral to add up the values on the pieces.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6925}{}%
For example, if we have a nonnegative velocity function that is not constant, over a short time interval \(\Delta t\), we know that the distance traveled is approximately \(v(t) \Delta t\) since \(v(t)\) is almost constant on a small interval. Similarly, if we are thinking about the area under a nonnegative function \(f\) whose value is changing, on a short interval \(\Delta x\), the area under the curve is approximately the area of the rectangle whose height is \(f(x)\) and whose width is \(\Delta x\): \(f(x) \Delta x\). Both of these principles are represented visually in \hyperref[F-6-3-VelArea]{Figure~\ref{F-6-3-VelArea}}.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/6_3_VelArea.pdf}
\caption{At left, estimating a small amount of distance traveled, \(v(t) \Delta t\), and at right, a small amount of area under the curve, \(f(x) \Delta x\).\label{F-6-3-VelArea}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-6926}{}%
In a similar way, if the density of some object is not constant, we can use a definite integral to compute the overall mass of the object. We will focus on problems where the density varies in only one dimension, say along a single axis.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-287}
\hypertarget{p-6927}{}%
Let's consider a thin bar of length \(b\) whose left end is at the origin, where \(x = 0\), and assume that the bar has constant cross-sectional area of 1 cm\(^2\). We let \(\rho(x)\) represent the mass density function of the bar, measured in grams per cubic centimeter. That is, given a location \(x\), \(\rho(x)\) tells us approximately how much mass will be found in a one-centimeter wide slice of the bar at \(x\).%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/6_3_Bar.pdf}
\caption{A thin bar of constant cross-sectional area 1 cm\(^2\) with density function \(\rho(x)\) g/cm\(^3\).\label{F-6-3-Bar}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-6928}{}%
The volume of a thin slice of the bar of width \(\Delta x\), as pictured in \hyperref[F-6-3-Bar]{Figure~\ref{F-6-3-Bar}}, is the cross-sectional area times \(\Delta x\). Since the cross-sections each have constant area 1 cm\(^2\), it follows that the volume of the slice is \(1 \Delta x\) cm\(^3\). And because mass is the product of density and volume, we see that the mass of this slice is approximately%
\begin{equation*}
\text{mass} _{\text{slice} } \approx \rho(x) \ \frac{\mbox{g} }{\mbox{cm} ^3} \cdot 1 \Delta x \ \mbox{cm} ^3 = \rho(x) \cdot \Delta x \ \mbox{g}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6929}{}%
Therefore, the total mass of the bar is measured by the corresponding Riemann sum (and the integral that it approximates)%
\begin{equation*}
\sum_{i=1}^n \rho(x_i) \Delta x \approx \int_0^b \rho(x) \, dx=\text{mass}_{\text{total}}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
(As usual, the Riemann sum is an approximation, while the integral will be the exact mass.)%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-6930}{}%
For objects whose cross-sectional area is constant and whose mass is distributed relative to horizontal location, \(x\), it makes sense to think of the density function \(\rho(x)\) with units ``mass per unit length,'' such as g/cm. Thus, when we compute \(\rho(x) \cdot \Delta x\) on a small slice \(\Delta x\), the resulting units are (g/cm) \(\cdot\) (cm) = g, which thus measures the mass of the slice. The general principle follows.%
\begin{assemblage}[Calculating Mass using a Definite Integral]\label{assemblage-145}
\hypertarget{p-6931}{}%
For an object of constant cross-sectional area whose mass is distributed along a single axis according to the function \(\rho(x)\) (whose units are units of mass per unit of length), the total mass, \(M\), of the object between \(x = a\) and \(x = b\) is given by%
\begin{equation*}
M = \int_a^b \rho(x) \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
\begin{example}[]\label{act-6-3-1}
\hypertarget{p-6932}{}%
Consider the following situations in which mass is distributed in a non-constant manner. \leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4424}{}\hypertarget{p-6933}{}%
Suppose that a thin rod with constant cross-sectional area of 1 cm\(^2\) has its mass distributed according to the density function \(\rho(x) = 2e^{-0.2x}\), where \(x\) is the distance in cm from the left end of the rod, and the units of \(\rho(x)\) are g/cm. If the rod is 10 cm long, determine the exact mass of the rod.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4425}{}\hypertarget{p-6934}{}%
Consider the cone that has a base of radius 4 m and a height of 5 m. \includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/6_4_Ex3b_Figure.png}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6935}{}%
Picture with the center of its base at the origin and think of the cone as a solid of revolution. %
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4426}{}\hypertarget{p-6936}{}%
Write and evaluate a definite integral whose value is the volume of the cone.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4427}{}\hypertarget{p-6937}{}%
Next, suppose that the cone has uniform density of 800 kg/m\(^3\). What is the mass of the solid cone?%
\item\hypertarget{li-4428}{}\hypertarget{p-6938}{}%
Now suppose that the cone's density is not uniform, but rather that the cone is most dense at its base. In particular, assume that the density of the cone is uniform across cross sections parallel to its base, but that in each such cross section that is a distance \(x\) units from the origin, the density of the cross section is given by the function \(\rho(x) = 400 + \frac{200}{1+x^2}\), measured in kg/m\(^3\). Determine and evaluate a definite integral whose value is the mass of this cone of non-uniform density. Do so by first thinking about the mass of a given slice of the cone \(x\) units away from the base; remember that in such a slice, the density will be \emph{essentially constant}.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4429}{}\hypertarget{p-6939}{}%
Let a thin rod of constant cross-sectional area 1 cm\(^2\) and length 12 cm have its mass be distributed according to the density function \(\rho(x) = \frac{1}{25}(x-15)^2\), measured in g/cm. Find the exact location \(x\) at which to cut the bar so that the two pieces will each have identical mass.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-192}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6940}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4430}{}\hypertarget{p-6941}{}%
Remember that \(M = \int_a^b \rho(x) \, dx\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4431}{}\hypertarget{p-6942}{}%
Think about slices: what's the volume of a slice? what's the mass of a slice?%
\item\hypertarget{li-4432}{}\hypertarget{p-6943}{}%
Consider \(\int_0^b \rho(x) \, dx\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-319}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6944}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4433}{}\hypertarget{p-6945}{}%
\(M = 0.1 - 0.1e^{-4} \approx 0.0981684\) grams.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4434}{}\hypertarget{p-6946}{}%
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6947}{}%
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4435}{}\hypertarget{p-6948}{}%
\(V = \int_{0}^{5} \pi (4 - \frac{4}{5}x)^2 \, dx = \frac{80\pi}{3} \approx 83.7758 \mbox{m}^3\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4436}{}\hypertarget{p-6949}{}%
\(M = \int_{0}^{5} (400 + \frac{200}{1+x^2}) \cdot \pi (4-\frac{4}{5}x)^2 \, dx  \) \(= \frac{32}{5}\pi(25015 - 5 \ln(17576) + 72\tan^{-1}(5) \approx 33597.4664 \mbox{kg}\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4437}{}\hypertarget{p-6950}{}%
\(b \approx 3.0652\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-376}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6951}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4438}{}\hypertarget{p-6952}{}%
Since the mass, \(M\), is given by \(M = \int_a^b \rho(x) \, dx\), it follows that%
\begin{equation*}
M = \int_{0}^{10} 2e^{-0.2x} = \left. \frac{2}{-0.2}e^{-0.2x} \right|_{0}^{20} = -0.1e^{-4}+0.1e^{0}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and hence \(M = 0.1 - 0.1e^{-4} \approx 0.0981684\) grams.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4439}{}\hypertarget{p-6953}{}%
Consider the cone that has a base of radius 4 m and a height of 5 m.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6954}{}%
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4440}{}\hypertarget{p-6955}{}%
With the cone having its base centered at the origin and being a solid of revolution about the \(x\)-axis, the cone is generated by the line \(y = 4 - \frac{4}{5}x\). Using the disk method, it follows that the cone's volume is%
\begin{equation*}
V = \int_{0}^{5} \pi (4 - \frac{4}{5}x)^2 \, dx = \frac{80\pi}{3} \approx 83.7758 \mbox{m}^3\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4441}{}\hypertarget{p-6956}{}%
If the cone has uniform density 800 kg/m\(^3\), we know that the cone's mass is the product of its density and volume, and thus%
\begin{equation*}
M = \rho \cdot V = 800 \cdot \frac{80\pi}{3} = \frac{6400\pi}{3} \approx 67020.6433 \mbox{kg}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4442}{}\hypertarget{p-6957}{}%
If the cone has non-uniform density, but is uniform across cross sections parallel to its base such that in each cross section a distance \(x\) units from the origin has its density given by \(\rho(x) = 400 + \frac{200}{1+x^2}\) kg/m\(^3\), we naturally consider slices of the cone that are perpendicular to the \(x\)-axis. For each such slice, the radius is \(r(x) = 4 - \frac{4}{5}x\), which makes the volume of the slice%
\begin{equation*}
V_{\text{slice}} \approx \pi (4-\frac{4}{5}x)^2 \Delta x\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Since the density is constant on the slice with value \(\rho(x) = 400 + \frac{200}{1+x^2}\), it follows that the mass of the slice is%
\begin{equation*}
M_{\text{slice}} \approx (400 + \frac{200}{1+x^2}) \cdot \pi (4-\frac{4}{5}x)^2 \Delta x\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Using a definite integral to let \(\Delta x \to 0\) and add up the values of all of the slices, we thus find the mass of the cone with this density distribution to be%
\begin{align*}
M \amp = \int_{0}^{5} (400 + \frac{200}{1+x^2}) \cdot \pi (4-\frac{4}{5}x)^2 \, dx\\
\amp = \frac{32}{5}\pi(25015 - 5 \ln(17576) + 72\tan^{-1}(5) \approx 33597.4664 \mbox{kg}\\
\amp \approx 33597.4664 \mbox{kg}\text{.}
\end{align*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4443}{}\hypertarget{p-6958}{}%
The total mass of the bar is given by \(M = \int_{0}^{12} \frac{1}{25}(x-15)^2 \, dx = \frac{1116}{25}\). To find where to cut the bar in two so that the two pieces have equal mass, we have to determine the value of \(b\) such that%
\begin{equation*}
\int_{0}^{b} \frac{1}{25}(x-15)^2 \, dx = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1116}{25}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Since \(\int_{0}^{b} \frac{1}{25}(x-15)^2 \, dx = \frac{1}{75}( (b-15)^3 - (-15)^3 )\), we need to have \(b\) satisfy the equation%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{75}( (b-15)^3 - (-15)^3 ) = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1116}{25}\text{.}
\end{equation*}
Thus, \((b-15)^3 - (-15)^3 = 75 \cdot \frac{558}{25} = 3 \cdot 558 = 1674\), so \((b-15)^3 = 1675 - 3375 = -1700\). It follows that \(b-15 = \sqrt[3]{-1700} \approx -11.9348\), so \(b \approx 3.0652\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 6.4.2 Radial Density}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Radial Density}]{Radial Density}\label{subsection-176}
\hypertarget{p-6959}{}%
In some 2D or 3D objects, density depends on distance from a center point. In this case, we will apply the principle from the previous section (that mass is the integral of density), but must make a slight adjustment to account for the fact that layers of the same thickness will have different volumes depending on their distance from the center.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-289}
\hypertarget{p-6960}{}%
Consider a 1 meter long metal pipe covered with a layer of insulation. \includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/6_4_Ex4_Figure.pdf}
 How would we find the total mass of the pipe? We would need to add up the masses of the metal and the insulation, and these masses can be found by taking density times volume:%
\begin{equation*}
\text{mass}_{\text{layer}}=\rho_{\text{layer}}V_{\text{layer}}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6961}{}%
But note that the density of the layer depends on its distance from the center: close to the center of the pipe, the hollow core of the pipe has 0 density, at a radius of \(r_1\) the metal pipe has a high density, and at a radius of \(r_2\) the insulation has a low density. Let us use \(\rho(r)\) to denote the density as a function of distance \(r\) from the center.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6962}{}%
Next, to get \(V_{\text{layer}}\) we can use approximate volume as circumference times thickness times length, so \(V \approx (2\pi r_i)(\Delta r)(1 \text{ meter})=(2\pi r_i)(\Delta r)\). Thus the mass of a single layer is approximately%
\begin{equation*}
\text{mass}_i \approx \rho(r_i)(2\pi r_i)(\Delta r).
\end{equation*}
Summing both layers, we get that%
\begin{equation*}
\text{mass} \approx \displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^2 \rho(r_i)(2\pi r_i)(\Delta r)
\end{equation*}
is the total mass of the pipe.%
\end{example}
\hypertarget{p-6963}{}%
We can generalize the formula we found in the previous example to any object for which density depends on radius. That more general formula is%
\begin{equation*}
\text{mass} \approx \displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n \rho(r_i)(2\pi r_i)(\Delta r)
\end{equation*}
where \(\rho(r)\) is the density of the object a distance of \(r_i\) from the center.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6964}{}%
Similar to the earlier applications in this chapter: we will take the limit as \(\Delta r \rightarrow 0 \), and doing so turns the sum into an integral.%
\begin{assemblage}[Calculating Mass using a Definite Integral for Radially Symmetric Objects]\label{assemblage-146}
\hypertarget{p-6965}{}%
For a 2D disk (respectively, 3D cylinder), if the density of the object depends only on the distance from the center point (respectively, center axis) according to the function \(\rho(r)\), then the mass per unit length (respectively, mass of the object)  is given by the formula%
\begin{equation*}
\text{mass} = \displaystyle \int_{0}^R \rho(r)(2\pi r)\,  dr= \displaystyle \int_{0}^R 2 \pi r\rho(r)\,  dr
\end{equation*}
where \(R\) is the outer radius of the object.%
\end{assemblage}
\hypertarget{p-6966}{}%
Note that this formula is almost identical to the one we use for calculating mass of an object with constant cross-sectional area, except that this formula incorporates a factor of \(2 \pi r\) (the circumference of a circle) inside the integral.%
\begin{example}[]\label{example-290}
\hypertarget{p-6967}{}%
After an oil spill, scientists measure that the concentration of oil depends on the distance from the source according to the function \(\rho(r)=150 e^{-r^2}\) where \(r\) is in miles, and \(\rho(r)\) is in barrels per square mile. If the spill has reached a maximum radius of 5 miles, how much oil was spilled?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-193}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6968}{}%
Set up the integral like for the mass of a disk, then integrate. To evaluate the integral use the \(u\)-substitution \(u=-r^2\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-320}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6969}{}%
\(471.23\) barrels.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-377}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6970}{}%
Since the density depends on the radius, we will use the mass of a disk formula \(\displaystyle \int_{0}^R \rho(r)(2\pi r)\,  dr\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6971}{}%
For us, the maximum radius is \(R=5\) miles, so the total amount of oil is%
\begin{equation*}
\displaystyle \int_{0}^5 (150e^{-r^2})(2\pi r)\,  dr = \left.-150 \pi e^{-r^2} \right|_0^5 \\
(-150\pi e^{-(5)^2}) - (-150\pi e^{-(0)^2})=471.23 \text{ barrels}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{example-291}
\hypertarget{p-6972}{}%
The 2D region bounded by \(y=6-x\), \(x=0\), \(x=3\), and \(y=0\) (pictured below), is rotated around the \(x\)-axis to make a solid of revolution.%
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.3\linewidth]{../../html/Calculus/images/6_4_Ex5_Figure.pdf}
\caption{The 2D region before it is rotated around the \(x\)-axis.\label{F-6-5-Region}}
\end{figure}
\hypertarget{p-6973}{}%
When this object is carved out of material, its density depends on the distance from the \(x\)-axis according to \(\rho_{radial}(r)=9-r\).%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4444}{}\hypertarget{p-6974}{}%
Fix a value of \(x\) in the interval \([0,3]\). Set up and evaluate the integral to find \(\rho_{axis}(x)\), the mass per unit length of the circular cross-section at that \(x\)-value. (Your answer will be in terms of \(x\).)%
\item\hypertarget{li-4445}{}\hypertarget{p-6975}{}%
Use your answer to the previous question and the techniques in the ``Calculating Mass using a Definite Integral'' section to find the total mass of the object.%
\end{enumerate}
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-194}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6976}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4446}{}\hypertarget{p-6977}{}%
Each cross-section is a disk with outer radius \(y=6-x\).%
\item\hypertarget{li-4447}{}Use your formula for \(\rho_{axis}(x)\) and the formula from "Calculating Mass using a Definite Integral":%
\begin{equation*}
M=\int_a^b \rho(x)dx
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-321}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6978}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4448}{}\hypertarget{p-6979}{}%
\(\rho_{axis}(x)=\pi(\frac{2}{3} x^3 - 3x^2 -36x+180)\)%
\item\hypertarget{li-4449}{}\(M=364.5 \pi  \approx 1145.11 \)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-378}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6980}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4450}{}\hypertarget{p-6981}{}%
Since we have circular cross-sections and their density only depends on the distance to the center of the circle (which is the \(x\)-axis), we will integrate as we do for a disk. Note that our outer radius depends on the \(x\)-value, and in fact, the outer radius is \(y=6-x\). Therefore,%
\begin{equation*}
\rho_{axis}(x)= \int_0^{6-x}(2 \pi r) \rho_{radial}(r) \, dr \\
= \int_0^{6-x}(2 \pi r) (9-r) \, dr \\
= \left. (9 \pi r^2- \frac{2\pi}{3} r^3) \right|_{r=0}^{r=6-x}\\
=  (9 \pi (6-x)^2- \frac{2\pi}{3} (6-x)^3)-(0)\\
= \pi(\frac{2}{3} x^3 - 3x^2 -36x+180)
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4451}{}\hypertarget{p-6982}{}%
What we found in the previous part is the mass per unit length, so just as in "Calculating Mass using a Definite Integral", we simply need to integrate \(\rho_{axis}(x)\) from the endpoints \(a=0\) to \(b=3\):%
\begin{equation*}
M= \int_0^3 \rho_{axis}(x) \, dx =\int_0^3 \pi(\frac{2}{3} x^3 - 3x -36x+180) \, dx \\
= \left. \pi(\frac{1}{6} x^4 - x^3 -18x^2+180x) \right|_{0}^3\\
=\pi(\frac{1}{6} (3)^4 - (3)^3 -18(3)^2+180(3))-(0)\\
= 364.5 \pi  \approx 1145.11
\end{equation*}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{example-292}
\hypertarget{p-6983}{}%
Suppose that a circular city's population density is given by \(\rho(r)=1000-100r\), where \(r\) is the distance from the city's center in miles and \(\rho(r)\) is in units of people per square mile. If the city has a radius of 6 miles, find the population of the city.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-195}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6984}{}%
Set up the integral like for the mass of a disk, then integrate.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-322}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6985}{}%
\(67858\)  people.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-379}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6986}{}%
Since the density depends on the radius, we will use the mass of a disk formula \(\displaystyle \int_{0}^R \rho(r)(2\pi r)\,  dr\).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6987}{}%
For us, the maximum radius is \(R=6\) miles, so the total population is%
\begin{equation*}
\displaystyle \int_{0}^6 ((1000-100r)(2\pi r)\,  dr = \left. 1000 \pi r^2-\frac{200\pi}{3}r^3 \right|_0^6 \\
(1000 \pi (6)^2 - \frac{200 \pi}{3} (6)^3) - (0) \approx 67858 \text{ people}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}
\begin{example}[]\label{example-293}
\hypertarget{p-6988}{}%
When the density of a spherical object only depends on the distance from the center, the formula for the object's mass is%
\begin{equation*}
\text{mass}= \int_0^R 4 \pi r^2 \rho(r)\, dr
\end{equation*}
which is identical to the formula for a circular object, except that the circumference of a circle (\(C=2\pi r\)) is replaced by the surface area of a sphere (\(A=4\pi r^2\)).%
\par
\hypertarget{p-6989}{}%
The earth is denser near its core. Suppose that the density of the earth was given by \(\rho(r)=(-0.0016)r+13 \) where \(r\) has units of kilometers and \(\rho\) is in trillions of kilograms per cubic kilometer (in more normal units, \(1 \text{ trillion }\frac{kg}{km^3}=1 \frac{g}{cm^3}\)).%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4452}{}\hypertarget{p-6990}{}%
The earth has a radius of approximately 6300 kilometers. Find the total mass of the earth.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4453}{}\hypertarget{p-6991}{}%
The volume of a sphere is \(V=\frac 43 \pi R^3\). Find the volume of the earth, and calculate the average density of the earth. (Average density is the total mass divided by total volume.)%
\item\hypertarget{li-4454}{}\hypertarget{p-6992}{}%
Goofus sees that at the center of the earth, the density is \(\rho(0)=13\), and at the surface the density is \(\rho(6300)=2.92\), and therefore concludes that the average density of the earth is \(\frac{13+2.92}{2}=7.96\). Is Goofus correct? If he is not, explain why his calculation is incorrect.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4455}{}\hypertarget{p-6993}{}%
The earth's inner core has a radius of 1200 kilometers. Find the average density of the earth's inner core.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4456}{}\hypertarget{p-6994}{}%
What percent of the earth's mass is in the inner core? What percent of the earth's volume is in the inner core?%
\end{enumerate}
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Hint.}\hypertarget{hint-196}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-6995}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4457}{}\hypertarget{p-6996}{}%
Set up and evaluate the integral given by the equation%
\begin{equation*}
\text{mass}= \int_0^R 4 \pi r^2 \rho(r)\, dr
\end{equation*}
%
\item\hypertarget{li-4458}{}\hypertarget{p-6997}{}%
Use the volume formula to get the volume, then divide mass by volume to get the average density.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4459}{}\hypertarget{p-6998}{}%
Goofus is incorrect.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4460}{}\hypertarget{p-6999}{}%
Perform the same calculations as parts (a.) and (b.) but for the smaller radius.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4461}{}\hypertarget{p-7000}{}%
Divide your answers to the previous parts.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Answer.}\hypertarget{answer-323}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-7001}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4462}{}\hypertarget{p-7002}{}%
The mass of the earth is roughly \(5.7 \times 10^{12} \) trillions of kilograms.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4463}{}\hypertarget{p-7003}{}%
The volume of the earth is \(V=1.05 \times 10^{12}\) cubic kilometers. Its average density is \(5.44\) trillions of kilograms per cubic kilometer.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4464}{}\hypertarget{p-7004}{}%
Goofus is incorrect.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4465}{}\hypertarget{p-7005}{}%
The density is \(11.56 \) trillion kilograms per cubic kilometer.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4466}{}\hypertarget{p-7006}{}%
Approximately \(1.47 \%\) of the earth's mass is in the inner core.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-7007}{}%
Approximately \(0.689 \%\) of the earth's volume is in the inner core.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{Solution.}\hypertarget{solution-380}{}\quad%
\hypertarget{p-7008}{}%
\leavevmode%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item\hypertarget{li-4467}{}\hypertarget{p-7009}{}%
We must take the integral:%
\begin{equation*}
\text{mass}= \int_0^R 4 \pi r^2 \rho(r)\, dr = \int_0^{6300} 4 \pi r^2(-0.0016r+13)\, dr \\
= \left. 4\pi(-0.0004 r^4+\frac{13}{3}r^3) \right |_0^{6300}\\
\approx 5.7 \times 10^{12}
\end{equation*}
so the mass of the earth is roughly \(5.7 \times 10^{12} \) trillions of kilograms.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4468}{}\hypertarget{p-7010}{}%
The volume formula for a sphere says that the volume of the earth is \(V=\frac{4}{3}\pi (6300)^3=1.05 \times 10^{12}\) cubic kilometers. Therefore, its average density is \(\displaystyle \frac{5.7 \times 10^{12}}{1.05 \times 10^{12}}=5.44\) trillions of kilograms per cubic kilometer.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4469}{}\hypertarget{p-7011}{}%
Goofus is incorrect. His calculation is wrong because he is not taking into account the factor of \(r^2\) inside the integral, which counts the lower-density parts on the outside of the earth more than the higher-density parts near the center. For instance, his average treated innermost 1 kilometer of the earth as having the same volume as the outermost 1 kilometer of earth, even though the latter is much larger in terms of volume.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4470}{}\hypertarget{p-7012}{}%
We will essentially repeat our calculations from parts (a.) and (b.), except with 1200 as the maximum radius instead of 6300. Therefore, the volume of the inner core is \(V=\frac{4}{3}\pi (1200)^3=7.24 \times 10^{9}\) cubic killometers, and the mass is%
\begin{equation*}
\text{mass}= \int_0^R 4 \pi r^2 \rho(r)\, dr = \int_0^{1200} 4 \pi r^2(-0.0016r+13)\, dr \\
= \left. 4\pi(-0.0004 r^4+\frac{13}{3}r^3) \right |_0^{1200}\\
\approx 8.37 \times 10^{10}
\end{equation*}
so the density is \((8.37 \times 10^{10})/(7.24 \times 10^{9})=11.56 \) trillion kilograms per cubic kilometer.%
\item\hypertarget{li-4471}{}\hypertarget{p-7013}{}%
In the previous parts, we saw that the mass of the inner core was \(8.37 \times 10^{10}\) and the mass of the whole earth was \(5.7 \times 10^{12}\), so dividing gives that approximately \(1.47 \%\) of the earth's mass is in the inner core.%
\par
\hypertarget{p-7014}{}%
In the previous parts, we saw that the volume of the inner core was \(7.24 \times 10^{9}\) and the volume of the whole earth was \(1.05 \times 10^{12}\), so dividing gives that approximately \(0.689 \%\) of the earth's volume is in the inner core.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection 6.4.3 Weighted Averages}
\typeout{************************************************}
\subsection[{Weighted Averages}]{Weighted Averages}\label{subsection-177}
\hypertarget{p-7015}{}%
The concept of an average is a natural one, and one that we have used repeatedly as part of our understanding of the meaning of the definite integral. If we have \(n\) values \(a_1\), \(a_2\), \(\ldots\), \(a_n\), we know that their average is given by%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{a_1 + a_2 + \cdots + a_n}{n}\text{,}
\end{equation*}
and for a quantity being measured by a function \(f\) on an interval \([a,b]\), the average value of the quantity on \([a,b]\) is%
\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{b-a} \int_a^b f(x) \, dx\text{.}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
\hypertarget{p-7016}{}%
As we continue to think about problems involving the distribution of mass, it is natural to consider the idea of a \emph{weighted} average, \index{weighted average} where certain quantities involved are counted more in the average.%
% group protects changes to lengths, releases boxes (?)

% set panel max height to practical minimum, created in preamble
\setlength{\panelmax}{0pt}
\ifdefined\panelboxAp\else\newsavebox{\panelboxAp}\fi%
\savebox{\panelboxAp}{%
\raisebox{\depth}{\parbox{0.41\linewidth}{A common use of weighted averages is in the computation of a student's GPA, where grades are weighted according to credit hours. Let's consider the scenario in \hyperref[T-6-3-grades]{Table~\ref{T-6-3-grades}}.}}}
\ifdefined\phAp\else\newlength{\phAp}\fi%

class&grade&grade points&credits\tabularnewline\hrulethin
chemistry&B+&3.3&5\tabularnewline\hrulethin
calculus&A-&3.7&4\tabularnewline\hrulethin

psychology&B-&2.7&3\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\end{tabular}
}}}

\par\medskip\noindent
